Pitchfork: You opened for Wilco recently. How was that?

Greg Saunier: When I was in the audience
column3: watching their show
column4: they would start a song
column5:
and people next to me would start hugging each other because they loved that song. And I thought that was something that I would really aspire to. To do something where music becomes-- and this sounds ridiculous or pretentious or something-- but where music becomes more than just good music.* * *

Any band taking cues from Wilco-- let alone the best band in the world-- that's hard to stomach. Says Dominique Leone
column6: ""You don't always have to sound poignant to make poignant music."" But I appreciate Deerhoof's challenge here: to comb hair without cutting it
column7: to wash face without popping all the pimples
column8: to be the best band in the world
column9: but beyond that
column10: to be the most lovable
column11:
too.

So tomorrow
column12: Deerhoof put on their Tuesday best and release their first straight-up guitar-rock album-- short
column13: dense songs packed into familiar forms
column14: full-bodied vocals for unabashed
column15: often gut-punching melodies
column16: less herk-jerk
column17:
less of that house-of-cards spirit that coursed through Reveille and Apple O. Some people will miss that.

Milk Man
column18: Pt. 2? Not really. Deerhoof aren't holding back here so much as redistributing their energies; where before we found cute in the grotesque
column19: now the opposite. My offer: I'll concede that Milk Man was poppy
column20: watered down
column21: desperate love shit if you'll actually listen close to The Runners Four and realize that it's onto something else entirely-- by turns jubilant
column22: confused
column28:
yes. They've made us a hugging record. Nothing ridiculous or pretentious about hugging.

Almost twice the length of their other LPs
column29: The Runners Four plays not as one big song
column30: but as three swoops of six or seven. That first swoop (from ""Chatterboxes"" to ""Odyssey"") might dishearten the diehard
column34: but in his absence we get compositional tension
column35: which is sometimes more intense than Saunier's top-down.  Dueling guitar lines bristle close in the rub (""Chatterboxes"")
column36: and harmonics stab away at Chris Cohen's existential pirate ballad ""Odyssey"": ""Pirates on an odyssey/ We ask the captain 'What will be?'"" Now pirates count for some of the biggest douchebags this world has ever seen
column38:
too-- people forget that.

""Wrong Time Capsule"" starts swoop #2 with Runners' most on-the-sleeves guitar riff
column39: a cry to echo singer Satomi's dejected message in a bottle: ""Don't forget me yesterday/ 'Cause today's no place to stay.""  The trill stays fever-high with unison chants on guitars and vox (""Scream Team"")
column40: folksy-bluesy confessions/comeuppance on ""After Me the Deluge"" (""Middle love I did do you harm whenever I want to"")
column43:
like nothing they've written before. I think it's about a werewolf.

The next third dips into more emotionally resonant stuff-- the furthest capitulation of Deerhoof's animalism so far
column44: where lyrically they can guess the emotions of all things living (people being chased by spies) or non-living (lightning rods).  We can wonder
column46: if lemons are sad when we eat them
column48: though Deerhoof make sure to push things inside-out
column49: rescuing something human from the rumination. Runners' gut-puncher
column50:
the third swoop rounds out with ""You're Our Two"" as needly guitar lines sandwich Satomi's image-heavy paranoia: ""Cast afloat on icy water/ Can I really leave?"" then ""Ark sailing/ Believe all fools or die.""

A somber if slightly perplexing note to end on
column51: it's the right one for this album.  But Deerhoof don't leave us there.  Instead they give us ""RRRRRRight""
column54: primitive cut รก la ""Come See the Duck"".  Of course
column55: after an album so unafraid to ask for our love
column56: Satomi's ga-gas and oompah-oompahs feel somewhat inconsequential.  Then I saw Deerhoof play the song live and understood why they have it here: The song is ginger
column57: a palette cleanser as much for us as for them.  Love what happened

There will always be something a little iffy about a live album from an act that relies heavily on computers. The live album has usually been there to capture a moment
column2: something presumably spurred by the excitement of artists walking the performance tightrope in real time. The more you rely on the playback of digital sound files
column3:
the more likely we are to wonder why you don't just mix in the studio rather than onstage.

Mouse on Mars in concert goes well beyond file management. In the touring configuration they've had in place since 2001
column4: with Dodo Nkishi on drums and vocals
column5: Andi Toma on bass guitar and electronics
column6: and the busy Jan St. Werner piloting from the bridge
column7: Mouse on Mars shows are unpredictable
column8: occasionally sloppy
column9: and relentlessly fun. It's not that they're recreating the renowned complexity of the records live. My guess is roughly 70% of everything the audience hears comes from one of St. Werner's machines
column10: but there's still a fair amount of wiggle room for the imperfect human element. Something about the way Nkishi's spazzy live drumming mingles with the programmed beats
column11: or the way a Toma bassline might slip momentarily behind the tempo of the sequencer
column12:
adds an appealing layer of awkwardness to music that lends itself to imperfection.

The first Mouse on Mars live album was pieced together from shows recorded during the band's extensive 2004 tours
column13: and it's a good snapshot of how they sounded last year. Pleasantly short at nine songs and 56 minutes
column14: Live04 sounds minimally retouched in the studio. The setlist spans the band's career. Three songs from Radical Connector
column15: one from Idiology
column16: three from Niun Niggung
column17: one from Autoditacker
column18: and one from Vulvaland. About half the tracks contains vocals
column19: and though Nkishi sings live
column20: fragments of his voice are constantly being ensnared in St. Werner's digital net and mixed in as pure sound. Generally speaking songs make do with slightly less clutter
column21: though it's still a busy environment with rich
column22: cartoonish color.

column1: The best moments showcase the band's remarkable musical humor. The frantic ""Distroia"" lurches madly from bar-to-bar
column2: building steam through variations on its stomping
column3: distorted rhythm before exploding into a tuneful hook that would make Harold Faltermeyer proud. ""Twift"" makes one yearn for the lovable goofiness the band displayed in the mid-90s
column4: with another synth riff worth building a career on and splashy fills from Nkishi. ""Wipe That Sound"" goes on a tad long but is a highlight
column5: with its gradual builds to the explosive chorus. As did the last show I saw
column6: the set closes with ""Frosch""
column7: the first Mouse on Mars single
column8: first released in 1994. This version is faster
column9: funnier
column10: and more dramatic than the original record
column11: with an epic chord progression designed to send shivers when it kicks in after a sequencer break.

column1: It's difficult to fault the set list or the performances
column2: and if the sound quality occasionally sounds a tad flat next to the meticulously layered records
column3: in this context the crudeness seems appropriate. With the readily apparent crowd noise and the occasionally dodgy mix
column4: Live04 almost sounds more like an audience recording. If there were quiet moments you could probably hear people talking next to the microphones
column5:
but Mouse on Mars in performance generally avoids quiet moments. Live04 is a soundtrack to a raucous little party.

column1: Now to loosen up these R.E.M. handcuffs; until this album these guys were making a serious case for the ""American Mogwai"" title. Not that Metropolis reveals a sudden interested in perfecting the three-minute folk-pop song

column4: baby/ This scene's got a western theme."" However

Here's an album that begs for vinyl
column2: although not for the reason you might think. Certainly
column3: My Morning Jacket's worn-in rock 'n' roll-- its starchy guitar riffs and Jim James' other-end-of-a-long-tunnel vocals-- seems tailor-made for the intimate crackle of a dusty turntable. But the concisely titled Z
column4: the band's fourth full-length
column5: needs to be flipped over: It has two distinct sides. Granted
column6: most albums still rely on the two-sided format the same way most movies still rely on the three-act plot
column7: adhering to it almost subconsciously. But I'm not entirely sure My Morning Jacket intended such a dramatic difference between these two half Zs.

column1: As Side One begins
column2: the presence of producer John Leckie (of Radiohead
column3: Stone Roses
column4: and
column5: er
column6: Kula Shaker fame) is immediately evident. ""Wordless Chorus"" launches Z with a hardscrabble sound that recalls their earlier material
column7: suggesting that the brighter production and looser
column8: jambandier approach of It Still Moveswas a slight detour. There are more keyboards on these songs
column9: courtesy of new member Bo Koster

column11: a little r&b
column12: even a little ambient. Defiantly flaunting their rural eccentricities
column13: My Morning Jacket once again recall the earliest of early R.E.M.
column14: before you could understand Stipe's mumbling
column15: back when the Georgia foursome defined themselves by claiming a birthright to kudzu-covered mythology. It's not really My Morning Jacket's sound that suggests this comparison
column16: but their willingness to let the music retain its mystery despite the risk of seeming obscure or evasive.

column1: So Z abandons the Skynyrdisms of It Still Moves
column2: but that album's lessons remain intact: Compared to those on previous albums
column3: these tracks have more guitar crunch and tighter song structures. Even single ""Off the Record""
column4: with its driving reggae rhythms and James' lively performance
column5: foregoes a dueling-guitar climax in favor of an unraveling outro that sounds like Air noir. ""Wordless Chorus"" hinges on just what its title suggests: Jim James singing aaahs and ohhhs between verses as the band rocks around him. It's as if the entire album
column6: not just this song
column7: could be stripped of literal meaning
column8: as if everything My Morning Jacket needs to say can be communicated exclusively through sound. And it works
column9: especially at the end of ""Wordless Chorus""
column10: when James breaks into a rapturous r&b yowl that recalls the Passion of the Prince.

column1: But My Morning Jacket does have something to say. Zis a spiritual album-- or at least Side One is-- with references to religion and a few barely veiled allusions to Jesus Christ himself. ""Religion should appeal to the hearts of the young
column2: James sings on ""Gideon""
column3: and guess who the bouncy ""What a Wonderful Man"" is about. Here's a hint: ""He was leading us through the dark/ He was saying that love goes on."" Even that title itself suggests an omega to some unknown alpha-- sex or death or both. These hints at larger meanings infuse the songs with a weird sense of questing adventure
column4: as if the band is revealing its secrets only to present even more riddles.

column1: Side Two
column2: however
column3: loses much of the strange steam that fuels Side One
column4: struggling to find its momentum and bringing the album back to reality with pedestrian problems like pacing. Following ""Off the Record""
column5: ""Into the Woods"" breaks that spell
column6: making everything that comes after it sound a little pale and less immediate. A dark-carnival organ sets the sideshow stage for James to sing about burning kittens and babies in blenders
column7: and the overly literal production inserts a me-oww and a wahhh into the mix

column9: but the song still dawdles to a conclusion. As if to apologize for ""Into the Woods""
column10: ""Anytime"" is straightforward rock
column11: enlivened by a pogoing guitar riff and James singing himself ragged. Disregarding its low-lying bass and piano lines

column2: Z ends with the intense

Paul Wall is probably the first white rap star who doesn't feel the need to talk about his race. No white rapper has ever managed to reach any level of fame without addressing his race
column4: whether it be the Beastie Boys' downtown dorkatronix
column5: House of Pain's Irish-pride chest-beating
column6: Eminem's obsessive self-loathing
column7: or Bubba Sparxxx's country-rap album. Even Vanilla Ice concocted an elaborately fake backstory and put the word ""Vanilla"" in his name. Not Paul Wall. If you never saw a picture of this guy
column8: you'd have no idea that he's the only white guy in his video; you'd just know that he's a dude with a low
column9: thick drawl who loves cars and diamonds. A large part of Paul's success comes from his sheer implausibility-- he's a goofy guy with a fratboy goatee who went to college and then made his name designing platinum grills
column10: and he rolls with an underground
column11: provincial rap crew who became tremendously famous once MTV realized that Houston has this whole long-standing self-contained rap culture.

column1: None of this general weirdness (except the Houston stuff) actually comes through in Paul's music
column2: which is all straight unadulterated H-Town rap
column3: with all the slow booming drums and woozy organs and dizzying clustered bleeps that come with the territory. One of the reasons that The People's Champ succeeds is that it's the first album from Houston's rap Renaissance that doesn't remotely compromise the region's aesthetic-- it's all hazy
column4: narcotic trunk music. Of the album's 17 tracks
column5: only one was made by out-of-town producers
column6: and even that track (DJ Paul and Juicy J's ""I'm a Playa"") has a heavy
column7: off-kilter stagger that sounds completely Texas. Salih Williams and Mr. Lee
column8: who produced
column9: respectively
column10: Mike Jones' ""Still Tippin'"" and Slim Thug's ""Three Kings""
column11: both make appearances
column12: but the album really belongs to the previously unknown producer Grid Iron
column13: whose handful of stormy
column14: gliding tracks are consistently the best on the album.

column1: The record also boasts a number of ridiculously great guest appearances. One of the great things about Houston funk is that it forces out-of-town guests to conform to its aesthetics
column2: so the album doesn't come off sounding like a patched-together collection of tracks. The R&B; singer Trey Songz' guest spot on ""Ridin' Dirty"" is all gorgeous silky swagger
column3: and it greases the track just right
column4: while Lil Wayne spits cold
column5: hard gangsta contempt on ""March N' Step"". It's a tribute to Paul Wall that Kanye Wests's near-perfect ""Drive Slow"" doesn't sound out of place when it appears here.

column1: As for Paul himself
column2: he's fine
column3: nothing special. He's a better rapper than labelmate Mike Jones (notably absent here)
column4: but not as good a rapper as Slim Thug. (In fact
column5: on the bonus screwed-and-chopped disc
column6: Paul's slowed-down voice sounds almost exactly like Slim's normal voice
column7: which is weird.) He sounds calm and matter-of-fact on top of these expert beats
column8: and he truly loves to talk about diamonds: ""I've got a deep freezer up in my mouth and sno-cones up in my ear/ A ice tray up in my mouth
column9: I'm looking something like a chandelier.""

column1: Wall can be awkward and goofy

The Hackensaw Boys have developed a solid reputation as purveyors of fine Appalachian bluegrass-tinted folk
column2: but after listening to their new album
column3: <i>Love What You Do
column4: I've come to the conclusion that they're really just a band of indie revivalists who search for authenticity in the esoteric and traditional. It's just that their tradition is much older
column5: more rural
column6: and less popular than those of most other indie bands we review here-- Bill Monroe and Ralph Stanley instead of Brian Wilson or Joy Division.

column1: I don't mean that observation as a purely negative criticism
column2: but I'm skeptical of <i>Love What You Do in the same way I'm skeptical of Interpol
column3: the Killers
column4: and other bands who hew closely to their influences. Exhibiting the Boys' capable
column5: if unspectacular
column6: picking and fiddling
column7: several songs veer toward re-creation rather than reinterpretation
column8: as though their primary goal is to write songs that sound like they were written decades ago. ""Buildings Are Our Cages"" meditates on our modern social enslavement
column9: using a caterpillar as an exemplar of personal freedom. Addressing unsavory politics via a train metaphor
column10: ""Cannonball"" is the musical equivalent of an old editorial cartoon
column11: with only a mention of Columbine making clear they're talking about the 2000s and not the 1900s. ""Parking Lot Song"" and ""Kiss You Down There"" are faux-randy romps
column12: but does anyone really need a bluegrass song about oral sex? At least I hope the Boys intend the chorus ""I wanna kiss you down there"" as a double entendre. If not
column13: we need to talk.

column1: The Boys sound best when they sound thoroughly modern
column2: less beholden to tradition and more focused in the present. Slower and quieter numbers like ""Bordertown"" and ""All Good Dogs"" allow for more candid reflection
column3: making sore thumbs of the faster numbers. Opening the album
column4: ""Sun's Work Undone"" is a tender lament about impossible love
column5: made all the more poignant for Dave Sickmen's rough vocals. But it's ""Alabama Shamrock"" that proves the highlight of <i>Love What You Do. Seeming at first like an ode to the creative freedom of touring
column6: the song eventually complicates its sentiment
column7: aptly and affectingly conveying the out-of-time feeling of being born too late
column8:
of identifying so strongly with the past that you can never make the present your home. That the Boys sounds so rooted in the here and now only makes the song more powerful and that makes you wish they'd stick around.

If you don't fall in love with Amusement Parks on Fire's self-titled debut after the first few notes of ""Venus in Cancer""
column2: you never will. A throbbing dose of 4/4 overdriven pop
column3: the song casually channels the melody from Dinosaur Jr.'s ""Little Fury Things"" via frontman Michael Feerick's smooth delivery
column4: which conveys a sense of angst without over-emoting.

column1: It's an impressive feat considering Feerick recorded the album entirely on his own
column2: but after you've heard the first two tracks-- the slow-building
column3: piano-and-strings instrumental ""23 Jewels"" that leads to ""Venus""-- you've pretty much heard the entire record. As the album proceeds
column4: APOF's waves of distorted guitar continue to rise and fall and the instrumental breathers come at just the right moments
column5: but there are no more tricks up Feerick's sleeve. ""Venosa"" delivers jagged guitars and a jaunty melody
column6: and it's followed with another plodding piano-driven instrumental
column7: ""Asphalt (Interlude)"". Even the moments of derivation
column8: like the tape-recorded dialogue over the breakdown in ""Eighty Eight"" or the gradual crescendos and declines of the eight-minute ""Wiper""
column9: seem predictable.

column1: At times
column2: the transitions between tracks can be charming-- ""The Ramones Book"" is a modest
column3: maudlin piano ballad that kicks unexpectedly into the soaring shoegaze of ""Local Boy Makes God""-- but the album simply revisits the same couple of sounds. It's not just that the pacing is so methodical it nearly makes the record sterile
column4: or that the best song just reminds me of someone else's better song
column5: but for all of the overhwlelming guitars layered onto these songs
column6: sentimental ballads like ""The Ramones Book"" are what's at the record's heart. My perception might be colored by hearing the ""rustic"" version of ""Venus in Caner"" from that song's single release
column7: a precious acoustic rendition that stands perfectly on it's own. It was a revelation: These tracks aren't bult to bruise
column8: they're bedroom pop in a blanket of distortion as a defense. Feerick's simple melodies sound much more apt with subtle coloration instead of overkill. Amusement Parks on Fire has undeniable focus
column9:
but it's moments like ""The Ramones Book"" that reveal the most.

Ex-Blake Baby Juliana Hatfield might whine
column2: ""Singing stupid songs/ I'm going blonde
column3: but she hasn't gone nearly blonde enough: Angsty tinny-voiced colleague Liz Phair probably kicks more ass as a sellout than overgrown college rocker Hatfield does covering well-trodden ground on her latest self-released album-- make note of the pictorial entreaty to navel gaze. Still
column4: everything's not lost: Made in China will find its audience-- moody high school girls with jerk boyfriends will listen to this album while scrawling lyrics on their Chucks in multi-colored ball points (probably pink).

column1: The album's main setback is its schizo-""love in the 90s is paranoid"" philosophy--scuffed-up ""Sex in the City"" mindset
column2: lusting after problems of girls 10 or 15 years your junior. Hatfield's going on 40 but still stuck in adolescene
column3: complaining
column4: ""I don't want to go to school today/ I just wanna play guitar all day"" on ""Stay Awake"". During ""Digital Penetration""-- is this an 'N Sync cover?-- she protests ""shiny girls with no opinions
column5: and parties where everybody knows the words except her; ""Send Money"" has to break some record for most unimpassioned petition for allowance money (albeit from God).

column1: But what's she so pissed off about anyway? School hasn't been the root of her problems for years
column2: and while retro stunts do well to remind us of comparatively jaded pseudo-punk femme fatales of yesteryear
column3: what's past is past: ""New Waif"" might portend potentially catchy bulimia-rock (a 90s Bettie Serveert and Velocity Girl vomitfest
column4: at best) but gets old quick: Hatfield has nothing new to say besides ""You don't know what it's like to be perfect
column5: and it might explain her perfect-person tendency toward carelessness-- guitar solos
column6: grating vocals (remember that time she picked up smoking to make her voice edgier?)
column7: overdone crabbiness-- all signs that point to thinly veiled midlife crisis rock.

column1: But Hatfield doesn't care what we think-- doesn't care if we buy her records-- and the half-assedness shows. At best
column2: the inattention doubles up as deeply felt passion; at worst-- and it's mostly always at worst-- it's self-inflicted cuts doused in lemon juice. On ""What Do I Care""
column3: she's shocked when we don't sing her praises-- ""I'm amazed you don't find me delicious/ Look at me
column4:
I'm a rock star!""-- and we're shocked she can't see why not.

Human hearing is a pretty incredible thing. After millions of years of predator-avoidance natural selection
column4: we've evolved     the ability to discriminate very slight differences in     frequency and to recall entire sequences of tones from     memory. [NOTE: statement not applicable in Kansas and     Harrisburg
column5: Pa.] In modern times
column6: we've     harnessed this fantastic skill for truly awe-inspiring     tasks
column7: such as perfectly beat-matching LCD Soundsystem     into New Order
column8: or scowling derisively when a band's rhythm guitarist is a half-step out of tune.

column1: These wondrous abilities are what had me dreading the American reissue of the Go! Team's excellent debut Thunder
column2: Lightning
column3: Strike. If you haven't heard the backstory
column4: this lawyer-stuffed country     made it difficult for the Go! Team to clear the     original album's samples for domestic release
column5: forcing the band to slightly     tweak the material in order to purge the recordings of     legal pitfalls. In addition
column6: the record was     reportedly given a gift certificate to the remastering     day spa
column7: a process with the potential to thoughtlessly     drain some of the group's messy
column8: homemade charm in the name of fidelity. With an album that's been     widely available for over a year
column9: even the smallest changes could prove annoyingly distracting to those who've been with the Go! Team from their blog-hype birth.

column1: Fortunately
column2: 1) <i>Thunder
column3: Lightning
column4: Strike is no Paul's Boutique
column5: and 2) Cheerleaders have crappy legal     representation. To these obsessive ears
column6: it seems     that roughly 95% of the original music is intact
column7: and     the differences
column8: where they arise
column9: are minimally     distracting. The fanfare horns that kick off ""Junior     Kickstart"" might be slightly tweaked
column10: ""Bottle Rocket""     might have a new rap from new frontwoman Ninja
column11: they may have swapped one schmaltzy trumpet solo     for another on ""Everyone's a VIP to Someone""
column12: but     rarely do the alterations change the character of the     song. Even the EPCOT ride through girl-group history     ""Ladyflash""
column13: which I had most feared would go under     the knife
column14: is left unspoiled by copyright     considerations
column15: praise the courts.

column1: Equally non-intrusive is the remastering
column2: which does a     nice job of housekeeping the extraneous hisses while     maintaining the band's collage and needle-in-the-red     sensibilities. In fact
column3: the remix doesn't so     much clean up the songs' pools of bleedover sound so     much as merely stir them up
column4: bringing to the surface     some new elements that might not have been so readily     apparent on the first release. ""Panther Dash""
column5: for     example
column6: seems to contain a lot more power-tool     noise-guitar parts than I remembered
column7: reinforcing my impression from their live show that Sonic Youth is just as big an influence as cop themes and Avalanches.

column1: With these factors decidedly non-intrusive
column2: the most     significant change to <i>Thunder
column3: Lightning
column4: Strike is the promotion of ""We Just Won't Be Defeated"" and ""Hold Yr Terror Close""
column5: formerly both B-sides
column6: to the     major league roster. Even this switch isn't all that     disorienting
column7: as ""Defeated"" adds a fresh cheerleader     track to break up the mostly instrumental middle
column8: and ""Terror"" offers a glimpse of the band's Children's Workshop twee side amidst the swirl of drum breaks and marching band blasts.

column1: So the main point of this comparative review is that
column2: well
column3: there really is no comparison to be made. The     Go! Team
column4: rather skillfully
column5: navigated the     treacherous waters of sample clearance and remastering     to prepare a domestic version of <i>Thunder
column6: Lightning
column7: Strike no better or worse than the charming original. As such
column8:
it's only fitting to affix the same score upon it.

The legend of John Lennon
column2: stripped bare of its romantic and willfully misinformed tales of idealism and near-religious fervor for ""changing the world
column3: is mostly a lot of short stories about a stubborn
column4: quick-witted domestic hero. Working class? That's debatable
column5: as is much of Lennon's life for everyone save his widow and second son-- but then all good stories have an air of mystery about them. If I were more cynical
column6: I'd point out that one person's mystery is another's propaganda
column7: but ultimately
column8: Lennon is going to be remembered for songs
column9: not his personal life.  Of course his personal life was his songs; to a fault
column10: Lennon wrote about what he knew
column11: however skewed by bitterness
column12: confusion
column13: regret
column14: braggadocio
column15: or even peace and love.

column1: Consequently
column2: it's difficult to hear Lennon's post-Beatles music beyond the frame of whatever commotion was going on in his world at the time. Be it bed-ins for peace
column3: trouble with Immigration
column4: various political rants
column5: relationship highs and woes
column6: or his undying love of old rock and roll
column7: Lennon was as partial as the most insular blogger-- and with no pretense of linking his sources. But then
column8: he was probably smarter than anyone he knew (again
column9: save Yoko Ono)
column10: and you can hardly blame a generation of spiritual hangers-on for letting his idiosyncrasies and tantrums run rampant. He wasn't the first punk; he wasn't ever really a hippie; he wasn't a poet
column11: exactly
column12: and he was barely a guitarist. He was a middle-class boomer with a short fuse
column13: overtly provocative social and political ideals
column14: but who was uncut for anything besides making music.

column1: Lennon's music
column2: as a window into his life
column3: is serviceable. As pop
column4: it's immediately distinctive
column5: if frustrating and inconsistent. As something in lieu of new Beatles albums
column6: it's mostly disappointing. But as Working Class Hero: The Definitive Lennon makes abundantly clear over the span of two CDs
column7: it was also a pretty amazing document of a mature artist going through the same shit as everyone else does. No
column8: I don't recall asking for another Lennon comp
column9: but as I get older
column10: and we all get further from the circumstances that made him an icon
column11: I'm reminded that his insight into growing up and getting on with life (and any number of distractions) was as keen as anyone's.

column1: Collections like this generally serve to rewrite history more often than give representative pictures of reality
column2: but even Lennon's best moments are rife with contradiction and awkward expression. The good news is that <em>Working Class Hero really does include most of his best stuff: ""Imagine""
column3: ""Instant Karma""
column4: ""(Just Like) Starting Over""
column5: and ""Give Peace a Chance"" are obligated to any Lennon best-of
column6: but Ono and Capitol were pretty spot-on by including ace stuff like ""Gimme Some Truth""
column7: ""Jealous Guy""
column8: ""#9 Dream"" and a fantastic ""Real Love"" demo-- not to mention most of Plastic Ono Band. In truth
column9: had this set also included the acerbic
column10: Paul-hating ""How Do You Sleep?"" from Imagine
column11: I could've recommended it over any of his solo records save POB. Yet again
column12: Lennon is inconsistent to the end. As for rarities
column13: beyond ""Real Love""
column14: there is a live version of ""Come Together"" (wherein Lennon warns the crowd they may know more of the words than he does-- and then proves it)
column15: but <em>Working Class Hero is supposed to be ""definitive
column16: not all-inclusive.

column1: The <em>Double Fantasy-era songs-- ""(Just Like) Starting Over""
column2: ""Watching the Wheels""
column3: ""Beautiful Boy (Darling Boy)""
column4: ""Woman""
column5: ""Losing You""
column6: and the Milk and Honey single ""Nobody Told Me""-- stand out from the rest as being a bit slick and out of steam
column7: though in all fairness
column8: also seem far less bitter than
column9: say
column10: ""Mind Games"". Again
column11: it's all part of the legend that comes crumbling down when you actually listen to the songs-- his ""greatest hits"" suggest a guy who
column12: while overcoming some of his darkest demons
column13: was still a long way from being comfortable with himself even as he was living in the lap of luxury. The buttoned-up
column14: proto-adult-contemporary sheen of Double Fantasy seems like a big slap in the face to real
column15: live marital friction-- certainly about as far a cry as one could get from the uber-stark performances on ""God"" or ""Working Class Hero"". Pundits might argue that as Lennon matured as an artist
column16: he felt less need to be musically confrontational. I would argue back that I'm a long way from relating to adult contemporary sheen.

column1: As a collection
column2: Working Class Hero succeeds: The single-disc Lennon Legend always seemed reductive to me
column3: and there's no way I need the four discs of solo Lennon available on the Anthology box set. Better still
column4: this really does give me most of the stuff I'd want to put in my Lennon mp3 folder
column5: and at this point
column6:
that's about as good a recommendation as I can give a compilation-- at least until the next one comes around in a couple of years. And what was that about instant karma...

The Hospitals' sophomore album I've Visited the Island of Jocks and Jazz is their first for Load
column4: following a self-titled 2003 debut on In the Red. Albeit brief
column5: that label lineage might tell savvy listeners all they need to know about the Portland group's depraved roots-noise mayhem. You could also track down their recent 12"" on the Yakisakana imprint on which they cover the Who
column6: the Kinks
column7: and Harry Pussy with equally fond but irreverent abuse. Put more plainly
column8: the Hospitals bring the chaotic trash-rock of acts like the Country Teasers or Cheater Slicks to an inevitable-- if not exactly logical-- conclusion
column9: creating a willfully primitive
column10: atonal scree whose flash is that of a string of firecrackers: sharp
column11: immediate
column12: and short-lasting.

column1: Since their debut
column2: the Hospitals have grown from a two-piece to a three-piece
column3: with dual guitarists Ned Meiners and Rob Enbom joining drummer/vocalist Adam Stonehouse. This expansion has
column4: if anything
column5: resulted in a further degeneration of the band's sound. Whereas many of the songs on the debut maintained
column6: or at least alluded to
column7: standard garage-punk structures
column8: most tracks here are deconstructed
column9: with heavily reverbed vocals and serrated chords flying haphazardly past in fiery chunks. Unlike obvious precursors like Harry Pussy or Sightings
column10: however
column11: the Hospitals appear to have little ambition to drive these raucous exercises anywhere beyond their initial skin-deep assaultive shock.

column1: The guitars on tracks like ""Olympic Ghost"" and ""She's Not There"" feature some vicious Bad Moon Rising tones that'll carry innate appeal for a certain segment of the garage/noise audience
column2: and others like ""Moving/Shaking"" or ""Airplanes There"" actually contain rudimentary melodic hooks. Across it all
column3: Stonehouse strikes a curious presence
column4: providing most tracks with surprisingly straightforward rhythms while submitting his tortured vocals and shiftless lyrical observations to an ocean of distorted effects. His work is at its most effective on the album's more experimental cuts like ""Problems""
column5: which reaches depths of almost Jandek-like imprecision
column6: or the aggressive dissonance of ""Be""
column7: the only track here that surpasses the three-minute mark.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: however
column3: the Hospitals seem stubbornly intent on blurring their abstractions into sheer crude apathy. ""I Had a Crummy Shift"" wastes its promising title on an aimless 30-second slur
column4: while ""Rich People"" contains a pointless goof on the familiar ballpark ""Go team go!"" ascending riff. Thankfully
column5: this is a group that values brevity
column6: and the majority the album's several one-dimensional non-starters (""Art Project""
column7: ""Bands""
column8: ""Jocks and Jazz"") won't cost you more than a minute or two. This is a small
column9:
welcome courtesy from a band who don't otherwise seem to take listener satisfaction into much account at all.

column2: he runs it into the ground hard. The first time he lays a cheesed-out 70s rock vocal sample over chugging house drums
column3: it's mildly sweeping and glamorous. By the fourth time
column4: it's clear that he doesn't have any more tricks to pull out. And by the time we get to the final track of the album
column5: where Tim Holden says a bunch of echoey poetry-slam stuff over a lumbering
column6: ungainly riff for six and a half minutes
column7:
it's clear that ""Hear My Name"" deserved a much better album.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/247/homepage_large.ba5552a7.jpg|Extraordinary Machine [Jon Brion version]|116.0|Fiona Apple|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['mp3']|2005-10-04 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:53:42.363317|"

If you're particularly web savvy
column2: you may have seen the previous version of this review up on the site before its replacement with the edition you're reading right now. Here's the story: I crafted the original to be my most ambitious yet-- epic in scope
column3: embellished with the richest prose I could possibly summon. But alas
column4: the powers that be were not
column5: as they say
column6: feeling it
column7: and sent me back to the drawing board to craft a review less eccentric and more crowd-friendly. Or actually
column8: maybe I had second thoughts about the original review myself
column9: choosing to self-regulate and take a mulligan. I don't know
column10: it's very confusing; but know that all this vacillation was never for publicity's sake
column11: no
column12: never that.

column1: So I can empathize with Fiona Apple
column2: who has gone through a similarly arduous journey on the road to releasing her first album in six years. Earlier this year
column3: Extraordinary Machine appeared destined for Yankee Hotel Foxtrot status
column4: as the nearly-finished album Apple made with longtime collaborator Jon Brion was shelved
column5: then surreptitiously leaked to the world's music thieves. But rather than graciously accepting a starring role in Fuck the Man Rock N' Roll Myth #67
column6: Apple did a do-over
column7: this time working with Mike Elizondo
column8: best known as right-hand man to the good Dr. Dre.

column1: Unfortunately for Apple and Elizondo
column2: that Brion version isn't going away quietly. And now
column3: upon the release of the official retail version
column4: it only makes sense to compare the two-- a sort of musical Pepsi challenge-- given that they share 11 of 12 songs. The differences are far from subtle: For all but two songs
column5: the title track and ""Waltz (Better Than Fine)""
column6: Elizondo overhauled the original takes-- or maybe underhauled is the more appropriate term in this case
column7: given the addition-by-subtraction philosophy applied throughout.

column1: Apple is a songwriter who can turn every relationship hiccup into a calamitous tragedy
column2: and Brion fittingly applied his production talents with the intent of blowing up her songs to 2.35:1 aspect ratio. On ""Not About Love"" and ""O' Sailor""
column3: Brion scored Apple's compositions no less extravagantly than his soundtracking work for the indie-film elite
column4: applying dollops of lush orchestration to place her piano and throwback vocals in an epic frame. Though the material wasn't always Apple's best-- ""Oh Well"" and ""Window"" in particular
column5: sounding a bit through-the-motions-- the symphonic presentation kept it interesting and gave the LP a cohesive flavor.

column1: Elizondo's approach is more eclectic: Rather than applying copious amounts of strings
column2: he employs bits of organ
column3: backwards loops
column4: and busier drumming to flesh out Fiona's sound. But the fleshing out is kept skeletal
column5: so as not to distract from the central elements of Apple's voice and piano. Though the Brion version was likely unmastered
column6: it's still striking how much the emphasis has shifted from a broader sound to Apple's contributions alone
column7: like demos in reverse. You can also pour a 40 out for fallen countermelodies
column8: as Elizondo hacks away Brion's embellishments upon ""Not About Love"" and ""Window"" in his efforts to keep the spotlight fixed solely on the star.

column1: Not to say that there aren't moments where Elizondo either improves or offers a valid alternative to the Brion takes
column2: as ""Tymps (The Sick in the Head Song)"" remakes the routine ""Used to Love Him"" with twitchy synth-bass and ""Oh Well"" benefits from a stronger vocal take. The dreamy ""O' Sailor""
column3: meanwhile
column4: refuses to be ruined
column5: though the new version knocks the original out of its cosmic moody-blue orbit by insultingly replacing actual strings with the synthesized variety. Not so tamper-proof are the triplets ""Red Red Red"" and ""Please Please Please""
column6: the former losing most of its drama thanks to a dull ambient backdrop
column7: the latter ironically softening its single-ready punch on what's supposed to be the more traditionally commercial album.

column1: The officially released version of Extraordinary Machine remains a decent-to-good album
column2: one that showcases Apple's considerable vocal and key-pounding talents. In its new clothes
column3: the album fits alongside her prior two albums
column4: with only the slightly less consistent material bringing it down a peg. The shame of it all is that Apple
column5: after six years of silence
column6: could've made a more definitive
column7:
progressive statement rather than something familiar and similar-- and we've got the bootlegs to prove it.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/4579/homepage_large.5651aac6.jpg|The Witching Hour|2408.0|Ladytron|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ryko']|2005-10-04 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:53:42.921517|"

Even though the warm breath of October has made it easier (here in Toronto
column3: anyway) to pretend we're still in July
column4: the spell is becoming increasingly difficult to maintain. From the browning leaves to the scarves in the windows of the downtown department stores
column5: it's understood that we're just playing in injury time now
column6: and that any prickly chill might signal autumn's speed trials on the way to another interminable winter.

column1: Beyond the first snowfall
column2: I am not a finds-comfort-in-December kind of person
column3: which is probably why my treasured winter albums mean a lot more to me than the summer ones. There's something to be said for all records that lend themselves to certain seasons; the really good ones have this strange ability to extrapolate themselves across time. When Bjรถrk's Vespertine came out in 2001
column4: I knew it wasn't just going to be a record I listened to a lot that winter
column5: but in every one after it. It's instant
column6: like a mirror-in-mirror hallway
column7: folding out into the future for God knows how long
column8: always as much a mystery as it is a comfort.

column1: This year
column2: for reasons I haven't figured out yet
column3: I'm feeling like perhaps the good winter records are going to be even more important than usual. Maybe it's because I'm getting older
column4: and the mirrors are getting smaller. Or maybe it's just going to be that much harder to fend off the creeping feeling of end days without the benefit of summer's attendant glories.

column1: I won't lie: I didn't expect this to be one of those records. In fact
column2: with the exception of a handful of singles
column3: the best of which still felt brittle and two-dimensional
column4: I never cared much for Ladytron. Granted
column5: the whole electroclash thing getting levied against them seemed kind of unfair (the takeaway: keyboard basslines and polygonal haircuts are a gateway drug to dumb press)
column6: but for a type of music that was supposed to be emblematic of
column7: if not a stand-in for
column8: mountains of cocaine
column9: Ladytron always seemed kind of enfeebled
column10: their glassy tick-tock a weak substitute for anything properly muscular.

column1: If they lacked the horsepower before
column2: the year plus they spent touring behind 2002's Light & Magic put the meat on their bones. Despite being delayed for nearly a year thanks to the collapse of their UK label Telstar and the emergency room administration required for their still-dormant U.S. label Emperor Norton
column3: The Witching Hour is the most urgent and immediate of their career. The earlier records were sort of toylike and plastic; this not only has a pulse
column4: it has chilled blood in its veins.

column1: Every quantum leap record has a quantum leap single
column2: and in this case
column3: it's ""Destroy Everything You Touch"". With a charging chorus and shivery production that sounds as equally indebted to shoegaze as it does synthpop
column4: this is probably the most confident and menacing thing they've ever done. Almost as good is ""International Dateline""
column5: which marries a pogo punk rhythm and a post-punky guitar lead with a keening vocal hook. With nothing but a transparent wash of synths and a simple minor-key vocal melody
column6: closer ""All the Way"" demonstrates that Ladytron's advancement owes as much to their songwriting as it does to their increased production prowess. And
column7: for better or worse
column8: the barely concealed cocaine metaphor of ""Sugar"" (""If I get the sugar
column9: will you get me/ Something elusive and temporary"") proves they could go there if they wanted to.

column1: But perhaps the most surprising thing about The Witching Hour is how affecting it is. Beyond the crumbling synths and the uneasy washes of white noise are lyrics that move between sounding commanding and hopelessly lost; where vocalists Mira Aroyo and Helena Marnie once sang about things like movie theatres and Commodore computers from about four steps back from mic
column2: they're right between your ears now
column3: their lungs fighting with the wheezing synths for airspace. That's as good an illustration as any of how far they've come in these last three years: if Ladytron of old was a truckful of ice
column4: this one's a winter storm
column5:
bundled up people and all.

"|4635.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/4635-the-witching-hour/|8.3|Mark Pytlik

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/4546/homepage_large.f394287e.jpg|Misty Medley|2390.0|Kiss Me Deadly|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Alien8']|2005-10-04 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:53:43.529074|"

If the word ethereal did not exist
column2: it would be necessary to invent it. Like so many other terms in our desperately comprehensive language-- unicorn
column3: utopia
column4: Kevin Federline-- it describes a concept that is essentially nonexistent. Ethereality is more of an absence than an entity
column5: a lacuna in human understanding that encapsulates all things insubstantial and fleeting
column6: intangible and delicate
column7: ineffable and intuitively not-of-this-world. Certain sensations are impossible to explain without it
column8: the diffuse frissons of post-rock (the dreamy
column9: shoegazey '90s variety
column10:
not the modern conflated-with-math-rock stripe) ranking high among them.

n Kiss Me Deadly's lusciously ethereal post-rock is leavened with stark contrasts--the tension between languorous shoegaze and kinetic shuffle beats
column11: for instance--but the starkest one is between the band's pulpy name and their pristine music. Kiss Me Deadly is a Mickey Spillane book made into a 1955 film noir by director Robert Aldrich
column12: and there's nothing less ethereal than the bleak
column13: fatalistic archetypes of film noir; every face striped with the hard-edged shadows of moon-obscuring Venetian blinds. As Nitsuh Abebe pointed out in his recent Pitchfork article on '90s post-rock
column14: ""early post-rock bands were constantly talking about the moon
column15: with all of its usual connotations: Weightlessness
column16: futurism
column17: blank space
column18: and serenity; dreamy
column19: cerebral moods; and of course the beeps and hums of the old technology that first got people there."" As if to signal this affinity
column20: Misty Medley's cover features a contour line drawing of a blank-eyed astronaut gazing past the moon and out of the frame
column21: perhaps at shoes tied at the laces and drifting through space.

column1: Not content to recreate the cerebral palimpsests of Stereolab and Bark Psychosis
column2: Kiss Me Deadly updates classic post-rock swoon with gentle dance rhythms and poppy
column3: lucid song structures. The immediate grabber is Emily Elizabeth's breathy
column4: helium-infused voice
column5: which brims with more chirrups
column6: squeaks
column7: and indelible flourishes than anything this side of Life Without Buildings. As the gliding guitar melody of ""Dance 4"" finishes chiming out the national anthem of some lunar colony and settles into a fluid cadence
column8: Elizabeth's stage whisper wafts into the mix
column9: culminating in shrill screams that woozily bend into mellifluous vowels. On the lilting ""Dance 2""
column10: she makes like a human slide-whistle
column11: cooing and squealing about ""candy eyes""
column12: and on the jittery ""Dance 3""
column13: she sounds like a club-pop diva who wandered into Echo and the Bunnymen's practice space.

column1: If Elizabeth's voice is exquisitely odd
column2: then Adam Poulin's serviceable croon is a welcome ballast. On ""Pop""
column3: he rides the stuttering wave toward a grandiose chorus like an indie Bono; on ""Let's""
column4: he hunkers down in sibilant percussion and a characteristic melody that pairs a dominant
column5: simple guitar figure with a recessed
column6: twitchy lead. The music's most striking quality is that of gliding
column7: which requires equilibrium. Kiss Me Deadly
column8: with their outrรฉ female and mundane male vocals
column9: their coasting rhythms and anxious melodies
column10: strikes a balance that holds Misty Medley easily
column11:
weightlessly aloft.

"|4602.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/4602-misty-medley/|7.8|Brian Howe

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/7710/homepage_large.404ed12c.jpg|Blame It on the Youth|4138.0|The Sun|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2005-10-04 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:53:44.143723|"

Blame it on the Youth is not a CD. The bright red sticker on the front will tell you that instead it's The World's First DVD-only Album. No audio disc comes packaged with The Sun's debut album
column2: only a DVD with videos for each of its 14 songs. You can rip .WAV files from the disc with the DVD-ROM drive of your computer
column3: or purchase mp3s from iTunes or other digital vendors
column4: but put it into your car or home stereo and all you'll hear is the faint whirr of useless plastic spinning in place.

column1: The band decided that a DualDisc or an audio/video package-- a route taken by artists as disparate as Super Furry Animals
column2: Wire
column3: and 50 Cent-- would be too costly. Admitting to leaking their record tp p2p networks five months before its release
column4: their choice acknowledges and tacitly encourages file-sharing
column5: while trying to give the consumer a package to get excited about. But aren't there a number of people who buy CDs
column6: yet don't have DVD-ROM drives in their computer? And don't they download most of their music
column7: legally or otherwise?

column1: The videos were reportedly put together on the cheap
column2: using handheld cameras and pooling volunteers from Craigslist. Some are undeniably amateurish
column3: but ""Justice""
column4: ""Waiting on High""
column5: or ""Valentine"" all feature competent lighting and editing production values. There's even some ingenuity to the racy shoot for ""Romantic Death""
column6: which splices together grainy shots of men and women facing the camera while masturbating (from the shoulders up). ""2B4"" or ""We Try"" are a little less creative with their limited budget
column7: and the animated collage for ""Taking the Lord's Name in Vein""
column8: full of blunt political imagery
column9: would have been better off with just straight performance shots.

column1: ""Lose Your Money"" is a continuous shot of a man sitting
column2: staring at a mirror and a bottle of wine
column3: while half-heartedly mouthing the song's lyrics in between sips of alcohol. He lights a cigarette and rubs his brow
column4: then it ends suddenly with an inscrutable montage of color-saturated nature imagery. It's trite
column5: self-involved
column6: Film Production 101 fare-- yet I've had nights just like it
column7: with songs plenty more embarrassing than the dirge-y ""Lose Your Money"". The director took a risk
column8: and I can't deny my sentimental reaction.

column1: I wish I could say the same for the songs. Not that Blame it on the Youth lacks catchy melodies
column2: or that they're aren't meticulous arrangements under the hooks. The band executes polite slices of pop like ""Justice"" and ""We Try"" with precision
column3: but the moments of supposed catharsis-- the red-faced screaming through the third verse of ""Must be You""
column4: or the flubbed guitar solo and thrashy finale of ""Say Goodbye""-- come off as forced. Even the borderline freakout ""Taking the Lords Name in Vein"" sounds rehearsed and mannered. Try as they might
column5: the Sun just can't seem to sweat or get dirty on Blame it on the Youth.

column1: I'm not just reviewing a batch of songs here
column2: I'm reviewing a DVD that a good section of the buying public can't even listen to without watching TV for an hour. While there's a broad palette of sounds and images to be found
column3: their multi-pronged multimedia gamble just points toward my main complaint with Blame it on the Youth: The Sun want to master all the mediums
column4:
but they don't have much to say.

"|7833.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/7833-blame-it-on-the-youth/|5.9|Jason Crock

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/5840/homepage_large.4cdcd888.jpg|City Lights Volume 1.5|3120.0|Nicolay|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['BBE']|2005-10-04 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:53:44.766358|"

You can get away with murder just by calling it ""uninteresting."" See: The omnibus of crit on instrumental hip-hop. Pitchfork's own Jess Harvell laid it down
column2: though. While conceding no other genre has ""forced us to sit through more un-reconstituted dreck than rap-less rap
column3: he gives credit where it's due (in this case to Dabrye's Instrmntl): ""The one good thing about wallpaper is that it's just thereรignorability is part of the deal.""

column1: So the review writes itself. But
column2: interested in what the parsing of an artistic process can reveal
column3: I try to be optimistic. City Lights Volume 1.5 puts us behind the boards of Dutch producer Nicolay
column4: who helmed last year's most fortuitous hook-up-- that unbearably sensuous Foreign Exchange record. An interesting spot
column5: 'cause Connected miraculously eschewed the desert island its emcee
column6: Little Brother's Phonte
column7: steered it straight for: blundering backpack innocuousness.

column1: Was it an illogical
column2: disproportionate synergy
column3: or were Nicolay's watercolor-light compositions that good? Does vox-stripped <em>City Lights reveal the elusive
column4: indwelling spirit of a talented producer's beats? Results are inconclusive. For one
column5: Nic's beats are weaker
column6: which confounds the experiment. This set offers nothing as luminous as the french horn-gilt ""Let's Move"" or ""Be Alright""'s blush-hued synths.

column1: But take care not to give the purple-sand beat-making shores of Foreign Exchange's intercontinental entente too much credit. For all Phonte's unmoving prattle on Connected
column2: his verses did provide a crucial texture. The album's single holler-able refrain was a bated ""Let's Move""; otherwise
column3: voice was cornstarch
column4: a cooked-in thickener. Lacking that unifier
column5: <em>City Lights feels incomplete-- yes
column6: even for rap-less rap. And thinness is the genre's death knell; it stifles listeners looking for an immersive opiate spell.

column1: Sameyness that doesn't even hold up as drapery? Sounds like ""meh"" personified. Nic's a savvy dude
column2: howevs. He counterbalances our ears' inclination to drift with some jarringly offset kicks. Nothing too bold
column3: mind you
column4: lest it ruffle his fine-knit haberdashery. But ""Intro"" (which incidentally sports tactful backgrounded voices) sways on a rushed snare feel
column5: flamming the simple changes. Details like that are missed on the boringly syncopated ""Fantastic"" and the hopelessly listless ""Indian Summer"". Throughout the latter
column6: undulating vibes await their cup of coffee
column7: but the skipper benches his top prospects
column8: losing with groovin' hand percussion and fusty flutes.

column1: It'd be interesting if <em>City Lights threw us a bone-- a vocal track
column2: just one!-- for comparison's sake. Many songs concede noncommittal spoken word outros
column3: but their formulaic placement (always as a predictable
column4: faded segue into the next track) is fruitless. Monotony is expected
column5: risquรฉ nice but not required; this thing's just too bleary-eyed to sustain itself
column6:
much less our generous half-attention.

"|5920.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/5920-city-lights-volume-15/|4.8|Sam Ubl

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/668/homepage_large.9a61ff85.jpg|The Best of the Beta Band|339.0|The Beta Band|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Astralwerks']|2005-10-03 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:53:45.442117|"

If they loved the Beta Band so much
column2: why did people give them so much shit

column1: while they were still alive? Their early development was so startling-- from
pleasant late 90s stoner-hop to a startling mix of folk
column2: kraut
column3: and acid

column1: house in less than six months-- that we just assumed they could go anywhere.
Then they released an album that did go anywhere
column2: and they got

column1: castigated for it. Then they toned down the shit-talking and liberties-taking
and accentuated the beat-science and hippie-gentleness
column2: and they got castigated

column1: for it. Then they released an album of pleasant
column2: conventional indie rock and

column1: couldn't even get castigated. They were as exhausted as we were and broke up.
It's pretty clear they weren't the assholes here: There's not a single band
in the past year with the balls-- or lack of sense
column2: your call-- to release

column1: a debut album as overgrown with ideas (not always good ones
column2: mind you) as

column1: <i>The Beta Band. And in 2001
column2: what Hot Shots II was offering--

column1: guitars meet Timbaland
column2: to be reductive-- was pretty much all many of us

column1: wanted from a rock band.
A best-of released in the aftermath of an ignominious break-up always feels
a little less radiant than a best-of from a band who went out on a high note.
<i>The Best of the Beta Band is a funny beast.  Collecting singles
column2: it

column1: should ideally give haters what they always wanted: All the band's styles
in one place. Unfortunately
column2: it has the probably unintended effect of shaving

column1: off the shag. Missing an obnoxious piece of audience baiting like ""The Beta
Band Rap"" or the cuckoo twentysomething-crisis of ""Round the Bend"" means
you're not getting the Betas as they were.
Sequenced chronologically
column2: <i>The Best of the Beta Band features a

column1: whopping five tracks from their last album
column2: Heroes to Zeros.

column1: So it's missing a few choice cuts
column2: though exactly which ones are up for

column1: debate.  They could have made room for live-staple ""The House Song""
column2: the

column1: mournful
column2: rain-soaked ""Push It Out""
column3: or the playful ""Brokenupadingdong"".

column1: The only thing it's incontrovertibly lacking is ""Sequinsizer""
column2: where over

column1: a punchy groove they weave lonely brass

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/948/homepage_large.e631aed9.jpg|Broken Social Scene|475.0|Broken Social Scene|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Arts & Crafts']|2005-10-03 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:53:45.912907|"

Expectations are a bitch. Ask J.D. Salinger. Or George Lucas. Or Kevin Shields. After Broken Social Scene stumbled out of the incestuous Toronto alt-rock scene with Feel Good Lost-- a postrumental refrigerator-hum stiff of a debut-- few would have guessed this group of scruffed-up bohos had a veritable classic lurking in their collective consciousness. Then
column2: ignited by a rabid internet reception
column3: You Forgot It in People gracefully went boom
column4: and lots of people remembered why they loved indie rock-- the shambling ecstasy
column5: the pitch-perfect experimentation
column6:
the unabashed heart-on-sleeveness of it all.

Now
column7: with file-sharers queuing up like mad and pre-orders bumping them to Amazon Top 50 status
column8: the collective reacts to the furor by expanding and magnifying; another six members join the brood for its self-titled third full-length
column9:
and the band's once-refined studio sound is blown up into a pixilated blur of blood-gush guitars and squall-of-sound production that's somehow meticulously unhinged. This exercise in excess makes the ambitious You Forgot It in People seem positively understated by comparison.

De facto band leader Kevin Drew recently told Pitchfork that Broken Social Scene producer (and NYPD punching bag) David Newfeld ""got addicted to the idea of trying to top YFIIP."" He added: ""His massage therapist says he might die in 10 years unless he changes his lifestyle."" It's Newfeld's risky mixing and uncanny knack for coalescing myriad instruments and voices into a propulsive whole that defines this new album. Whereas You Forgot It in People was exacting and refined-- each cymbal crash snipped to perfection
column10: each underlying string melody was spare and to-the-point-- Broken Social Scene is wily and flowing. Just consider each disc's mood-setting introduction: YFIIP's ""Capture the Flag"" is muted and tasteful; BSS's ""Our Faces Split the Coast in Half"" gets out of bed
column11: trips
column12: falls down
column13: does a sloppy summersault
column14: and gets back up no worse for the wear.  The contrasting titles alone-- one direct
column15: one Dali-esque-- speak volumes.  But
column16: however symbolic
column17: ""Faces"" is only a casual stretch
column18:
with follower ""Ibi Dreams of Pavement (A Better Half)"" serving as the album's first true workout.

""Ibi"" breaks in with a woozy
column19: five-alarm guitar-- a warning call for the track's off-key surrealism and pile-on distortion.  Like the shaky ascent of a homemade rocketship
column20: the song constantly teeters on cataclysmic oblivion; shards of chords slip away and grind against each other as the track embarks.  Buried between the static and the void
column21: mumbled vocals are folded in before the brass enters and elevates the endeavor to fist-pumping
column22:
room-on-fire glory.

That track's garbled vocals and lyrical ambiguity are filtered throughout this record. With no accompanying lyric sheet
column23: most of the album's highly interpretable words not only provide fans with a time-wasting message-board guessing game but add another layer of atmospheric haze to the group's already out-there takes on sex
column25: and that whole indies-vs.-majors thing.  On the wispy
column27: the chorus could be ""I'm all hooked up"" or ""I'm all fucked up
column28:
but either meaning snidely puts down the rockstar clichรฉs Broken Social Scene are determined to avoid.

Anyone's who's been to a Broken Social Scene show over the past few years probably knows ""Major Label Debut"" as a rollicking
column29: open hi-hat dust storm.  But here
column30: that version is relegated to an accompanying EP (otherwise filled with mostly expendable outtakes and instrumentals) while the album version is slowed down and fogged up-- and decidedly less single-worthy.  Another live favorite and possible crossover contender
column34:
in-between-vox production subverts any chance at overt smashdom.

Such insular stubbornness leads to Broken Social Scene's few overly self-indulgent moments
column35: when their lack of inhibitions turns from charming to faintly annoying.  Their tendency to jam out-- not entirely surprising given bassist Brendan Canning's striking Trey Anastasio-meets-Elmo look-- turn the seven-minute ""Bandwitch"" into an aimless jumble.  Along with the similarly too-free-spirited ""Windsurfing Nation"" and ""Handjobs for the Holidays""
column36:
such unchecked exorbitance damages the album's hard-won continuity.

But a few regrettable overreachings are somewhat inevitable when a band tries to top a record as strong as YFIIP. Looser and slightly kinkier
column37: Broken Social Scene indulges in the pop eccentricities and keen melodic ears of more than a dozen Canadians who take willful pride in their ability to lock together into one solid unit and make good on the sum of their unique individual talents. With its doomsday provocation of a title
column38: the epic Springsteenian endcap ""It's All Gonna Break"" bursts forth with enough ideas to keep a lesser band productive for years. The song ecstatically encapsulates Broken Social Scene's heightened ambitions and flawed Icarus journeys
column40:
brash love-in infatuated with its own bumps and bruises.

column2: lo-fi aesthetic
column3: organic
column4: unadorned instrumentation
column5: and the usual surfeit of opaque first-person narration. Even its premise-- Microphones/Mount Eerie oldies recast in ""sing-along"" versions-- promises business as usual. But ""Singers"" succeeds
column6: for one

column8: bleeding microphones. On ""Singers""

column7: but
column8: gussied up with a tidy instrumental and enough team spirit to power Mt. Eerie to a Great Outdoor Games medal
column9: its seldom been as sharp as on ""I Can't Believe You Actually Died""

Jackson Fourgeaud doesn't write songs. He builds ridiculously elaborate toys that run on their own silicon-plated gears. Perhaps he starts with something very small
column2: takes it apart

column11: and even then
column12: they'd probably end up in a closet with the junior chemistry set and last year's iPod model. There are a lot of people who will tell you that these kinds of toys are pointless because of their exclusivity and built-in obsolescence. I'd agree that the shelf life of your average glitch-core
column13: robo-pop CD is distressingly short

column11: in the years since the song's first appearance

column1: The new single ""Rock On"" is an admirable stab at straightforward dance-oriented pop
column2: perhaps the nerdy cousin of Daft Punk's ""Robot Rock""
column3: but trades any melodic momentum for an almost constantly shifting rhythmic base. Snares turn into handclaps

column4: heavily reverbed falsetto

column14:
this is pop: I can put up with haters telling me you can't dance to this stuff as long as Jackson keeps things interesting.

Can you resist a girl who calls you a bum before offering to knit you mittens and make you pie? Who sings like a Pound Puppy while agreeing to push your bail bonds when cash was tight? column3: all-natural
column4: and bursting the seams"" keester on it?

column2: which also went top 10 over     here in that late-90s moment when anything with a fake r&b; beat and a     sunshine attitude charted as a welcome relief from
column3: like
column4: the Toadies and stuff. She's disappeared from our radar for the past eight years-- as Euro pop stars tend to do-- but Robyn is as stupidly ebullient as any record released this year. ""You wanna rumble in my jungle?/ I'll take you on/ You wanna rumble in space/ I'll put my laser on stun/ And on the North Pole/ I'll ice you
column5: son."" Uh-oh!

column1: Over canned synbeats and zaps
column2: she struts her stuff
column3: castigating silly boys     who think they're playing in her weight class and generally acting like the     shit. ""Who's That Girl"" sez ""no
column4: no
column5: no"" like Destiny's Child to     institutionalized sexism-- or something. ""Handle Me"" tells bar star     douchebags with flipped polo shirt collars that she's too much.     Okay
column6: so ""Robot Boy"" is pretty much insufferable
column7: a swerve too sickly for     Radio Disney and kinda creepy when you factor in the songs about coming on     tongues. (Those nails she's sporting on the cover don't look designed for     wiping tears and mending broken hearts.) But ""Be Mine""
column8: which I blathered on     about in the tracks section a few weeks ago
column9: is a disarming     heartbreaker perfectly poised between twee and tuff
column10: like if Pete Wiggs and Bob Stanley and the Neptunes got trapped in Jeff Goldblum's Fly pods.

column2: but yr mileage may vary) with added early     Madonna quotes. ""Konichiwa Bitches"" suffers from a bad Dave Chappelle joke     title (not that it'll matter in 10 years)
column3: but redeemed by the fact that     it's 2:35 of boasting so compressed you'll rewind it three or four times in     a row. ""Bum Like You"" isn't a ballad
column4: really
column5: but it is slow and acoustic guitar driven. It's also nice to know that someone out there was willing to rewrite ""No Scrubs"" with a modicum of humanity granted to the scrubs in question.

column1: Robyn is already being called ""this year's Annie
column2: which is horseshit     because she actually emotes. And unlike the aforementioned Fannypack
column3:
she's got a range beyond ""ripping off L'Trimm."" Her pop fun is a bit knowing-- she's 26 after all. But trust the Swedes. They know what they're doing with this sort of thing. Plus it's all over in 35 minutes. If you think people should be fined for albums over 60 minutes-- is that ballad really worth it?-- you'll appreciate this.

column1: cultural and economic centers of Francophone West Africa

In fact

column2: and voices drift through. Both Amadou & Mariam sing (Chao's voice is

As pleasing as his voice is

column3: liquid skill.

And evidently this time apart allowed the two to approach their partnership rejuvenated and ready for some serious woodshedding

What happened to the Rosebuds?

I can't wait until they get divorced.

It's impossible to discuss Sheffield singer and songwriter Richard Hawley without a glance backward in the general direction of strong
column2: dignified vocalists like Roy Orbison
column3: Fred Neil
column4: and Johnny Cash. Hawley himself

column1: Coles Corner is Hawley's third full-length
column2: and it finds him further refining his sound. His voice is richer and the arrangements have an extra smidge of polish. The songs are remarkably clear and direct
column3: trading almost exclusively in familiar couplets that have become part of western pop currency. ""Hold back the night"" is the first line of the opening title track
column4: and the chorus begins ""Going downtown where there's music/ Going where voices fill the air."" It's rarely difficult to pick out the next line. Yes
column5: it's tears Hawley is talking about in ""Just Like the Rain"". The countrypolitan ballad ""Wait for Me"" seems plucked from another epoch: ""So think of me when you feel that moon
column6: Hawley croons
column7: ""oh it calls to me
column8: as it calls to you."" First time through you might want to stop and say
column9: Hold up
column10: there's still a moon? I thought it fell from the sky somewhere in the early 70s.

column1: Yes
column2: the moon is still up there
column3: and Coles Corner is unapologetically retro to the max but it works. Hawley's style
column4: his sturdy baritone singing songs that combine hints of country with pre-rock pop and orchestral flourishes overlaid with healthy dollop of reverb

column1: The closing piano instrumental ""Last Orders"" is a cover that nicely punctuates how and why Hawley got here. It's played on an upright with the sustain pedal to the floor inside an empty cavern of a room. As the tune progresses the echo around the piano mixes with a dusty cloud of Eno-esque electronic treatment

column3:
light-speckled drone of aching poignancy. It's then you realize that Hawley's music can go wherever he wants it to go. He's not stuck in the past. He inhabits his record collection because he likes it there and has a feeling we will too. He's right.

There was a time when artistic beauty wasn't regarded as a matter of intuitive personal vision or a relative standard buttressing the values of the elite class. Before the Enlightenment freed beauty from the dim hedge-maze of superstition and ushered it into the pure light of empiricism; before aesthetics became a valid mode of philosophical inquiry that favored beauty's mundane qualities over its divine ones; before post-structuralism wrought violence on binary values; an object's beauty was inextricably linked to its internal harmony of structure and function and its external harmony with the natural world. In other words
column2: anything beautiful had to mirror divine creation
column3: not subjective human values.

column1: Here in 2005
column2: beauty remains under siege-- it's the new boring; it's all tied into hidden power structures; it's hard to dance to and resists innovation-- yet the concept of beauty
column3: and our perception of it
column4: persists. No matter how abstracted and censured it becomes
column5: few would deny that
column6: say
column7: the oceans are beautiful. In a musical climate where beauty is often disregarded or located in asymmetrical euphony
column8: bands like Kepler are clinging to an older and more concrete conception of beauty-- one that hinges on order
column9: balance
column10: and tradition. Like its namesake
column11: the Canadian ex-slowcore (now just songcore) troupe arrays celestial happenings in elegant orbits
column12: making songs that fit perfectly into circles like Leonardo da Vinci's Vitruvian Man.

column1: If you replace ""slowcore"" with ""post-rock"" in Kepler's biography
column2: the band's trajectory is parallel with Karate's (if compressed): Attic Salt is analagous to Pockets in its basic sonics and its triumphant
column3: post-deconstructive lucidity. Here's ""Broken Bottles
column4: Blackened Hearts""
column5: a stately tide of lambent piano chords
column6: lush reverb
column7: and hushed cymbals ebbing and flowing below Samir Khan's tweedy (Jeff Tweedy
column8: that is) vocals. Here's ""The Bedside Manner""
column9: loping with the graceful yet muscular fluidity of a trotting horse. And here's ""Rented Limosine""
column10: with arpeggios refracting through lapidary percussion like light through a prism. Here's an album that locates its force in its artisanal skill
column11: not in its theoretical or innovative dimensions
column12: and if it's not a dying breed
column13: it's certainly an endangered one.

column1: This is not a call for art to return to Middle Age
column2: or even neo-classical
column3: values-- I place a high premium on art's capacity for innovation and social commentary. Rather
column4: it is a call for a reassessment of the value of beauty
column5: disabused of Judeo-Christian overtones but in full possession of its divine symmetry
column6: at a time when its cultural relevance is dwindling. To reject the beauty of order is to reject the natural world. At the end of the day
column7: Kepler's music is beautiful
column8: like the sea is beautiful
column9: and while we might not know exactly what this means
column10: to disregard it wholesale as a biased cultural construct is to throw out the baby and the bath. It is also a deep loss to another confounding yet lasting
column11:
embarassing abstraction: The human spirit.

column6: and on the album opener
column7: ""The Painter""
column8: he nods to old friends who are either long gone or still hanging around for another album. Several of the musicians on <i>Prairie Wind have played with Young many times before
column9: including keyboard player Spooner Oldham
column10: guitarist Ben Keith
column11: bassist Rick Rosas
column12: and Emmylou Harris. For such a seasoned band
column13: though
column14: they sound maybe a little too familiar: They tend to let the songs drag out
column15: clocking in at five
column16: six
column17: or even seven minutes (the tiring title track) when three would work just fine.

column1: Intermingled with these private memories are larger concerns about Bush-era America
column2: across which a cold prairie wind apparently blows. Yet Young's music is so rooted in the past
column3: specifically the spirit of the 60s
column4: that his stabs at contemporary relevance sound awkward and even curmudgeonly
column5: as on ""No Wonder"" when he refers to ""America the Beautiful"" as ""that song from 9/11"" and quotes Chris Rock. Prairie Wind tries to gauge the present via the past
column6: but there's a profound disconnect. But maybe Young is aware of it: ""I try to tell the people
column7: he sings on the title track
column8: ""But they never hear a word I say/ They say there's nothin' out there but wheat field anyway."" He sounds pretty frustrated
column9:
but Prairie Wind mostly is frustrating.
