column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/2082/homepage_large.736d23c0.jpg|Just Say Sire|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rhino'
column2:
'WEA']|2005-09-27 00:00:00||2016-06-11 20:53:58.365064|"

I can't honestly recommend that you drop $59 dollars on this box set
column3: but I can certainly advise that you damn the revisionist historians and love it in spirit. Because there's a fight going on-- a fight over who constituted the ""real"" alternative audience of the 1980s-- and I'm making it my responsibility to put you on the right side of the thing.

column1: To get a sense of the battle lines
column2: just listen to the Dead Milkmen's ""Instant Club Hit"" (1987)
column3: a fake dance track in which a band of American punk pranksters take their shots at goths
column4: ""art fags
column5: ""boring bisexuals
column6: and ""Danceateria types"": ""You'll dance to anything by the Smiths/ You'll dance to anything by Depeche Commode [sic]."" One of few things funnier than this song is the fact that the stuff inside it is still at issue. Poke around
column7: and you'll find plenty of people who'll tell you that the real
column8: important music of the 1980s came from bug-eyed Californian punks (like Black Flag)
column9: beer-friendly Midwestern rockers (like Hรผsker Dรผ)
column10: and D.C. hardcore kids (like Minor Threat); that major labels did nothing but ruin greedy bands (like the Replacements); that make-up
column11: synthesizers
column12: and the Milkmen's ""stupid Europeans with big hairdos"" didn't matter and/or exist; and that singer-songwriters
column13: ""rootsy"" music
column14: and adult pop were a million miles away.

column1: In the opposite camp
column2: you'll find clear-eyed realists with actual memories
column3: who'll happily admit that as of the mid-80s plenty of well-informed people really liked R.E.M. and Suzanne Vega.

column1: Both of these groups can be right
column2: in the end
column3: but notice how much the first of them relies on selective memory? Every time they talk about the ""real underground"" or nitpick about which bands were on truly independent labels
column4: what they're really doing is writing off those who genuinely liked 10
column5: 000 Maniacs or Echo & the Bunnymen-- the equivalent of someone
column6: 20 years from now
column7: pretending that this decade was all about Wolf Eyes and Lightning Bolt
column8: and nobody listened to Feist
column9: or Annie
column10: or Radiohead. Here's the truth: If you flipped on your local college radio station toward the close of the 80s
column11: chances are you'd hear all of this stuff
column12: jumbled together-- Milkmen and Minutemen
column13: Ministry and Morrissey
column14: plus Edie Brickell to boot. Arguing about which 80s breeds were important and which were merely incidental forgets the sheer variety of stuff that got thrown into the not-quite-mainstream fold.

column1: And what's bizarre is this: Even in our current climate
column2: where mp3 trading has supposedly made it so that everyone is pop-friendly
column3: fun-loving
column4: non-rockist
column5: and open-eared
column6: the Real Underground Music camp still seems to be winning this argument.

column1: Why this matters: Because Seymour Stein's Sire Records
column2: an imprint founded in 1966 and folded into Warner Bros a decade later
column3: was a pretty major source of the quirky
column4: often-accessible
column5: sometimes-popular ""college rock"" the Undergrounders are so keen on telling you they paid no attention to-- and this box collects three CDs and one video disc of the label's peak-era highlights. As a corrective to some people's critical histories
column6: it's a joy. Better still: If I were rating this collection based on the pure quality of the music it contains
column7: as opposed to a whole bunch of considerations about your time and your money
column8: it'd be up there in the eights.

column1: Sire's catalog spent most of its time straddling the lines of stylish
column2: accessible pop and acts just a little too different to push at the mainstream. Stein was attuned to New York City punk (Ramones
column3: Richard Hell)
column4: and even more so to its new-wave trajectory (Talking Heads
column5: Tom Tom Club
column6: Kid Creole). He picked winners from cross-Atlantic new wave (Rezillos
column7: Plastic Bertrand)
column8: and followed synth-pop from its grotty start (Telex
column9: the Normal) to its stupid-European-big-hair heyday (Erasure
column10: Pet Shop Boys
column11: Soft Cell). Across the length of the 80s
column12: Stein's Sire played the same role Geffen's DGC played for the 90s
column13: rounding up the popular
column14: accessible end of America's college-rock guitar bands (Dinosaur Jr
column15: the Replacements
column16: the Ocean Blue) and-- maybe more importantly-- licensing the rest from the UK (Cure
column17: Smiths
column18: and Bunnymen)
column19: to the point where the 1990 edition of their Just Say... samplers managed to import early tastes of My Bloody Valentine's ""Soon"" and Primal Scream's ""Higher Than the Sun"". And Sire also served as a home for adult
column20: mainstream-y pop acts whose sounds or personas scared everyone else off
column21: such as k.d. lang or Israeli icon Ofra Haza.

column1: What does this mean? It means that instead of the straight-line history of Important Underground Bands
column2: this box offers something that looks more like what some of your 1977-1993 analogs might really have been paying attention to. Like the Pretenders
column3: pop godfathers of the ""college"" audience. Like synth-pop
column4: or like 2-Tone-ish cuts from Madness and the English Beat. Like Wilco and Uncle Tupelo
column5: back when ""rootsy"" music was considered polite and adult and niche-marketed
column6: instead of being touted as progressive. Like fresh or just plain lovable pop singles: Seal's futurist ""Crazy""
column7: Modern English's ""I Melt with You""
column8: and the Cult's ""Fire Woman"" (or the Farm's ""Groovy Train
column9: more for nostalgia than quality). Like Brian Wilson and Lou Reed
column10: popular figures important to the ""underground"" in the same studied way they are today. Like the Rezillos' ""Top of the Pops""
column11: the most gleefully spiky new-punk single ever not-released by the Buzzcocks
column12: or Aztec Camera's ""Oblivious""
column13: the distilled core of the kind of pretty 1980s British guitar-pop your Black Flag fans would spit on. And
column14: this era marking the birth of the music video
column15: a full disc of those-- from M's ""Pop Muzik"" to the Replacements and Madonna to Belly and Aphex Twin.

column1: Now look: I don't necessarily fault the Undergrounders. All they're really trying to do is narrow their critical history down to talk about the ""important"" things that happened in the underground
column2: the things that really changed. They can leave it to pop writers to talk about synthesizers and ""traditional"" guitar bands-- and the slurs they'd have thrown at those types are certainly true for some of the acts here
column3: from the Mighty Lemon Drops to Martini Ranch. Maybe it really isn't so important to talk about a singer-songwriter like Suzanne Vega when people today will just pick up Keren Ann records doing the exact same thing. But in that process of narrowing everything down
column4: the first victim is
column5: well
column6: reality-- and any hope of talking seriously about the actual music culture of people who were probably a lot like you. Twenty years from now
column7: when someone's going on about the underground of the oughts
column8: some of you may need to step forward and let it be known: A lot of you really like the Arcade Fire
column9: too. A lot of you really like the Decemberists
column10: M.I.A.
column11: Devendra Banhart
column12: Madvillain
column13: Antony & the Johnsons
column14: the Fiery Furnaces
column15: Basement Jaxx
column16: and whatever other acts the future writes off as conventional or popular in the interest of its Grand Narrative of Music Going Forward. Their narrative may be ""right"" and ""important
column17: but yours will be ""true
column18:
and therefore probably ""more interesting.""

This Big Star really isn't Big Star. Sure
column2: it has two of the founding members
column3: Alex Chilton and Jody Stephens
column4: and it has two touring members
column5: Jonathan Auer and Ken Stringfellow of the Posies. Sure
column6: that's the same line-up that played on Big Star's last release
column7: Columbia: Live at Missouri University 4/25/93
column8: and that's the same line-up that's been touring on and off for years as Big Star. They've remained Big Star longer than any other of the other incarnations
column9:
but judging from the band's first album of new material-- the first bearing the name Big Star in nearly 30 years-- they sound more like the countless Big Star followers than Big Star.

Band names are essentially brand names
column10: especially in the case of Big Star
column11: which took its moniker from a regional chain of grocery stores. That choice proved ironic: Despite critical acclaim and best efforts
column12: the band never achieved any sort of stardom
column13: but instead gradually became cult kings. For a band like Big Star to release a new album of original material 30 years after what most believed was their last is a calculated risk: It's sure to get people's attention
column14:
but it also threatens to devalue the brand.

In Space isn't as terrible as internet chatter predicted. In fact
column15: it's not really bad at all
column16: even though it starts off aggressively mediocre. The opener ""Dony"" has Jim Spake's out-of-nowhere sax solo to enliven its midtempo pop
column17: but Auer and Stringfellow's ""Lady Sweet"" and Stephens' ""Best Chance We've Ever Had"" lack any such flourish. ""Turn My Back on the Sun"" starts with a Beach Boys fake-out-- a toy piano melody and the words ""Wouldn't it...""
column18: but ""be nice"" is replaced with ""surprise somebody to find."" That's the lyrical highlight of In Space. Most other songs are full of banal sentiments (""the sunlight in your hair seems to stop time"")
column19: hoary cliches (""Lady Sweet/ Looks like she can't be beat"")
column20: and simplistic rhyme schemes. The band sounds hesitant and maybe uncommitted
column21: and instead of conveying feelings
column22: these first songs reveal a lack of ideas
column23:
suggesting that Big Star don't have much to say.

It's not until ""Love Revolution"" that In Space begins to pick up a little. The song is so silly it's almost embarrassing-- a disco-lite anthem with shout-outs for all-night lovemaking and platform shoes. But at least it sounds like they're having fun. It kicks off a middle section that's a lively and energetic remedy to the songs that precede it. Stephens' ""February's Quiet"" is no revelation
column24: but it's a sweet ode to making it through the cold months with the one you love. ""A Whole New Thing""
column26: and their cover of the Olympics' ""Mine Exclusively"" bounce with a groove that recalls their former label's house band
column28: and the awkwardly charming ""Aria Largo"" sounds like the coolest wedding processional ever. But In Space ends on a dim note
column29:
with the mess that they've titled ""Makeover"". It's the inverse of ""Love Revolution""-- a self-impressed racket that's not even salvaged by its insistent bassline.

Still
column31: In Space is not much more than adequate power pop. It's hard to judge the album on its own terms and almost impossible to shake the fact that it would sound better with another band's name on the spine
column32: one that didn't invite hopeless comparisons to #1 Record
column35: In Space would be a decent Posies album
column36: and there's enough for a passable Chilton solo joint
column37: but as a Big Star release

Some of my favorite bands pull melody from miasma
column3: but Mommy and Daddy's melodies are miasmas
column4: hard brusque things that team up with their gritty backdrops. There is no faint glow seeping through clouds of cosmic dust
column5: no trapped heart pulsing beneath spiritless pummel; just two robo-kids who happen to know a few scales. So forget tenderness
column6: Mommy and Daddy have none. Each song on Duel at Dawn promises two things: a stupid-hard drumbeat and oversaturated synths. Such is the extent of its aesthetic breadth
column7: and Mommy and Daddy make no apologies for their insularity.

column1: Ignore the almost wholly synthetic sound matter and you get garage rock
column2: more or less. ""A Good Deal"" is a shuffle of arena-sized proportions
column3: all boom-bap drums and fuzzy one-line hook. It might be directly inspired by any number of Jock Jams staples. Same goes for ""Cops""
column4: which psyched me with a sibilant modified schaffel intro before taking the caveman stomp route. (Best part: dissonant
column5: half-step organ quarters-- Andrew W.K.
column6: meet your evil doppelganger.) ""Lost the Plot"" even calls in tambourine to accompany its growling bass-as-hook and standard-issue ""whoa-oh-oh""s.

column1: Mommy and Daddy seem hellbent on making fatuous
column2: subtlety-free music
column3: but sometimes they can't help it-- everyone needs a little sonic primping. Witness: the beats. These aren't graceless 808 belches
column4: but coordinated
column5: if simplistic
column6: rhythms comprised of carefully chosen sounds. 'Cause hey
column7: each violent throb has its proper snare timbre and cymbal decay. So
column8: while what I really want from a track like ""Way West Way""-- which has all the riffy makings of awesomeness-- is unchecked Keith Moon bombast
column9: I can appreciate the button-pressing technique.

column1: This variant of DIY electro-punk is the Miami booty bass of indie rock: music with sharp angles and dubious ambitions. But unlike booty bass
column2: which has a forum to release its glorious
column3: vapid
column4: think-with-your-pelvis energy
column5: Mommy and Daddy do not own any dancefloors. Their breed of dumb fun gets turned away at the door and rebottled as headachey tension. I'd love to say the lyrics bolster the sound
column6: but
column7: like the hooks
column8: they're subservient to the scuzz and sass
column9: more vibe than content. Really
column10:
it's sedative or bust: Spend the full two-thirds' hour in this rubber room of an album and you'll be overhyped and screaming to be let out.

column3: abrasive approximations of

column1: Sixth in Sixes may have sounded like a wall of hysterics at first

So
column2: then
column3: seven years later Domino reissues In the Aeroplane Over the Sea and the arguments can begin anew. I've talked about this album with a lot of people
column4: including Pitchfork readers and music writers
column5: and while it is loved in the indie world like few others
column6: a small but still significant number despise it. Aeroplane doesn't have the near-consensus of top-shelf 90s rock artifacts like
column7: say
column8: Loveless
column9: OK Computer
column10: or Slanted and Enchanted. These records are varied
column11: of course
column12:
different in many ways. But in one key respect Aeroplane stands apart: This album is not cool.

Shortly after the release of In the Aeroplane Over the Sea
column13: Puncture magazine had a cover story on Neutral Milk Hotel. In it Mangum told of the influence on the record of Anne Frank's The Diary of a Young Girl. He explained that shortly after releasing On Avery Island he read the book for the first time
column14: and found himself completely overwhelmed with sadness and grief. Back in 1998 this admission made my jaw drop. What the hell? A guy in a rock band saying he was emotionally devastated by a book everyone else in America read for a middle-school assignment? I felt embarrassed for him at first
column15: but then
column16: the more I thought about it and the more I heard the record
column17: I was awed. Mangum's honesty on this point
column18: translated directly to his music
column19:
turned out to be a source of great power.

In the Aeroplane Over the Sea is a personal album but not in the way you expect. It's not biography. It's a record of images
column20: associations
column21: and threads; no single word describes it so well as the beautiful and overused ""kaleidoscope."" It has the cracked logic of a dream
column22: beginning with ""King of Carrot Flowers Part 1"". The easiest song on the record to like on first listen
column23: it quietly introduces the listener to the to the album's world
column24: Mangum singing in a muted voice closer to where he left off with the more restrained On Avery Island (through most of Aeroplane he sounds like he's running out of time and struggling to get everything said). The first four words are so important: ""When you were young..."" Like every perceptive artist trafficking in memory
column25: Mangum knows dark surrealism to be the language of childhood. At a certain age the leap from kitchen utensils jammed into dad's shoulder to feet encircled by holy rattlesnakes is nothing. A cock of the head; a squint

column1: Inside this dream it all begins in the body. Moments of trauma
column2: joy
column3: shame-- here they're all experienced first as physical sensation. A flash of awkward intimacy is recalled as ""now how I remember you/ how I would push my fingers through your mouth/ to make those muscles move."" Sometimes I hear this line and chuckle. I think of Steve Martin in The Jerk
column4: licking Bernadette Peters' entire face as a sign of affection. Mangum here reflects the age when biological drives outpace the knowledge of what to do with them
column5: a time you're seeing sex in everything (""semen stains the mountaintops"") or that sex can be awkward and unintentionally painful (""fingers in the notches of your spine"" is not what one usually hopes for in the dark). Obsessed as it is with the textures of the flesh and the physical self as an emotional antenna
column6: listening to Aeroplane sometimes seems to involve more than just your ears.

column1: Then there's the record's disorienting relationship to time. The instrumentation seems plucked randomly from different years in the 20th century: singing saws
column2: Salvation Army horn arrangements
column3: banjo
column4: accordion
column5: pipes. Lyrical references to technology are hard to fix. Anne Frank's lifespan from 1929 to 1945 is perhaps the record's historical center
column6: but the perspective jumps back and forth over centuries
column7: with images and figures sucked from their own age and squirted out somewhere else. When ""The King of Carrot Flowers Part 3"" mentions ""a synthetic flying machine"" our minds leap to something like Leonardo da Vinci's 15th Century drawings of his helicopter prototype. The image in ""Two-Headed Boy"" of a mutant child trapped in a jar of formaldehyde is pulled from Dr. Moreau's industrial age island. The radio play powered by pre-electric pulleys and weights
column8: the nuclear holocaust in the title track. What's it all about? Mangum offers an explanation for these jarring leaps in a line about Anne Frank in ""Oh Comely
column9: where he sings
column10: ""I know they buried her body with others/ her sister and mother and 500 families/ and will she remember me 50 years later/ I wished I could save her in some sort of time machine."" If you can move through time
column11: see
column12: nothing ever really dies.

column1: Seven years it's been
column2: and whether Mangum has had personal trouble or somehow lost his way with music
column3: it's not unreasonable to think that we've heard the last from Neutral Milk Hotel. I hope he does
column4: but he may never pick up the guitar he set down after ""Two-Headed Boy Part Two."" Even so
column5: we have this album and another very good one
column6: and that to me is serious riches. Amazing to think how it started
column7: how at the core of it all was guts. I keep thinking of ""It's Alright Ma
column8: I'm Only Bleeding
column9:
and one of Dylan's truest lines: ""If my thought-dreams could be seen/ They'd probably put my head in a guillotine."" Aeroplane is what happens when you have that knowledge and still take the risk.

As evidenced by their explosive appearance on this year's epic The Tone of the Universe (= The Tone of the Earth) compilation
column3: Leeds-based quintet Vibracathedral Orchestra (VCO) have long since earned themselves a place of honor in the international avant-drone firmament. In parallel with such like-minded contemporaries as Birchville Cat Motel and Richard Youngs
column4: Vibracathedral have operated at their own unique nexus of Kraut-damaged rock
column5: turbulent pan-ethnic folk
column6: and Terry Riley/Tony Conrad-inspired minimalism. Before now
column7: however
column8: all of the group's copious output-- at least 17 full-length releases in various formats-- had been recorded live directly to two-track. But for Tuning to the Rooster
column9: VCO joined producer Richard Formby (Spaceman 3
column10: Spectrum) in a full 24-track studio
column11: an upgrade that has resulted in what is surely the group's most vibrantly detailed eruption to date.

column1: Centered since their formation in 1998 around the veteran axis of Julian Bradley
column2: Neil Campbell
column3: and Michael Flower-- and here joined by longtime regulars Adam Davenport and Bridget Hayden-- the group's work has always possessed the ornate density to justify the ""Orchestra"" designation despite their relatively small roll-call. Perhaps it's appropriate
column4: then
column5: that the four lengthy pieces gathered here can resemble the movements of an extended drone symphony
column6: one that is clearly best absorbed in its entirety. The album's adept symmetry and cohesion seems particularly noteworthy considering that each of these pieces has previously appeared elsewhere in the VCO discography in an alternate or abbreviated form.

column1: Shorter versions of the two opening tracks both originally appeared on VCO's 2002 split LP with Jackie-O Motherfucker. ""Baptism>Bar>Blues"" commences the album with the group already in mid-sunburst
column2: as their lacerating layers of violin
column3: guitar feedback and roiling percussion quickly reach prolonged crescendos that sound as if they've already been building for hours. Before long
column4: this view dissolves seamlessly into ""Wearing Clothes of Ash
column5: a 17-minute edifice of drone featuring placid ripples of piano that pierce through the ongoing sandstorm din like tiny shafts of starlight. On this track the higher resolution of the album's production is particularly effective; where on previous records Vibracathedral's individual instruments might all be consumed into one singular monochromatic blur
column6: here each jagged note is free to swirl past with microscopic
column7: technicolor clarity.

column1: Following next is the violin/harmonium/electronic stomp ""Stole Some Sentimental Jewelry""
column2: which conjures Cale-era VU improvising on a sabre-rattling Eastern European folk motif
column3: while ""Girls with Rocks in Their Hands"" encircles a ambient riff with a steadfast patience that suggests that Vibracathedral Orchestra might easily be capable of prolonging its repetitions indefinitely. And since Tuning to the Rooster cuts off with the group still arched in mid-swell
column4: when set on continuous play this finale can be joined almost imperceptibly back to the album's beginning to create a Mobius Strip-like listening experience
column5:
one whose mesmeric loops you'll be happy to uncoil for hours.

column1: A few tracks on Home for Orphans actually are covers. In addition to the steamrolling live cut of the Breakers' ""Don't Send Me Flowers I Ain't Dead Yet"" that closes the album
column2: a few of these songs originally appeared on the Reigning Sound's previous album
column3: the aptly titled <em>Too Much Guitar!
column4: which buried the lyrics and melodies under six feet of dirty
column5: frustrated guitars and asked listeners to excavate them over repeated listens. Home for Orphans digs them out
column6: dusts them off
column7: slows them down
column8: and puts the vocals back on top
column9: and only a little of their original vitality is lost. ""Medication Blues"" sheds its frenzy but gains a more legible humor as Cartwright admits
column10: ""It's not that I don't want to work/ It's just that I don't want to fill out all the applications."" And beneath the skuzzy fuzz
column11: both ""Love Is a Funny Thing"" and ""If You Can't Give Me Everything"" reveal sadsack odes to impossible love that match the ache in Cartwright's voice
column12: which remains one of the best in rock today.

column1: In toning down the guitars and slowing down the tempos
column2: the Reigning Sound have come full circle: Home for Orphans recalls the confident melodies and deceptively gentle sounds of their debut
column3: Break Up Break Down
column4: which was also released on Sympathy for the Record Industry. The band has stripped down its sound to the very basic elements: Cartwright's prickly guitar
column5: the Stax-tight rhythm section of Greg Roberson and Jeremy Scott
column6: and thrumming organ courtesy of Alex Greene
column7: who returns as a full band member. This set-up is of course an age-old combination
column8: but within these constraints
column9:
the Reigning Sound finds a little bit of freedom to make the old sound heartbreakingly new.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/1168/homepage_large.5bbe3f27.jpg|Lights Out|613.0|Nat Baldwin|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Broken Sparrow']|2005-09-25 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:54:07.558077|"

It may be the norm to pour out your feelings over an acoustic guitar
column2: but that's not enough for Nat Baldwin: He sings over a double-bass
column3: which he plays with raw
column4: lonely intensity. At its worst
column5: that bass evokes the beast that every scrawny
column6: neatly kempt one of us feels in our guts when our soon-to-be-ex refuses to answer the phone. Lights Out
column7: Baldwin's debut mini-album
column8: feels like one desparate night alone
column9: and if it were a minute longer it would be unbearable.

column1: A member of Newburyport
column2: Massachusetts' Tigersaw
column3: Baldwin regularly performs solo
column4: and although this record uses some overdubs
column5: it sounds live and intimate. Baldwin's croon-- a pure
column6: clear tone with a discomforting waver-- evokes Thom Yorke's anxiety or Andrew Bird's eerier solo performances
column7: and the album's ambience reminds me of Nina Nastasia's gothic Americana: Like Nastasia
column8: Baldwin turns in a chamber performance that butts against the void.

column1: On the eight songs that he penned for Lights Out
column2: Baldwin takes all-too-familiar impulses and stretches them to desparate conclusions. For example
column3: the rote ""don't leave me"" lyrics of ""Goodbye"" come out as a primal moan
column4: while his bow jolts against the strings like a highstrung heartbeat. Throughout the album
column5: he tries to keep his vocals on an even keel as if he's just an observer to the intensity that comes out of the bass-- like he can step back and ask if this is what it's like to become a stalker. That keeps up through almost the entire 20 minutes
column6: until the last song
column7: a spent ditty that basically just gives you a minute to breathe.

column1: Although this is technically an EP
column2: it feels complete
column3: and exhausting. In fact
column4: it makes me curious what Baldwin would do on a full-length record. Aside from a couple of guest singers
column5: he performs this one alone
column6: and it would be intriguing to see where he could go with a band-- or how he would sound across a wider emotional range. After all
column7:
he got through this album; what happens the next morning?

column1: <i>The
Fast Rise & Fall of the South is the band's fourth full-length. After flirting with heavier rhythms and a more overt
pop sound on 2003's Aztec Discipline

column3: understated sound of their first two LPs. Their sound is again subtle and stately
column4: full of the humid

column1: tension and electric tingle of a summer thunderstorm. It has something
of an affinity

column3: with early-70s Pink Floyd

column1: especially Obscured By Clouds and side 1 of Meddle. The record is stuffed
with two-part harmonies and country-lane textures-- banjos
column2: acoustic guitars

column1: and wood block percussion mix with piano
column2: mellotron
column3: and organ.

column1: The waltz has always been a formidable weapon in the hands of the Manx

column1: they outdo themselves on opener ""Harness and Wheel""
column2: with swaying pianos

column1: woozy harmonies
column2: and cyclical guitar picking. ""And What Fallout!"" follows

column1: with a 5/4 groove
column2: acoustic strings burbling on a bed of piano and drums and

column1: those sleepy harmonies leading the charge. Electric guitar freaks out low in
the mix
column2: setting the placid vibe ever-so-slightly off-balance. ""1000 8"" is

column1: insistent rhythm leaves the sly melody in your head for hours
column2: even after

column1: they assault the song's pastoralism with distortion that gives way to laser
synth on the fade-out. ""Ruins""
column2: meanwhile
column3: is nimble backroads pop with an

column1: opening drum fill that hints at zydeco.
Two late songs embody the band's weather affinity better than any others:
""Nova""
column2: which pours down a hailstorm of guitar of the bridge
column3: and ""Ol'

column2: there are

leading to a handful of tracks such as ""Greenland"" and the organ-and-voice plodder
""Zero G"" that feel
like filler. The mix fails to give proper weight to the vocals from time to
time
column2: as well

column2: never

ostentatious but sure to captivate.

The press release for Moistboyz's previous album
column2: III
column3: has a number of illuminating things to say about the band
column4: not least among them being
column5: ""The Moistboyz know this will offend the androgyny of the modern person
column6: and the young intellectual. The Moistboyz are holdouts in a nation of pussies and jerk-offs."" Since the Pitchfork readership is mainly comprised of modern androgynes
column7: young intellectuals
column8: pussies
column9: and jerk-offs
column10: it's safe to say that the only reason we're covering this record is because it's Dean Ween's cock-metal side project. And hey
column11: don't be offended by this characterization of the Pitchfork audience; take it as a compliment: Add ""Europeans"" and ""fags"" to these pejoratives and you've got a pretty exhaustive list of things that anti-intellectuals use as shorthand to describe anyone goin' around all usin' their brains and stuff.

column1: So on first glance you'd have to be either incredibly stupid or terminally ironic to like this record. There is a third option
column2: if those don't suit: There is a class of reasonably intelligent people that is attracted to all things willfully stupid and crude
column3: a stance that seems to stem from a misconstrued notion of the value of transgression and a reaction against the intellectual posturing of academics. This is the portion of the population entirely responsible for Team America DVD sales
column4: and Moistboyz IV is just one ""Fuck yeah!"" away from being its soundtrack. It sounds like the Hot Snakes trying to figure out whether they want to be Motรถrhead or the Scorpions
column5: which isn't so bad. It's the lyrics that really grate
column6: but if the slogans to be found on Urban Outfitters t-shirts are any indication
column7: willful stupidity is still cool
column8: so there's probably a market for it.

column1: Whether Moistboyz's gross-out schlock is earnest or satiric makes little difference: Either way
column2: grim doings are afoot. It starts out okay
column3: with three silly but entertaining anti-America screeds. ""I Don't Give a Fuck Where the Eagle Flies""
column4: is pretty funny
column5: and it's a damn sight better than the jingoistic John Ashcroft anthem it ripostes. ""Uncle Sam and Me"" celebrates the illusory power of rock in the face of fascism
column6: with its snarled chorus of ""Don't take my rock and roll/ Because it's all I am"" offsetting its straightforwardly anti-patriotic verses. But by the time ""Roy""
column7: the funny song about pedophilia rolls around
column8: with ""Everybody'd Fucked Her"" hot on its heels
column9: you start to miss Warrant
column10: who at least had the class to obscure their misogyny with pastry metaphors
column11: and Electric 6
column12: whose self-skewering shtick sounded more like an indictment of the ugly American than a self-satisfied
column13:
anti-intellectual glorification of it.

When Echo & the Bunnymen initially reunited in 1997
column3: they seemed to make a

column1: concerted effort to bring their old
column2: moody post-punk sound up to date with

column1: what was happening at the time. That year's Evergreen was a pretty decent
record
column2: but one that took a lot of cues from the Verve
column3: Oasis
column4: and Britpop's other masters of the big

column1: ballad. The 1999 follow-up <em>What Are You Going to Do With Your Life? was Bunnymen lite
column2: a band

column1: lost in the treacle of middle age
column2: but since then they've really been striving to turn back the clock

column1: if not all the way to the glory days of Porcupine and Heaven Up
Here
column2: then at least to ""Bring on the Dancing Horses"". 2001's <em>Flowers sounded

column1: like a tamer sequel to Ocean Rain
column2: and Siberia
column3: the fourth

column1: studio installment from the reconvened band
column2: sounds
column3: well
column4: like an even tamer

column1: sequel.
The band is now down to a sunglasses-in-the-dark duo of Ian McCulloch and
Will Sergeant with hired guns to stand in for Les Pattinson and the late Pete
de Freitas. Simon Finley and Peter Wilkinson do a dead-on impression
of their forebears in concert
column2: but these

column1: McCulloch/Sergeant compositions-- unlike the bulk of Echo's early work-- don't offer the rhythm section much to do. Wilkinson does throw down a pumping
column2: Pattinson-style bass line on ""Parthenon

column1: Drive""
column2: but that's the only real flash of rhythmic brilliance

column1: we're offered. It's no coincidence that it's also the most impressive song
on the album-- the great bass part gives Sergeant his most interesting
jumping-off point for his squirming lead guitar lines.
Much more typical is ""All Because of You Days""
column2: a mid-tempo slice of

column1: brood-rock slathered in Sergeant's pyrotechnics
column2: and McCulloch's baritone

column1: which he uses in a far more hushed fashion these days than he used to when
he was wailing away on ""Rescue"" and ""The Cutter"". If McCulloch now sounds
conspicuously like someone's dad it's probably because
he is
column2: and even if when dipping back into the well

column1: of dark psych
column2: the age and weariness displayed on <i>What Are You Going to

column1: Do... is still very much in evidence.
In fact
column2: for all the noisemaking that goes on in between
column3: the album is

column1: bookended by a pair of songs that look back only lyrically
column2: preferring a

column1: gentler musical approach. Opener ""Stormy Weather"" is a jangling piece of pop
that largely eschews the guitar squalls suggested by its title
while closer ""What If We Are"" is the big piano ballad. ""Maybe I'm not the
boy/ Maybe I'm not the man/ But what if I am/ What if I am/ Then it's love
column2: yes

column1: it's love/ Like it should be..."" it goes on like that
column2: and it's frankly one

column1: of the most boring songs the band has ever done
column2: too stuck in the middle of

column1: the road to have the world-moving impact it seems to aspire to.
If nothing else
column2: Siberia proves McCulloch and Sergeant still have their

column1: songwriting craft in good working order
column2: but it's hard to recommend an album

column1: on strength of craft alone-- it has to have a little verve
column2: and unfortunately it's lacking. In the end
column3: the band's retreat to

column1:
the 80s falters because they can't find their way back.

Here are some things about Run-DMC that you might already know: They were the first rap group to go gold
column2: platinum
column3: and multi-platinum
column4: to perform on     American Bandstand
column5: to appear on the cover of Rolling Stone
column6: to land in     rotation on MTV
column7: to endorse a sneaker
column8: and to tour the country. Here's what that impressive list of accomplishments tells you about the group's music: just about nothing.

column1: It's hard to hear Run-DMC's music as music in 2005. For 20 years
column2: their     singles have been dorm-room staples like Hendrix and Marley; they danced     with Steven Tyler on a hundred VH-1 video countdowns
column3: their     fedora-clad images have fossilized into pop consciousness. The group hasn't     been relevant to rap in nearly 20 years; most of the music played on     urban stations' old-school mixes comes from years after the group's peak.     More importantly
column4: the group spent the twilight of its career making     embarrassing career move after embarrassing career move: performing at the     VMAs with Kid Rock
column5: endorsing Virgin Cola
column6: releasing the god-awful 2001 failed-comeback album Crown Royal (featuring collaborations with douchebags like Fred Durst and the guy from Third Eye Blind)
column7: and performing at every college in the country again and again and again even though DMC's voice was clearly gone and Run had to help him with all his lines.

column1: Now that the group's first four albums are being reissued
column2: it makes sense to     ask whether they're worth buying
column3: especially since multiple     hits collections have already compiled their essential singles. The simple answer is no. Every one of these studio albums     has filler
column4: especially now that they've been loaded down with bonus tracks
column5: and the excellent compilation <i>Together Forever is still available at finer     used record stores nationwide. But Run-DMC remains probably the most     important group in rap history
column6: and its albums deserve careful scrutiny
column7: as historical documents and sometimes as more.

column1: The group's self-titled debut album
column2: released in 1984
column3: remains its most     powerful and immediate studio record
column4: the LP that forever tore rap away     from disco and made it its own thing. Famously
column5: the album's production     removed all the glossy live-band funk popular on the rap records of the day     and replaced it with a harsh
column6: spacey stripped-down electronic boom. Album     opener ""Hard Times"" is a good case in point: Producer Larry Smith lays down     a spooky
column7: chilly electro beat
column8: nothing but a few drum-machine ticks and     claps
column9: some heavy breathing
column10: a couple of synth stabs. Run and DMC toss lines     back and forth in a tag-team style that never really caught on
column11: yelling     rather than flowing
column12: building up to the end of the verse where they're both     yelling in tandem. Lyrically
column13: it's nothing special; their street reportage     is just another take on their first single ""It's Like That""
column14: which is itself a vanilla version of Melle Mel's rap on ""The Message"".

column1: But musically
column2: it's     spare and hard and densely compelling
column3: and it probably sounded terrifying in     1984. The rest of the album sounds pretty much like this
column4: hard empty beats     with yelled old-school catchphrase-slinging rapping
column5: and it's a strong and     forceful time capsule from an era when rap's hardness came from its sound     rather than its lyrics or its' practitioners' biographies. The only real     misstep is ""Rock Box""
column6: a track that buries a decent banger under layers of     unbearable hair-metal guitar wheedling. The amazing early live track ""Here     We Go (Live at the Funhouse)""
column7: included on the reissue
column8: proves that Run-DMC     were actually better rappers onstage than they were in the studio
column9: but then that track is already on Together Forever
column10: as are five of the original     album's nine tracks. So <i>Run-DMC is pretty great
column11: but you probably don't need to own it.

column1: King of Rock takes ""Rock Box"" as its starting-off point
column2: adding a whole     lot of heavy rock guitars to the group's musical palette. The new approach     endeared the group to suburban America
column3: but it meant that they'd never again     capture the dystopian heaviness of their debut. Fortunately
column4: they improve on     the precedent of ""Rock Box""
column5: finding more effective ways to throw rock into     the mix. The title track rests on a huge
column6: stomping AC/DC riff
column7: and the two     rappers sound pretty amazing yelling over it. ""Can You Rock It Like This""
column8: with its 80s synth and glossy oriental plinks
column9: could be a Duran     Duran song until the rapping starts. This is effective stuff
column10: but it lacks     the sonic oneness of the debut and thus carries an exponentially lesser     impact. The rapping hasn't gotten much better; they say it's ""never ever old     school"" before biting Melle Mel again on the token social-message track.     Today
column11: their lyrics sound archaic to the point ridiculousness (""You're a     funny-looking slop eating shish kabob/ You're the reason that my eyes are     on the doorknob
column12: ""Why don't you find a short pier and take a long walk?"").     ""Roots
column13: Rap
column14: Reggae"" is a truly shitty and forced collaboration with     Yellowman
column15: and it captures absolutely none of what makes rap or dancehall     great. The album offers little more than the still-thrilling     rapping-over-guitars charge of the title track
column16: but again: greatest hits.

column1: Raising Hell is generally considered to be the group's all-time classic
column2: and it certainly has its share of classic moments. Rick Rubin had by this     point taken over production from Larry Smith
column3: and he kept the group's     thunderous stomp while adding a host of sly sampled musical touches:     unbelievably funky bells on ""Peter Piper""
column4: a great cartoonish piano line on     ""You Be Illin'""
column5: a dirty Southern-rock guitar riff on the title track. Run     and DMC had also stepped their rap game up; ""It's Tricky"" is basically as     good as the two of them ever got
column6: spitting quick-tongue witticisms and     yelling booming threats with equal abandon. The album
column7: however
column8: has a ton of filler: the goofy     human-beatbox jam ""Hit It Run""
column9: the ridiculously tossed-off dis ""Dumb Girl""
column10: the utterly blatant Slick Rick bite ""Perfection"". And ""Walk This Way"". ""Walk     This Way"" totally fucking sucks
column11: a weak and half-baked novelty-rap jam which got them (and Aerosmith) all over MTV but which sounds no better for having anticipated the commercial possibilities of rap-rock.

column1: That record was the group's commercial apex (it went triple platinum)
column2: but     the band took too much time off after its release
column3: spending a couple of     years making a shitty movie and losing a court battle against its record     label. During those couple of years
column4: the landscape of rap changed     completely; 1988 was the genre's quote-unquote Golden Age
column5: and Run-DMC     looked like relics next to young
column6: more skilled rappers like Rakim and Big Daddy Kane and hungrier crews like Public Enemy and NWA. Tougher Than Leather found the group playing catch-up
column7: enlisting a new producer in Davy D and rapping on the Marley Marl-ish breakbeats popular at the time rather than the booming drum machines that they'd always used.

column1: On tracks like ""They Call Us Run-DMC"" and ""Radio Station""
column2: they sound confused and out-of-touch
column3: kicking old-school applause lines over anemic drum breaks. They also revert     to formula a few too many times
column4: coming with tracks that essentially amount     to sequels of previous hits: adding weird parental angst to the honking     goofball punchlines of ""You Be Illin'"" on ""Papa Crazy""
column5: awkwardly attempting     to shoehorn breakbeats onto a ""King of Rock""-style banger on ""Soul to Rock     and Roll""
column6: biting Slick Rick again on ""Ragtime"". But parts of Tougher Than Leather are just great
column7: especially ""Beats to the Rhyme""
column8: which found Run and DMC quick-tongue rapping in tandem over an amazing state-of-the-art busy breakbeat with awesome sonar pings like Timbaland would use 10 years later. Tougher Than Leather is a failure
column9: but it's a noble one. The reissue     includes ""Christmas in Hollis""
column10: maybe the first time they would allow     themselves to become cartoon characters
column11: kicking it with Santa
column12: DMC chilling and cooling just like a snowman in a line that seems touchingly naรฏve in the Jeezy era.

column1: And that's it. Nobody is going to be reissuing the group's 1990 album Back From Hell anytime soon
column2: and the group became an old-school signifier
column3: someone for rappers to quote or reference but never hire for features or     anything. The group was essentially irrelevant only five years after     releasing its first single-- to put that in perspective
column4: Bow Wow has     been popular for a longer time. The group was hugely important in changing rap and making it an industry force
column5: but you can't really say they had much influence on the way it sounds today. They removed the flash and gloss of the disco-rap of the Sugar Hill label
column6: and they influenced a young LL Cool J
column7: who influenced Boogie Down     Productions and Eric B & Rakim
column8: who influenced the Juice Crew and Public     Enemy and NWA
column9: and on and on and on
column10: as rap would undergo sea change after     sea change. By the late 90s
column11: much of the music was flashier and glossier     than it ever had been in the Sugar Hill era
column12: and any changes that Run-DMC     made were changed themselves to the point of being unrecognizable. And so     what we have now are four historical documents
column13: each with at least a handful of thrilling moments. And most of those thrilling moments are on Together Forever or other singles compilations
column14: so unless you're a historian or a rich person
column15:
save your money.

column15: and it captures absolutely none of what makes rap or dancehall     great. The album offers little more than the still-thrilling     rapping-over-guitars charge of the title track

column1: Raising Hell is generally considered to be the group's all-time classic

column3: and he kept the group's     thunderous stomp while adding a host of sly sampled musical touches:     unbelievably funky bells on ""Peter Piper""
column4: a great cartoonish piano line on     ""You Be Illin'""
column5: a dirty Southern-rock guitar riff on the title track. Run     and DMC had also stepped their rap game up; ""It's Tricky"" is basically as     good as the two of them ever got
column6: spitting quick-tongue witticisms and     yelling booming threats with equal abandon. The album
column7: however

column9: the ridiculously tossed-off dis ""Dumb Girl""
column10: the utterly blatant Slick Rick bite ""Perfection"". And ""Walk This Way"". ""Walk     This Way"" totally fucking sucks
column11: a weak and half-baked novelty-rap jam which got them (and Aerosmith) all over MTV but which sounds no better for having anticipated the commercial possibilities of rap-rock.

column1: That record was the group's commercial apex (it went triple platinum)
column2: but     the band took too much time off after its release
column3: spending a couple of     years making a shitty movie and losing a court battle against its record     label. During those couple of years
column4: the landscape of rap changed     completely; 1988 was the genre's quote-unquote Golden Age
column5: and Run-DMC     looked like relics next to young
column6: more skilled rappers like Rakim and Big Daddy Kane and hungrier crews like Public Enemy and NWA. Tougher Than Leather found the group playing catch-up
column7: enlisting a new producer in Davy D and rapping on the Marley Marl-ish breakbeats popular at the time rather than the booming drum machines that they'd always used.

column1: On tracks like ""They Call Us Run-DMC"" and ""Radio Station""
column2: they sound confused and out-of-touch

column4: coming with tracks that essentially amount     to sequels of previous hits: adding weird parental angst to the honking     goofball punchlines of ""You Be Illin'"" on ""Papa Crazy""
column5: awkwardly attempting     to shoehorn breakbeats onto a ""King of Rock""-style banger on ""Soul to Rock     and Roll""
column6: biting Slick Rick again on ""Ragtime"". But parts of Tougher Than Leather are just great
column7: especially ""Beats to the Rhyme""
column8: which found Run and DMC quick-tongue rapping in tandem over an amazing state-of-the-art busy breakbeat with awesome sonar pings like Timbaland would use 10 years later. Tougher Than Leather is a failure

column10: maybe the first time they would allow     themselves to become cartoon characters
column11: kicking it with Santa
column12: DMC chilling and cooling just like a snowman in a line that seems touchingly naรฏve in the Jeezy era.

column4: Bow Wow has     been popular for a longer time. The group was hugely important in changing rap and making it an industry force
column5: but you can't really say they had much influence on the way it sounds today. They removed the flash and gloss of the disco-rap of the Sugar Hill label
column6: and they influenced a young LL Cool J
column7: who influenced Boogie Down     Productions and Eric B & Rakim
column8: who influenced the Juice Crew and Public     Enemy and NWA

column10: as rap would undergo sea change after     sea change. By the late 90s
column11: much of the music was flashier and glossier     than it ever had been in the Sugar Hill era

save your money.

Here are some things about Run-DMC that you might already know: They were the first rap group to go gold
column2: platinum
column3: and multi-platinum
column4: to perform on     American Bandstand
column5: to appear on the cover of Rolling Stone
column6: to land in     rotation on MTV
column7: to endorse a sneaker
column8: and to tour the country. Here's what that impressive list of accomplishments tells you about the group's music: just about nothing.

column1: It's hard to hear Run-DMC's music as music in 2005. For 20 years
column2: their     singles have been dorm-room staples like Hendrix and Marley; they danced     with Steven Tyler on a hundred VH-1 video countdowns
column3: their     fedora-clad images have fossilized into pop consciousness. The group hasn't     been relevant to rap in nearly 20 years; most of the music played on     urban stations' old-school mixes comes from years after the group's peak.     More importantly
column4: the group spent the twilight of its career making     embarrassing career move after embarrassing career move: performing at the     VMAs with Kid Rock
column5: endorsing Virgin Cola
column6: releasing the god-awful 2001 failed-comeback album Crown Royal (featuring collaborations with douchebags like Fred Durst and the guy from Third Eye Blind)
column7: and performing at every college in the country again and again and again even though DMC's voice was clearly gone and Run had to help him with all his lines.

column1: Now that the group's first four albums are being reissued
column2: it makes sense to     ask whether they're worth buying
column3: especially since multiple     hits collections have already compiled their essential singles. The simple answer is no. Every one of these studio albums     has filler

column5: and the excellent compilation <i>Together Forever is still available at finer     used record stores nationwide. But Run-DMC remains probably the most     important group in rap history
column6: and its albums deserve careful scrutiny

These days the once great divide between musical
genres is little more than a crack. There was a time when punk
column2: hardcore
column3: metal

column1: the 80s

column3: the members of

column1: each scene treated theirs like a religion
column2: and relating to
column3: borrowing

column1: from or
column2: frankly
column3: enjoying any of the others were surefire ways to be subjected to ridicule and scorn. But as the years went on

column1: new bands that sought to revitalize their genre found themselves
blending styles. Punk and hardcore bands got faster and heavier until
they were sidled right up against thrash and metal acts
column2: who in turn

column1: were often turning to the classic rock of the past for renewed
inspiration. By the late-90s
column2: it had become commonplace to find

It seems unlikely
column2: then

column1: any time other than their own. Had they released Swords 20
years ago

column2: wondering why the

column1: time signature changed so much and where the guitar solos were
respectively. Lords' blitzkrieg approach-- this disc crams 13

In 2002
column2: the nomadic Montreal electronic arts collective Champ Libre enlisted maverick composer Francisco Lรณpez as musical curator for its multimedia ""Citรฉ des Ondes"" event. For the occasion Lรณpez assembled a formidable international roster of experimental sound artists that included such disparate talents as Japanese noise mainstay Merzbow
column3: Australian avant-garde guitarist Oren Ambarchi
column4: and Portland
column5: Ore.-based sound sculptor Daniel Menche. Now Lรณpez has edited and mixed Blank Field

column7: the collection proves to be a remarkable

column1: Performed and recorded live at Montreal's Craig pumping station-- a structure built in 1887 to help control the floodwaters of the St. Lawrence River-- this music was created as just one aspect of a program that also showcased various electronic
column2: architectural
column3: and video art installations. In his own work
column4: Lรณpez has advocated an immersive listening environment

column3: gently plucked guitar tones that compares favorably to some of Loren Connor's most lyrical solo work. From there it's a rather abrupt segue into the digital anthill of Japan's Shunichiro Okada
column4: who presents an itchy
column5: beatless series of scrapes and buzzes with little regard for listener comfort.

column3: especially if you've still got your speakers cranked from trying to hear the Northam track. Though predictably noisy
column4: Merzbow's contribution is actually a reasonably tempered affair
column5: its grainy
column6: unsettled lurch providing one of the collection's only instances of discernable rhythm. And Menche furnishes the album a fittingly radical capper with his droning symphonic swells and amplified organic contortions. Throughout it all

The common threads are Jรณhannsson's airy use of space and the fundamental simplicity with which he approaches melody and arrangement. column3: ""Changes""

column6: not a collection of virtuoso day laborers supplicating at the feet of the Artiste.

column1: For one thing
column2: the singing remains gloriously     unsweetened
column3: not by studio overdubs for the original     release nor by digital trickery-- save a spit polish of the highs and fattening of     the lows-- this time. Bowie's is not exactly a golden     throat
column4: but by the mid-70s he could will his     untrained voice into a soulful squeal
column5: a come-hither     lounge croon
column6: and so on; he misses some notes but never the     dramatic pitch of the line. He also used to be one of those singers who need half a set to get     entirely comfortable on stage
column7: and
column8: as a result
column9: Disc Two of both David Live and Stage is the stronger one by far. If by the beginning of each concert
column10: Bowie simply performs the songs
column11: by the end he is twisting them into entirely new creatures. David Live contains arguably the all-time greatest display of Bowie's voice as he lets loose on an r&b; version of ""Rock'n'Roll Suicide""
column12: festooned with James Brownian stops
column13: croaks
column14: pregnant     pauses
column15: and beat-chasing rephrasings
column16: as well as a     completely sudden detonation of a very
column17: very high falsetto.

column1: Both albums start
column2: predictably
column3: with some selections from albums Bowie was promoting at the time-- Diamond Dogs and Heroes
column4: respectively
column5: before launching into a great big chunk of Ziggy Stardust. Interestingly enough
column6: there are no     overlaps here (name another '70s rock act that     produced two 22-song concert sets in four years     without repeating a single number)
column7: but an almost-complete live version of Ziggy can be put together by combining the two
column8: if desired. In the     battle of the openers
column9: Stage wins-- the damp gloom of ""Warszawa"" easily trumps the glam doom of ""1984"".

column1: David Live is a more genial album
column2: as its title indicates. It's loaded with Diamond Dogs material-- nobody's favorite Bowie album-- but works hard to ingratiate itself: there's ""Space Oddity""
column3: ""Changes""
column4: ""Jean Genie""
column5: ""All The Young Dudes"". What a difference four years and a move to Berlin make: David of Stage doesn't appear to be the least bit concerned with what you'll think of it
column6: or him. Recorded between Low and Lodger-- in the odd period that found the singer at his gauntest and most ashen-faced
column7: listlessly flirting with Aryan imagery and ignoring the verse-chorus song form-- Stage is a challenging and idiosyncratic set. Some of the risks don't quite pay off: The cover of ""Alabama Song"" is just a bad idea through and through
column8: its original Weillness matted with Jim Morrisson's greasy fingerprints. And some do-- the colossal trifecta of Station To Station's eponymous track
column9: ""Stay"" and ""TVC 15""     comprise a powerful (and punishing) 20-minute     concert-closing gambit. It's just like Bowie
column10: of     course
column11:
to make two mutually exclusive modes of engaging the arena-- as a party palace and as a horror-movie science lab-- fit together in a remarkably cohesive whole.

column1: Yep

column5: programmed drums bend Mazarin's sun-kissed guitar pop toward the Postal Service side of things

column1: For real

column1: If there's a proverbial elephant in the room

column3: and we all know that an elephant never forgets. So while Mazarin might be too late to break bread with like-minded retro-popists from the future like Apples in Stereo and Neutral Milk Hotel

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/1569/homepage_large.610cf7d5.jpg|Bryant Park Moratorium Rally (1969)|816.0|Tony Conrad|['Rock'
column3: experimental composer and artist Tony Conrad was living in midtown Manhattan
column4: just down 42nd street from Bryant Park. On October 15 of that year a rally was held in the park as part of the nationwide Moratorium protest against the Vietnam War
column5: and Conrad
column6: in a moment of inspired wit
column7: began rolling audio tape in his loft. Directing one microphone out the window towards the rally
column8: and another towards a television broadcasting live coverage of the event
column9: Conrad was able to create this strange
column10: often fascinating document by combining these parallel currents of media and reality.

column1: Containing a single
column2: uninterrupted 50-minute chronicle of the day's events
column3: Bryant Park Moratorium Rally bears more relation to Conrad's subsequent career as a video artist and media scholar (and SUNY-Buffalo professor) than to his work as a musician. Although the piece-- despite a constant barrage of car horns
column4: police sirens and generalized crowd noise-- does reveal a certain hushed beauty in its steady
column5: muffled tide of amassed human activity
column6: this slice of audio veritรฉ could only be classified as music by the most indiscriminate avant-garde definition.

column1: On its most immediate level
column2: the piece functions as an entertaining
column3: occasionally instructive
column4: cultural time capsule. Considering the circumstances and stakes
column5: the rally itself often proves to be a markedly congenial affair. In addition to eloquent anti-war speeches from the likes of Eugene McCarthy and the Rev. William Sloan Coffin
column6: the program also featured the rather inconsequential presence of a stageful of Broadway actors (""Miss Helen Hayes...Eli Wallach...Ben Gazzara!"") Meanwhile
column7: the TV coverage includes brief interviews with such notables as Dick Cavett (interviewer: ""Do you believe in this Moratorium day program?"" Cavett: ""I think it's kind of been poorly defined what it's about."") and Woody Allen (""I think it's obviously proved already that it is working
column8: has already worked
column9: and will work even more as the next few days go by."")

column1: As illustrated by these various speeches and live interviews
column2: one the most remarkable things about these recordings is the fact that the audio from the TV broadcast reaches Conrad's microphones sooner (and considerably more intelligibly) than the actual sounds produced outside his window. This delay not only creates a disorienting split between the album's dual channels
column3: but also raises the rather uncomfortable notion that
column4: at least from Conrad's vantage point
column5: the Moratorium rally could be argued to have been more effectual as a media event than as a live one. Of course
column6: the effects of this captured TV footage are amplified by the astonishing concentration of the newscast's live coverage
column7: which consists of the type of continuous
column8: uncut feed that is now essentially extinct-- outside of the odd C-SPAN broadcast-- in our current age of the 10-second sound byte.

column1: Far murkier
column2: however
column3: is the impact of Bryant Park Moratorium Rally as a political instrument. Conrad originally made this recording available as a free mp3 on the eve of the U.S. invasion of Iraq in 2003
column4: but it's unclear what new insights this piece truly provides for today's listeners and/or activists. At a time when 24-hour news channels routinely feature on-air anchors sitting at their computers reading e-mails and blogs aloud
column5: the idea that the media filters and distorts our political reality surely seems a rather obvious one. And though this record does provide an engaging window through which we can witness a crucial sliver of our recent history
column6:
it's a portal that grows smaller and cloudier with each successive listen.

I downloaded a few house tracks the other day on the recommendation of one of the Euro shop/distributor sites (concise and efficiently presented
column3: of course)
column4: and noticed rampant usage of the word ""minimal"" as a positive qualifier. In this sect of music retail
column5: everything from minimal pop to ""minimal techno banger"" to ""functional minimalism"" is esteemed. I couldn't find any negative references of the word minimal
column6: and I wondered if
column7: in this environment
column8: it was possible to tag anything minimal and not simultaneously be giving it a compliment. Of course
column9: I read this at a merchant website
column10: so not finding much in the way of objective critique isn't surprising. Nevertheless
column11: I forged ahead.

column1: Next
column2: I googled Pitchfork's very own review archives for the word. Okay
column3: so the first thing I found was my review of a techno single
column4: so that doesn't count. The next one was Philip Shelburne's excellent ""The Month in Techno"" column from August
column5: wherein he asked
column6: ""Can we please stop calling Cologne techno 'minimal'?"" His point was that in the scheme of hip
column7: new techno
column8: a lot of what gets called minimal isn't actually all that minimal. Next
column9: I found Mark Richardson asking ""how minimal is too minimal?"" suggesting that there really is a limit to how much (or little) minimalism we can stand. Later
column10: he goes on to criticize the music as ""flat and one-dimensional""
column11: and thus provides a decent benchmark for this: When you get down to one dimension
column12: you've gone too far.

column1: The problem is that the ""less is more"" concept in music is trickier than it looks. On Excepter's Self Destruction
column2: I imagine some effort was made to quantize a sound that had theretofore been notable mostly because it seemed almost totally immune to imposed organization. The Brooklyn outfit
column3: headed by John Fell Ryan
column4: drifted spectrally through the same cosmic ether as neighbors Black Dice on occasion
column5: playing ""noise"" that dove headfirst into modernist (and post-modernist) arenas of mechanization and detachment-- from the rest of the noise-improv underground
column6: if from nowhere else-- even while it was psychedelic in the extreme. I would have had a hard time picking out minimalism in previous records KA and Throne
column7: and though I was interested from the moment I heard they'd made a ""house"" record
column8: I'm not sure I hear it here either.

column1: But then house isn't the same thing as minimalism
column2: though they share some ideas (like how to use repetition to best effect). Yet
column3: Self Destruction confuses me: If this is a house record
column4: where are the climaxes and releases? The gradual builds and subtle modulations? The beats?? As it happens
column5: there are beats to be found here
column6: but they're uniformly small
column7: brittle
column8: and possibly Casio-generated. Even then
column9: I'd like to give them credit for turning workaday house drama on its head with dry
column10: impersonal sounds
column11: but I think that rather than make a house record
column12: they've made a haphazardly minimal one. Rather than paint from a grid using colors from another world
column13: they've simply reduced the number of colors they use and painted freehand geometrical objects.

column1: To Excepter's credit
column2: Self Destruction is billed as a house record in name only
column3: apparently inspired more in spirit by the genre than in ""realized form"". That translates to a pretty liberal usage of
column4: well
column5: everything-- which has always seemed part of the Excepter M.O. ""Shoot Me First"" begins as electric sting synth and human barks at the moon
column6: occasionally punctuated by falling stars and electro-drum pads. As moaning voices are added and the disparate tones cut into each other for screen time
column7: the song shares much with past Excepter music. However
column8: there are subtle differences: The sound is cleaner (probably due to this album being the band's first to feature multi-track recording and mixing)
column9: there's a lot less reverb than usual
column10: and the general mood is less claustrophobic
column11: more bluntly dissonant. It's as if you took a wet-dry vac to one of Excepter's spongy pieces
column12: and sucked all the liquid out
column13: leaving just a dry
column14: porous mass.

column1: ""Bad Vibration"" is similarly anemic
column2: but uses a steady
column3: pulsating drum machine tambourine to keep things moving
column4: and a subterranean
column5: almost submerged bass line
column6: sounding as if blasted from an underwater cave. Ryan's lead vocal/tripping mumble is pretty out-in-front
column7: as Excepter songs go
column8: though is none the sturdier for it. Even surfing over the rhythmic ebb and flow
column9: it's still a pretty queasy ""melody
column10: though aided by the hazy
column11: brooding vibe of the track
column12: it imparts a whole range of confusion
column13: fatalism and solemn dementia. Likewise
column14: ""BB+B (For 2b/2c)"" uses a steady beat (midtempo and hip electro
column15: but rudimentary) and vocals to make ghostly dance music
column16: but here seems reigned in rather than reformed. It's not that the beats are bad
column17: per se; rather
column18: they're transparent
column19: as if the lo-fi instrumentation that went into the mixing board got the better of the house concept. The vocals again seem called in from another planet
column20: but aren't enough to keep me from falling through the holes in the architecture of the piece as a whole.

column1: Still
column2: when Self Destruction works
column3: it works well. ""Interplay: Lock Room"" and ""Interplay: Your House""-- surely the most bizarre husband-wife (Caitlin Cook and Calder Martin) duets ever-- features house-esque arrangement of 808 tambourine
column4: cowbell and handclaps
column5: alongside Cook's alto calls
column6: and even a recurring
column7: harmonized synth line that almost lulls me into the idea I'm listening to actual dance music. The end of ""Your House"" falls off the piece like water retreating from the beach
column8: back into the sea; the lone vocal evaporates and dark
column9: metallic synth sparkles dim out into nothing. If KA was meditations on chaos
column10: this is more nihilistic
column11: and accepting of the void. But I'm cool with that. Better to minimize the arrangement than the emotional truth
column12: regardless of where it takes you.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/4209/homepage_large.8d367bfa.jpg|Picks Us Apart|2194.0|The Jim Yoshii Pile-Up|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Absolutely Kosher']|2005-09-19 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:54:22.138329|"

The Jim Yoshii Pile-Up is a deceptively enticing name for a band specializing in schmaltzy gut-spilling over dadaist Death Cab arrangements. Then again
column2: when histrionics are your thing and you're inextricably linked to a drama queen extraodinaire such as Xiu Xiu's Jamie Stewart
column3: being upstaged is inevitable. Yet despite the perpetual malaise
column4: the Oakland five-piece has parlayed their nihilism into two impressive LPs.

column1: Since a 2003 joint EP with the indie tear-jerkers
column2: the Pile-Up's bleak sound is becoming too depressing to sustain itself
column3: and Picks Us Apart lopsidedly focuses on melancholia over music. Although formulaic
column4: these guys have their sterilized take on Sunny Day Real Estate down pat. Paul Gonzenbach's listless demeanor manifests itself in equally colorless guitars and austere basslines-- basically emo in its rawest form. To no one's surprise
column5: Ben Gibbard hails the band as his personal favorite
column6: though fortunately they haven't exchanged their challenging sound for teeny bop fawning like Death Cab's new crossover-tailored approach. Of course
column7: none of this instrumental stuff matters once Picks Us Apart starts rolling and Gonzenbach stoically sings along to a suicide note on ""A Toast to the Happy Couple"".

column1: In this opening track
column2: Gonzenbach exudes despair
column3: failure
column4: and indignation in one fell swoop. Before you can say ""Sounds like Pedro the Lion!""
column5: Gonzenbach drops the morbid line ""To my father...I leave a blood-stained mattress/ To my mother with her head to the wall/ I tried...but failed to do the simplest things that somehow mean the most."" After four more minutes of excruciating introspection
column6: the persona concludes his letter with one final ""fuck you"" to the world: ""You are all hereby formally indicted."" Not exactly the most riveting opener
column7: the song hangs like an albatross
column8: and the album never really recovers. ""Silver Sparkler"" sports a nifty bassline reminiscent of early-90s lo-fi
column9: though it repeats till exhaustion. Likewise
column10: ""Heart My Home"" shines as the lone ballad amidst an array of homogenous slow-rockers
column11: but sadly Gonzenbach fails to reproduce anything equally beautiful yet straightforward.

column1: Fortunately
column2: the Pile-Up's unwavering consistency does damage control for this suicide pact of an album. Some of the more sprawling numbers evoke early Interpol EPs as droning
column3: reverberating riffs are in no short supply. Still
column4: Gonzenbach's funeral party doesn't seem to do justice to its own gravitas. When Jamie Stewart screams about chopping his own head off
column5: he means business. In contrast
column6: Gonzenbach's deadpan delivery has the emotional directness of an embittered AOL conversation and the lasting appeal of MSN Instant Messenger
column7:
making these spotlighted vocals all the more puzzling on an otherwise solid album.

The Apes make a strange and sludgy stew without the help of guitars
column2: using the distorted low-end of bassist Erick Jackson and the mushroom-fed organs and moogs of Amanda Kleinman
column3: while Paul Weil wails like a snake-oil salesman and drummer Jeff Schid holds it all down. The bass and organ are great textures in themselves
column4: but Apes consistently pull it all together for a unique and surprisingly dense sound.

column1: With two albums and two EPs behind them
column2: the Apes don't change their approach much on Baba's Mountain
column3: but it is a more ambitious record
column4: folding new rhythms
column5: a few moments of calm
column6: and more than a few moments of manipulated vocal weirdness into their smirking psychedelia. It's a little less similar to heavyweights like Black Sabbath and more like Jesus Ape Superstar
column7: especially on the organ-driven tracks such as ""The Green Bus"" or the sunny ""Ornaments and Windchimes"". Ape Amanda is flexing her muscles more
column8: while Weil is along for the ride
column9: echoing the themes that Kleinman outlines and just as quickly discards.

column1: Apes match their ambition on ""Imp Ahh""
column2: the rhythm and melody shifting wildly while the band displays its usual swagger. Weil takes the reins on the melody and the chaos seems controlled when he's in command. Baba's Mountain still sounds more or less like Apes
column3: but this is a band full of percussion instruments-- change the rhythm too often
column4: you risk losing the listener. Songs that remain static
column5: like the strutting bass line and smarmy vocal tics on ""What We Do Best""
column6: leave a stronger impression.

column1: Without the band broadening their palette
column2: you wouldn't have songs like ""The Zookeeper's Night Out""
column3: where feral drumming and a cautious organ melody meet with a wall of face-melting fuzz bass
column4: and ""Imp Ahh"" or ""Can U Handle This"" would be half as stunning without their fluid structure. However
column5: Apes still sound best with their inimitable sound over a heavy
column6: steady groove. Put ""What We Do Best"" against any other track here
column7:
and see which one you remember.

Richard Swift sure sounds like a bedroom auteur. He penned all the songwriterly songs and wrote all the whimsical interludes on his first two mini-albums
column2: The Novelist and Walking Without Effort
column3: and handled engineering and artwork duties
column4: and played most of the instruments. He even self-released both of them before signing with Secretly Canadian
column5: which is collecting them as one release
column6: immodestly subtitled <i>The Richard Swift Collection
column7: Vol. 1. That canonical title heralds more to come
column8: and I wouldn't be surprised if he already has his next six albums written and recorded (in fact
column9: his next is planned for early 2006). Just to bring these two records into existence requires a forceful willpower and an unflagging self-confidence
column10: and for better or worse
column11: the two albums reflect a serious perfectionist streak.

column1: The Novelist is the more distinctive of the two: as the title suggests
column2: the album wears its concept on its sleeve
column3: even spelling it out on the title track: ""I try to write a book each time I speak."" As if to conjure visions of the cardigan-wearing artist toiling at his trusty typewriter
column4: Swift dolls up the songs in dapper pre-rock accessories that suggest a Roaring Twenties setting. ""Lady Day"" floats on a subdued samba and lofty vocals
column5: ""Sadsong St."" features a ukulele
column6: and ""Lovely Night"" is dark cabaret pop bristling with spiky clarinets. Yet for all the trappings
column7: Swift sounds a little indistinct
column8: like a straight Rufus Wainwright. That pop scion's entire identity is bound up in the musical styles he appropriates to express gay desire-- or re-appropriates
column9: since many of these genres originally expressed gay desire. The Novelist never sounds like Swift has that immense an investment in these styles: they're just novelties. So by the mini-album's final chapter
column10: the motif has grown superfluous and even tiresome.

column1: Fortunately
column2: for <i><span style=""font-style: normal;"">Walking Without Effort
column3: Swift leaves the creaky prewar radio he's been singing from and takes a few steps toward the present day. Less self-consciously ambitious but more dramatically realized
column4: Walking Without Effort collects all the urbane lyrics and drawn-out choruses of The Novelist
column5: but loses the glued-on razzmatazz. Sounding like both Jakob Dylan and Randy Newman
column6: Swift seems much more at home among the 70s-pop guitars
column7: Brian Wilson wood-block percussion
column8: and Jon Brion reeds. He wastes no time proving his mettle on ""Half Lit"" and ""As I Go""
column9: two diagonal rays of sunny pop whose horns and handclaps make their dark
column10: desperate lyrics sound casual. Before closing with the refined valedictions of ""Not Wasting Time"" and ""Beautifulheart""
column11: Swift hits his peak with ""Losing Sleep""
column12: which handily achieves all of Swift's ambitions
column13: not so much for its lush backing vocals or its sophisticated
column14:
crescendoing arrangement than for its elegant melody and heartfelt lyrics-- the two elements to anticipate most on the inevitable Vol. 2.
