column3: Susumu Yokota's bedrock musical preoccupations have moved to the fore. Symbol
column4: his latest album
column5: is in a sense the finest encapsulation yet of his core aesthetic. It's not his best record (I am still partial to the restraint and austerity of <i>Sakura)
column6: but is perhaps the clearest rendering yet of how he hears the world.

column1: Most of the sounds on Symbol come from sampled classical music. Choice bits from famous and not-so-famous pieces are plucked from history
column2: placed alongside Yokota's synths and programmed drums
column3: and looped incessantly to create a dreamy quasi-ambient fabric of sound. The sample credits stretch on like a Dust Brothers album but most of the pilfered have been dead for 100 years or more. Generally the sources lean toward the romantic. Favored throughout are the rich
column4: swirling strings and piano from composers like Debussy
column5: Ravel
column6: and Tchaikovsky
column7: and Yokota finds something pop in all of them. The wordless and ethereal female voice
column8: a long established obsession of Yokota's
column9: is also present. In addition to some original vocals several tracks incorporate samples of Meredith Monk
column10: with her elastic tone veering from childlike whimsy to quasi-liturgical seriousness.

column1: Setting works by famous composers set to beats was a pretty sizable cottage industry in the late 1970s and early 80s
column2: but Yokota's approach is far removed from Hooked on Classics. Rather than using long and familiar sections of pieces
column3: Yokota taps into the emotional material embedded in the sounds of certain instruments and severely truncated melodic fragments. Many samples remain for me
column4: a classical novice
column5: just below the identifiable threshold
column6: something I've heard before in another context but can't quite place. This works to the music's advantage
column7: as it toys with memory and the associations inherent in certain types of sound without giving itself away completely. Obvious exceptions like the loop of Beethoven's ""Moonlight Sonata"" and swell of Mussorgsky's ""A Night on Bald Mountain"" stuck into ""Flaming Love and Destiny"" break the record's spell
column8: but these are exceptions.

column1: It's an aesthetic that's easy to like
column2: with a relentless prettiness so extreme at time it takes on an almost surreal quality. Something about Symbol says ""ecstasy album"" to me
column3: with a mix and arrangements seem designed to highlight the music's considerable tactile qualities above all else. There's nothing life changing about Symbol but it's not that kind of record; ultimately it's a lush
column4: ornate
column5:
and elegant celebration of the oft-maligned pleasure of pure surface-level beauty.

column4: Little Brother's battle cry of returning the art form to its rightful place makes less sense than it did nearly 10 years ago
column5: when artists who weren't signed to a major label proclaimed them. So what is Little Brother saving hip-hop from? According to them
column6: commercial artists' focus on sex
column7: guns
column8: and accessories are the modern-day equivalent of Vaudevillian blackface performers
column9: seizing upon the worst characteristics of black society and hyperbolizing them to entertain a non-black audience. The proposed minstrelsy of hip-hop doesn't explain how the #1 album and single in the country come from a guy whose lyrics are more introspective than Conor Oberst's
column10: whose biggest hit to date is about Jesus
column11: and whose name is in everyone's mouth from suburbia to the White House because of his nationally-televised political stance.

column1: Is Kanye in blackface? Better yet
column2: is Missy? Or Outkast? These aren't fringe performers. They are a few of the biggest selling pop artists of the last half-decade
column3: all of whom enjoy widespread cultural influence and power. Little Brother imply that anyone who raps about anything other than ""real life"" [read: middle-class struggles] is a disgrace
column4: a Pied Piper to the youth
column5: a traitor to his or her culture who needs to be shown the path to redemption. Their stance also assumes that the listening audience isn't intelligent enough to distinguish between fact and fiction
column6: reality from rented props. If Little Brother's product were as enticing as any of the artists they decry as sellouts
column7: their message might carry more weight
column8: but The Minstrel Show adds up to little more than a loose concept constructed on tiresome production so that the group can pound its ham-fisted homilies.

column1: The album's Minstrel Show is a fictional Saturday Night Live-type program televised on the UBN (U Black Niggas-- a revealing bit of finger-pointing) network
column2: which provides the basis for the bounty of skits and jokes throughout. Some of the skits are funny at first listen
column3: but the skit long ago became the wanky guitar solo of hip-hop. Save the skits and one stab at soft targets
column4: R. Kelly and Ronald Isley
column5: Little Brother make no attempt to adhere to the concept. Lyrically
column6: Phonte and Big Pooh offer a variety of ""we're better than you"" battle rhymes but aren't bold enough to say why. If they're on a higher plane
column7: it seems they could come up with a few clever metaphors explaining such
column8: but no. On ""All For You"" they tackle the difficulties of fatherhood
column9: but it's an all-too-brief blip of social consciousness. To his credit
column10: Phonte is an intelligent lyricist
column11: and when he isn't married to bad ideas
column12: he shines
column13: as on his Foreign Exchange album with Nicolay.

column1: And then there's 9th Wonder
column2: whose production was supposed to change the game ever since the Roots' ?uestlove got a crush on Little Brother's early demos in 1999. The ever-graying cloud over 9th's beats is that they still sound like early demos. Despite being signed to a major and scoring scads of outside production work
column3: 9th still sounds like he's tapping his fingers on a Best Buy synthesizer. His whispy snare hits have become so predictable you could sync your grandmother's treadmill to their rhythmic lethargy. And can we put an end to the neighborhood D'Angelo singing hooks on hip-hop records? 9th Wonder is proficient enough in selecting a soul sample and throttling the bassline that not everything is a dud (lead-single
column4: ""Lovin' It""
column5: ""Hiding Place"" featuring Elzhi
column6: and ""Say It Again"").

column1: Little Brother have good intentions. They want to sound like the groups they grew up enjoying
column2: namely A Tribe Called Quest
column3: De La Soul
column4: and Pete Rock & CL Smooth (they even homage ATCQ's ""Oh My God"" on ""Still Lives Through"")
column5: but their songs sound more like signifiers of those groups
column6: not their logical descendents. Unfortunately
column7: the hype that floated Little Brother's careers over the last six years may have affirmed some bad habits (narrow content
column8: homemade beats) and encouraged lofty aspirations not yet attainable. If they want to create an alternative to the types of hip-hop they don't respect
column9:
they would do well to study the lessons of their favorite records.

As a kid I went through long stretches where I bought records that I understood to be important to the development of rock music; so
column3: inevitably
column4: I had a protracted blues phase. There was something puzzling about this music
column5: though
column6: a discord between what I read and what I heard. In print I gathered that blues was fundamentally social; I was always reading something about the big names of the genre getting their start playing fish-fries
column7: juke joints
column8: and rent parties. From these descriptions blues sounded like party music designed to get people dancing
column9: but the music I was hearing was for the most part slow
column10: brooding
column11: and personal
column12: often performed by a single guitar and voice. Even with
column13: say
column14: Muddy Waters' full band and a faster tempo
column15: I still couldn't imagine dancing to 12-bar. What kind of parties were we talking about?

column1: Somewhere along the line I acquired an album by Mississippi Fred McDowell called Somebody Keeps Calling Me
column2: and
column3: hearing ""Shake 'Em on Down"" and ""Drop Down Mama"" it all made sense. McDowell's guitar playing on these songs was all about rhythm
column4: a distinctive syncopated chug that emphasized the offbeats and often stayed on a single chord. The structure seemed so much more open and inspired movement. This blues sounded like a party. Up near McDowell in the Mississippi hill country lived a man 22 years his junior named R.L. Burnside who heard his elder play and ultimately put his own spin on the stomping monochord vamp.

column1: Burnside recorded his share of solo acoustic 12-bar
column2: but he'll be remembered for driving electric blues. He died recently. In the last 10 years of his life he enjoyed a modest amount of fame in the indie world due largely to this record
column3: a 1996 collaboration with the Jon Spencer Blues Explosion originally released on Matador. Burnside had already toured with the Blues Explosion by this point. When Spencer got the idea to cut a record
column4: the band dispatched to an isolated spot in rural Mississippi with nothing but their equipment and what one imagines was a vast amount of booze. It's hard to imagine a more masculine scene: A half-dozen guys in a hunting cabin
column5: drinking whiskey
column6: cursing a blue streak
column7: talking about women
column8: and playing the kind of raunchy blues where ""I'd rather see you dead than with another man"" is as close as one gets to ""I love you.""

column1: No question A Ass Pocket of Whiskey has a fair amount of contextual baggage. Just the idea
column2: a bunch of privileged indie rockers in the presence of a senior citizen performer from a different universe. So much opportunity for condescension and general bad faith. Even the sound of Spencer's voice
column3: the man forever burdened by his background as a semiotics student at Brown
column4: yelping words of encouragement every few bars (""Aw
column5: yeah! R.L.! Snake drive!""). It's going to bug some people.

column1: Me
column2: I think it works. More than anything Spencer's shouts remind me of Johnny Winter on Muddy Waters' comeback album Hard Again
column3: the sound of an admirer in the presence of a hero
column4: rallying him to hit the heights that originally brought the followers into his orbit. He knows he sounds like a dork. These guys
column5: all of them
column6: are having a ball. The band is loose but swings
column7: the production is appropriately rough and leaking like a sieve
column8: and the song selection draws from Burnside favorites. Listen to this take on ""Shake 'Em on Down"" and compare it to those on other Burnside records. The menace of the chords and behind-the-beat looseness of the drums can't be touched. That the Blues Explosion combed the entire Lower East Side in search of the perfect guitar/amp interface pays off. This record sounds like a blues album should.

column1: The entire record is filled with funky rhythms
column2: even the weird spoken story-songs like ""The Criminal Inside Me"" and ""Tojo Told Hitler"" where the Blues Explosion comps while Burnside talks shit. It all feels thrown together
column3: with tracks that begin mid-song and sudden exclamations that send the recording deep into the red. In this context the offhand nature is a plus. A Ass Pocket of Whiskey is smart and funny and full of life. Fine American music we can all be proud of
column4:
now back on Fat Possum where it belongs and where the final chapter of R.L. Burnside's life began.

column1: The real strength of At the Center is just how contemporary it sounds. Dangers never succumbs to the temptation to phone it in

column1: One trait Loose in the Air noticeably shares with Turn On the Bright Lights is a distinct shortage of laughs
column2: or even courteous smiles
column3: as the men of the Double here knit their brows resolutely towards the skylines. Seemingly every track carries vague messages of some imminent
column4: unnamed trouble
column5: as Greenhill's desperate lyrics struggle to make themselves intelligible above the music's potent static. On the lurching
column6: powerful ""On Our Way""
column7: such lines as ""The radio turns itself up...the continent's turned on its side"" intermittently bubble through like transmissions from a bad satellite feed
column8: while on the following ""Hot Air""
column9: Morris' sinister carnival organ takes over to sweat out an urgent post-punk ""Five To One"" pulse.

column1: Throughout the album
column2: the Double are at their best on patiently-built tracks like the throbbing
column3: wormwood dub of ""Up All Night"" or the seven-minute epic ""Dance""
column4: both of which rise by increments to reach impressive
column5: shrieking heights of amp feedback and distorted electronics. Less compelling
column6: however
column7: are those songs they attempt to drive headlong into more conventional popcraft
column8: such as the perfunctory indie bounce ""Icy"" or the freeze-dried grunge of ""What Sound It Makes the Thunder""
column9:
an overcooked stomp that simply begs for the type of unhinged performance that the Double seem unwilling (or unable) to give it. These periodic lapses of over-constraint are especially disappointing given the group's obvious talent for making spontaneous mid-air adjustments to their sound; but there's enough evidence here to be optimistic that one day soon the group will gain the swagger necessary to more consistently abandon themselves to their wilder sonic impulses.

As ""freak-folk"" began to hit a stride last summer
column3: Devendra Banhart's Golden Apples of the Sun compilation suggested a cogent introduction to the genre. A year later
column4: Cripple Crow provides
column5: in a sense
column6: the loose-knit scene's strongest group effort to date.  Banhart's fourth album isn't a compilation
column7: nor is it billed as a group project
column8: but he's assembled such a rich cast of cohorts here
column9:
it feels more like the fruit of community interaction than the product of a lone singer/songwriter.

The communal vibe is hinted at by the album's artwork: Rather than adorning the cover with his usual calligraphic scribbles
column10: Banhart offers a composite photo of ""The Family"" (a term he often ascribes to his musical friends)
column11: gathered beneath a large knotty tree and accompanied by the disembodied heads of smiling spirits. Sgt. Pepper is the obvious point of departure
column12: though unlike the Beatles' classic
column13: there are no numbered silhouettes in the liner notes to decode the relative anonymity of the photo subjects. Fittingly
column14: the only immediately recognizable figure is Banhart himself
column15: crouching front and center
column16:
wings spread wide.

The artwork conjures Native America
column17: an attribute Banhart seemingly alluded to in a recent email exchange
column18: admitting that he's ""a little terrified at how white most of the people are
column19: but reassuring me that ""68% of the people on the cover have Native American blood.""  Indeed
column20: Banhart strives for ethnic diversity on Cripple Crow
column21: boasting the highest concentration of Spanish-sung tracks of any of his albums (he was raised in Venezuela where Spanish was his mother tongue)
column22: and finding him moving further beyond ""freak"" territory and into a worldly blend of various exotic approaches.  Banhart has always experimented with method and sound
column23: but he's never before approached Cripple Crow's expertise and variety. In all its obvious details
column24: the album not only finds Banhart coming into his own as a songwriter and performer
column25:
but suggests future directions for the 24-year-old as well.

Having started out on primitive recorders and four-track machines
column26: Banhart only recently graduated to proper studios
column32: are especially assured and less flaky than on previous outings.  And as mentioned above
column33: an ensemble cast showed up to back him: There's best chum Andy Cabic (aka Vetiver)
column34: Noah Georgeson (of Joanna Newsom's old rock band the Pleased
column36: and Thom Monohan (Pernice Brother and production whiz).  The cast also includes members of Currituck Co.
column43:
it's a traveling band of hippies excited about Donovan who aren't afraid to rock.

On Oh Me Oh My's ""Roots""
column45: ""I don't play rock 'n' roll."" All that's changed. Cripple Crow features an explosion of psychedelic R&R stuffs. ""Long Haired Child"" maneuvers a three-pronged guitar attack-- Adam Forkner's distorted noodling
column47: and acoustic coupling-- backed with Otto Hauser's drums and Jona Bechtolt's percussion.  ""Lazy Butterfly"" is memorable for Cabic's closely mic'd backing vocals and a tambora sheen along with hand drums and guitars.  And ""Little Boys""
column48: which Banhart alleges is sung from the perspective of a schizophrenic Hermaphrodite
column49: is divided in half by a mid-song bass change-up which shifts the song up from a sorta boring Oldham prom-dance lament to its sinister
column50:
surfy refrain: ""I see so many little boys I wanna marry/ I see plenty little kids I've yet to had.""

Juxtaposed against a number of upbeat rock tracks
column52: more introspective material often makes a stronger impact. ""Dragonflies""
column53: a whispered duet between Banhart and Matteah Baim of Metallic Falcons
column54: flutters by in less than a minute with a cryptically tender lyricism.  Likewise
column55: album opener ""Now That I Know"" is one of his most beautiful and controlled tracks yet. It finds him backed only by cello and his own guitar
column56:
in confessional: ""12 years old/ In [my] mama's clothes/ Shut the blinds and lock up every door/ And if you hear someone's coming near/ Just close your eyes it'll make 'em disappear.""

Elsewhere
column59: with Feathers' lovely vocals adding witch-hunt background layers. Banhart gently lays down the thesis-- ""Heard somebody say the war ended today/ But everybody knows it's going still""-- before winding around to the chill-inducing punchline
column60: the easiest anti-war slogan ever: ""It's simple
column61: we don't want to kill.""  Later
column62: he tries out Dylan rhyme schemes on ""I Feel Just Like a Child""
column63:
while ""Some People Ride the Wave"" is Louis Armstrong with New Orleans toy jazz (""some people write the songs that stay inside our souls""); ""The Beatles"" lets it be known that ""Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr are the only Beatles in the world"" before shifting gears into Spanish; Pangea and various fertility myths are given new legs in ""Chinese Children""; and endless love song ""Korean Dogwood"" tells as thorough an elliptical story as Banhart's tackled.

Banhart's ambition is apparent throughout
column64: but at 22 tracks and almost 75 minutes
column65: the album does stretch its legs too long.  Though it feels like an attempt to document as thoroughly as possible his late winter retreat to Woodstock
column66: any more experienced mystics will tell you that blanks
column69: and other ingredients for mystery could've made it even richer. Still
column72:
and an inspired listening experience where Banhart again proves himself one of the more talented and charismatic forces in modern music.

column1: Stereolab are as reliable an institution as anything you'll encounter in formal education. After umpteen albums

column14: er
column15: clav

a B-average isn't bad.

column7: The Curious City is the sound of your band all grown up. Compared to previous album Thunder + Lightning there's more melody
column8: more ambitious structures
column9: more psychedelic detours
column10: and more surprises here.

column1: ""Bucket of Butterflies"" sets the tone
column2: moving from a sludgy
column3: lumbering opening riff into a lighter
column4: melodic shuffle through strummed sparkling pop into a three-note Disney villain gallop onto a snarling chorus and adroitly back to square one to start again. The streamlined ""Sleepwalkers"" is little less flashy
column5: but still weaves electronic and psychedelic influences into a sleek whole
column6: and the ghostly organs on the bouncy ""In Another Land"" provide some of the album's most psych-rock moments. They can also pull back and quiet down
column7: as on the melodramatic mid-tempo ""In the Cemetery""
column8: and the record's lyrics are sung with clarity and restraint.

column1: The fluidity dulls some of the immediate punch of the songs might have otherwise-- the brief chorus to ""Bucket of Butterflies"" would make a fine song itself if the band wanted to keep things static-- but seamlessness is it's most impressive quality
column2: especially following the apparently simple Thunder + Lightning. That old band appears every once in a while
column3: popping up for a moment in ""Bucket of Butterflies"" or the reckless riffage and wailing of ""Mr. Mercedes"" like a hand gripping the inside brim of a boiling cauldron
column4: but never for more than a moment.

column1: The relentless shifting works best when not spending too long on any one idea
column2: and when leaning on the monumental drumming of Paul Quattrone. ""Bucket of Butterflies"" is ably carried through hairpin turns in tempo and rhythm
column3: and scurrying keyboard riffs like the one to ""Red Lights"" are pummeled senseless. Without Quattrone
column4: the band couldn't get away with all this.

column1: They don't get away with everything
column2: though; The organ drenched ""Fingers
column3: Drains"" gets bogged down in execution
column4: and while the acoustic plucking of ""Countries"" is a pleasant change in sound
column5: it's not nearly as captivating. Plus
column6: the groove to the closing ""Trapped Rabbits"" is deadly
column7: but not enough to sustain its 16-minute runtime. But that's another surprise: These 10 tracks feel epic with all their twists and turns
column8: but rarely exceed the five-minute mark
column9:
and lose none of the urgency of the band's earlier work.

Last year Six Organs of Admittance's Ben Chasny contributed liner notes for VHF's reissue of the early-90s Japanese psych-folk rarity L's Holy Letters
column2: in which he paid homage to the music and its creator
column3: Hiroyuki Usui. And one didn't have to listen long to the crackled textures of Holy Letters' deeply evocative outsider folk-blues to detect Usui's influence on Chasny's subsequent work. Since then
column4: the two musicians have cultivated an extensive correspondence which has now culminated in the formation of August Born. Collaborating by way of tapes exchanged in the mail
column5: August Born's debut album finds the duo attempting to overcome the barriers of language and distance to quarry their substantial expanses of musical and spiritual common ground.

column1: In addition to his multi-instrumental work as L
column2: Usui has made wide-ranging experimental music with underground luminaries Keiji Haino in Fushitsusha and various members of Ghost in Marble Sheep. Here
column3: however
column4: August Born maintain a respectful simplicity in their partnership. Most of these tracks are constructed from spare
column5: interwoven splinters of banjo
column6: amp feedback
column7: muffled percussion
column8: and various found sounds in accompaniment to Chasny's distinctive finger-picked guitars
column9: while both musicians take turns trading blurred vocals. Usui's music is heavily steeped in rural American blues-- as evidenced by his spectral version of Blind Willie Johnson's ""Cold Was the Ground"" on Holy Letters-- and his playing here results in several performances that are as traditional as anything Chasny has previously put his hand to. And though the limitations of its recording process can make the album seem like a fragmentary sketchbook
column10: it also contains in its depths glowing coals that could only have been sparked by the collision of such similarly high-charged
column11: inspiriting talents.

column1: As is often the case with mail-based collaborations-- Christina Carter & Loren Connor's <em>Meditations on the Ascension of Blind Joe Death
column2: for instance-- listening to August Born's loose dialogue feels like eavesdropping on an intercepted cell phone conversation. Voices speak over one another
column3: phrases are inadvertently interrupted
column4: and promising leads not followed up. ""Birds & Sun & Clay"" sounds like a pleasant but uneventful outtake from Six Organs's School of the Flower
column5: while on ""Song of the Dead"" the two musicians lightly paw around ideas
column6: each perhaps too deferentially waiting for the other to make something happen.

column1: But then there are the moments that
column2: with little advance warning
column3: the duo manage to achieve offhanded heights of an enthralling symbiosis. ""More Dead Bird Blues"" grows out of Usui's incantatory vocal to become a weightless volley of skeletal guitar
column4: gauzy voices and shimmering percussion
column5: a hypnotic exchange that carries over to the following ""Last Breath of the Bird""
column6: as if the two were reflecting beams of sunlight to one another via handheld mirrors. And as the album closes with the electric hum of ""A Lot Like You"" and the intimate guitar of ""You Will Be Warm""
column7: it becomes increasingly difficult to distinguish one musician from the other
column8: their individual voices gradually converging into the same ungrounded tongue
column9:
and leaving one with the hope that this proves to be merely the beginning of a long and mutually beneficial association.

column1: Sadly

column3: a moment when Britpop's creativity was crashing but its popularity and the belief that its success was tied to England's national identity was ebbing. It <i>felt like a time when normally tangential artists could command the spotlight

column2: and the best way to reclaim the glories of mid-Sixties British guitar rock was to lazily build MOR bridges to the past. Ten years later the UK indie circuit is so unadventurous and tepid that we have the editor-in-chief of the <i>NME scrunching his nose up at Antony and the Johnsons' Mercury Prize win
column3: calling an album of gorgeous cabaret-pop ""too weird"" for his audience. So step forward Keane

column5: the Coral
column6: Damien Rice
column7: Elbow
column8: Hard-Fi
column9: Razorlight
column10: Kaiser Chiefs
column11: etc.
column12: and take your seat at the current Help! table

column4: ""You and Whose Army?"" mold

Covers of ""Goodbye Yellow Brick Road"" (Keane with Faultline) and ""I Heard It Through the Grapevine"" (the Kasier Chiefs) were more puzzling choices. Both are breakup songs-- one about a young gay man leaving his sugar daddy; the other sees the jilted learning his fate through heresay and rumor-- and neither work. Keane's effort is largely innocuous

column1: So here's the pride of UK indie
column2: and the best tracks are from a cartoon band and a group from Mali. Damon Albarn-- one of three holdovers from the first set (along with Radiohead and the Manic Street Preachers)-- does a 180 from ""Eine Kleine Lift Musik""

column4: almost reflective ""Hong Kong""

column6: an influence on Albarn

column1: What's missing this time around? Non-guitar music

column4: Orbital

column6: Portishead
column7: Andrew Weatherall and James Hardway

It's also a fundamental failure of the organizers
column14: who've drawn a narrow pool of artists at the detriment of the record's ultimate goal-- raising as much money as possible for War Child. It's not difficult to imagine that a wider variety of artists or the inclusion of pop
column15: r&b;
column16: grime
column17: and dance music would translate to a larger number of potential buyers.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the worthwhile project also risks becoming relatively lost amidst the outpouring of aid and money for Hurricane Katrina relief. On the face of it
column3: the work of War Child-- providing assistance to children affected by war and conflict-- and hurricane relief are drastically different; one an ongoing
column4: manmade problem and the other a natural disaster. In another sense
column5: War Child does exactly what was not done for thousands of Katrina victims-- provide aid for those who can't help themselves. It's a deeply unfashionable idea in today's ""ownership society"" America
column6: but just as Katrina horrifically demonstrated the failings of such policies
column7: spotlighting the America that the architects of an ownership society seek to sweep under the rug
column8: to abandon
column9: to demonize even as they're being preyed upon within their own communities by those who use violence as an organizing tool and power grab
column10:
War Child seeks to do the same around the world.

Considering the context around its release

or nuance.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/4867/homepage_large.d1053b17.jpg|Vocalcity|2560.0|Luomo|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Force Tracks']|2005-09-08 00:00:00|2000|2016-06-11 20:54:43.730083|"

New Year's Day
column2: 2003. At a semi-luxury hotel a few kilometers from the coast
column3: a sprawling complex of balconied buildings and a swimming pool nestled next to a stand of trees
column4: a few hundred ravers in summer duds-- some in dirty Diesels
column5: some in bikinis
column6: and all eyes hidden behind enormous
column7: smoke-colored shades-- pivot and sway while the last molecules of MDMA sweat their way out of their systems. On a stage facing the pool
column8: a skinny young man with a blond mane swigs champagne from the bottle while he nudges absently at a computer mouse; his own massive eyeshield tosses off disco glints that mirror the flashes of light that go tearing up the firelines between bass and space in his music.

column1: It's every Balearic clichรฉ at once
column2: except that this isn't Ibiza
column3: it's Reรฑaca
column4: Chile; and the laptop jockey isn't Sasha van Oakenweed but a skinny Finn named Luomo
column5: nรฉe Sasu Ripatti
column6: best known until not long before as Vladislav Delay-- a former free-jazz drummer who made the leap to Chain Reaction-styled ""heroin house"" before being crowned prince of clicks + cuts. The event is notable for several reasons
column7: among them the globalization of European leisure culture; but the real significance here concerns the ongoing conversion of tight-lipped minimalism into something self-consciously sexy and sophisticated and Ecstasy-friendly. It's the preface to an ongoing evolution that is only coming to fruition in 2005
column8: when the Sasha van Oakenweeds of the world pepper their mixes with tracks from Kompakt and Traum
column9: and Creamfields' beachside raves feature the likes of Ellen Allien and Blackstrobe alongside Deep Dish and Carl Cox. In many ways
column10: all this began with Luomo's 2000 debut
column11: <i>Vocalcity
column12: reissued this month on Ripatti's own Huume label.

column1: Vocalcity was unexpected
column2: and not a little audacious: ""Luomo-- The Next Episode in House-- prod. by Vladislav Delay
column3: proclaimed a sticker on the sleeve. The album was published by Force Tracks
column4: one of an avalanche of sublabels from Frankfurt's Force Inc.
column5: an erstwhile ""proper"" techno imprint that had gone all theoretical as it aged
column6: christening sublabels after Deleuze and Guattari tomes and fashioning grand philosophies around concepts like ""clicks + cuts."" (Full disclosure: I wrote the liner notes for <i>Clicks + Cuts 2.) ""The Next Episode in House"" sounded like the kind of sweeping
column7: appropriationist
column8: Zeitgeist-stroking statement that Force would make-- but damned if it weren't true. If anything
column9: it sounds even truer today. It's not that Luomo advanced the cause of house music in some way that his forebears (Chez Damier
column10: Derrick May
column11: and Maurizio
column12: to pick three) didn't manage to. But there was nothing else that sounded like Vocalcity at the time
column13: and there's been precious little that sounds like it since
column14: including Luomo's slightly disappointing
column15: ill-fated 2003 followup The Present Lover.

column1: Writing in <em>The Wire back in 2001
column2: I pegged Vocalcity as the tipping point (the clipping point?) in what I called microhouse-- a genre that seemed to take the essential template of house music and shrink its constituent parts (that shoomping beat
column3: a cavernous sense of space
column4: and an echo of soul music as processed through disco) down to byte-sized pieces
column5: leaving a schematic of dotted lines swimming through oceans of dubwise absence. But listening now
column6: it's clear that I got it exactly backwards
column7: at least in Luomo's case. What stands out now
column8: a half-decade later
column9: isn't the smallness of Vocalcity's sounds but its fullness. Sure
column10: Luomo has the requisite clicks and clanks; as ""Market""
column11: the absolutely epic lead track
column12: opens up
column13: half the action is in the chattering of truncated hi-hats and a distant rattle that sounds like an army of mechanics spinning their ratchets. But house music has always had these kind of details; for comparison
column14: just listen to E-Dancer (Kevin Saunderson)'s 1997 cut ""World of Deep""
column15: the track I've come to believe most closely heralds what Luomo would later attempt. Beneath those enormous
column16: cascading pads
column17: the hi-hats and bells have been whittled down to needlepoint proportions. Luomo emphasized his details by framing them in white space
column18: but what you hear now
column19: after the demise of clicks + cuts
column20: aren't the pinpricks but the enormous
column21: inflated sounds of everything else-- bass
column22: pads

column1: True to its name
column2: Vocalcity put breathy
column3: yearning male and female vocals at the center of its pneumatic mix. Tracks like ""Market""
column4: ""Class""
column5: ""Synkro""
column6: and ""Tessio""-- a full two-thirds of the six-track
column7: triple LP-- expand like inner tubes as those voices come rushing in. Indeed
column8: my favorite element of the album has always been the way that ""Market"" begins by teasing in the vocalist's breaths and sighs
column9: one tiny gasp at a time
column10: along with fragments of sung melody buried deep
column11: deep
column12: deep in the mix. Only at 4:48
column13: nearly halfway through the 12-minute track
column14: does she finally introduce the full vocal hook. And when the sad reprimand drops-- ""There's nothing in the world that you can do
column15: repeated a full five times
column16: then a quick breath
column17: and finally the explosive charge buried in the slug
column18: ""For me""-- Well
column19: we could talk about formalism all day
column20: but people
column21: that right there is one of the most perfect moments in the world of pop music
column22: albeit a full minute and 18 seconds after most pop songs have punched out the clock and gone home to sleep.

column1: That's the triumph of Vocalcity. Not reduction
column2: but expansion. Vladislav Delay has always aimed for the long view. (If you think Luomo's tracks are long-- ""She-Center""
column3: at 10 minutes
column4: is the shortest thing on Vocalcity
column5: and the rest average around 12 minutes apiece-- check out Vladislav Delay's 2000 album Entain
column6: where the cuts run from 15 to 22 minutes long. 2001's Anima went even further
column7: comprising a single
column8: hourlong track that swirls in place like a dead tide.) If there's anything ""micro"" in <em>Vocalcity
column9: it's the way tiny little holes open up within the frizzing chords
column10: as though you could see the pixels framing each fraying waveform. But that's all academic. Five years later
column11: ""minimal"" techno has fattened itself up again. Most of today's rave hits don't sound anything like Luomo
column12: but I don't think anything today would sound the way it does if Luomo hadn't seduced the tinkerers away from their mouse pads and back to the land of goosebumps and sex. What you hear most in Luomo today are the stomach-punching bass lines
column13: the pistoning chords inherited straight from Chicago's finest
column14: and those maddeningly ambiguous vocals
column15: always hovering just out of reach. Perhaps the long exception is the male refrain in ""Synkro""
column16:
which could stand as the tautological epigraph to the album's simple brilliance: ""Because you move/ The way you move.""

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/6839/homepage_large.5d96f741.jpg|Capture/Release|3665.0|The Rakes|['Rock'
column3: the meme spreading like memefire through the UK press seems to be that the Rakes are doing for London's indie denizens what Mike Skinner did for its chavs-- making mountains of their molehilly tribulations and turning music's often abstracted focus onto a particular modern niche. And it's true that everything about their debut
column4: Capture/Release
column5: screams NOW
column6: from the nervous post-Wire guitars familiar from Franz Ferdinand and Kaiser Chiefs
column7: to the tattoos-under-starched-shirts lyrical purview
column8: to the Paul Epworth production. Unfortunately
column9: Capture/Release might be the victim of bad timing: It's going to sound pretty rote to American audiences who've been steeped in this stuff for the past couple years
column10: and while it's doubtful that the Rakes are overtly ripping off any of the bands they resemble
column11: it scans as a failure of imagination on the listener's end.

column1: Art Brut's mundane
column2: declarative statements are funny as hell
column3: balanced perfectly on the sincerity/irony axis
column4: and Skinner's are richly detailed. The Rakes aren't as witty as Art Brut
column5: and they lack Skinner's close scrutiny
column6: but their lyrical slant-- revolving around the working trendy person's guilt and ennui-- is not without interest. ""Retreat"" sets the tone for the album by swinging wildly between earnestness and apathy. ""Everything is temporary these days
column7: Alan Donohoe laments. But in a record that's all about jaded acquiesce
column8: he immediately gives up: ""Might as well go out for the third night in a row."" After wondering whether he should donate his money to a charity or go on holiday
column9: Donohoe succumbs to malaise: ""Walk home
column10: come down
column11: retreat to sleep/ Wake up
column12: go out again
column13: repeat."" The working man's blues even creep into the paranoid ""Terror!"": ""And my job in the city won't matter no more/ When the network is down and my flesh is all torn."" While a portrait of a generation's concerns
column14: however superficial
column15: does emerge
column16: the triteness of these concerns and the clichรฉs Donohoe often uses to limn them fall short of endearing. ""I had just woke up in someone else's bed/ She was overweight/ Who did I do last night?"" he charmingly wonders on ""The Guilt"".

column1: But if you find the lyrics resonant (maybe it helps to be a young working Brit with a ""22 Grand Job"") and you aren't sick of jittery eight-notes yet
column2: Capture/Release is a well-mounted entry. ""Strasbourg"" introduces a searing two-tone lead
column3: a fluid rhythmic drive
column4: and Donohoe's winning sneer in perfect pop succession
column5: while ""Retreat"" fulfills the off-kilter Talking Heads impulse with chomping guitars and muted harmonics. ""Open Book"" is a staccato shuffle with verse-busting ""oh-ohs"" and a suavely sexy vocal line; ""Binary Love"" gleams with squiggly guitars and hooky
column6: romantic verses; the slight reverb and sparse
column7: hollow percussion of ""Violet"" fit in the mandatory ""sorta reggae"" slot just fine. But by the time ""Work Work Work (Pub

Emmylou Harris is the queen of the midtempo lament. The 20 tracks on her new retrospective Heartaches & Highways all adhere to a similar metronomic setting
column3: somewhere between a country ballad and a church hymn-- steady
column4: patient
column5: and reserved
column6: not really slow but certainly not fast. ""I don't have that many up-tempo songs
column7: she confesses to Robert K. Oermann in the liner notes. In a sense this plays to her strengths and allows her to draw out every note so that her ragged
column8: dignified voice can wring as much pain from the syllables as possible. Kicking off Heartaches & Highways
column9: ""Love Hurts""
column10: her duet with Gram Parsons
column11: bursts with exquisite heartbreak
column12: so tended and curated that it sounds museum-worthy. Following that song is ""Boulder to Birmingham""
column13: which Harris wrote for Parsons following his death in 1973. Those two songs are about as perfectly sad and weepy as you could ever hope for
column14: and the circumstances of their recording give them an extra punch
column15: although ""Boulder to Birmingham"" seems to be missing something essential
column16: and after a few listens you realize it's Parsons' voice.

column1: The 18 songs that follow never quite reach these musical heights or emotional depths
column2: but do we really expect them to? In the ensuing 30 years
column3: Harris has gone out and come back into fashion
column4: her jet-black hair has turned alluringly silver
column5: and she has recorded more than 20 mostly solid albums and countless collaborations
column6: most of which are chronicled on <em>Heartaches & Highways. Her voice blends mesmerically with Roy Orbison's gentle warble on ""That Lovin' You Feelin' Again""
column7: and Harris re-creates 1960s girl-group harmonies with Dolly Parton and Linda Ronstadt on their gentle cover of Phil Spector's ""To Know Him Is to Love Him"". Her collaboration with producer Daniel Lanois on 1995's Wrecking Ball-- represented here by the Gillian Welch cover ""Orphan Girl""-- reinvigorated her career with its darker
column8: less traditional sounds
column9: but it also set the tone for every album since
column10: which all seem to prize atmosphere as much as songs.

column1: Over three-and-a-half decades
column2: Harris has exhibited an exceptional taste in covers. Those included on <i>Heartaches & Highways are deep-catalog picks from established artists
column3: avoiding obvious choices or previous hits. Harris recorded Townes Van Zandt's ""Pancho & Lefty"" before it was a hit for Merle Haggard and Willie Nelson and gives their more popular version a serious run for its money. In addition to providing impeccable material
column4: these covers often allow her to step outside of her midtempo comfort zone: she retains the skipping rhythms of the Louvin Brothers' ""If I Could Only Win Your Love"" and even quickens her pace for Delbert McClinton's ""Two More Bottles of Wine"".

column1: Harris's gift for inspired covers culminates with the collection's only new track
column2: a version of Randy Sharp's ""The Connection"" that teams Harris with original producer Brian Ahern and early collaborator Fayssoux Starling. It's yet another midtempo song
column3: a downbeat number that might sound better on an album that wasn't entirely comprised of downbeat numbers. And that's the crucial flaw in <em>Heartaches & Highways: It implies that Harris's talents were limited to a certain breed of song
column4: and while these twenty tracks all prove dynamic showcases for her singular voice
column5:
they barely hint at her considerable range of abilities and interests.

So constant has been Devendra Banhart's florid
column3: wayfaring presence-- both within and without the still flourishing neo-folk scene-- that it seems difficult to believe that it's been less than three years since his Oh Me Oh My... debut. He's made the most of these 30-odd (sometimes extremely odd) intervening months: In addition to maintaining his near-continuous schedule of solo touring and recording
column4: he's made cameo appearances with acts ranging from Vetiver to Antony and the Johnsons

column1: In this latter role

column3: plus he deserves at least partial credit for helping to coax 60s folk legend Vashti Bunyan out of retirement
column4: and later this year he'll help launch a new label

column3: formerly of Matty & Mossy
column4: whose ""Farm
column5: CA"" was one of Golden Apples's dusky highlights. And now Banhart has provided Hunter's career yet another boost with the release of this vinyl-only split LP. The album contains five songs from Devendra and five from Hunter

column7: according to Troubleman Unlimited

column9: this weird little record sparkles with enough tiny moments of peculiar
column10: glowing beauty that it should carry honest appeal for the rest of us as well.

column3: three are alternate versions of Rojo tracks

column6: a match that unfortunately sounds nowhere near as strange as it looks on paper. Throughout these songs
column7: Banhart displays a deft touch as both a singer and guitarist
column8: treating the tracks as living
column9: breathing entities as he fluidly bends notes and syllables in subtle new directions. And though the redundancy of many of these tracks may keep them from seeming truly essential
column10: the lively
column11: infectious joy of his performances ensures that none ever qualifies as a pure throwaway.

column7: as with her others here

column11:
her songs brimming with the same sort of unique promise one might've detected on Banhart's own early demos just a few short years ago.

column11: ""Metal is what it is
column12: when it is what it always was.""

the kind that has you up at night wondering why we even bother holding jobs when we barely get paid enough to pay for our housing and vehicles or why we bother befriending people if they are just gonna turn on us. And those methodical bastards in YOB probably enjoy causing that pain.

Because this record sports wacky titles and Asian Man Records' Tao of Pepsi logo
column2: you might assume that Ten in the Swear Jar (or XITSJ
column3: if you please) is a bitchin' ska-punk combo. The found audio that opens the disc seems to confirm this suspicion
column4: folding every offensive gay stereotype into one lisping soliloquy. This is unfortunate
column5: since
column6: unless Asian Man is wise enough to release the album with a sticker reading ""featuring Xiu Xiu's Jamie Stewart
column7: a large portion of its target audience might miss out. XITSJ's existence (around the turn of the millennium) was brief
column8: but they managed to record enough material for this 22-track prรฉcis. Accordion Solo! collects the bulk of XITSJ's debut LP
column9: My Very Private Map
column10: the follow-up EP Inside the Computer Are All of My Feelings
column11: the unreleased Eat Death Orphans!
column12: and a handful of live tracks.

column1: In short
column2: this is a must-have for Xiu Xiu fans-- while it's naturally less developed
column3: it contains plenty of winning experimentation and choleric melody; more importantly
column4: it's a digest
column5: albeit a slightly inchoate one
column6: of the techniques Stewart is perfecting with Xiu Xiu: Here's a portrait of the mannered provocateur as questing manquรฉ. Xiu Xiu's silvery guitars and murmur-to-caterwaul vocals are predicted on ""Hot Karl""; the regal synth line on ""San Jose Fight Song"" sound like late-Dismemberment Plan but foreshadows the digital sculptures of recent Xiu Xiu; and La Foret's clattery dirges can easily be traced back to XITSJ tracks like ""Gauntlet of Thor the Destroyer"" and ""When You Write"".

column1: But the biggest hook for collectors will be the early versions of Xiu Xiu tracks: ""I Love the Valley""
column2: which became a fan favorite when it appeared on Fabulous Muscles as ""I Luv the Valley OH!""
column3: appears in studio and live versions. This starker rendering keeps the guitar line and the lyrics
column4: but finds Stewart's voice clambering between emphatic and tremulous passages
column5: and replaces the vigorous lead melody with loopy
column6: sliding synths. Happily
column7: it includes the terse scream that pinions the middle
column8: and drops in a jackbooted synth line that strikes with goosebumpy force. There's also an almost industrial version of A Promise's ""Sad Pony Guerilla Girl"" (here called ""Sad Girl"") and a wistful take on Fag Patrol's ""Helsabot"".

column1: Usually
column2: this is where the disclaimer goes-- ""only recommended to diehard fans."" But Accordion Solo! is the rare early-career document that works as a stand-alone record. One gets the sense that Stewart had yet to develop the confidence to be as melodramatic as he'd like (he even sings in a quite unaffected
column3: lovely voice on several tracks)
column4: and Xiu Xiu detractors might find this preferable to the more realized recent work
column5: while for neophytes
column6: it will provide a valuable foothold on Stewart's daunting
column7:
alien terrain.

Last summer
column2: I dug a copy of Gogol Bordello Vs. Tamir Muskat by J.U.F. out of the promo box. (Or was it J.U.F. by Gogol Bordello Vs. Tamir Muskat? These pomo remixing shenanigans are hell on attribution.) I was vaguely familiar with Gogol Boredello-- a kind of fire-spitting punk cabaret troupe with traditional gypsy elements (or so I thought) outta NYC-- but this was something else entirely.

column1: There were beats
column2: for starters-- dancehall
column3: hip-hop
column4: jigs and reels
column5: thumping drum machines-- and samples (or was it all being played live?) of guitars
column6: horns
column7: and accordions. The vocals were declaimed in a style somewhere between uppity Balkan cabbie and ragga toaster
column8: heavy on the nasal. The lyrics were about Spanish car service drivers and ""supernatural and infantile"" little spies. In other words
column9: it sounded pretty much like my Sunday morning walk to get the paper when I lived in Queens.

column1: I later found out Gogol Bordello frontman Eugene Hutz DJs regularly in NYC
column2: and his playlists sound like a dream: Dancehall
column3: klezmer
column4: rai
column5: jungle
column6: old Polish jazz-- all played at warp speed for a stupid-drunk audience of revelers to spit beer on each other and hump legs. The J.U.F. record was itself a mash-up of Gogol's live band punk gymboree and the ""play the best bits"" genrefuck of Hutz' DJ sets.

column1: So I was a little apprehensive about hearing the real Gogol for the first time. Given my personal biases-- DJ culture over live band
column2: etc.-- how could it live up to such a perfectly formed little nubbin of modern eclecticism kulture? Especially when it was-- gasp!-- produced by Steve Albini! You can't mike a drum machine for maximum live-room sound.

column1: But
column2: you know
column3: it's great. The first thing I thought was ""the Ex"" and the second thing I thought was ""this is pretty fucking unique
column4: really."" Like the Ex
column5: they trade in ""world rhythms"" occasionally but don't make a big deal out of it. And there's a bit of the same guitar tone and scrabbling
column6: scratching playing style (on violin as well) in there too. But whereas the vocals in the Ex can be passionate but kind of stilted
column7: Hutz is pure sleaze
column8: a long tongue down your mama's ear. ""Think Globally
column9: Fuck Locally""
column10: a song title and a catchphrase
column11: one so obviously ripe for mass dissemination that Hutz wears it down his shirtsleeves.

column1: It also has a drum-break purportedly played on a overturned fire bucket
column2: but I gotta admit it's a pretty well-miked fire bucket. There's also some bestially played guitar and sawed-off fiddlin'
column3: strangled cascades of notes that goes well with the loosely tethered drumming. Like a ton of the best rock
column4: Gogol sounds like it's often on the verge of total chaos. Which is not to say they don't groove; the tension of near-collapse makes them swing even harder. ""Trouble Friends"" plays slashing guitar against a heavy one-drop reggae groove
column5: a dubbed-out perversion of the one-drop roots sound that's all over dancehall this year. ""60 Revolutions (Per Minute)"" rescues the accordion from kitsch
column6: mostly by speeding everything up to polka-punk tempo and throwing a little Latin rap in because they can. ""Immigrant Punk"" pairs another reggae groove against Morricone guitar and Hutz frothing about being eyeballed by small-minded townies just because he looks like he fell down at a Jo-Ann Fabrics store.

column1: In many ways
column2: the fact that they ooze the same kind of stinky
column3: trash-soaked
column4: Greek-pizza-joint-coffee-tastin
column5: Canal Street-on-a-high-summer-afternoon aroma through just a band in a room is even more amazing than the cut-and-paste J.U.F. record. (If not quite as thrilling.) Gogol don't play funk
column6: but they sure are funky. And no one
column7: not even Greg Norton
column8:
has a better mustache in rock than Hutz.

When mainstream rappers do stuff like this

column6: greasy fake G-funk from Atmosphere producer Ant. Here's Slug: ""Thug white girl

column2: sidelong pimp jam ""Breaker Down Like a Shotgun"". And when they do get heavy
column3: like on the thick
column4: stormy confession ""Marvin Gaye"" (Slug: ""Open apology for anyone who follows me/ Didn't realize I was a self-made power-freak"")
column5: it doesn't last. A track later

column1: Other than a couple of throwaway skits where they talk condescendingly to girls on the phone
column2: Felt 2 is pretty great. There's a sense of relief
column3: like they've been doing this chest-beating thing for too long and they're relieved to figure out that they still have some knucklehead in them. And so when they inevitable Anticon moment does come on the last two songs

column5: it feels well-earned
column6: like they can go back to this stuff secure in the knowledge that they're still great rappers. And
column7: you know
column8: they're really good at this emo-rap stuff
column9:
too.

The garage rock trend has peaked and is in obvious decline
column3: but many bands remain ever devoted to their '60s influences: They were playing this kind of revivalist rock long before the minimovement became popular
column4: and they're not going to stop now just because the radioplay prospects are shrinking. The Cincinnati-based Greenhornes have been working this particular corner of rock history since 1999
column5: when they released their rough-and-tumble debut
column6: Gun for You. Since then
column7: amid several line-up changes that whittled the quintet down to a streamlined trio
column8: the band has released three albums of blistering pop-rock that's better than most of the groups that stole their thunder
column9: and they have shown their surprising range as Loretta Lynn's backing band (which she christened the Do Whaters) on her stately comeback album
column10: <em.van lear=""Lear"" rose=""Rose"">
column11: produced by friend-of-the-band Jack White. Even though the moment has passed them by
column12: the Greenhornes are sticking to their guns and insisting their influences are timeless.

column1: Their new EP
column2: East Grand Blues
column3: expands their repertoire considerably
column4: thanks to producer and White collaborator Brendan Benson
column5: who polishes and sophisticates the Greenhornes' sound. Whereas their previous material was blisteringly raw and rowdy
column6: these five songs prove much cleaner and more studied
column7: hinting at a slightly different approach and a radically different direction. Parts of the EP sound invigorated by the change and exhibit the trio's range
column8: but this new tack has its drawbacks. East Grand Blues begins with its most lackluster tracks: ""I'm Going Away"" sets dreamy harmonies to a Roger McGuinn guitar theme but seems lifeless
column9: and ""Shelter of Your Arms"" perks up only for Craig Fox's insistent ""Don't walk away!"" on the chorus. The Greenhornes sound subdued and
column10: worse
column11: dull
column12: especially compared to their previous material.

column1: Fortunately
column2: on the EP's third track
column3: the band shows more of its cards
column4: recapturing and fine-tuning the heady momentum and rarified nostalgia the band is known for. ""At Night"" sets a tense Kinks-y verse against a darkly psychedelic chorus that's drenched in paisley organ swirls
column5: and yet for all Benson's pristine production
column6: the song sounds completely off the cuff-- simple
column7: yet spontaneous. Building on that foundation
column8: ""Pattern Skies"" rides Craig Fox's Creation-inspired guitar riff and Jack Lawrence's percolating basslines. Wood-block percussion keeps time on the closer
column9: ""Shine Like the Sun
column10: as Fox sings one of the band's best melodies
column11: a short series of ascending phrases that's beguiling in its straightforwardness. These songs point to a further refinement of the band's sound on albums to come
column12: but it's hard not to think that East Grand Blues would come across much better in a different context-- say
column13: three or four years ago. Despite their best efforts
column14:
the EP sound twice dated: reminiscent of a decade long past and recalling a revival that's a few years gone.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/2479/homepage_large.cfd534ae.jpg|No Direction Home: The Soundtrack: The Bootleg Series Vol. 7|1177.0|Bob Dylan|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2005-09-05 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:54:53.349017|"

In his 2004 memoir Chronicles
column2: Bob Dylan writes of his time in Greenwich Village in the early 1960s: ""Down in the Village
column3: nothing seemed wrong. Life was not complex.  Everybody was looking for openings. Some would get 'em and they'd be gone and others never did. Mine was coming
column4: but just not yet."" No Direction Home traces Dylan's career from the summer of 1961 (when Dylan first moved to New York) through the 1966 release of Blonde on Blonde
column5: and doubles as the soundtrack to the Martin Scorsese documentary of the same name
column6: which will be aired on PBS later this month.

column1: Unlike the previous three installments of the Bootleg Series
column2: which captured complete live performances
column3: No Direction Home is a collection of demos
column4: alternate takes
column5: and live recordings
column6: ranging from a barely audible ""When I Got Trouble""
column7: recorded in 1959 by one of Dylan's high school classmates (making it
column8: in all probability
column9: the first original song Dylan ever laid to tape
column10: all strummy guitar and dim
column11: somersaulting blues-vocals) to the raucous
column12: full-band explosion of ""Like a Rolling Stone"" (the infamous ""Judas!"" version
column13: which also appeared on the fourth volume of the Bootleg Series
column14: Live 1966). The songs are laid out chronologically
column15: designed to let listeners see exactly how far Bob Dylan came in six years. 2005 has seen a new glut of Dylan insight
column16: and <em>Chronicles
column17: No Direction Home
column18: and Live at the Gaslight 1962 (a companion piece to No Direction Home
column19: presently available only at your local Starbucks
column20: and sadly worth the stench of burned milk and spilled espresso) are impossibly telling when swallowed together: the end result is a comprehensive glimpse into Dylan-at-21
column21: an oddly detailed examination of a perpetually misunderstood artist.

column1: ""This Land Is Your Land""
column2: recorded in 1961 at New York's Carnegie Chapter Hall (little sister to the famed concert space) is an earnest homage to Dylan's beloved muse Woody Guthrie
column3: growled with endearing conviction. ""This Land"" is followed by a wobbly-voiced ""Song to Woody"" (""I'm singing you this song
column4: but I can't sing enough/ 'Cause there's not many men who've done the things that you've done""); Dylan's unfettered admiration for Guthrie's work is perfectly (and prominently) posed
column5: captured six years before Dylan perched himself on Guthrie's deathbed. Both feature Dylan's early caw and watchful strums
column6: his veneration for Guthrie's politics and practices heartbreakingly rendered.

column1: Dylan has always been an especially convincing protest singer
column2: and given the post-Katrina events of the last week
column3: his heartfelt rendition of ""This Land is Your Land"" is almost too much to take: it may be every Kindergarten class' premier singalong
column4: but ""This Land"" is still one of the most elegant and subversive folk songs ever written. Guthrie's anthem was scribbled in terse response to Irving Berlin's comparably one-sided ""God Bless America
column5: and the song's telling fourth verse (typically censored in service of patriotism) seems just as apt now as it did in 1940: ""One bright sunny morning in the shadow of the steeple/ By the Relief Office I saw my people/ As they stood hungry
column6: I stood there wondering/ If God Blessed America for me."" Appropriately
column7: ""Song to Woody"" features Dylan's response: ""It's sick and it's hungry/ It's tired and it's torn/ It looks like it's dying and its hardly been born/ But hey Woody Guthrie
column8: I know that you know."" Guthrie and Dylan's distress is palpable
column9: thick: Nudge your dial
column10: put CNN on mute
column11: and sob yourself to sleep. (Don't stop when you get to ""Masters of War""
column12: or
column13: worst of all
column14: ""A Hard Rain's A-Gonna Fall"").

column1: An early demo of ""Don't Think Twice
column2: It's Alright"" (sometimes circulated as a part of the Witmark Demos) sees Dylan cawing with atypical prettiness
column3: his guitar nimble and soft. Recorded in Lou Levy's office at Columbia (""I opened my guitar case
column4: took the guitar out and began fingering the strings. Lou had put a microphone on the desk in front of me and plugged the cord into one of the tape recorders
column5: all the while chomping on a big
column6: exotic stogie
column7: Dylan writes)
column8: ""Don't Think Twice"" justifies the purchase price of No Direction Home all on its own: Levy had Dylan recording original songs
column9: which would eventually be transposed into sheet music and offered around to other artists
column10: Brill Building-style. Accordingly
column11: Dylan seems less concerned with perpetuating his own mythology than with capturing the grim soul of the song
column12: and we're rewarded with three and a half minutes of pure
column13: un-smirking
column14: alarmingly honest Dylan (read: three minutes more than usual).

column1: Disc Two features some outstandingly weird studio outtakes
column2: including Take 9 of Highway 61 Revisited's ""Tombstone Blues""
column3: complete with loping fuzztone bass
column4: backing vocals
column5: noodling by guitarist Mike Bloomfield of the Butterfield Band
column6: and Dylan's own giggles. Largely electric
column7: Disc Two also offers a source-tape recording of Dylan's infamous 1965 Newport Folk Festival performance of ""Maggie's Farm""
column8: where he plugged-in
column9: brazenly defaming the acoustic-only preservationists present
column10: most of whom had comprised much of his fanbase (supposedly
column11: Pete Seeger was hovering nervous backstage
column12: muttering to himself and threatening to cut the power lines.) The Newport Folk Festival had long admitted a thorny relationship with amplifiers
column13: even when the music demanded magnification-- festival organizers often stuck howling blues musicians with tiny
column14: whispering stacks
column15: smugly denying their right to wail. Even though Dylan had released the largely electric Bringing It All Back Home earlier that year
column16: ""Maggie's Farm"" was ultimately received with a mixture of limp
column17: knee-jerk applause and wildly dissatisfied boos-- and folk music changed.

column1: No Direction Home is fairly essential listening for Dylan enthusiasts and an interesting history lesson for everyone else. Not only is American politics skewered and forked apart
column2: but one songwriter's artistic evolution is laid out bare. As ever
column3:
Dylan reminds us that there is plenty left to learn.

The Flamin' Groovies were a band out of time.

column1: Formed in 1965
column2: they played lean
column3: hard-driving boogie and had a sharp-cut

column1: stylish image in a San Francisco scene that was more about free love
secondhand clothes
column2: and 28-minute modal jams. That raucous
column3: explosive

column1: version of the band lasted until 1972
column2: when original vocalist Roy Loney left and guitarist Cyril Jordan took the reins
column3: moving them to Britain.

column1: There
column2: they hooked up with roots rocker Dave Edmunds
column3: who produced a session

column1: for them that pointed toward a distinctly different path
column2: one deeply

column1: indebted to the British Invasion sounds that everyone else had moved on
from.
Amongst their Stones-influenced cuts lay two of the most
exquisite power-pop tracks of the 70s
column2: ""You Tore Me Down"" and ""Shake Some

column1: Action""
column2: which gave its title to the album the band made in 1976 after a

column1: lengthy recording hiatus. Shake Some Action was in every sense both a
comeback and a re-invention
column2: and it's been rightly championed by collectors and critics extolling its effortless pop

column1: perfection. If it had been released in 1966
column2: it could have been a smash and

column1: a popular landmark
column2: but a decade later
column3: the Spector-loving sound and

column1: Beatle-loving songcraft (they even covered ""Misery"") sank like a stone in
the marketplace. It would be one thing if the record merely aped an era the
band had spent playing other music
column2: but the Groovies had the songs and

column1: nuanced understanding of the music needed to elevate themselves above
pastiche.
""Shake Some Action"" itself is a minor masterpiece of jangling
harmony-soaked guitar pop
column2: an instantly memorable song that piles wave upon

column1: wave of hooks on a solid backbeat
column2: all wrapped up in big
column3: wet reverb. It's a

column1: classic in every way except one: Almost nobody's heard it. A shame
column2: because

column1: it's just the tip of the iceberg on an album stuffed with great tunes. There
are six covers amongst the 14 tracks
column2: following the blueprint of the

column1: original British Invasion records
column2: and with the exception of ""Sometimes"" and

column1: ""Misery""
column2: the band uses these as their license to revisit their more raucous

column1: rootsรถtheir take on ""St. Louis Blues"" is especially good
column2: though they're not

column1: as convincing on Chuck Berry's ""Don't You Lie to Me""-- their version just
doesn't have the angry bite it needs to succeed.
The band's other originals
column2: mostly penned by Jordan and fellow

column1: singer/guitarist Chris Wilson
column2: range from the majestic ballad ""I Saw Her""-- a

column1: slow
column2: spooky
column3: even operatic track stuffed with the band's best harmonies and

column1: some truly knockout lead guitar-- to the speedy rocker ""Please Please Girl""
(one guess whose early singles it sounds like). ""Teenage Confidential"" is
another magisterial ballad
column2: though it harkens even further back
column3: with the

column1: ring of 50s tear-jerkers and teen idol pop. ""You Tore Me Down"" and ""I Can't
Hide"" are sweeping ear candy with to-die-for melodies and accomplished
solos.
One thing that's striking
column2: considering when the album was released
column3: is its

column1: efficiency and brevity. In an era where five songs in 45 minutes
wasn't uncommon
column2: they jammed 14 into a 36-minute runtime
column3: meaning that the

column1: album is a concentrated sugar bomb. This has lead to some revisionist
positioning of the band as forebears of the punk explosion
column2: but it's a

column1: specious claim at best
column2: even if the Ramones did open for them on a tour of

column1: Europe. The Groovies were simply cut from a completely different cloth.
It's about time this album got a proper reissue treatment in the band's home
country
column2: and the DBK Works people have done a great job putting together an

column1: informative package
column2: though don't come expecting any bonus material
column3: because

column1: there is none-- in fact
column2: it's thought that the extra tapes from the

column1: album sessions were destroyed. Remastering helps
immensely
column2: too
column3: clearing up the sound a great deal over previous CD issues

column1: of the albumรถmy old copy was an Australian import that sounded like garbage.
Remastering can't actually change the production of the record
column2: though
column3: and

column1: if there's any complaint to be had with Shake Some Action
column2: it's that

column1: Edmunds' work at the boards is sometimes too hazyรถhe was recording them like
a harder rock band than they were at that point
column2: and truthfully
column3: a slicker

column1: sound would have helped.
The flawed production
column2: however
column3: does not dim the quality of the album. Shake Some Action is
column4: quite

column1: simply
column2: one of the best guitar pop albums ever made
column3: and its lack of popular

column1: notoriety is more a symptom of its timing than anything else (it's tough not
to think that the band's name made things a little harder
column2: too). Hopefully

column1: having a high-quality version of it readily available will help more people
to hear it. The Groovies made only one more good album (<em>Flamin' Groovies Now!)
column2: before embarking on a confusing series of

column1: relocations and reunions
column2: but Shake Some Action stands as their

column1:
crowning achievement.

June Carter Cash's first-ever retrospective is subtitled Her Life in Music
column3: and rightly so. June began singing with the Carter Family at age 9
column4: when the precocious child was harmonizing on the family signature song
column5: ""Keep on the Sunny Side""
column6: and taking a solo with ""Oh Susannah"" (which she pronounces with an extra syllable-- ""oh Susie Anna""). The first disc in this two-disc set focuses on her early career
column7: with songs performed by the Carter Family and the Carter Sisters and Mother Maybelle alongside solo tracks and duets. As much as it tracks the various lineups that played barn-dances around Appalachia during the 1930s and 1940s
column8: this disc traces June's growing confidence as a singer and comedienne. That confidence is evident on tracks like ""I Guess I Told You Off"" and ""Baby It's Cold Outside""
column9: with Homer & Jethro
column10: and grows through later songs like ""Strange Woman"" and ""Without a Love to Call My Own"".

column1: Admittedly
column2: many of these songs are mere trifles-- short entertainments full of virtuoso picking from her mother and sisters and lots of cornpone humor from June. This is no criticism: These songs are apt showcases for June's gracious wit and robust vocals
column3: and their primary purpose was to rouse all-ages audiences
column4: which makes them part country music
column5: part vaudeville. Heard outside their original live context
column6: these songs lose something essential but still sound complex and amusing
column7: so we can only imagine the impact they had on their original listeners.

column1: June's third husband joins the Carter Family on the first disc's final track
column2: a full version of ""Keep on the Sunny Side""
column3: although Johnny's presence is hinted at on the previous track
column4: ""Ring of Fire""
column5: performed by the Carter Family. Gone are the mariachi horns and the gravity of Johnny's vocals; in this earlier version
column6: a simple drum taps out a two-step rhythm and a chorale of voices testifies to the overwhelming risks of love like a church choir singing a hymn to God-- thankful
column7: yet awed.

column1: According to the second disk of Keep On the Sunny Side
column2: June and Johnny's inevitable collaboration didn't initially pay off. ""Jackson"" still sounds like a barnstormer
column3: but its complex view of a cooling marriage offsets the sentimentality of their duets on Tim Hardin's worst song
column4: ""If I Were a Carpenter""
column5: and Kris Kristofferson's ""The Loving Gift""-- both of which suggest that a woman's ultimate act of love is procreation. Johnny also pops up in the jokey ""Slewfoot""
column6: which
column7: coming so soon after their duets
column8: seems to be exploiting their very public relationship. But really
column9: it's just another vaudeville song like ""Baby
column10: It's Cold Outside""
column11: only this time performed in the studio instead of on the stage.

column1: That distinction is important. Despite its overbearing production
column2: the studio material on the second disk isn't necessarily inferior to her earlier live songs
column3: but it does afford her far fewer opportunities to showcase her outsize personality. Often she inhabits characters-- like the reformed harlot in ""The Shadow of a Lady"" or the woeful gunman in ""East Virginia Blues""-- but never with the liveliness and commitment with which she played Aunt Polly or Little Junie. June needed an audience
column4: her autoharp
column5: and a few agile pickers and fiddlers. But she had her moments in the studio
column6: such as the duet with her husband on ""Far Banks of the River Jordan""
column7: which proves eerily prophetic. And the final three tracks
column8: taken from the last few years of her life
column9: reveal a gritty authority in her aged voice. Keep On the Sunny Side ends with yet another version of the title track
column10: recorded in 2001. At 73 June sings those lyrics with the same determined pluck as she did at 9
column11:
revealing an artist whose hopefulness proved as solid and indefatigable as her voice.

Originally the project of Robert Suchan
column2: Koufax now also boast the former Get-Up Kids' rhythm section
column3: brothers Ryan and Robert Pope
column4: as full-time members. The band claims to mix 70s rock with modern indie and pop
column5: and cite ELO
column6: Supertramp
column7: and Steely Dan as their biggest influences. After hearing Hard Times are in Fashion
column8: I'll grant them this: They have pianos. Opener ""Why Bother At All"" adds an extraneous barrel-boogie piano line to it's jerky new-wave rhythm. ""Back on Forth"" follows
column9: a joyless mid-tempo track where Suchan chokes back lyrics like ""We can go back and forth on this one/ Always in denial/ About a president evidently cheating/ Through that awful smile""
column10: sounding not only smug
column11: but clumsy.

column1: So here's my suggestion: Listen to Hard Times Are in Fashion in reverse. If you want to hear the record Koufax claim to be making
column2: you'll hear it most in closing track ""Colour Us Canadian""
column3: and much more in the album's second half than in its opening songs. ""Canadian"" opens on a sassy piano strut with only a few squaks of single-note guitar
column4: and somehow pulls off the sweeping faux-string keyboards in the chorus without sounding cliched. Suchan's words hint towards Americans lying about their background when traveling abroad to avoid criticism and just try to fit in (""We never bothered to learn anyone else's language...We heard their jokes
column5: and we wanted in""). 70s pop-prog it isn't
column6: but it has one foot firmly in the unhip past and shows personal
column7: relatable insight in its lyrics.

column1: The galloping drums on the penultimate track
column2: ""Her Laughter""
column3: are far more kinetic than Hard Times' opener
column4: and ""A Sad Man's Face"" is another stubbornly catchy piano-driven number. ""Steven James"" crams two or three of the album's best hooks into one song
column5: and Suchan hits upon a charm here that overcomes his range (either cooing or yelping
column6: and mostly the latter).

column1: The following batch of songs-- the woozy march of ""Trouble will Find You"" or the strum-happy ""Five Years of Madness""-- are fine
column2: inoffensive songs
column3: but are stingier with the swagger or melody. ""Get Us Sober"" switches rhythms and instruments so many times
column4: it seems adrift in it's middling tempo. ""Blind Faith""
column5: however
column6: is a well-paced
column7: confident ballad with surprising restraint
column8: given the youthful exuberance on the rest of Hard Times. Its lyrics dip back into shallow political perspective (""The mothers want and need to know/why and where their sons must go"")
column9: but the performance is strong enough to let it slide. ""Isabelle""... well
column10: ""Isabelle"" would make a great closer. Forget those two closing (er
column11: opening) tracks
column12: albums are too long these days anyways. Let that familiar pedal steel guitar finish a record that appropriates the spirit
column13: if not the craft
column14:
of some oft-ignored giants.

column11: Black Rebel Motorcycle Club has opted to regroup and pilfer a new musical spectrum
column12: this time tackling classic American blues
column13: country
column14: and gospel. The trio has traded in their pedals and sneers for slides and acoustics. Guitarist/vocalist Robert Turner has reverted back to his given name
column15: Robert Levon Been (originally changed to distance Been from his father
column16: Michael Been of 1980s rockers the Call). Vago is back
