column1: There may be something awkwardly rote about BRMC's sudden interest in capturing gothic country goo (""Fault Line"" features an extended harmonica solo; T-Bone Burnett cops multiple gratis in the liner notes)
column2: but Howl is still considerably more compelling than the bellowing
column3: Jesus and Mary Chain retreads the band formerly relied on. All the Oasis posturing and NME-drool puddles made it easy to forget that BRMC were actually born in blue-sky California
column4: and their new album title
column5: which groaningly salutes periodic San Francisco-resident Allen Ginsberg
column6: gently reminds listeners of the band's scraggly American roots-- which is appropriate
column7: given all the rising-south thievery BRMC is indulging here for the very first time. The snag is
column8: heartless posturing is still heartless posturing
column9: no matter how sharp the change of scenery: at its best
column10: Howl twists slide guitar and acoustic strums into vaguely convincing neo-Band jams
column11: and at its worst
column12: it sounds like cartoon-Americana (shockingly
column13: unplugging your guitar and cawing about Jesus doesn't make you country.)  Still
column14: it's that tension-- between classic BRMC bluster and squeaky Delta organics-- that makes Howl an unusually interesting record.

column1: Howl is predominantly acoustic
column2: but so sopped with fuzz and echo that it actually manages to sound much bigger than it is. BRMC have hinted at Jack White-ian fetishes before
column3: but Howl is still a remarkable departure for the band
column4: and their trademark druggy dirges are noticeably absent here. ""Devil's Waitin'"" (sort of embarrassingly) mines Johnny Cash's lyrical stash
column5: all Jesus and prison
column6: proclamations about life and the Devil growled over careful acoustic strums and tiny wisps of pedal steel. The song's closing coyote Howls-- bayed gently
column7: with cactus-stuck
column8: old west conviction-- give way to a three-man hum-along
column9: and finally slip into a gospel vocal swell (even the echoes seem to scream ""We're in church!"") Lead single ""Ain't No Easy Way"" is jammed with raucous steel guitar riffs and harmonica canoodling
column10: all country-rock stomp and barn dance fervor. BRMC's natural penchant for the loud and bombastic work well here; surprisingly
column11: ""Ain't No Easy Way"" is a perfectly convincing throwdown
column12: oddly free of awkward contrivances. Much of ""Gospel Song"" is whispered
column13: slipping in and out of thick full-band buzz
column14: plodding on and on but never actually landing anywhere particularly interesting; opener ""Shuffle Your Feet"" starts with an a capella ""Time won't save our souls!"" whine
column15: before slipping into a handclapping
column16: honky-tonk rhythm.

column1: There might be a tiny hint of desperation fueling much of Howl
column2: but ultimately the record is an oddly earnest experiment for BRMC
column3: and once they learn to drop the weird
column4: obligatory signifiers
column5: their new direction may actually prove more fruitful than their last: Cramming together brash rock snottiness with meek country hollers is hardly uncharted territory (not that it matters)
column6:
but BRMC's particular mash-up still makes for a strangely intriguing party.

Drawn Dead is one of a pair of full-length Hair Police albums that arrived virtually simultaneously earlier this year-- the other being the supremely discomfiting Constantly Terrified on Troubleman Unlimited. And though each of these releases offers a unique and valuable entry to the prolific Kentucky/Michigan trio's ever-suppurating noise
column3: for my ticket Drawn Dead is the slightly more compelling of the two. It's almost inarguably Hair Police's most doggedly single-minded release to date
column4: as its four untitled tracks combine to essentially form one continuous ashen flow
column5: an unearthly current that represents the group's most self-assured departure yet from the more punk-centric splatter of earlier releases like 2002's Blow Out Your Blood.

column1: Recorded live with no overdubs
column2: Drawn Dead pitilessly captures a doomed sonic wreckage that Hair Police have succinctly described as ""the sound of a burning human body."" Though performed by the trio's regular line-up of Mike Connelly (Wolf Eyes)
column3: Trevor Tremaine
column4: and Robert Beatty
column5: the instrumental line-up here is unorthodox even by the group's nebulous standards. Without a true percussive in sight
column6: drummer Tremaine joins Connelly on guitar and occasional vocals
column7: while Beatty manipulates the proceedings electronically in real-time.

column1: But the description of their process or set-up alone does little to prepare the listener for the album's patiently devised ambient crawl
column2: since few of these generated drones and scrapes originate from easily pinpointed sources. Instead
column3: in a manner reminiscent of Merzbow's grainiest abstractions
column4: the group's various thrums here frequently coalesce into a single unified black-lit beam that sweeps scythe-like across the countryside
column5: mowing everything in its trajectory down at the ankles.

column1: Viewed from a safe distance
column2: the surfaces of Drawn Dead can appear almost lifelessly monolithic and static
column3: but upon closer investigation one can see that these tracks actually teem with movement and action. Over the course of the album's first two tracks
column4: mud-caked walls of feedback and crackling distortion build
column5: then collapse
column6: then build again
column7: while unsettling echoes
column8: pauses
column9: and stereo-panning techniques ensure perpetual listener disorientation. And just as you're beginning to get a feel for this murky new habitat
column10: the 11-minute third track enters
column11: raining shrieks of industrial detritus and disembodied spectral cries over the sickly
column12: low-lying amplifier growls
column13: before the brief finale sets everything spinning off in the undertow of its dark tide. It's an impressive performance in its own right
column14: but when taken in conjunction with <em>Constantly Terrified it signals that Hair Police are open for engagement with any mutated extremity of noise that crosses their collective snares
column15:
making their future possible directions seem virtually limitless.

When The Unseen was released in 2000 as the solo debut from Lootpack MC/producer Madlib
column2: no one could have known that it would be just the first album in an arm's-length discography that would cover everything from live jazz to Doom and Dilla collaborations
column3: mostly to gushing critical acclaim. At the time
column4: it was simply a quirky leftfield hip-hop record by a guy who burned grass like a wildfire and lived in Peanut Butter Wolf's basement-- like literally lived in the basement studio known as the Bomb Shelter. No one knew that Madlib preferred the solitude of the studio to pretty much anything else and that records flowed from his mind and sampler at a dizzying pace. Now
column5: thanks to endless profiles and album reviews
column6: we know
column7: and it makes The Unseen even more interesting.

column1: What once seemed a crafty producer's gimmick now sounds more like the imaginary friend of a shy dude who needed someone to talk to in the studio while he chain-smoked blunts. Reefer Madness? Probably
column2: but wildly entertaining
column3: as well
column4: imagining Madlib sitting in a basement making songs all day everyday and getting so bored with himself that he finds a way to put a pig-nosed yellow hippo on record. And most of what he says under that persona is crazy shit
column5: outlandish
column6: hilarious fiction. Exactly what everyone stands around thinking about when he's got a helium balloon pinched in his fingers is what comes out of Lord Quas' mouth. We all know profanity is crass
column7: violence a nuisance
column8: and misogyny quite boring
column9: but dude
column10: his voice sounds funny when he says it.  Whether it's the grandiose self-shout-outs
column11: ludicrous threats
column12: or adolescent come-ons
column13: Quas is Webster with pimp juice while Madlib leans on the wall
column14: mumbling affirmations and encouragement
column15: and if you want to justify the content to your stuffy friends just tell them the pitch-shifted vocals are Madlib's commentary on the mental immaturity and irresponsibility of typical hip-hop subject matter.

column1: Of course
column2: the main attraction of any Madlib record is his production
column3: and The Unseen holds up particularly well because Madlib hasn't changed this particular strain of his beatmaking all that much. Instead of tinkering with his style
column4: he creates a new one. When he wanted to do some live jazz
column5: he did Yesterday's New Quintet. Street bangers went to the Jaylib album. Pop remixes
column6: reggae mixtapes
column7: instrumental 12""s
column8: nothing stays on paper with Madlib. So anyone who slobbered over Madvillainy or The Further Adventures of Lord Quas won't be disappointed by the now five-year-old production
column9: nor should they skip Lootpack's Soundpieces or MED's Push Comes to Shove. If anything
column10: The Unseen is a better ""album"" than Further Adventures because the compositions are more fleshed-out
column11: more cohesive and
column12: well
column13: more. Madlib has a short attention span
column14: but he kept most of the songs to almost three minutes here without much junk. The jazz and soul samples are as obscure and well-selected as ever
column15: with Madlib's particular style of chopping a drum sample keeping the beat from becoming a bore. The skits and interludes play to the mood
column16: and the seamless transitions
column17: which usually include a bonus beat or two
column18: echo the give 'em more of DJ Premier of Gang Starr.

column1: I can't say for sure why The Unseen is being re-released
column2: other than Madlib didn't a have another record ready this month. It's a nice treat for the Serato kids to have the full instrumentals on one CD
column3: which is included. And if there's anything to be learned from George Lucas
column4: it's that trusting the public to remember how awesome you are is a fool's paradise. Legacies are constructed
column5: and with the new Quasimoto album still on the New Release wall
column6: it doesn't hurt Madlib or Stones Throw to jog some memories. I'm sure Quas would say
column7: ""Buy my shit
column8: or I'll cut your head off and smoke green out your socketholes
column9:
or something to that effect.

I should probably like this more than I actually do. Who doesn't want to get behind Alison Goldfrapp and company? She's nothing if not on the ball
column3: having transformed herself from elegant mid-90s Orbital cooer to elegant late-90s spook to an equally timely role-- something like a cross between Kylie Minogue and PJ Harvey
column4: between Annie and Siouxsie Sioux
column5: between Rachel Stevens and Beth Gibbons
column6: the evil-twin model of the shimmery dancefloor princess-bot. And Supernature kicks off with that flag flying high
column7: on ""Ooh La La"": some hard schaffel
column8: some hand-clapping glam-rock stomp
column9: some dangerously icy taunting
column10: and enough Germanic electro-house action to make you want to drop it like it's cold
column11: ruthlessly efficient
column12: and strangely angular. Why do I have a sick suspicion that this is how awesome Peaches thinks she sounds?

column1: So I do half-go for it
column2: from that first rush of ice to the veins to the dots of old-model cabaret spook that crop up later
column3: and from there through the buzz and pulse of the inbetween. Witchy English vibes
column4: analog synth surgery
column5: superhuman icy-vulnerable vocals
column6: and production that sounds alternately like high-polish chrome and a sucking black hole: What more do I usually ask for?

column1: Well
column2: something
column3: obviously
column4: because somewhere along the line I lose it. Maybe it's the part where Alison wants to ""ride on a white horse
column5: though I suppose there's both a half-decent hero/heroin joke and a T. Rex reference in there. Maybe it's the part where I remember that I have Gary Numan and Siouxsie albums I still haven't listened to it enough. Or maybe it's just the peculiar plaint of the electro dance-pop full-length: the sound of those mid-tempo album-completing tracks. They're effortlessly organized
column6: full of so much dense trebly shimmer and helium swooning and sighing that you actually zone out and stop hearing them
column7: right up until you realize your ears hurt a little from taking it all in. They're loads of effort poured into a product that winds up sounding like nothing in particular
column8: immaculate synth arrangements not quite making up for the fact that the song will neither bang and swell nor relax into a dreamy lull. If Alison were Kylie
column9: she could at least spice things up by switching modes-- sunny here
column10: earnest here
column11: then back to machine-tooled intimidation. Alison
column12: being Alison
column13: has to stay all witchy all the time.

column1: And there's the non-shocker: This is sure to sound better in the variegated sweep of a good DJ mix-- something that's not
column2: given the present currency of ""electro-house
column3: so difficult to come across. The bangers here will sound fab on the pop ends of said mixes
column4: ""Ooh La La"" owning all. The tracks that lapse back into Goldfrapp's old <em>Felt Mountain electronic-chanteuse mold will sound fine in your apartment. (""U Never Know"" and ""Let it Take You"" make a gorgeous break from the ultra-dense buzz
column5: getting progressively softer
column6: silkier
column7: and more minimal.) But plenty of these tracks keep feeling like exercises: too thick and melodic to work like dance music
column8: but with melodies that refuse to stick as satisfyingly as pop.

column1: Which makes this pretty much what you'd expect: the prime-time flagship of glammy electroid dancefloor pop
column2: curiously expensive-sounding and accessible to all
column3: but strangely stripped of the functionalism of the dance record and the full thrills of pop. Sometimes that lands it in the sweet spot. Just as often
column4: though
column5:
it seems to have forgotten what in the world it was meant to offer in the first place.

column3: the members of Providence
column4: R.I.'s the White Mice
column5: who go by the names Anonymouse
column6: Euronymouse
column7: and Mousferatu
column8: wear mouse masks and bloodied clothes
column9: giving off the appearance of a lab experiment gone horribly awry. Most of their pun-filled song titles are mouse-related-- either dealing with cheese
column10: traps
column11: or the rodents themselves. If it weren't for the disturbing barrage of noise on ASSPhIXXXEATATESHUN
column12: the whole thing might come off as either oddly cute
column13: blandly gimmicky
column14: or as some sort of PETA protest. But the only things the White Mice seem to be protesting are good taste
column15: traditional song structure
column16: and anything remotely resembling a melody.

column1: The noise-metal miscreants use drums
column2: bass
column3: and an oscillator to create a gloriously god-awful racket. Most of the songs clock in at around two minutes and follow the grindcore style of relentlessly bludgeoning the listener over the head with brutal drums and distorted-beyond-recognition instruments. The vocals
column4: which are buried in the mix
column5: seem to consist primarily of howls and wails
column6: at times so seamlessly blending with the squealing feedback that it's difficult to tell there's a human behind them.

column1: The songs that come closest to having a structure are the longer ones
column2: comparatively speaking. ""Limburger Baby"" spends an echoing minute building up a spacey
column3: sci-fi atmosphere before busting wide open into a full-on assault. ""Mouse Trap"" begins with swirling oscillator tones leading into a jerky rhythm that plays out for the bulk of the song. The title can even been heard over and over beneath the horror of alarm-clock buzz and booming bass guitar. Similarly
column4: ""Slo Poison"" suits its name
column5: creeping through three-and-a-half minutes of sludge as if it's slowly shutting down your nervous system.

column1: While everything on the disc could certainly qualify as noise
column2: there are several tracks that wear that label more obviously than others. Opener ""Foreskin Rug"" utilizes sliced-and-diced rushes of buzz-saw tones on top of slo-mo rumble. ""Dieorhearama"" picks up this theme nine songs later and adds the swoosh of back-masked drums and squealing feedback on top.

column1: The disc's final track is ""Microjackass""
column2: which spans almost 50 minutes (over twice the length of the other 10 tracks combined). Over its first four minutes the song builds in speed and intensity before fading to static; by minute five
column3: silence has set in. It's not until 43 minutes later that we get the final burst: a quick blast of a repeating drum and bass beat
column4: ringing oscillator tones
column5: and a telephone operator delivering a voice-mail message. While it's been a common gag since the early 90s to include a bonus track at the tail end of a CD
column6: forcing the listener to wear out the fast-forward button accessing the track
column7: it seems here that the silence is a part of the song. The White Mice want you to think you've escaped harm
column8: and at the last conceivable moment
column9:
the trap snaps down on your neck.

It's just what it sounds like: A track-by-track remix of Bloc Party's awfully solid debut
column3: as executed by a selection of reasonably big names and reasonably reliable artists. On the other hand
column4: it's not at all what it sounds like: It's actually really good. Surprisingly good
column5: and surprisingly often-- good enough that I spent half of my first listen wondering if I was really going to wind up giving it a better rating than the original. Weird
column6: right?

column1: Maybe I shouldn't act so shocked. It's just that something's gone wrong with the rhetoric around the word ""dance"" lately. Suddenly it's considered perfectly normal to say any given uptempo guitar band from north of the English Channel is some kind of ""dance"" group
column2: something that just isn't true according to anything but mid-sixties standards. (""Hey look
column3: it's popular dance combo the Dave Clarke Five!"") Bloc Party may have a pretty good rhythm section
column4: but that doesn't exactly make them Masters at Work
column5: does it? But wouldn't you expect the fashion of the day to dictate that their occasional hustles get remixed and extended out into a series of faux bangers
column6: something to throw on when the club's mysteriously overrun with indie kids and you need a cheap way to get them on the floor?

column1: And here's the trick: The best of these remixes don't even dream of that. The best of these remixes use beats as not much more than a grid around which to reorganize the raw sounds of the original tracks-- a frame around which to tweak the sound of Bloc Party into something a little more fractured and abstract. It's Sheriff Whitey's mix of ""Helicopter"" that seals the deal. Instead of the sound of Bloc Party lushed up and given groove
column2: we get the sound of some alternate-world Bloc Party
column3: one that's more interested in rocking spare and spindly
column4: like Wire
column5: than their usual habits of scripting professional-sounding twists and turns. When I reviewed <em>Silent Alarm
column6: I said that being a good ol' unchallenging rock band was this group's biggest strength; for the length of this mix
column7: it sounds like they've traded in a little of the ""ol'"" and the ""unchallenging."" For a few stretches of tracks
column8: it's a best-case scenario: all of the hot performances and satisfying hooks without the slight aftertaste of plain-old-band boredom.

column1: So it's really only a lull in the middle that keeps it from topping the original
column2: and even that gets redeemed fairly quickly. A surprisingly-limp Erol Alkan mix gets followed up by what might be the best thing here: Dave P. and Adam Sparkles making a sunny 80s number out of ""This Modern Love""
column3: complete with handclaps and some synths at the end that leave the whole thing feeling like the Cure jamming out on ""Just Like Heaven"". (Nick Zinner of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs leaves ""Compliments"" sounding like a whole other Cure
column4: actually.) It's the same trick again-- it sounds like something some bizarro version of the group might actually play
column5: if they'd just chill out for a second and stop trying to be so damned grand.

column1: Surprise: It's all a good fit with the sound of the original. right?

column3: and ""Rock and Roll Can't Save Your Life""

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/8415/homepage_large.851cb265.jpg|Freedom and Weep|4540.0|Waco Brothers|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bloodshot']|2005-08-29 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:55:06.337455|"

As the grim smirk of its title implies
column2: Freedom and Weep finds Jon Langford and the Waco Brothers-- now rather unbelievably 10 years and seven albums into the game-- in a cranky
column3: dispirited frame of mind. Though outwardly the group's foursquare
column4: whiskey-soaked country-rock remains as wry and ornery as ever
column5: on many of these tracks a distinctive air of bitter
column6: spiteful resignation has crept in
column7: leaving the album with a depressive
column8: hungover pallor around its gills. And while by this point one could never question the Brothers' zealous devotion to their cause
column9: nor their unimpeachable talents as a riotous live act
column10: one can't help but wish that their righteous anger more frequently translated itself into similarly fiery
column11: unrestrained abandon in the recording studio.

column1: For their first album since 2002's <em>New Deal
column2: the Waco Bros. have scaled back on their twang slightly-- and on the vestiges of actual punk almost completely-- and have now cozily settled into a tempered Crazy Horse/Skynyrd mid-range classicism. Early in the group's career the Wacos were often perceived as merely another of Jon Langford's numerous side projects away from the Mekons-- and rather a play-acting novelty at that. But they've long since matured into a true
column3: fully democratic band
column4: and here Langford splits microphone time with guitarist Deano as well as mandolinist Tracy Dear. Performances are stout if generally uneventful throughout
column5: and often it's the tasteful pedal steel contributions of Mark Durante (formerly of Revolting Cocks and KMFDM) and the relentless pummel of drummer Steve Goulding (who's played with everyone from Graham Parker and Elvis Costello to Archer Prewitt) that rescue these tracks from their most hidebound roadhouse tendencies.

column1: ""What if our history means nothing at all?"" worries Deano on the opening blue-collar lament ""Nothing At All""
column2: a Son Voltish scorcher that immediately (if unsurprisingly) reestablishes the Wacos' alignment with the woebegotton
column3: put-upon underdog. This can't-win-for-losing stance leads the band quite naturally to the election night blues of ""The Rest of the World""
column4: (""Champagne's still on ice/ Might as well down it tonight/ It ain't going to last four more years/ Nor are your rights
column5: ) as well as to Langford's exquisitely vindictive Bush diatribe ""Chosen One"".

column1: On the well-titled ""Drinkin' & Cheatin' and Death""
column2: Langford returns another of his favorite barn-sized targets-- commercial Nashville country. Over the album's best woozy hook he drops the newsflash ""Country radio lost its balls/ And started selling fantasy/ No drinking
column3: no killing and the only divorce is from reality
column4: tidily bringing up-to-date those listeners who've been comatose or otherwise out-of-pocket for the past couple decades. Elsewhere
column5: the Brothers direct barbs at reality TV (""Fantasy"")
column6: crass materialism (""Lincoln Town Car"")
column7: and Intelligent Design (""Missing Link"") with varying degrees of wit and subtlety
column8: but unfortunately the band's staunch musical conservatism ensures that none of these tracks ever ventures far from the predictable. Freedom and Weep culminates with the raucous
column9: misery-loves-company anthem ""Join the Club""
column10:
an appropriately cheerless finale for what's arguably the Waco Brothers' most accomplished but least fun album to date.

Cowboy Junkies formed 20 years ago; this is their 10th proper album
in addition to a number of live recordings and odds-and-ends
collections. They amassed this much material without a break
column2: steadily

column1: releasing records and touring since the still-great The Trinity Sessions
put them on the map in 1988. The band also retains a solid base of fans devoted to its distinctive countrified folk-pop.
Early 21st Century Blues-- released on the band's own label-- is a concept album
column2: the subject matter of which

column1: you can probably guess from the peace sign painting on the cover. At the start of the year the band members met to discuss ideas for songs that addressed
current political issues-- war
violence
column2: greed
column3: and so on. Over a few days they recorded nine covers

column1: and two Michael Timmons originals. Cowboy Junkies have always been
skilled at absorbing the songs of others into their aesthetic
column2: and for

column1: the most part this album flows like a collection of originals written to
a theme.
This is the record's biggest plus
column2: the way Cowboy Junkies still

column1: evoke a convincing mood of deliberate contemplation. The flawless
diction of singer Margo Timmins keeps the lyrics in the foreground
column2: each

column1: line clear and plain as the spare
column2: subtle musical backing. The band's

column1: long stream of Bruce Springsteen covers continues with ""Brothers Under the
Bridge"" and ""You're Missing""
column2: both of which sound great in this

column1: environment. At their best
column2: they can help you find new things in old

column1: songs. Turns out Bob Dylan's ""License to Kill"" from Infidels actually has a
gorgeous melody wrapped around the cryptic and evocative lyrics.
Still
column2: although there will always be certain comfort in Margo Timmins'

column1: voice
column2: her limitations are frustrating. She can certainly

column1: deliver a song and make you hear the craft that went into its
creation
column2: but she never really inhabits one. She's never done

column1: abandon and has always preferred being a conduit for a songwriter to
imparting her own personality. So the more familiar the song is
column2: or the

column1: more the arrangement and production is pushed to the background
column2: the

column1: less interesting the track becomes. Contrast Cowboy Junkies' plodding
take here on George Harrison's ""Isn't It a Pity"" with Galaxie 500's
untethered cover from On Fire. When we hear U2's ""One"" we can appreciate
the song's mighty chords but never feel that sense of elevation. And
then there's the cover of ""I Don't Want to Be a Solider""
column2: which augments John

column1: Lennon's verses with fresh new rhymes from guest rapper Rebel. It's not
as bad as ""guest rap on a Cowboy Junkies album"" would lead you to
believe
column2: but it's a misstep from a band that's done a surprisingly good

column1:
job avoiding them.

""Can I talk my shit again?""

Contrary to popular opinion
column3: hubris does have a righteous appeal. Those who claim Kanye West's antics hinder his work are missing the point. His self-importance is obvious
column4: but the arrogance that comes pre-packaged with his insecurity is what makes West the most interesting hip-hop figure of the past five years. That's the reason he landed on ""Oprah"" and the cover of Time Magazine last week
column5:
rather than 50 Cent or Nelly or Slug. It's not sales; it's souls.

That said
column6: at the end of the day
column7: it's his ear
column8: a golden instrument
column9: and his adventurous collaborative spirit that have made him the most fully formed artist of his genre. The sprawling Late Registration is the year's most accomplished rap album
column10: and in turn
column11: he's done something that his heroes-- the Pharcyde and Nas
column12: and father figure Jay-Z-- couldn't do: deliver on a promise the second time around.  With the help of co-producer Jon Brion
column13: West has taken his jumbled personae
column14: buoyant enthusiasm
column15: and vision for the grandiose
column16: and transformed his chattering
column17: seemingly unrealistic ideas into an expansive
column18:
imperfect masterpiece.

Without Brion
column19: this album probably sounds a lot like its predecessor
column20: The College Dropout-- full of tough horns
column21: jacked soul
column22: and flashes of brilliance. What the former Fiona Apple maestro brings to the proceedings
column23: aside from a conductor's wand and a smile
column24: is the ability to inflate and infuse West's ideas with even more life.  A case in point is ""Hey Mama""
column25: a track that leaked more than a year ago. The song is traditionally purty
column26: dominated by handclaps and a flittering sample of Donal Leace's ""Today Won't Come Again""; basically a trad-Kanye production. The Brion redux inserts a moaning vocoder
column30:
all without mucking up the heart in the middle.

Flashes like this surround the sometimes urbane
column31: often cheeky West with a new resonance.  Where would ""Crack Music""
column33: be without its soaring choir and biblically extended outro?  Probably somewhere on the Game's album.  Could Kanye have single-handedly fused the showboating old school boom bap of ""We Major"" with its build-it-up and watch it all fall down production without Brion or co-producer Waryn Campbell?  Not likely.  By opening the studio to admired colleagues
column34:
he's allowed himself room to think even bigger than the multi-tracked ""Jesus Walks"".

On the mic
column35: West sounds sharper and more battle-tested
column36: though he'll never have the effortless insouciance of Jigga or teeth-gritting religiosity of Nas.  To his credit and detriment he continues to surround himself with superior MCs like Common (on the sober ""My Way Home"")
column37: impressive newcomer Lupe Fiasco (Just Blaze's life-affirming ""Touch the Sky"")
column39: who continues his magical run with savant-like witticisms on ""Gone"".  Even Houston's Paul Wall manages to fit ""illuminate
column41: and ""caterpillar"" into 16 bizarre bars on the woozy ""Drive Slow"".  All this to go along with curious shouts from two conflicted giants
column43:
who hang like specters over the album.

Unlike the ""great"" hip-hop releases of yore
column44: the productions here are so insistent that even a charismatic voice like West's can become an afterthought.  Only ""Roses"" delivers the endearing sentimentality of ""Jesus Walks"" or ""Family Business"".  ""Diamonds From Sierra Leone (Remix)"" offers some admirable if dubious political grandstanding
column45: but as with every colossal undertaking
column46: you gotta pay the cost to be the boss.  The album's worst track
column49: courtesy of Brion. It also presumes that anyone still cares about Brandy
column50: who sounds like she's recording her voice through a Cuisinart. ""Celebration""
column56: and a few innocuous if unnecessary skits about a fraternity for the financially impaired called Broke Phi Broke
column57: the rest is aces.  ""Addiction"" is unsophisticated in concept but inspired in delivery.  ""Gold Digger"" is also simple but not subtle
column58: tearing into the realm of the obvious with a Ray Charles-aping Jamie Foxx and recycled drums
column59: but succeeding with humor and reverence. Opener ""Heard 'Em Say"" might be the most bandied about joint here
column60: thanks to the presence of Maroon 5's Adam Levine
column61: but guess what?  He sounds great.  Off-key and blue-eyed selling his soul
column62: but like nearly every risk here
column63:
the syrupy pop works.

""We all self-conscious"" has not taken on a new meaning post-Dropout. Conjecture about West revolutionizing the sound of modern hip-hop is mostly a fallacy. Not much has changed
column64: though a few Brion hacks might appear to offer someone like Cassidy an oboe loop or two.  In general
column65: what makes West's sound and personality so vital is that it is completely singular. The maddening contradiction
column67:
and the furious fist-raising still comprise an original voice. Though you'll notice I hesitate to use the phrase ""everyman"" to describe West. Not every man could have written a headphones album that'll rattle your trunk.

It's been weird to see people try to puff up A Certain Ratio in the last few years
column4: to make them more than they ever were during their lifetime. On the     one hand
column5: it's just a side effect of post-punk necrophilia; at some point
column6: on or around August 2003
column7: any remaining good (just good!) post-punk bands     had finally been exhumed
column8: renovated
column9: rehabilitated
column10: whatever. That's two     years now of chasing up the lesser lights
column11: dodgy one-shots
column12: side-projects and general jerk-offery. C'mon-- those Brazilian p-punk comps are bad Cure demos with a tropical frosting.

column1: Yes
column2: I know the Early comp came out in March 2002. Let's just say ACR was ahead of the crap curve. The facts remain: Simon Topping still sounds like Ian Curtis Cliff's Notes. The purported funkiness will still not be backing up any asses. Their name is just more lamentable Factory Nazi-chic. And there's very little ACR did that someone (Joy Division
column3: the Cure
column4: Liquid Liquid
column5: Funkadelic
column6: your     mom) didn't do better. This is not to say they didn't have their charms. The     double EP that contained ""Do The Du""
column7: ""The Fox""
column8: their (overrated but still     pretty funny) cover of ""Shack Up""
column9: and ""Flight"" is good fun if you enjoy     mooning with the blinds closed to twitchy approximations of forward     momentum. (And hey
column10: sometimes
column11: who doesn't?)

column1: But when they started fucking with jazz
column2: Latin
column3: electro
column4: disco-- check
column5: pleez.     This is not some sort of inverse pop-snobbery talking. This is a purely     functionalist argument. By 1982
column6: the disco tradition was just that: a     tradition
column7: one where all-night
column8: non-stop dancing was the rule of law. Plenty     of other cultures had been fucking with this for years
column9: and it showed up in     things like northern soul. Even when they tried to bodyrock
column10: ACR were still hampered by their stiffness and leftover gloom. (Let's not even get into the inherent racism in the fallback ""but they had a black guy drumming for them!"" argument. Rhythm != drumming.)

column1: I'd Like To See You Again was a swiftly recorded follow up to Sextet (the only ACR release of note after the early singles and half of The Graveyard and the Ballroom and even that's pushing its essentialness). Martha Tilson's proto-trip-hop vocals on Sextet were at least pleasing to the ear
column2: if still     essentially ballast
column3: but here they're gone. So the band goes for longer     grooves
column4: more instrumental passages
column5: and fewer vocals. I'd call it smart if     the music were better. ""Touch"" acknowledges the new pop that ruled '82
column6: but refuses to deal with it head on. ""Showcase"" has slap bass (slap bass). They throw party whistles and P-Funk backup chants on ""Saturn""
column7: and fair play
column8: they're at least trying to     have fun. But Martin Moscrop's trumpet
column9: once the source of an amusing kind     of fake electric-Miles fog (one thing they had that JD didn't)
column10: just sounds anodyne here. If you listen closely you can hear the beige Howard Jones records they would soon be making.

column1: A year later
column2: of course
column3: New Order     released one of the biggest 12"" singles in history
column4: tore up NYC clubs like     the Funhouse
column5: and permanently shook the Joy Division out of their hair. They     even got to retain a slight creatures-of-the-night aftertaste that ACR were     desperately distancing themselves from. All in all
column6: ACR must have been pretty pissed off.

column1: Live 1980 was from a show recorded after their fateful trip to the U.S.
column2: where they recorded their debut album
column3: To Each
column4: with Martin Hannett (which     means it sounds exactly how you think it sounds) and had their wigs flipped     by the hustle and bustle of early 80s NYC. And it shows
column5: with a sound that     has the tension between their sketchy raincoat beginnings and the good foot     already breaking down. They're already straining to breath some of that     American air
column6: to suck up that mythical fonk
column7: to banish the sooty taint of     their homelands. Which pretty well killed them as a band. To make matters     worse they avoid their hits in favor of album tracks
column8: and then decide to do     realt-time extended remixes
column9: with lotsa percussion. The reissue includes two     bonus tracks. If that excites you
column10: check your pulse.

column1: All this is not to say I didn't enjoy parts
column2: sometimes even large parts
column3: of     both records. But I can't imagine ever listening to them again. The problem     with reissue culture
column4: like real archaeology
column5: is that eventually you're just     hitting dirt. Sometimes an arrowhead is just a rock
column6: you know? We all have     finite time on this planet; do you want to listen to fake Funkadelic or the     real thing? Ready your angry emails and dismissive blog posts if you must
column7: but just think about it the next time your survey your gigs of mp3s
column8: stacks     of CD-R's
column9:
or mounds of .99 vinyl. How are you using your time?

column2: Year of Meteors
column3: will sound familiar to listeners
column4: newcomers and old fans alike. Her voice recalls Liz Phair without the accusations
column5: and like Patti Smith
column6: she comes off like a poet first and a singer second
column7: although with a much more MFA-friendly style and without the rock-priestess performance. Her songs indulge flights of verbal fancy
column8: like Ben Gibbard but less unctuous. And Veirs is routinely compared to Suzanne Vega for the dryness of her delivery and to Beth Orton for the way she melds folk rock with dance sonics. There is
column9: however
column10: the vague sense on Year of Meteors that she is trying to distinguish herself from these comparisons and even from her previous album
column11: last year's Carbon Glaciers
column12: a breakthrough in Europe and a cult favorite in America. Leaving behind that release's barebones sound
column13: Veirs recorded Year of Meteors with her touring band
column14: the Tortured Souls
column15: which includes bassist Karl Blau
column16: keyboard player Steve Moore
column17: and percussionist/producer Tucker Martine. The result is a fuller sound that
column18: for better or worse
column19: is less like the work of a solitary musician and more like a collaborative effort.

column1: These essentially spare songs have been dressed up with full-band arrangements and treatments that employ glittery electronic effects intended both to offset the organic acoustics and to set Veirs apart from every other female with a guitar. Often these additions work well within the songs: the band propels ""Secret Someones"" and ""Rialto"" with pop-song momentum
column2: and Eyvind Kang's strings on ""Fire Snakes"" and ""Parisian Dream"" perfectly compliment Veirs's dreamy lyrics. But often
column3: as on ""Galaxies"" and ""Through the Glow""
column4: these treatments sound entirely superfluous
column5: diluting the potent simplicity of Veirs's understated performance.

column1: Besides
column2: Veirs needs no further distinction: despite the justifiable comparisons with artists past and present
column3: she has developed a musical style that is maybe not groundbreaking
column4: but is at least highly personal and distinctively expressive. Lyrically
column5: her songs make abstractions concrete and conjure eerie images and strange associations
column6: some of which belie her background as a geology student. The standout ""Spelunking"" develops an elaborate metaphor that connects subterranean exploration with romantic commitment: ""If I took you
column7: darling/ to the caverns of my heart/ would you light the lamp
column8: dear?"" she asks
column9: before describing the denizens of the darkness-- ""fish without eyes
column10: bats with their heads/hanging down towards the ground."" Veirs confronts everyday subjects with the same imaginativeness and eye for detail: on ""Secret Someones"" she addresses the loneliness of touring: ""O a smile would melt me to an asphalt strip
column11: she sings before asking in the bridge
column12: ""tell me
column13: did you make it to the show?""

column1: Lyrics reproduced outside of their songs can often sound flat or pretentious
column2: and the words above desperately need Veirs's intonations to achieve their full effect; merely typing them or reading them won't do. For all the decorousness of her music and songs
column3: it's her voice-- usually charmingly flat
column4: precisely overenunciating
column5: and gently assertive-- that conveys the deepest sense of wonder and truly sells these songs. Veirs really doesn't need much in the way of accompaniment: the primary components of her music are voice and guitar. If Year of Meteors feels a little too busy and overworked
column6: so what? Veirs is maybe the gazillionth iteration of the quiet voice and plucked guitar
column7:
but she serves as a potent reminder how variable and compelling that combination can be.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/3643/homepage_large.6754d5f1.jpg|The Moon Is a Dead World|1856.0|Gospel|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Level Plane']|2005-08-28 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:55:10.030375|"

Let's face it: Prog has never been cool. Your first guitar teacher
column2: the one with the Yes shirt
column3: was not cool. The kid I knew who worshipped Neil Peart
column4: and had a license plate that read ""DRUMGUY"" was not cool. And no matter how much you may love Genesis
column5: that won't erase the fact that Peter Gabriel eventually left Phil Collins in charge. On the other hand
column6: Gospel are cool. Cool enough to get approval from the white-studded belt
column7: sideways trucker hat
column8: back pocket bandana crowd
column9: and the unadorned (and girlfriendless) music geek crowd.

column1: What makes Gospel so cool? It could be the patchwork of functional King Crimson via Converge riffs
column2: sprayed out drum work that's reminiscent of Damon Che of Don Caballero fame at his drunkest
column3: and Dazzling Killmen-esque guttural yells. Then again
column4: it could just be that the band sprawls out on a nice medium ground between math-rock and technical hardcore/metal. It's not a crowded genre as the years have shown that heavy bands with prog influences end up becoming black metal
column5: Dream Theater
column6: Ruins
column7: or a brutal prog era Weasel Walter project.

column1: It's a good thing Gospel have an entertaining drummer: His corrugated beats are the highest item in the mix. We're actually allowed some prominently displayed keyboard work as well
column2: which is abnormal for a non dancepunk album that's fit to be sold at Hot Topic. But how do you get the kids with scene hair to listen to mutant prog? Just make all the tracks hover around the five-minute mark. Cautious? Of course. But the nine-minute ""A Golden Dawn"" proves why this works-- it's by far the poorest song on The Moon. It fails to shimmer and ends up sounding like an outtake from a Trail of Dead practice.

column1: Gospel use the tools of the trade to fix the problems attention deficit listeners (hardcore kids) had with prog. The spiraling arms of the guitar lines and the splotchy drums of ""Yr Electric Surge is Sweet"" bridge the gap between the rage of hardcore and the extensive rehearsal of prog. ""And Redemption Fills the Emptiest of Hearts"" evens manages to inject a perverted version of the most standard of hardcore gimmicks
column2: the breakdown. Sure
column3: they disguise it a little
column4: but not enough to displease the ears of Norma Jean kids
column5: and then they move straight into King Crimson-inspired keyboard and synthed guitar interplay. They even go so far as to make Tool palatable to the underground with the Middle Eastern guitar lines and echoing soundscaped instrumentation of ""Opium"". (I was digging Gospel until they made me reference Tool and lose what little cred I had as a music reviewer.)

column1: Tricking the kids would be shameless if I didn't wallow in Gospel's message. Granted
column2: they're displaying their influences a mite too visibly. Gospel strip down their influences to compensate for many of their favorite band's substituting polish for violent energy. Maybe Gospel are cool because they are smart enough to meld prog with today's updated hardcore. But knowing today's hardcore scene
column3:
maybe Gospel are just cool because Kurt Ballou of Converge recorded their album and Converge make some of the hippest hoodies on the market.

Iron Maiden's importance in the history of rock music can hardly be overstated. The band formed at a time when heavy rock music was becoming old and passรฉ
column3: yet despite little radio play and a refusal to bow to music business demands
column4: they managed to sell out stadiums the world over. Bassist and primary songwriter Steve Harris had a clear vision of what he wanted his band to be from the beginning: His dedication to complex songwriting
column5: rousing
column6: hook-laden choruses
column7: and a powerful stage show put the band head and shoulders above their New Wave of British Heavy Metal counterparts. In fact
column8: now
column9: almost 30 years later
column10: the only other band from that scene who remains relatively well-known is Def Leppard
column11: and they sound radically different today than when they started.

column1: Perusing the Maiden discography reveals as many live and ""greatest hits"" packages as studio records. In 1996
column2: the band released what was expected to be the definitive Maiden hits package: Best of the Beast. Since then
column3: however
column4: we've seen The Best of Iron Maiden
column5: Ed Hunter
column6: Eddie's Head
column7: Edward the Great
column8: and now
column9: finally
column10: The Essential. And this isn't even counting the live albums.

column1: So why
column2: then
column3: do we need another greatest hits package? I'll leave that one to the accountants. It's a discussion that belongs in the same realm as longtime fans arguing over how they could have possibly left off ""Children of the Damned""
column4: ""Where Eagles Dare""
column5: or ""Can I Play with Madness"". But this isn't a for-fans package; instead
column6: The Essential is an two-disc primer on a band that has released 13 studio albums
column7: recorded upwards of 150 songs
column8: and spent the last 25 years defining a genre.

column1: The tracks here are arranged in reverse-chronological order
column2: a curious choice
column3: but ultimately a good one
column4: forcing attention on newer tracks that may otherwise have been lost. The disc opens with ""Paschendale"" from 2003's underrated Dance of Death. An epic
column5: classic-style Maiden track
column6: clocking in at over eight minutes
column7: ""Paschendale"" shows anyone who isn't familiar with the band's newer catalogue that little has changed over the years. Singer Bruce Dickinson's pipes are as crisp as ever
column8: and the Steve Harris/Nicko McBrain rhythm section is still bombastic and powerful.

column1: From Brave New World
column2: the disc that marked Dickinson's triumphant return to the band
column3: we get ""The Wicker Man"" and the title track. Comeback single ""The Wicker Man"" dispelled worries that the band couldn't recapture the ferocity of its earlier work. ""Brave New World"" starts with mellow
column4: echoed guitar and synth strings
column5: while Dickinson croons over top
column6: but goes on to feature out-of-nowhere time changes
column7: winding solos
column8: and dual- and three-guitar harmonies.

column1: From the mid-90s we get two tracks apiece from Virtual XI and The X Factor. Both albums featured vocalist Blaze Bayley-- an accomplished if not exactly original vocalist temporarily replaced Dickinson. The band could've easily found a clone and carried on
column2: and it's to their credit that they avoided that trap
column3: but it's hard to get over the missing Dickinson. Bayley's vocals are somewhere between Dickinson's and original mic-man Paul Di'anno. He's gruff
column4: but he's got range
column5: able to hold a note with the best of them. Unfortunately the songs just never seem capture the spirit of the band.

column1: Fear of the Dark (1990) and No Prayer for the Dying (1992) had some strong moments but far too much filler
column2: and both suffered from going-through-the-motions syndrome. The four tracks featured here from those discs are just about all the casual fan needs. All four are strong
column3: especially ""Be Quick or Be Dead""
column4: one of the angriest songs in the band's history. And even though ""Bring Your Daughter...to the Slaughter"" has long been lampooned for its silliness
column5: it's worth revisiting as a reminder that these guys aren't nearly as serious as their moody music would indicate.

column1: From 1988's Seventh Son of a Seventh Son
column2: we get ""The Clairvoyant"" and ""The Evil that Men Do."" This was Maiden at both their biggest and their most commercially accessible. The concept album featured tons of hooks and prominently featured synthesizers
column3: and these two tracks showcase those traits magnificently
column4: with ""The Clairvoyant"" containing this set's most triumphant melody.

column1: Continuing backwards through their career
column2: we arrive at Somewhere in Time
column3: Maiden's first album to feature keyboards. ""Wasted Years""
column4: where Dickinson worries that the his golden years are slipping by while he's trapped in a tour bus
column5: begins with one of the most recognizable guitar leads in heavy metal. ""Heaven Can Wait"" is just as anthemic
column6: forgoing the band's often gloomy imagery for an upbeat
column7: positive message.

column1: The band's first three albums to feature Bruce Dickinson were released in quick succession: Barely a year separated Number of the Beast and Piece of Mind. The band spent a large chunk of 1983 and 1984 on the road
column2: then fired back with Powerslave. All three are powerhouses
column3: and they are laced with many of the band's most well-known songs. By Powerslave
column4: the line-up had finally solidified
column5: and
column6: and the benefits of this tightness were apparent. ""2 Minutes to Midnight""
column7: ""Aces High""
column8: ""Flight of Icarus""
column9: ""The Trooper""
column10: ""Number of the Beast""
column11: and ""Run to the Hills"" are live staples to this day. This is Maiden at its strongest
column12: its most confident
column13: and its most adventurous.

column1: From the band's earliest period we get ""Wrathchild"" and ""Killers"" from Killers and ""Phantom of the Opera"" from their self-titled debut. Paul Di'anno's raspy voice is a pretty stark contrast to Dickinson's
column2: but these songs
column3: and the albums they come from
column4: show a younger band still trying to find its sound. ""Wrathchild"" and ""Killers"" both feature an infusion of punk attitude
column5: and ""Phantom of the Opera"" is a an amateur attempt at prog-rock
column6: featuring tons of time changes
column7: odd vocal harmonies
column8: and an instrumental breakdown in full of tinkling guitar and high-end bass.

column1: The collection closes with two live tracks: ""Running Free"" from 1985's Live After Death and ""Iron Maiden"" from the forthcoming Death on the Road. The two tracks do well to bridge the old Iron Maiden with the new. The two songs were originally recorded over 25 years ago
column2: and hearing these versions
column3: themselves 20 years apart
column4:
back to back gives strong evidence that these guys are just as powerful today as when they first crawled their way out of East London almost three decades ago.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/2078/homepage_large.584a2983.jpg|Artificial Intelligence|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Warp']|2005-08-25 00:00:00|1992|2016-06-11 20:55:11.340093|"

Compilations like Warp's Artificial Intelligence don't come around often enough. Everything about it was gutsy. Warp had started three years earlier as a dance-oriented label that grew out of a DJ shop. Its founders had fallen in love with Detroit techno and set about releasing music that would further that tradition. But they noticed that in addition to dancing at clubs and raves
column2: people were using electronic music in another way. The iconic cover illustration said it all: A robot
column3: reclining in his living room
column4: quite possibly stoned
column5: with Kraftwerk and Pink Floyd LPs strewn about his floor. They envisioned a post-rave head session
column6: a time for a contemplative and cerebral journey into music's future.

column1: A bit hippie
column2: isn't it? Warp didn't care. And they didn't just suggest these things with a title and images; they laid it all out explicitly on the record's cover. ""Artificial Intelligence is electronic listening music for long journeys
column3: quiet nights and club drowsy dawns"" and ""Artificial Intelligence is the first in a series of 'listening albums' from Warp."" These statements now sound like they would be affixed to some sort of Ultimate Chill compilation sold at a coffee shop circa 1999
column4: but this wasn't polite
column5: head-nodding downtempo. Most of Artificial Intelligence was just a click or two away from the music that would have filled a dance floor. Tempos were a little slower and textures were more labored over but the LP was built on techno's sturdy foundation.

column1: The idea was to retreat to a place removed from the utilitarian demands of the dance floor to engage in electronic music R&D.; Everything about the package was presented as a paradigm shift
column2: all the way down to the disarmingly earnest answers to standard questions (""Why did you contribute to A.I.""?) supplied by the artists on the inside sleeve. In sum
column3: Warp said ""Here is something new and original
column4: and you are going to be hearing a lot more if it
column5: and then delivered on the promise. A genre was born
column6: but Warp's ""Electronic Listening Music"" term never caught on. Instead
column7: we got the much-reviled ""Intelligent Dance Music
column8: named after the popular e-mail list of the same name.

column1: With Warp going out on a limb to place itself at the forefront of ""progressive"" electronic music
column2: revisiting both newly reissued volumes of Artificial Intelligence more than a decade later is in some ways problematic. You want to hear tracks as music first
column3: but you can't help but listen to it as a historical document. I can say that nearly all of Volume I still sounds great. Richard D. James kicks things off as the Dice Man on ""Polygon Window""
column4: and while his synths sound slightly crude by today's standards
column5: the datedness is ultimately appealing
column6: the weight of history adding substance in the same way as
column7: say
column8: heavy reverb does to countrypolitan. Autechre here is ridged and steeped in early futurist hip-hop; they contribute two great tracks including the astounding ""The Egg""
column9: with its heavily chopped and rhythmically precise vocals. Naturally Dr. Alex Patterson brings the most archetypal ambient with the gauzy
column10: sound-effects heavy ""Loving You Live"". I never particularly cared about Speedy J but the Dutch producer lightens the mood effectively with the bubbly and popish ""De-Orbit"" and then closes with the drifting ""Fill 3"".

column1: Relatively speaking
column2: the second volume doesn't hold up nearly as well. Oddly
column3: while it has more variety it also seems more generic. By 1994 there were a lot of people making ""electronic listening music"" and this doesn't feel like a particularly special assemblage of what was out there. Canned breaks ruin Link's ""Arcadian""
column4: while a recurring sample of a woman intoning ""Feel...strange..."" throughout Mark Franklin's ""Release to the System""
column5: unlike the Richard D. James synth textures mentioned earlier
column6: loses meaning when plucked from its rave-era context. Tracks by Richard Kirk and Higher Intelligence Agency are pleasant and engaging techno but not particularly memorable. The peak again comes from Autechre
column7: whose ""Chatter"" finds them fusing half-speed Cybotron-style electro with languid acid textures
column8: the soundtrack for breakdancing ecstasy in slow motion.

column1: In the liner notes to the first volume
column2: the Autechre boys then just 19 and 21
column3: respond to the question ""Electronic Music. Where next?"" with an unintentionally prophetic answer. ""When people run dry copying each other
column4:
a deeper more creative music will occur where ideas and originality will play a central role."" By now they are all too aware that the well of mimicry is essentially bottomless and there may not be as many original ideas as we once thought. Listening to the first Artificial Intelligence compilation is a reminder of how nice it must have been back in 1992 to dream such a thing.

Difficult to pigeonhole yet instantly recognizable
column2: Los Angeles-based Foreign Born vexes indie taxonomists like hardcore porn does Supreme Court justices
column3: leaving critics to play the Potter Stewart ""I know it when I see it"" card rather than enumerate the requisites. In the Remote Woods is too fidgety for shoegazer
column4: too upbeat for dour post-punk
column5: and too varied for indie pop. Nevertheless
column6: Foreign Born evoke all the familiar touchstones
column7: stitching together Slowdive and the Stone Roses with newer benchmarks the Walkmen and Arcade Fire while carving their own niche alongside those artists.

column1: Armed with bassist/producer and singer/composer tandem Lewis Pesacov and Matt Popieluch
column2: these guys shrewdly cram every inch of the EP with lush keyboards and strings
column3: complementing Popieluch's taut
column4: reverb-soaked melodies. Yet Garrett Ray's aggressive drumming and driving tempos prevent this from being <em>Souvlaki
column5: not to mention Popieluch's penchant for Bono-like theatrics. Opening track ""The Entryway"" shows off the group's repertoire
column6: beginning with a gritty goth bassline flanked by spotless synths and ringing guitar. From the first uttered lyrics
column7: Popieluch steadily crescendos
column8: nearly blowing out his vocal chords before a guitar solo brings the song home.

column1: The EP's middle tracks follow the precedent set by ex-Star Time behemoths the Walkmen. Standout ""It Grew on You"" cops the Walkmen's searing guitar strumming and cataclysmic drum fills while Popieluch haphazardly slurs his lyrics a la Hamilton Leithauser. He's no clone though
column2: just Leithauser's spirit bottled up inside a deeper
column3: smoother croon. Dragging its feet on listless chords
column4: ""Exactly on the Verge""
column5: though lacking in quirky
column6: carnival playfulness
column7: would fit nicely among <em>Bows + Arrows nostalgic ballads
column8: ending dolefully on the phrase ""I was never so
column9: so young.""

column1: By the end of the record
column2: the group runs low on ideas
column3: and songs grow splotchy as a result. ""Exactly on the Verge"" both moves and drains as it structurally pales in comparison to its more complicated proceeding tracks. Closer ""Remote Woods"" starts with a primitive
column4: fist-pumping riff pilfered from ""I Will Follow""
column5: but a mediocre verse leads only to a deflated chorus
column6: and the repeated intro riff serves solely to resuscitate the song midway through. At final count though
column7: Foreign Born's tallies three shining nuggets and two intriguing yet fatigued tracks taken out of the oven too soon. It's a sterling debut from a well-bred band only one caffeine fix away from a solid
column8:
potent full-length.

Bottom of the Hudson is mostly the work of one man

column3: with assistance from regular collaborators. Previous BOTH albums were collections of bedroom demos and older material; their first EP for Absolutely Kosher
column4: Holiday Machine stays loyal to the 8-track. It's less diverse than The Omaha Record
column5: and if you were a fan of 90s indie rock
column6: it's probably nothing you haven't heard before-- some of Guided By Voices' scrappy production
column7: a dash of Pavement's ennui
column8: and some Archers of Loaf-brand scruff.

column1: The album opens with its title track-- deep
column2: detached vocals floating above swaying rhythms and chugging guitars
column3: It's a pleasant stroll down ""120 Minutes"" lane
column4: but things pick up with the second track
column5: ""Riot Act"". Jangly guitars hold court over strummed power chords
column6: pulled along by the double-tracked vocals of Simon on a simple
column7: reaching melody. These songs are deceptively basic with a hint of melancholy.

column1: Guided By Voices seems an apt comparison
column2: with ""One of Us"" aiming for the same target as subdued GBV gems like ""My Valuable Hunting Knife"" or ""I Am a Scientist."" I'm not saying it's just as affecting
column3: but BOTH wrench surprising gravity out of its few slow chords and simple hook
column4: ""But you're not/ One of us."" The way Simon phrases it
column5: cut between the ""not"" and ""one"" and sung in flat tone that doesn't pine or sneer
column6: makes getting ostracized sound like inevitable fact
column7: as commonplace as a high school gym line in order of ascending height.

column1: The remaining tracks hew even closer to Alien Lanes-era GBV
column2: particularly the roughshod electric drum beat under the jangle of ""Conjecture Measure""
column3: or the thin power chords
column4: strange accents
column5: and non sequitur lyrics of the effortlessly catchy ""Candyman"". The melodies aren't as instantly memorable as ""Riot Act"" or ""One of Us""
column6: but there's not a hint of filler
column7: and more than half of the tracks have me hitting repeat before this brief EP ends. Tracing over the lines of classic slacker bands is an easy way to sound unaffected
column8: yet I don't hear any ulterior motives in their nostalgia
column9: just simple
column10: self-assured songs from a band that never grew out of the 90s. Put it this way: Talent isn't flashing how much better you do something
column11:
it's making what you do better look easy.

Recording a Tape the Colour of the Light is everything instrumental post-rock should be and nothing it shouldn't: it sounds live but hardly loud and is brimming with sound but uncrowded. Renouncing formulaic bombast
column2: Bell Orchestre dazzles by finesse
column3: not force. Call it blank slate music-- oceans of negative space awaiting colonization-by-imagination.

column1: Bell Orchestre
column2: led by the Arcade Fire's Richard Reed Parry
column3: sparks memories of critically maligned early-decade instrumentalists Ghosts & Vodka and Telegraph Melts-- bands derided
column4: in part
column5: for their lack of distortion. Bell Orchestre is more frictional than the former
column6: less NPR-arty than the latter
column7: but its general drift is similar. From the stertorous
column8: semi-electronic horn swells of prelude ""Recording a Tunnel (the Horns Play Underneath the Canal)""
column9: the album worms into focus. Less like rain than a slowly gathering fog
column10: ""Les Lumieres Pt. 1"" builds from a murmur to a klaxon. To follow its development is to watch bacteria conquer a petri dish: New threads twist off somewhat chaotically from the brass nucleus-- an awakening string trill here
column11: a gingerly bell flourish there.

column1: On ""Les Lumieres Pt. 2"" the ecosystem hits full flower. Sultry
column2: echoing horns chafe against skittish strings and fast
column3: charging beats
column4: a textural contrast reminiscent of Godspeed You! Black Emperor. (The bands
column5: as Recording demonstrates
column6: also share a penchant for ungainly titling.) But Bell Orchestre are on a much happier tip. Where Godspeed ride an abandoned train through a miserable wasteland
column7: Bell Orchestre gallops across rich
column8: rustic landscapes. Like Lumen or Explosions in the Sky
column9: it's all a bit fantastical
column10: but the band goes easy on the symbolistic dalliances. Bell Orchestre is all about freeing our neural pathways
column11: not directing them.

column1: And hey
column2: here's an idea: concision. Five of Recording's 11 tracks undershoot four minutes. Despite a couple of longer
column3: jammier pieces the album is a still a breezy listen. That's because
column4: unlike lost siblings Do Make Say Think
column5: Bell Orchestre largely avoids ambient pussyfooting. Voluminosity and slenderness rarely cohabitate in instrumental post-rock
column6: but here both are integral. Nuggets ""Recording a Tunnel"" and the chilly ""The Bells Play the Band""
column7: which imagines Boards of Canada piped through ham radio
column8: would become boundless gorges of nothingness in the hands of many similar bands; Bell Orchestre wisely consigns its most shapeless passages to short stopgaps and segues. Meanwhile
column9: instrumentally verbose songs like ""Throw It on a Fire"" are kept asteer by bedrock percussion.

column1: Recording is designed to underwhelm. It rewards repeat listens and nurtures those lulled by its intoxicating spumes. Whether the album achieves its titular synesthesia is debatable
column2: but Bell Orchestre tap into a wide
column3:
mesmerizing range of the spectrum.

As the flagship act of the prolific Jewelled Antler Collective
column2: San Francisco-based quartet Thuja's recorded output-- four official albums and at least as many homemade CD-Rs released since 2000-- should be considered generous by any reasonable measure. Little were we to realize
column3: then
column4: that the group has in fact been holding out on us
column5: as evidenced by their substantial new double-album Pine Cone Temples. Assembled from previously unreleased tracks recorded between 1999-2004
column6: this collection again finds Thuja returning to their always captivating (if increasingly familiar) studies in pure environmental immersion and improvised
column7: keenly observant micro-folk.

column1: Performed
column2: as always
column3: by Jewelled Antler linchpins Loren Chasse (also of the Blithe Sons & Id Battery
column4: among others)
column5: Steven R. Smith (solo
column6: Hala Strana)
column7: Rob Reger (Franciscan Hobbies)
column8: and Glenn Donaldson (Skygreen Leopards
column9: Blithe Sons
column10: etc.)
column11: Pine Cone Temples differs from its predecessors most notably in terms of scope. Where earlier albums like Ghost Plants and Suns consisted predominantly of shorter pieces of widely varying tones and textures
column12: here Thuja works almost exclusively on larger scale compositions
column13: with most of these eight untitled tracks extending beyond the 10-minute mark as the group patiently allow their meticulous
column14: spontaneous music to spread vine-like beneath the forest canopies
column15: quietly chewing vast expanses of scenery with their soft mandibles.

column1: As with their previous works
column2: Thuja have recorded these pieces in a variety of natural settings
column3: using strategically placed contact mics to help integrate the tiniest audible details of their ambient surroundings into the group's gentle commotion. Theirs is a uniquely intuitive
column4: egoless species of improvisation
column5: as the musicians seem to be competing not for the listener's attention
column6: but to see who can most thoroughly camouflage himself in the underbrush. Though the quartet implements such conventional ingredients as guitar
column7: piano
column8: and hammered or bowed strings
column9: the album contains few unaltered or immediately recognizable sounds
column10: particularly since each musician seems determined to disguise his instrument as a conch shell or an acorn.

column1: The first disc of Pine Cone Temples opens with the brief
column2: jarring sound of a needle scratching across vinyl
column3: before Thuja unhurriedly settle into their first extended creation
column4: an effervescent mosaic of rustling percussion
column5: deep earthy drones
column6: and twinkling lights. From then on
column7: the events spread over the course of these two discs seldom achieve anything beyond the volume of a fallen branch crashing to earth
column8: as the group variously content themselves with gradually building swells of transistor rubble
column9: amp feedback
column10: and imprecisely Eastern-sounding acoustic strings. A notable exception occurs late in the second disc's epic 26-minute finale
column11: a piece that climbs from its tranquil intro of what sounds like a campfire dispassionately consuming manzanita to an apex of electrified noise as starkly dissonant as anything the group have ever cut.

column1: With its ambitious dimensions and the uncertain chronology of its compiled recordings
column2: Pine Cone Temples seems an especially diffuse addition to Thuja's discography
column3: one whose primary appeal will be to those already familiar with the group's organic methods and contours
column4: while newcomers are wisely directed to start with the more easily-digested likes of Ghost Plants. And as with any cross-sectional collection like this
column5: one can't help but wonder if Thuja isn't sitting on a virtually bottomless pile of such recordings
column6:
full of tapes that could equal or better anything included here.

Most bands would be better served by ditching the whole 45-minute album thing and focusing on a steady stream of concise 20-minute EPs. Furthermore
column2: considering their miniscule front-to-back odds

column5: I mean
column6: it's only an EP""-- it's about time those disgusting discriminations changed. The Mobius Band
column7: for one
column8: would benefit from such a less-is-more mentality. Following four increasingly focused EPs that saw the band go from quaint instrumental post-rock to this year's blip-rocking hybrid City vs Country
column9: the Brooklyn-based trio disappoints here by retracing the alienated posture of their previous release while rarely reaching its respectable heights.

column1: Predictably

column4: game-show acumen

column6: the affectless style is limiting. The vocals become even more troublesome when coupled with some of the record's offensively inane lyrics-- hipster-histrionics can only get you so far
column7: guys. On City vs Country
column8: the band's words were harmlessly and somewhat mysteriously vague
column9: but here the content dips into rote Bushy bitching on modern-day corruption with ""Twilight"" (""I will teach my children to lie/ They will know what's wrong will be right"")
column10: rote indie vs. mainstream bitching on ""Radio Coup"" (""Publicists tell you what to think/ They do a good job""-- of course
column11: the Mobius Band are hardly flack free)
column12: and inexcusable-- and rote-- repetitiveness on ""Philadelphia"" (""Ain't it funny how times can change/ Arrangements re-arrange""). The trio's words are remnicent of enduring heartthrob-misfit Jordan Catalano's uncanny appeal-- they're more believably brooding and tortured when expressed in detatched generalities rather than forced specifics.

column1: And instead of glossing over such uninspired wordplay with their dynamic newfound studio polish (Interpol associate Peter Katis helped produce the album)
column2: the mistakes are highlighted by an overdose of tepid electro-zzzz ballads. Revamped oldie ""Taxicab"" lasts nearly six minutes and is punctuated by a relatively raucous finale

column4: taxicab

column1: Static isn't a total between-stations affair. On the strength of an enticing synth line
column2: ""Doo Wop"" is the closest this band may ever get to quirky
column3: hip-shaking. The half-man
column4: half-machine blues of ""You're Wrong"" recalls Radiohead's ""I Might Be Wrong"" as it gives us a glimpse of what the Mobius Band's high expectations could have wrought with more structural massaging. And the perfectionist production is exquisite and exhausting in its attention to detail and nimble attempts at combining typical guitar jangle with zippy
column5: bionic beats. There's a decent EP buried within the album's 10 songs but
column6: as a whole
column7:
Static doesn't have the stamina to uphold its over-extended play.

column3: the former frontman of the oft-ignored
column4: occasionally maligned (not by me
column5: though) Rock*A*Teens. He takes a similar approach to his new project as he did his old band
column6: adding dark lyrics and complex emotions to the pop of the fifties. But where the Rock*A*Teens played an artful
column7: echo-laden take on rockabilly

column1: Knitting Needles and Bicycle Bells builds distinctive walls of instrumentation
column2: mostly from organs
column3: pianos
column4: and guitars. But rather than an inimitable Spector-like sound
column5: where every instrument can be clearly heard
column6: Knitting Needles is muddy. Organs and pianos drone on
column7: and guitars escape from the mire now and then
column8: but it's an impenetrable pastiche of instruments that needs Lopez's voice to pull them out. I think there's some sweeping cello work under the jangling guitars of ""Charlemagne""
column9: but I can't quite tell. That's probably a guitar being plucked in ""Marry Me""
column10: but I can't get past the keyboard effect that sounds like dentist's drill
column11: not to mention one of Knitting Needles whiniest vocal performances. The simple
column12: swaying chord changes are clamoring for a voice to belt out a melody and carry them forward. Lopez wails
column13: begs
column14: and hollers hoarsely at the top of his range
column15: but he never quite sings.

column1: Perhaps more sparse instrumentation would have suited Lopez' romantic melodies. The speedy skip of ""Plenty Is Never Enough"" gets by on just acoustic guitar and a few pounded keys
column2: and it's one of the album's more tolerable songs. If you're stalwart enough to have made it this far into the disc
column3: you still have to deal with ""Marry Me""
column4: and that's enough to send anyone over the nearest bridge even before hearing the toy-piano plink of ""When the Swifts Come Home"" or the swinging church bell sing-along ""Wicked Wicked Ways"".

column1: Lyrically
column2: Lopez sounds like a defeated man. No matter how perky opener ""Silver from the Silt"" sounds
column3: it's weighed down by the repetition of ""Just quit
column4: just quit
column5: it's the best you will find down""
column6: full of resignation. ""Now She Knows"" spits disillusionment through it's muddy meandering
column7: with lines like ""All that glitters isn't gold/ It's just shimmering paint on a cast-iron saint/ A scotch-sucking brute in a Brooks Brothers suit""
column8: a quirky bit of antiquated bile. Lopez likely has more perspective these days
column9: and he's brave for starting over in the face of relative apathy towards his old band
column10: but as the lone player and producer here
column11:
he could still use some guidance and maybe another set of ears.
