Please provide definitive answers for the following questions about soundtracks:

column1: 1. Does it matter if I haven't seen the movie?
2. Does it matter if I have seen the movie
column2: and think it's great
column3: and think the music goes with it
column4: but hate the soundtrack on its own?

column1: 3. Can I only like the soundtrack because it reminds me of the movie?
4. Is it really a good ""soundtrack"" if I love the music but hate the movie?
5. When pop stars write soundtracks
column2: isn't it better when they just contribute a few ""real"" songs and keep the noodling ""atmospherics"" to a minimum?

column1: 6. Why does there have to be noodling
column2: ""atmospheric"" music in movies?

column1: I've long held a bias against soundtracks. Not for their use
column2: mind you: a good soundtrack can make a movie better than its sum of train explosions
column3: drug deals and awkward romances. However
column4: taken on their own terms
column5: soundtracks tend to reek of passive-aggression. I can imagine how tough it was to score music that complimented
column6: yet never overwhelmed
column7: a film
column8: but my attention span usually demands more than music that just suggests emotion. Not that original scores are all bad-- I have soft spots for Danny Elfman
column9: Bernard Herrmann and Nino Rota-- but in the best case
column10: I imagine the symbiotic relationship between music and film to be a little more interesting a lot more often.

column1: Bjรถrk's music for Matthew Barney's Drawing Restraint 9-- in which the singer also stars-- is her second foray into film music (after 2000's Selmasongs)
column2: and commits all the crimes and good deeds a soundtrack should. I haven't seen the movie
column3: so I can only guess that throat singers and chimes enhanced it. However
column4: there are context clues suggesting Bjรถrk went out of her way to
column5: well
column6: get out of the way of the action onscreen. Pieces like the low brass-heavy ""Hunter Vessel"" and ""Vessel Shimenawa"" alternate the fat squelch of trombones
column7: trumpets
column8: and horns with more ethereal chord clusters
column9: evocative of perhaps a rocky landscape that meets the sea. Stripped of visuals
column10: there is still an impression left
column11: one that nails a kind of cold distance very well
column12: but doesn't sound like anything specifically.

column1: Still
column2: I'm most drawn to the songs
column3: and there are some notable ones for Bjรถrk fans. First is ""Gratitude""
column4: featuring solo vocals by Will Oldham. The song is very much in the vein of the classic Bjรถrkian ballad
column5: with a flowing
column6: seemingly open-ended melody that is running away from conventional pop phraseology as much as it seems ""accessible."" Oldham handles its melodies well
column7: though to my ears
column8: sounds a bit broken and delicate where I imagine Bjรถrk would be strident and flighty. Nevertheless
column9: supported by harp
column10: bells and chimes
column11: and featuring neat instrumental interludes that remind me of the xylophones in Steve Reich's <em>Drumming
column12: it's pleasant and unmistakably Bjรถrk. However
column13: my favorite song is ""Storm""
column14: which the composer has performed live over the past few years. Over a sinister backdrop of synth
column15: rain
column16: creaking doors (all of which appear and disappear without notice)
column17: Bjรถrk's lone vocal soars in the chorus (?) like the booming siren of a blue whale who suddenly realized she was the last of her species. The tragic
column18: detached vibe of the track only makes what sounds bitterly lonely all the more pressing. This would have been a highlight on Medulla or Vespertine
column19: much less here.

column1: And then there are the rest: A sound art piece based on throat singing (and very reminiscent of Medulla's ""Ancestors"")
column2: a longer (and way more excruciating if you don't happen to be into traditional Japanese Noh vocals) exotic vocal piece
column3: some nice
column4: if innocuous electro-music-box stuff and a couple of lesser vocals by Bjรถrk (the trippy
column5: plasmatic ballad ""Bath"" and simpler
column6: brighter ""Cetacea""). And that's where I usually end up with moderately interesting soundtracks: A couple of really cool parts
column7: and the rest I don't feel so bad for forgetting. I'm not sure I learned a ton about the form
column8:
but Bjรถrk's entry is more interesting than most.

column3: sometimes way-out distorted electric guitar. Denio's vocals are clear as day

column6: elegantly suggesting the original chord progression with spiked drones and the occasional shard of dissonance. W. Oliver Cooper and Minzo C. Jones' ""Heaven Will Surely Be Worth It All"" gets a rougher treatment
column7: with Palmer's martial
column8: oppressive drum machine going to battle with Bailey's flickering
column9: pointillist figures. Again
column10: Denio's pure alto seems non-phased by the chaos around
column11: though is kept at bay by the electric storm.

column1: Sometimes

column4: the record blends pop sensibilities and snatches of delicate
column5: off-kilter melody with free-flowing experimentation and avant-garde leanings. Several tracks incorporate breakbeat-style electronic drums (most notably the title track and ""Portland
column6: Oregon part 4"")
column7: and two songs are delivered via acoustic guitar (the appropriately titled ""Guitar 1"" and ""Guitar 2"")
column8: but for the most part May 23rd 2007 is an amalgam of tones
column9: sampled snippets
column10: and tape manipulation. Given this description
column11: there are many artists who come to mind (the Books
column12: the Wind-Up Bird
column13: even Philip Glass)
column14: but to confuse similarity of style with similarity of ideas is to sell all of those artists short.

column1: The Kallikak Family succeeds by creating a beautiful
column2: flowing piece of music that is at once engaging and understated. At times it can be heart-wrenchingly sad
column3: yet the uplifting are both impassioned and beautiful. With 17 tracks
column4: each averaging about two minutes in length
column5: Peterson gets the most out of his ideas
column6: building a record that blends seamlessly yet shifts shapes both over the course of the LP and within each track. As a result
column7: the true magnitude of May 23rd 2007 seeps out slowly
column8:
divulging more of its secrets with each listen.

Give Blood falls squarely in the ""pleasant surprise"" camp; a

Electric Soft Parade and the Tenderfoot
column2: Brakes is fronted by British

column1: Sea Power's Eamon Hamilton
column2: and besides Hamilton's mealy-mouthed

column1: singing
column2: the only thing the two bands share is a record deal with

column1: Rough Trade. Forget wall-of-sound pop glamour; forget coded references
to Dostoevsky; forget ruminative death ballads and arcane concepts.
Blazing through 16 songs in less than half an hour-- the longest
clocking in at about three-and-a-half minutes
column2: the shortest at seven

column1: seconds-- Brakes has turned out a weird
column2: riotous post-(cow)punk

column1: screed.
Yeah
column2: cowpunk. A country twang creeps into the album periodically:

column1: Check the bright jangle of ""NY Pie""
column2: where Hamilton affects a

column1: hilarious Southern drawl (American punk bands have been mangling
British accents forever
column2: and turnabout's fair play) to riff on

column1: big-city dreams with the curious but intuitively coherent refrain
""Oh
column2: get me a pony."" But the stylistic hopscotch doesn't stop there.

column1: The shuffle beat
column2: lockstep bass
column3: and explosive post-punk chorus of

column1: ""All Night Disco Party"" winks slyly in DFA's direction. The 30-second
""Pick Up the Phone"" precisely apes the Fall
column2: with its careening chords

column1: and histrionic vocal rhythm. ""I Can't Stand to Stand Beside You"" is
textbook Mission of Burma
column2: with its abrupt shifts between gliding

column1: repetitive menace and fist-pumping pop-punk choruses
column2: while songs like

column1: ""You'll Always Have a Place to Stay"" and ""The Most Fun"" trade in
aggression for dirgey indie-pop.
If it sounds all over the place
column2: it is
column3: but because Brakes couch their

column1: divagations in directness and simplicity
column2: it all hangs together. Their

column1: scene-baiting rants and snotty
column2: high-octane punk fill the void vacated

column1: by the late
column2: great Mclusky
column3: masters of the pointedly absurd tirade.

column1: Like Mclusky
column2: Brakes are at their best when they're sending up the

column1: scene and its discontents. ""Heard About Your Band"" could be an answer
to Art Brut's ""Formed a Band"": ""I heard about your band/ Whatever

Electralene
column2: eh?""
column3: Hamilton sneers at trendy rockers
column4: and thankfully

column1: he comes off more like a petty
column2: mean-spirited prick than a

column1: self-righteous artiste. ""Hi How Are You?"" begins with a prรฉcis of
scenester pick-up lines
column2: including ""what do you do
column3: ""how do you

column1: dress
column2: and ""who are your friends
column3: before being abruptly cockblocked

column1: with ""Won't you shut the fuck up

column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2005-08-18 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:55:25.513730|"

Maybe this is just an American's projection onto our northerly neighbors
column3: but I imagine Chad VanGaalen knows the cold very intimately. He hails from Calgary
column4: where he busked street corners and subways for years
column5: gradually building up a large catalog of original songs. Using a variety of instruments and equipment-- some of which he's fashioned by hand-- the relentless DIY'er has recorded hundreds of his songs in a makeshift studio in his bedroom
column6: where you can imagine him retreating from a frigid evening. On his debut album
column7: <em>Infiniheart
column8: which was released in Canada earlier this year and which Sub Pop is now releasing domestically
column9: that crisp chill hangs over every chiming note and every booming beat. Even the packaging cannot escape the cold front: Snow-white and ice-blue dominate the cover artwork
column10: and the inner sleeve is wind-chapped pink.

column1: This chilliness suggests an album full of spare
column2: soft songs conveying subtle emotions
column3: which is accurate but only to a degree. While he keeps his accompaniment to a minimum
column4: VanGaalen is no minimalist. His songs are balanced with only a few carefully chosen elements
column5: as if he has expended a great deal of energy trying to avoid adding another instrument here or overworking a beat there. But the range of sounds on <em>Infiniheart is impressively wide: When VanGaalen culled these 16 from the hundreds in his vault
column6: he chose with an ear toward the eclectic
column7: showcasing his musical ingenuity.

column1: In fact
column2: there's an almost maximalist spectrum of sound on <em>Infiniheart
column3: and the album is all the more impressive for creating and maintaining such a specific mood over 16 songs. Brushes stir against snares on ""Blood Machine"" imitating slow respiration
column4: and the prismatic guitars of ""Liquid + Light"" and ""Somewhere I Know There Is Nothing"" evoke the cutting cold in the air and the sharp glare of sunlight off frozen snow. On ""1000 Pound Eyelids"" a bleary trumpet suggests the bending metal and breaking bones of a car crash
column5: and the sharp notes of a dobro and a breezy penny whistle pierce ""Sunshine Snare Hits"".

column1: VanGaalen's guitar can be gentle or brutal
column2: his beats reserved or ostentatious
column3: and he has sequenced the album to showcase this dynamic. The two-guitar coda of ""Kill Me in My Sleep""
column4: which is perhaps best described as ""gossamer""
column5: is immediately followed by the instrumental ""J.C.'s Head on the Cross""
column6: which bounces frenetically on thudding beats. He sings these songs in a voice that stretches towards a shivering falsetto
column7: which cracks noticeably on ""Chronograph #1"" and adds to the otherworldliness of ""Red Blood"" and the videogamey ""The Warp Zone/Hidden Bridge"".

column1: If this chilliness enlivens the music
column2: it unfortunately dampens VanGaalen's songwriting
column3: which relies too heavily on weighty
column4: sci-fi concepts that seem frozen and immobile. In theory
column5: such reliance suggests a unique vision
column6: unflinching in its conception and execution
column7: but in practice
column8: he too often sounds coldly remote
column9: more aloof than elusive. ""Clinically Dead"" starts the album with the demise of a man-machine: ""Clinically he was dead
column10: and the modem inside his head was still working."" Conceptually
column11: it recalls the Flaming Lips (who based an entire album on the heartbreaking inner conflict of a crime-fighting cartoon) and Grandaddy (who based an entire album on the melding of humanity and machines in a post-apocalyptic world)
column12: but those artists play with the distance between their subject matter and the emotions they intend to communicate. Very rarely does any self-awareness come through on Infiniheart.

column1: When his flights of fancy are anchored in the actual
column2: <em>Infiniheart becomes a powerful combination of words and music. ""After the Afterlife"" asks about such mundane matters as a mother's haircut and a father's drug habit before conjuring eerie seaweed imagery that hints at tragedy. And ""Chronograph #1""
column3: about a party whose guest of honor is noticeably absent
column4: possesses more gravity than any of his oddball lyrics. But still
column5: those cumbersome songs stand out the most
column6: especially ""Blood Machine""
column7: which imagines a Matrix-like underworld where everyone is hooked up to a ""giant machine that could circulate blood."" He tries to connect it to larger
column8: existential issues
column9: but despite the fluttering guitarwork
column10: the song falls flat: ""One of them explained to me/ how they used to be free/ Before the machines got built/ And before there were laws regulating free will."" To his credit
column11: VanGaalen invests those clunky lines with a vocal intensity that's surprisingly graceful and even poignant. That's ultimately the sticking point with <em>Infiniheart: VanGaalen's songs tend toward folly
column12: yet it's impossible to discount his commitment to the material.

After two albums of post-Britpop mediocrity
column2: Manchester trio I Am Kloot kick things up a notch (or think they do)
column3: and suffer from bipolarity and an ambition that outstrips their ability. The disc plays like a sex operation gone botched-- Adonis to Medusa in 10 minutes tops. Three songs into a promising start
column4: the I Am Kloot of yesteryear rears its lyrically asinine head
column5: which wouldn't be so bad if the Kloot didn't regard themselves as ""Harold Pinter real deal to everyone else's overblown
column6: Cecil B. de Mille mock-ups.""

column1: More problems arise when this band wants to be somebody's soundtrack-- all vampires and exotic places-- and from there the degeneration's traceable: The straightforward ""No Direction"" largely succeeds
column2: ""Over My Shoulder"" straddles the good-to-ugly divide
column3: and ""An Ordinary Girl"" is a full-blown suck-fest. Moody Doves-like undercurrents work in small doses but wilt when spooned out in large doses.

column1: If you're looking for reference points
column2: Cinerama's shtick isn't far off
column3: except that was smart. You never caught David Gedge singing about the ""bald raging flame of your heart"" or recounting Gothic tales of ""ordinary"" girls in what he thinks are fifty-pence words. I Am Kloot singer John Bramwell's execution is gloomily expressive at best
column4: melodramatic as a rule
column5: and when the Wurlitzers materialize like dry ice at a Backstreet Boys concert
column6: shit's more exasperating than convincing-- and tiresome
column7: too.

column1: While it's true that stories don't tell themselves
column2: Kloot's stories might speak volumes if Bramwell sang less. Loungey ""Avenue of Hope"" could be an Angry Inch B-side
column3: if this Hedwig were a wholly sincere woman with a deep voice and razor-thin vocal range instead of an affected man with with an overdeveloped sense of misanthropy and a  razor-thin vocal range. ""Hong Kong Lullaby"" feels like a cheap shot at fluffy pillow-softness
column4: offering respite from billowing swells of over-instrumentation but little else; ""I Believe""
column5: a weirdly compelling Nick Drake anthem-cum-rescue mission
column6: comes tacked on as a bedside prayer finale that also fails to salvage or move (to tears or otherwise) thanks to the tyranny of circumstance. For all their godlike aspiration
column7:
it's a shame that I Am Kloot basically don't do Genesis.

It's tempting to look for an angle when ostensibly
""traditional"" artists re-interpret music originally
conceived for an entirely different context. You wonder if
they're making a statement first and thinking about the
music second. It can seem as though the artist with a
stronger connection to high culture is either extending a
hand down to welcome the other half into the club. Or
perhaps they're just having a laugh. A string quartet is
playing Metallica songs
column2: see
column3: because Metallica are actually

column1: interesting composers. See also Sebastian Cabot
column2: Actor/Bob

column1: Dylan
column2: Poet.

column1: New music ensemble Alarm Will Sound decided to follow its
album of Steve Reich compositions with a record of
all-acoustic interpretations of pieces by the Aphex Twin
but nothing about the project suggests condescension. Based
on the music and presentation this seems more like an
ambitious collective on the hunt for challenging projects
and the idea of scoring and arranging pieces that have lived
their entire lives inside a computer was too tempting to
pass up. In a sense Richard D. James seems the natural choice
for such a tribute
column2: both because of his surpassing melodic

column1: sense and that he's already penetrated the serious world
through collaboration with Philip Glass. A large assortment
of hoses
column2: whistles
column3: shop hardware
column4: and piano treatments were

column1: gathered for timbral approximations
column2: after the tracks were

column1: selected (curiously
column2: most are from most from Drukqs) and

column1: notated
column2: and this is the result.

column1: Though it never sounds to me like a gimmick
column2: <em>Acoustica

column1: remains oddly distant and difficult to inhabit. This music
often geared toward atmosphere and sound for sound's sake
is difficult to absorb when scored for traditional
instruments and easily slips into the background. Generally
the better and more exciting the original track
column2: the more

column1: the Alarm Will Sound version pales by comparison. On tracks
like ""Meltphace 6"" where the distinctive rolling drums serve
as the lead instrument
column2: Alarm Will Sound sounds overly

column1: restrained
column2: with its conservatory roots at the Eastman

column1: School of Music in full view. That they would even attempt
to record something like ""Cock/Ver 10"" live with acoustic
instruments is impressive
column2: certainly
column3: but the music itself

column1: doesn't quite survive the translation and loses its sense of
purpose.
Better are the tracks that were in their initial form more
open-ended. The short industrial percussion ditty ""Prep
Gwarlek 3B"" finds new life with live instrumentation
column2: and

column1: its unusual rhythm and texture easier becomes easier to
digest. The digital gamelan ""Jynweythek Ylow"" loses a pang
of longing without the sound of James's music box
column2: but Alarm

column1: Will Sound find the melodic core at the piece's center.
Still
column2: though <em>Acoustica is an interesting album and not

column1: unpleasant to listen to
column2: but nowhere does it capture James's

column1: energy or musical wit. It reminds me of when Derrick May
did an Invisible Jukebox session for the UK experimental
music magazine The Wire and the interviewer played him a brass
band version of ""Strings of Life"". His strong initial
excitement quickly dissipated and he groaned
column2: ""Oh
column3: I wish it

column1:
were better.""

James Osterburg was a man you might not look at twice on the street. Iggy Pop was his animal soul
column3: and when Iggy got loose on a stage just about     anything could happen. With the Stooges he was the     mesmerizing center of a maelstrom that helped to invent a whole host of rock's     musical clichรฉs
column4: a group that spun primal fury and     young adult frustration into some of the ugliest
column5: most brutal
column6: most alive music of its era.

column1: There were other subversive
column2: confrontational rock acts before the     Stooges-- the cover of the band's eponymous debut even subtly references the Doors'     own self-titled album-- but nobody before them had the good sense to take it     as far over the top as they did. Even the band's sturdiest compositions     have a feeling of instability about them
column3: like they might collapse or fly     asunder at any moment
column4: and there are moments when Iggy can't help screaming     and grunting as if he's trying to challenge Ron Asheton's guitar to some     nihilistic duel. In the middle of the hippie era
column5: their grimy
column6: depraved
column7: and     violent take on love and life had no natural place
column8: which is perhaps why it holds up so well.

column1: The Stooges' first two albums are a case study in a band marking its territory with a debut and then systematically destroying that territory and everything in it on their second. As rough and abrasive as The Stooges is
column2: it sounds positively genteel next to the apocalyptic garage meltdown of Fun House. The debut was produced by the Velvet Underground's John Cale
column3: an art-conscious violist who worked hard     to get the Stooges a crisp
column4: muscular sound that highlighted the bleakness of their vision but made them perhaps less threatening on record than they were on stage. For Fun House
column5: the band got Don Gallucci
column6: whose previous claim to rock trivia fame was as the guy going ""duh duh duh
column7: duh duh
column8: duh duh duh
column9: duh duh"" on the keyboards on the Kingsmen's epochal     ""Louie Louie"". Gallucci essentially recorded <i>Fun     House as though it were a live album
column10: letting the band simply attack the     songs in take after exhausting take
column11: and though the recording is less than     perfect from a technical standpoint
column12: it shoves the Stooges at the peak of their powers right in your face.

column1: Rhino's reissues do a fine job of shoving them even further
column2: benefitting from improved mastering that highlights the gut-punch     rhythm section of Dave Alexander and Scott Asheton
column3: who never get enough     credit for being the band's pounding heart and tortured soul. Alexander's bass keeps things grounded in blues and     psychedelia
column4: rumbling low and solid in the mix as Ron Asheton's lava guitar flows around it and Dave Asheton pummels out the most basic and accordingly perfect beats possible. The raging caveman groove they lay down on ""1969"" to open the debut is still one of the greatest undercarriages a rock song has ever had.

column1: The first album also contains the classic ""I Wanna Be Your Dog""
column2: notable almost as much for its inclusion of piano and sleigh bell in a     grinding rock arrangement as it is for its then-controversial refrain. The record also has two songs notable mostly for the fact that they show the     band going in a direction they never again pursued: ""We Will Fall""
column3: audaciously sequenced at track three
column4: is a droning
column5: 10-minute dirge     featuring a backing chant and Iggy's harrowing narration of a night in a     lonely hotel room. The way he sings
column6: ""Then I lay right down/ On my back/ On my     bed/ In my hotel"" makes what looks insanely mundane on paper sound like the     last existential gasps of a dying mind. Less oppressive but no more upbeat     is ""Ann""
column7: which is sort of the album's ballad if you wanted to stretch and call it that. Iggy wails for a lost lover and Ron Asheton reels off a sickeningly fuzzed-out guitar solo that anticipates the most unhinged moments of Fun House.

column1: Unhinged is too weak a word for the wildest moments of Fun House
column2: especially     closer ""L.A. Blues""
column3: a fiery freakout that's more heroin than LSD and makes     no pretense of song structure. Saxophonist Steven Mackay adds a nasty edge     to the album's second side
column4: blazing right along with the rest of the band to     create a texture that sounds exactly like the album cover-- Iggy tossed     in a flaming sea
column5: possibly hell. The record's first half is somewhat tamer
column6: with the heavy boogie of ""Down on the Street"" and the paranoid snarl of     ""T.V. Eye""
column7: where the band plays with deadly efficiency behind Iggy's demented vocal. Iggy actually captures the feel of the whole record in the opening line of ""1970"": ""Out of my mind on a Saturday night.""

column1: The reissues each add a whole disc of rarities
column2: though hardcore fans will     already know the <i>Fun House extras from the 1970 boxed set
column3: which is now out of print. On Stooges
column4: it's basically alternate mixes and extended versions
column5: while on <i>Fun House it's primarily outtakes
column6: but given the volatility of the     material on that album
column7: there's quite a bit of variation from version to     version. That said
column8: none of the out-takes are particularly revelatory     outside a twisted
column9: distended
column10: sax-soaked version of ""1970""
column11: and most casual listeners will probably not spin disc two of either set more than once or twice. Fun House does include two songs that didn't make the album
column12: but     it's hard to see where either the ravaged blues of ""Slide (Slidin' the     Blues)"" or ""Lost in the Future"" would have fit without destroying the     record's momentum. That said
column13: both songs offer a chance to hear more of Mackay's sax playing and give a glimpse toward what the band might have sounded like if a lineup had solidified with him in it.

column1: It should go without saying that these are two of the most important signposts on the way to the punk explosion
column2: and that any rock fan with a     sense of history owes it to themselves to check them out if they haven't     already. What's often lost as we place them in the canon
column3: though
column4: is the     fact that both albums sound incredibly good today on their own terms
column5:
raw and immediate and dripping with an aggression that's rarely been rivaled.

column2: though hardcore fans will     already know the <i>Fun House extras from the 1970 boxed set
column3: which is now out of print. On Stooges
column4: it's basically alternate mixes and extended versions
column5: while on <i>Fun House it's primarily outtakes
column6: but given the volatility of the     material on that album
column7: there's quite a bit of variation from version to     version. That said
column8: none of the out-takes are particularly revelatory     outside a twisted
column9: distended
column10: sax-soaked version of ""1970""
column11: and most casual listeners will probably not spin disc two of either set more than once or twice. Fun House does include two songs that didn't make the album
column12: but     it's hard to see where either the ravaged blues of ""Slide (Slidin' the     Blues)"" or ""Lost in the Future"" would have fit without destroying the     record's momentum. That said
column13: both songs offer a chance to hear more of Mackay's sax playing and give a glimpse toward what the band might have sounded like if a lineup had solidified with him in it.

column1: It should go without saying that these are two of the most important signposts on the way to the punk explosion
column2: and that any rock fan with a     sense of history owes it to themselves to check them out if they haven't     already. What's often lost as we place them in the canon
column3: though
column4: is the     fact that both albums sound incredibly good today on their own terms
column5:
raw and immediate and dripping with an aggression that's rarely been rivaled.

Since their formation as a duo in 2002
column2: the two sisters of Osaka's Afrirampo have enjoyed something of a meteoric rise through the avant-rock underground
column3: recording with Acid Mothers Temple and touring with Lightning Bolt and Sonic Youth. On Kore Ga Mayaku Da-- their first U.S. release following a handful of self-released recordings in Japan-- it isn't difficult to hear why their ascent has been so rapid. Though their national origin will surely prompt impulsive comparisons to Melt Banana or early Boredoms
column4: there's something entirely unique going on within Afrirampo's free-form
column5: primal garage-stomps. And on this album they join such acts as Magik Markers or Angelblood out beyond the farthest streetlight of rock's untamed outskirts
column6: where one wrong turn can plunk you directly into the foreboding
column7: impassable wilderness.

column1: Afrirampo (the name translates loosely yet accurately to ""naked rock"") is comprised of guitarist Oni and drummer Pikachu
column2: both of whom add wild
column3: lustful vocals that occasionally reach pitches of near-cartoonish intensity. With this denuded instrumental attack the duo recasts the trashy
column4: minimalist garage-rock of groups like the Oblivians or Cheater Slicks into decidedly more personalized abstract forms
column5: using open-ended song structures and free-spirited improvisation to create a mercurial strain of fuzzed-out thunder.

column1: While the duo's spare approach necessarily amplifies the relative weight of each individual element of their music
column2: on Kore Ga Mayaku Da it is Oni's guitar that proves to be the group's most indispensable weapon. At a time when noteworthy rock guitarists seem to be in uncommonly short supply
column3: Oni's work here consistently astonishes without being overtly flashy. One minute she sounds to be channeling Johnny Thunders
column4: the next it's a leopard skin-clad Derek Bailey
column5: as throughout the album she bursts enthusiastically from episode-to-episode with a slippery
column6: off-the-cuff grace that suggests that she's not always wholly aware of what her fingers are planning to do next. Behind the drumkit
column7: Pikachu acquits herself as well
column8: keeping pace with-- if not actually anticipating-- Oni's every frantic lane change.

column1: The duo certainly waste no time getting down to the nitty-gritty on their ecstatic 13-minute opening gush ""I Did Are
column2: a surprisingly metallic
column3: free-flowing epic that changes course roughly every 45 seconds
column4: including an extended mid-song breakdown of dizzy vocalizing and guitar-string chicken clucks. Things get slightly less complicated on blistering tracks like the onomatopoetic ""O"" or the crazed-scales of ""Kairaku Do Re Mi""
column5: while on quieter numbers like ""On Ska to Paar Ya"" or the erotically-charged plea ""Want You""
column6: the duo reveal an unsuspected Jamaican influence
column7: inflecting these songs with languid
column8: echo-heavy dub effects and erstwhile island rhythms. It's never long
column9: however
column10: before Afrirampo are again off and running
column11: joyfully veering to the cusp of feral
column12: white-hot noise
column13:
as they drag their songs kicking and screaming towards distant untold possibilities.

I Am Come is the second album from the UK's Part Chimp
column3: and their second for the label formed by Mogwai
column4: Rock Action. The band are certainly prone to slow
column5: ""Part Chimp Fear Satan"" guitar squalls
column6: but where those are emotional crescendos for some bands
column7: they're just interludes between the highlights of I Am Come. ""Bakahatsu"" is the prototypical grinding opener. Standing squarely under Mogwai's shadow for 90 seconds
column8: it's just buildup for the sludgy sweet tooth of album peak ""War Machine"". Ringing guitars march forward despite being interrupted by a distorted gallop every four bars
column9: with a melody and rhythm no less effective for their simplicity.

column1: Volume is Part Chimp's primary instrument
column2: and while brief respites like ""Bubbles"" are welcome and needed
column3: quiet moments are the enemy. Clean guitar chords creep quietly past
column4: waiting for the next bomb to fall. Sometimes they're safe for close to an entire song (""Bubbles"")
column5: sometimes there's only a few seconds before the next attack (""Bring Back the Sound""). The orderly assault of ""War Machine"" gives way to the steady
column6: relentless hammering of ""Hello Bastards""
column7: after which ""Bubbles"" is a trickle in comparison. By the time the Stooges-nodding ""Punishment Ride"" finishes and ""Bring Back the Ride"" is underway
column8: the fuzz pedals are planting their flag.

column1: ""Punishment Ride"" is one of the few songs following the quiet/loud dynamic; most just go from loud to louder. ""Dr. Horse Part Two"" is a solid wall of heavy psychedelia
column2: followed up by the reckless pace of ""Fasto"". The bent notes of the title track sound like support beams breaking under the weight of the song's monolithic blues riffing
column3: and ""30 Billion People"" sounds something like Black Sabbath covering Pavement's ""Two States""
column4: boiling over with layers of distortion and erratic guitar solos.

column1: Is it any different than last year's Chart Pimp? Is the loudness louder
column2: is the noise nosier? Well
column3: yes and yes
column4: not to mention tighter songs and the band getting a deeper grasp of their dynamics (meaning the few seconds of calm are more concise and effective). Hard to believe that with a sound that's all about overkill
column5: not one note is wasted. These songs are as tight as any pop groups
column6: just played with ear-splitting volume. I wouldn't call it unpredictable
column7: but I Am Come has slight variety amongst the chaos
column8: anchored by a canny sense of pacing. Add that to the 20-ton hooks of ""War Machine"" and ""Bring Back the Sound""
column9: you've got a noteworthy sophomore record-- and
column10: most importantly
column11:
one that rocks.

Electronicat: It's one French guy working electro-head backgrounds against old school rock'n'roll action

column6: it didn't sound half bad. The chances
column7: though
column8: of your wanting to bring it home with you? Slim. This
column9: after all
column10: is the sound of someone asking you to delight in the sheer dirty spazz of what he's doing-- an opportunity that nowadays only gets offered to noise acts with enough no-fun attitude to make the whole thing seem like ""art."" Strike two: The sort of camp
column11: yowling rock'n'roll schtick so many horrible American acts fall in love with
column12: the one we should have let drop well before Jon Spencer came around. Electronicat at least has the excuse of being French

column1: His other excuse is the album is kinda fun. Its intentions are made clear by the grotty digital sound
column2: which is basically the electronic equivalent of the four-track in the basement-- this weird laptop reversal where sounding too clean makes the whole thing sound awfully dirty. It's hard to think of a better context for all the just-for-fun old-rock quoting he does on here. When ""Dans la Bois"" kicks off with a psychdelic-Stones pastiche
column3: low-rent French Jagger posing over low-rent guitar and machine stomp
column4: it's not so difficult to get into. Same goes for the rockabilly swing on ""Wap Doowop"" and the fuzzed-out Bo Diddley beat on ""Savage Cat""
column5: if not the modified Deep Purple riff on ""Mummy Cat""; at best
column6: they wind up doing the same thing Junior Senior did to Bob Dylan on one of their album tracks
column7: revving up old tropes into some sleazy drum-machined present.

column1: Still
column2: an excuse is an excuse
column3: and there comes the point where you realize you're chuckling at some of his jackaround tracks more than you're actually feeling them. There comes the point where you remember that Stereo Total could do plenty of this pastiche and make it sound a lot sharper
column4: and there comes the point where you remember that you could get better sleazoid camp vibes off of the Cramps. There's some satisfying stomp-and-wail up in her-- and some lovable cut-ups on ""The Smell of Danger""
column5:
and some home-recording weirdism that could nearly slot into God Ween Satan-- but it's all going to need to get a lot better-developed if it's every going to fly.

column12: Criteria

column1: No Flashlight is the most musically undistinguished Elverum-related project to date

column1: Demanding listener input-- as Elverum does here by not-so-subtly inviting us to ponder him-- isn't a bad thing. But courting ears with such esoteric hooey is disingenuous and annoying. This is theoretical music in a whole 'nother sense: Largely untechnical and musically staid
column2: the meaning lies not in the notes

column4: and not even really in the words

column6: we are led to believe

column4: where he founders.

column1: Has his voice changed? Hardly. Coy
column2: lethargic

it becomes fuzzy what all the fuss is over.

Phosphorescent's lone member Matthew Houck plays the kind of glacially paced

column3: lyrically oblique songs that some people call ""beautiful"" and others call ""boring."" It's hard to deny the claims of the latter: Houck's second full-length

column8: as if to prove some sort of backporch authenticity).

At first blush
column2: the six-song Another Wound EP appears designed to lure back into the tent those garage-punk fans who might've found the Ponys' sophomore album Celebration Castle to be an overly tidied renovation of their 2004 debut Laced With Romance. Containing five older and/or non-LP tracks in addition to Celebration's ""Another Wound""
column3: this EP finds the group foraging through some of their noisiest
column4: most chancy material. But they've managed to do so with their acute melodic edges still fully honed
column5: and consequently it seems doubtful that there's anything on this short
column6: brash collection likely to either alienate the group's established fans or convert the sticklers.

column1: With its fortified Bunnymen-meets-<em>Chronic Town jangle
column2: ""Another Wound"" may initially seem an unlikely choice to headline such a punchy little set
column3: but once this addictive lead-off has cruised through a couple effortless verses
column4: its guitars have accumulated enough residual distortion to pack a not inconsiderable bite. Jered Gummere's distanced Richard Hell vocal hysterics remain a distinctly polarizing element throughout these tracks

column1: His approach serves the Ponys well on their buzzed
column2: surprisingly muscular cover of the Descendents' ""Good
column3: Good Things""

column5: which instead proves to be exactly the type of artful guitar-pop that would've made another good neighbor on <em>Celebration Castle
column6: with or without the chorus' casual swears. This cut does
column7: however

column9: torrential Flip Your Wig guitar solo as markedly dissonant as any the Ponys have yet featured.

column3: trebly guitars and echo-laden vocals

column5: one that provides for a sympathetic segue into the near-grunge of ""How Does It Taste""

column1: Somewhat strangely
column2: this short collection closes with a rather anti-climactic reprise of <em>Laced With Romance's ""Looking Out a Mirror"". A propulsive mรฉlange of skronky guitars and beach party organ
column3: the song contains what is still one of the Ponys' most impressive pop hooks

but its presence here does little to reassure listeners who're anxious to learn whether the group's most exciting work lies before them or behind them.

One of the most interesting side effects of the prevalence of mp3s and file-sharing is the way these streamlined modes of distribution have better enabled artists
column3: particularly those of the improv-based underground
column4: to become as absolutely hyper-productive as they dare to be. Experimental acts ranging from freeform tribes like Wooden Wand and the Vanishing Voice to electronic terrorists like Dead Machines or Hive Mind have managed to become almost ridiculously prolific
column5: carpet-bombing the landscape with one EP
column6: tour-only cassette
column7: or home-burned CD-R after another.

column1: And though typically released in modest quantities on a bevy of homemade micro-labels-- occasionally pressed in absurdly limited runs as small as 30 or 40 copies-- these rare crackled eggs always seem to eventually find their way to the internet
column2: helping the groups to build brand-recognition via word-of-mouth if only through their sheer abundance of material. But while such steady
column3: relentless output allows indiscriminate fans to live with a perpetual embarrassment of riches
column4: it's also meant that too often quality control has been kicked to the curbside
column5: as artists begin to place less importance on each individual recording
column6: instead emphasizing their overall
column7: ever-expanding body of work.

column1: This tendency towards continuous production has now seemingly become so pervasive that
column2: as evidenced by the Terrestrial Tones' Oboroed / Circus Lives
column3: it has begun to govern side projects as well. Terrestrial Tones is a duo consisting of Dave ""Avey Tare"" Porter and Eric Copeland of
column4: respectively
column5: Animal Collective and Black Dice
column6: two groups who've certainly never permitted cobwebs to settle on their discographies. Oboroed / Circus Lives follows the duo's debut album Blasted by a matter of months
column7: and provides another
column8: more potent dose of the twosome's burbling
column9: minimalist electronic emissions.

column1: Though titled and configured as if it's intended to be considered a single
column2: the two-track Oboroed / Circus Lives contains well over 40 minutes of music and certainly requires the same listener commitment as a full album. Both pieces are loosely-assembled
column3: home-recorded collages of processed samples
column4: tape loops and inscrutable electronic ephemera
column5: constructed with the same disheveled DIY charm as the abstractions on their debut. Here
column6: however
column7: the extended running time of each track has given the duo the necessary headroom for their unflappable
column8: languid repetitions to truly hold sway.

column1: Heard under the right circumstances
column2: the shifting waves of the opening ""Oboroed"" can be as richly enveloping as a warm cloud of honey-scented smoke
column3: its unhurried progressions calling to mind some of the more tranquil stretches of the Mille Plateaux back catalog. But the track's weave is so fragile that it threatens to disintegrate under close scrutiny
column4: and when heard in the wrong mood its static
column5: recurring loops of clipped laughter and processed chirping can quickly become as grating as intermittent wipers raking across a dry windshield.

column1: Less finicky is the follow-up/flipside ""Circus Lives"". With its noisier
column2: coarser features
column3: this slightly shorter cut demands (and rewards) more rapt attention. The track opens with a series of agitated sci-fi effects
column4: homely robot tones that later segue into what sounds like the malfunctioning calliope of a downtrodden circus. Towards song's end
column5: the curtain is lifted suddenly to reveal Porter and Copeland in their street clothes
column6: their hands clutching at puppet strings as the tune marches away on a pulse of cheap keyboards and distorted vocals.

column1: As with <em>Blasted
column2: one needs to strain a bit to hear much evidence of the musicians' other bands at work in Terrestrial Tones
column3: though fans of Black Dice's Creature Comforts might occasionally catch a familiar scent on the wind. And as with their debut
column4: one can't help but leave with the feeling that <em>Oboroed / Circus Lives could've withstood a vigorous revision or two
column5:
as well as with the realization that there's nothing to prevent these guys from releasing another couple records just like it before the year is out.

Windsor for the Derby has seen its fair share of changes over the years. The group formed in Tampa
column2: where the core duo of Dan Matz and Jason McNeely were joined by drummer Greg Anderson. Since that time
column3: the band grew to a four-piece
column4: then shrank again to just Matz and McNeely
column5: and those two have moved all over the country
column6: with McNeely residing in Austin
column7: Texas
column8: and Matz calling various East Coast cities home. In summer 2004
column9: however
column10: the two both moved to Philadelphia. As a result
column11: Giving up the Ghost is an anomaly in the band's catalogue. Instead of being forced to get together semi-annually to share ideas and record
column12: WFTD were able to record in their home studio
column13: creating an album that is more fluid than past efforts
column14: yet retains the band's characteristic disconnected feel.

column1: Windsor for the Derby's music has always been a bit of a mish-mash. Long instrumentals borrowed from post-rock sidle up next to folk-tinged pop songs; jarring
column2: discordant guitar lines ramble over subdued electronics. And although Ghost doesn't really break from that mold
column3: it finds the band moving further into the quiet
column4: low-key ambience they've been flirting with on the last couple of discs. Most of the songs feature solemn
column5: at times almost whispered
column6: vocals
column7: with several songs employing haunting
column8: catchy hooks.

column1: ""Empathy for People Unknown"" uses layered vocals and droning keyboards to create the hollow atmosphere that permeates the disc. Elsewhere
column2: the band flirts with new wave on ""Praise"" and post-punk on ""Gathering""; both fine examples of their knack for taking on a variety of styles while still sounding distinctive. In fact
column3: that dichotomy
column4: that ability to at once sound fresh and conventional
column5: has always been on of WFTD's greatest assets. Perhaps it's a result of Matz and McNeely building their musical relationship from different parts of the country.

column1: The strongest number here is ""Giving Up""
column2: a dark
column3: wistful ballad that begins with strained vocals and acoustic guitar that slowly lead into a somber
column4: repetitive middle section
column5: building to the refrain
column6: ""It's probable/ Things fall apart."" It's the sort of tune that could change Natalie Portman's life in Garden State II.

column1: There are only two instrumentals: Opener ""Dirge for a Pack of Lies"" and ""The Front"". The former features an odd
column2: minimalist beat accented by what sounds like an accordion
column3: while the latter is the closest thing here to post-rock
column4: with swirling echoes of keys
column5: guitar harmonics
column6: and other muffled ambient noise surrounding plaintive acoustic guitar strumming.

column1: With the addition of Anna Neighbor and Charlie Hall to the line-up
column2: Windsor for the Derby has once again branched into full-band status. The fact that this line-up has been frequently performing live only strengthens the cohesiveness of Giving up the Ghost
column3:
which may stand as the band's most focused disc to date.

Every few records Miguel Depedro of Kid606 steps away from loose and casual no-jacket-required IDM and changes his tone
column2: addressing his audience with an implied ""But seriously..."" These weightier releases typically feature nakedly emotional titles: P.S. I Love You
column3: The Soccergirl EP
column4: ""Sometimes""
column5: ""If My Heart Ever Ran Away It Would Be Looking For The Day When Right Beside You It Could Forever Stay"". I've always found these records charming
column6: as they convincingly render the dull romantic ache of a young artist who spends way too much time alone in front of his computer. Because of who Kid606 is and what we know of his obsessions
column7: there's a hint that perhaps technology has become an impediment to love.

column1: Resilience is the latest in this line
column2: and here Kid606 really puts himself in an artistically vulnerable place
column3: dedicating the record to his mom
column4: putting a photo of a young child on the cover (looks like Depedro at age three)
column5: and proclaiming that he ""didn't want to die without releasing Resilience."" More than most of his peers
column6: Kid606 understands that weird music without fixed emotional signposts can be shaped by titles and presentation. The unabashedly personal nature of <em>Resilience is supposed to make the music heavier and more resonant
column7: I guess
column8: but something feels off. Ultimately the directness with which Depedro addresses his audience is positive
column9: adding a goofy humanity to his machine music
column10: but the undercurrent of manipulation around Resilience is initially repellent.

column1: Which would of course be easily forgivable as long as the music is good. Resilience is quite different from earlier Kid606 forays into ambient
column2: mostly in that it's not really ambient at all. It is instead a stab at an electronic pop album
column3: with chords
column4: melodies and band-like arrangements. From there Kid606 feels from to wander
column5: from dark new wave in the tradition of Gary Numan (""Done With the Scene"" and ""Sugercoated"") to bubbly reggae (""Phoenix Riddim"" and ""Hold it Together""). The textures are not novel and are not supposed to be
column6: so a record like this is going to live or die on the basis of its tunes.

column1: A few make it for sure. ""I Miss You"" has a synth patch that sounds like Joe Zawinul's electric piano from Cannonball Adderly's ""Mercy
column2: Mercy
column3: Mercy"" and Kid606 goes to church with it
column4: piecing together a simply melody oozing with uplift. ""Banana Peel"" is robotic dub with a real sense of swing that slowly builds its infectious hook over its length
column5: so that when it finally comes together at the end the tension is released toward the sky. And ""King of Harm"" is a slight step down but still enjoyable
column6: convincing pastoral nostalgia dented in an interesting way by metallic percussion.

column1: If everything here were on par with these three tracks
column2: Kid606 would have something
column3: but the bulk of Resilience consists of indistinct mid-tempo beats and a lot vague loops that don't go anywhere. During certain stretches the music has an oddly narcotic effect
column4: tapping into that distracted alpha state that comes from listening to too many middling records from Morr. That these inoffensively dull tracks are collected as a Big Statement
column5: something the artist has longed to get off his chest
column6:
is a little depressing-- and not in a good way.

Apart from the Clash
column2: Joe Strummer's output was a little disappointing. Granted
column3: it seems impossible to get past the legend
column4: for him or for listeners. He appears to have been more intelligent-- or at least better spoken-- than your average first-generation punk
column5: and his vocals sounded fierce in their commitment to the material. His lefty politics had a bristling integrity
column6: yet weren't so extreme as to be inaccessible or unrealistic. All in all
column7: he showed many younger musicians that it was possible to play punk that was more than nihilist or fascist. To many
column8: he represents rock's most populist principles
column9: grandest ambitions
column10: and highest callings. A handful of good-not-great albums and one or two side projects were all the solo work he left when he died suddenly in 2002
column11: and none of it compares to his work with the Clash. But really
column12: most anything would have paled next to The Clash or London Calling.

column1: His influences were wide-ranging
column2: although nowadays they're rarely as regarded as those he influenced. He found inspiration in early rock n' roll
column3: particularly the Sun Studio sound (it's no coincidence Jim Jarmusch cast him in the Memphis-set <i>Mystery Train
column4: arguably his finest post-Clash work). And yet
column5: his later solo albums like Global A-Go-Go
column6: Rock Art and the X-Ray Style
column7: and parts of Streetcore drew from world music influences. As in his politics
column8: his music readily acknowledged a world and a culture apart from Western imperialists. Astralwerks is resurrecting two projects that showcase the diversity of his musical interests: a collection of songs from his band the 101'ers and a mid-1980s soundtrack he composed.

column1: The 101'ers were a London pub-rock band that formed in the early 1970s and played around London exhaustively. They cut several demos
column2: prepared a single
column3: and toured with the Sex Pistols before Strummer joined what would become the Clash. Elgin Avenue Breakdown Revisited-- a mouthful of a title-- collects all their recorded output onto one disc
column4: providing a brief but thorough overview of the band's short career. It encompasses the LP Elgin Avenue Breakdown
column5: which was released in 1981
column6: and a few live tracks and an alternate take of their lone single
column7: ""Keys to Your Heart"" (reportedly inspired by future Slits drummer Palmolive). In addition to contemporary groups like Dr. Feelgood
column8: the obvious pub-rock connection is early r&b;
column9: derived from early progenitors like Chuck Berry and Ike Turner through the early Beatles-- at times it sounds like Elgin Avenue could be located in Hamburg. They even cover ""Maybelline"".

column1: While pub-rock has modest aims
column2: <em>Revisited proves generally solid
column3: anchored by songs like ""letsagetabitarockin'"" and ""Steamgauge 99""
column4: rambunctious run-throughs that rush headlong into their melodies
column5: as Strummer delivers his lyrics in a garbled slur. But there really are no surprises here
column6: just a general consistency on the studio tracks that bleeds into repetitiveness
column7: hinting that Strummer turned to punk perhaps out of restlessness with pub-rock's strictures. The live cuts of ""Maybelline"" and ""Gloria"" suggest he was already halfway there by the time he met his future bandmates.

column1: Skip ahead almost a decade: After the Clash had a top 10 U.S. hit with ""Rock the Casbah""
column2: the group disbanded
column3: and an aimless Strummer acted in and soundtracked the Nicaraguan epic Walker
column4: starring Ed Harris and directed by Alex Cox. Cox was and still is notorious for Repo Man and Sid & Nancy
column5: and he and Strummer worked together on Straight to Hell around the same time. Walker was an ambitious flop
column6: but Strummer's soundtrack holds up fairly well
column7: thanks mainly to a group of seasoned musicians. His mix of Latin American music with a determined pop flair creates some intriguing moments
column8: like the rollicking rhythms and Zander Schloss's quick picking on ""Machete"" and the two versions of the samba ""Filibustero"" (the original and a remix that originally appeared on a rare 12"")
column9: which bookend the soundtrack nicely. The vocal tracks sound like barroom sing-alongs
column10: rowdy and slurred
column11: but tuneful and more atmospheric than many of the instrumental tracks.

column1: But Walker is as much a product of its time and circumstances as of Strummer's imagination. With its slick saxophone
column2: ""Latin Romance"" sounds like a lost '80s relic
column3: a slice of cinematic cheese. Strummer seems as confined here as he did with the 101'ers
column4: which may be due to the restrictions either of the film itself or of the soundtrack form. Like Elgin Avenue Breakdown Revisited
column5: Walker at the very least expands our picture of Strummer as it presents an artist whose imagination was often bigger than the forms he worked in-- a predicament that created a compelling tension between possibility and actuality
column6:
the music as it is and the music as it could have been.

column7: hinting that Strummer turned to punk perhaps out of restlessness with pub-rock's strictures. The live cuts of ""Maybelline"" and ""Gloria"" suggest he was already halfway there by the time he met his future bandmates.

column1: Skip ahead almost a decade: After the Clash had a top 10 U.S. hit with ""Rock the Casbah""
column2: the group disbanded
column3: and an aimless Strummer acted in and soundtracked the Nicaraguan epic Walker
column4: starring Ed Harris and directed by Alex Cox. Cox was and still is notorious for Repo Man and Sid & Nancy
column5: and he and Strummer worked together on Straight to Hell around the same time. Walker was an ambitious flop
column6: but Strummer's soundtrack holds up fairly well
column7: thanks mainly to a group of seasoned musicians. His mix of Latin American music with a determined pop flair creates some intriguing moments
column8: like the rollicking rhythms and Zander Schloss's quick picking on ""Machete"" and the two versions of the samba ""Filibustero"" (the original and a remix that originally appeared on a rare 12"")
column9: which bookend the soundtrack nicely. The vocal tracks sound like barroom sing-alongs
column10: rowdy and slurred
column11: but tuneful and more atmospheric than many of the instrumental tracks.

column1: But Walker is as much a product of its time and circumstances as of Strummer's imagination. With its slick saxophone
column2: ""Latin Romance"" sounds like a lost '80s relic
column3: a slice of cinematic cheese. Strummer seems as confined here as he did with the 101'ers
column4: which may be due to the restrictions either of the film itself or of the soundtrack form. Like Elgin Avenue Breakdown Revisited
column5: Walker at the very least expands our picture of Strummer as it presents an artist whose imagination was often bigger than the forms he worked in-- a predicament that created a compelling tension between possibility and actuality
column6:
the music as it is and the music as it could have been.

America likes its heroes to bleed of-the-dirt ""authenticity""-- to carry a bible and have spent time in jail
column2: to struggle with fidelity and caw about murder and remorse. Consequently
column3: the box set section of most American record stores currently boasts a big
column4: black mess of Johnny Cash-themed cubes. Posthumous marketing is particularly vicious: <em>The Original Sun Albums
column5: Unearthed
column6: Man in Black
column7: and now the four-disc The Legend bang corners
column8: demanding further canonization
column9: tapping persistently at our shoulders and wallets.

column1: Still
column2: the diversity of the Cash shopping spectrum is oddly apt: Both in-store and out
column3: there are loads of different Cash archetypes to choose from. Check Outlaw Cash
column4: with his middle finger shooting heavenward
column5: face scrunched into anti-authoritarian glee
column6: invading prison yards and calmly bellowing
column7: ""I shot a man in Reno/ Just to watch him die."" Conjure Country Cash
column8: standing alongside Jimmie Rodgers and Hank Williams
column9: eyes hard
column10: shaking his head at Nashville's pop-evolution. Note Family Cash
column11: devoutly religious
column12: wanting to record gospel songs with Sam Phillips
column13: curling into June
column14: and praying to be faithful. Or watch Neo-Cash lock arms with Rick Rubin
column15: inadvertently charming the PBR-and-Pumas set with loads of quasi-ironic covers.

column1: It's only logical
column2: then
column3: that The Legend is all-Cash in all forms. It's the most comprehensive Cash box released to date
column4: covering nearly a half-century (1955-2002) of song
column5: parsing his discography into four logically-titled discs: ""Win
column6: Place and Show: The Hits""
column7: which gathers radio favorites
column8: ""Old Favorites and New""
column9: all classic Cash
column10: ""The Great American Songbook""
column11: which sees Cash tackling traditional cuts
column12: and ""Family and Friends""
column13: two dozen collaborative cuts. The Legend is being released by Columbia
column14: and unsurprisingly
column15: focuses more heavily on Cash's Columbia work than his early Sun recordings. Regardless
column16: its four discs expertly showcase the astonishing scope of Cash's talent: ranging from goofy
column17: 1950s teen dance-pop (""Ballad of a Teenage Queen""
column18: ""Guess Things Happen That Way"") to gospel (""Were You There (When They Crucified My Lord)""
column19: with the Carter Family) to traditional Americana standards (""I've Been Working on the Railroad""
column20: ""Streets of Laredo""). The breadth of Cash's songbook almost justifies the dozens of roles he's been hustled into over the last 50 years-- and with seven previously unreleased songs
column21: dug up from tapes in a backroom at the House of Cash
column22: devotees are sure to start rethinking all other boxes crowding their shelves.

column1: Cash recorded his first single for Sun in 1955 (""Hey
column2: Porter"" / ""Cry
column3: Cry
column4: Cry"")
column5: featuring Marshall Grant on bass and Luther Perkins on guitar (then known as the Tennessee Two
column6: and later
column7: after W.S. Holland
column8: one of country music's very first drummers
column9: joined the lineup
column10: as the Tennessee Three). But it wasn't until 1956
column11: with the release of ""I Walk the Line""
column12: a dutiful promise of loyalty to then-wife Vivian Liberto
column13: that Cash managed to snag a hit. Appropriately
column14: ""I Walk the Line"" opens the first disc of <em>The Legend
column15: its meandering guitar line interrupted by Cash's tinny humming
column16: pitter-patter percussion
column17: and that voice: Soul and gravity were hard-wired into Johnny Cash's pipes. Rumbling and shockingly understated
column18: Cash's deep
column19: belly-blows sound like divine direction
column20: all confidence and purity. The effects are transformative: Imagine ""Ring of Fire"" sung karaoke-style
column21: and then reconsider how Cash's grim nonchalance pushes the song to new levels of weird profundity
column22: a sober counterpart to its yapping horns and jiggly rhythms.

column1: Disc One corrals all of Cash's proper hits
column2: making for a monstrous party record; Disc Two offers up a less cohesive collection (herded in under the vague heading ""Old Favorites and New"")
column3: but manages some impressive transitions. Cash's rendition of ""Long Black Veil"" (also attempted by Joan Baez
column4: David Allen Coe
column5: Marianne Faithful
column6: the Band
column7: and Bobby Bare) is properly captivating: when Cash gets to the ""me"" in ""The slayer who ran/ Looked a lot like me
column8: his voice presses delicately but firmly
column9: guaranteeing loads of jittery chills. Disc Two also harbors three previously unissued tracks
column10: the best of which falls first: ""Doin' My Time"" is a pert
column11: swinging ode to proper imprisonment
column12: complete with guitar solo and courthouse laments.

column1: Disc Three is packed with American classics
column2: including a handful of Leadbelly songs (collected by Alan Lomax
column3: of course)
column4: some Jimmie Rodgers
column5: and plenty of Traditional cuts. Disc Four
column6: which includes a mess of duets (see Waylon Jennings
column7: Willie Nelson
column8: Bob Dylan
column9: Elvis Costello
column10: the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band
column11: Ray Charles
column12: and others)
column13: has its questionable moments (Cash fronting U2 for ""The Wanderer"" is particularly gruesome)
column14: but closes with <em>The Legend's prized jewel: ""It Takes One to Know Me""
column15: written by Carlene Carter
column16: June Carter Cash's daughter from her marriage to country star Carl Smith. Johnny attempted to record the song in 1977
column17: as a duet with June
column18: but left the song unfinished; Carlene's brother
column19: John Carter Cash
column20: agreed to produce the track
column21: adding backing vocals by himself
column22: his wife Laura
column23: and his sister Carlene. ""It Takes One to Know Me"" mixes pristine
column24: swelling strings with schmaltzy piano and guitar
column25: but the vocals are mind-blowingly gritty: June and Johnny croon in perfect imperfect harmony
column26: vowing earnest devotion to each other
column27: acknowledging all the knots inherent to matrimony. The results are hauntingly real.

column1: People tend to discuss Johnny Cash with grave
column2: unbridled reverence
column3: which is appropriate but awkward: His website (which bursts open with a booming ""Hello
column4: I'm Johnny Cash
column5: welcome to JohnnyCash.com!""
column6: a proclamation just loud and weird enough to knock you off your chair)
column7: compares ""Hello
column8: I'm Johnny Cash"" to ""In God We Trust""
column9: claiming both ""resonate throughout the world"" and ""stand the test of time."" The liner notes to The Legend boast that in 1969
column10: Muhammad Ali and Johnny Cash were the best-known people on the planet. Cash's prominence may have wilted slightly in the past 35 years
column11: but not significantly
column12: and <em>The Legend. should only confirm Cash's American Hero cred-- not as some presupposed ""authentic
column13:
but as an astoundingly multi-talented songwriter.

The Repulsion Box opens with several seconds of naked kickdrum hammering out a 4/4 stomp. The next 31 minutes are a headlong blur of scratchy guitar
column2: Celtic and country influences
column3: pounding rhythm
column4: and Scottish accents
column5: a brand of danceable Glasgow post-punk that actually makes a sonic point of its Scottishness. The adversarial vocal interplay of Scott Paterson and Adele Bethel provides a dramatic focal point for the band's thumping arrangements. In my review of their debut EP
column6: last year's Love the Cup

column8: and the comparison still holds here.

column1: As it turns out
column2: the album's brief running time is something of a saving grace
column3: as the band's relentless approach-- even the quiet songs ride fast
column4: insistent beats-- is a bit numbing over the course of a whole LP. The music is intensely simple
column5: almost minimalist
column6: and Ailidh Lennon's bass (she switches to mandolin on opener ""Medicine"") locks in with drummer David Yow to create the irresistible undertow that churns Paterson's guitar into knotty tangles.

column1: Even with the band's relatively monochromatic range
column2: there are a few standout tracks. The jumpy scuzzbucket march ""Dance Me In""
column3: Bethel taking lead against a chorus of ""whoa-oh""ing Patersons as fierce snare drum crookedly crackles below. ""Taste the Last Girl"" rides a shuffle beat and features the album's biggest chorus
column4: one of the few that doesn't explode from a more subdued verse. Paterson's slide guitar gets its best workout on ""Choked""
column5: erupting in manic
column6: violent outbursts.

column1: The record's arid
column2: unadorned sound-- as captured with almost live rawness by Nick Cave and PJ Harvey producer Victor Van Vugt-- does have its occasional drawbacks
column3: one being that in some of her more outlandish moments of rage
column4: Bethel's vocals stand out a little too strongly
column5: such as her shrill screams on the chorus of ""Gone"" and some of her more emphatic shouts on ""Red Receiver"". But the rough-around-the-edges sound generally works in the band's favor
column6: the record's feeling of spontaneity often proving one of its biggest assets. Sons & Daughters are far from perfect
column7: but The Repulsion Box is an energetic
column8:
sometimes thrilling record by a band slowly but surely carving out a unique niche for themselves.

As my friend and I were riding around our mid-size southern town
column3: listening to the new Agoraphobic Nosebleed
column4: he turned to me and said
column5: ""This stuff's pretty cool but a whole album of it just turns into whatever after a few minutes...but
column6: they've got a good drummer."" That's because their percussionist is a fucking inanimate object from Japan called a drum machine.

column1: At least my friend was correct about one thing: Agoraphobic Nosebleed's digital grind-power violence-hardcore turns into ""whatever"" in just a short period of time. Their credo revolves around bringing glory to the sacred deity of speed and grind
column2: while their profane lyrics flicker with fury and pomposity. At least I assume they do
column3: as they don't feel the need to provide the listener with written lyrics for this 2xCD reissue
column4: which encompasses everything they did prior to their first Relapse record
column5: Honky Reduction.

column1: Recording for Relapse
column2: ANb grew restless with their standard grind sound and released Frozen Corpse Stuffed With Dope with all of its strange digital flourishes and Altered States of America with of all its two-second tracks. Bestial Machinery represents a purer time when the sorcery of a machine was being harnessed because of ANb's inability to find a drummer of suitable speed. It's definitely not ""straight"" grindcore but it's also not drastically different from any album that colorful reviewers call ""filled to the brim with buzz saw guitars that cut like a rusty bayonet through the ripe flesh of venereal diseased Vietnamese hookers."" You've heard many albums like it
column3: but in an  established hardcore genre it's not whether you break the formula
column4: it's whether you can give it enough attitude to make it interesting. ANb have a little bit of attitude-- and a bunch of kickass cartoon devils and skulls on their cover! I could see this cover art being photocopied and plastered on some notebooks at school
column5: right under someone's hand drawn Slayer logo. It's that good.

column1: Disc One contains 76 tracks-- taken from various 7-inch records and splits-- of flailing guitars and cathartic screaming
column2: while the drum machine farts off non-stop double bass. It's not metaphysics or anything
column3: but with titles such as ""From Filth to Defilement""
column4: ""The Newlyweds Are Raped""
column5: and ""The Executioner Vs. The Sodomite""
column6: it's just good
column7: wholesome Satan-influenced stuff. There are 60 more songs on Disc Two. The demos on Disc Two sag due to their lackluster mixing and production
column8: while compilation tracks seem misplaced.

column1: Most grind snaps you into attention at the beginning then you either catch the groove (if you can call it that) or you tune it out in an ambient fashion and let your mind wander. Bestial Machinery mixes the two and turns into a sort of interesting drone. It's not bad music as far as this goes
column2: it just isn't filled with one interesting idea after another
column3:
which is what is usually needed to be completely engrossed. After a little while it simply turns into ""whatever."" But it's a really loud and fast whatever.

In 2003
column2: Holopaw's self-titled debut prodded the overlap between vague electronic twitterings and scrappy folk tradition-- its follow-up
column3: Quit +/or Fight
column4: sees Holopaw striking a slightly more symbiotic medium
column5: the line between their blips and strums now appropriately faded. Quit +/or Fight may lack the immediate melodic punch of the band's debut-- it forsakes pristine strums for skewering electric guitar and scrappier arrangements-- but what the record sacrifices in warmth
column6: it makes up for in atmospherics. Quit +/or Fight is Holopaw's first Christmas record
column7: alternately sweet and grim
column8: an impeccable homage to snow and weird
column9: wintry disembodiment. These songs are dark and cold
column10: and their August release-- sent squirting out into an expanse of rotting
column11: hundred-plus days

column13: floppy gardens-- proves oddly apt. All the chills you'll feel will finally do some good.

column1: Holopaw's juxtapositions may be less striking now
column2: but the results are more cohesive. Still
column3: Quit takes a little extra time to settle into: Without being purposefully difficult
column4: Quit +/or Fight can still be willfully (and successfully) obtuse
column5: scrappy and determinably distanced from the shiny perfection of Holopaw. Since 2003
column6: the band has added another guitar player (Tom Reno of Florida post-rockers the Mercury Program)
column7: and with members currently scattered from their former home base of Gainesville
column8: FL
column9: Holopaw has adopted the increasingly popular U.S.P.S. method of sound recording
column10: drifting ideas back and forth from producer Mike Pecchio's studio in Bed-Stuy
column11: Brooklyn to Philadelphia
column12: Florida
column13: and elsewhere. Whimsical and charmingly slack
column14: Quit +/or Fight harnesses that distance to create a record intensely sympathetic to gaps in place and time.

column1: Opener ""Losing Light"" is all pause and thumping drums
column2: punctuated by prickly guitar lines and overdubbed vocals-- singer/lyricist John Orth (also of Isaac Brock side-project Ugly Cassanova) encapsulates late December with awkward
column3: crushing intimacy
column4: his voice drifting from half-whisper to full-song: ""The tree from the house to the curb/ Tinsel pathways to the yard...We're losing light/ The holiday
column5: whittled down to this/ Plenty of time winding out."" Orth hits all the seasonal notes
column6: from sugar plums to corduroys to fake snow to space heaters
column7: but also manages to capture (at times
column8: majestically) the glorious
column9: scarf-wrapping loneliness inherent to deep freeze.

column1: ""Velveteen (All Is Bright.)"" is painfully transformative and one of the band's strongest tracks to date: Michael Johnson's cymbal swats crack and whimper like icicles shattering
column2: filled in by Tobi Echevarria's thick
column3: loping bass (think snowshoes) and Jeff Hays' wispy
column4: hot-breath-on-cold-air pedal steel. Orth coos earnestly about Santa Claus steering his reindeer straight to the bottom of Lake Superior (""Without a thought he said 'Go Dasher
column5: Go Dancer'/ And they dropped their heads
column6: disappeared into the cloudbank...Those silver bells didn't make a sound when they fell to rest at the bottom of Superior"")
column7: which seems like a precious conceit
column8: until you stop thinking about it and just listen to his poem: slowly
column9: the song tumbles towards a thundering climax
column10: all heavy
column11: honking synths
column12: and guitar push
column13: Orth bellowing fervently ""All is calm/ All is bright/ And they're dragging the lake with peppermint hooks
column14: pink rushing to frostbite tips""-- before slinking back into the band's signature closing hush.

column1: Unsurprisingly
column2: Quit +/or Fight is also a breakup record
column3: heavy with heartache and dark
column4: belly-punching bits. Orth always had a photographer's sense of detail and light
column5: and here
column6: watching becomes an essential thematic reprise. In ""Curious""
column7: a lover is shakily peered at from a clearing
column8: and in ""Losing Light""
column9: Orth's eyes turn to a sleeping body: ""I watch you like some newborn kid/ Curling your fingers in and out of fists/ Run my thumb across your hip."" Things aren't good (""I'm lost to you"")
column10: but Orth is veiled and careful with his details
column11: immersing listeners in the fuzzy
column12: shaking haze of endings.

column1: Musically
column2: the band stretches its muscle: ""3-Shy-Clubs"" funnels mysterious percussive smacks into a groove-heavy bossa nova rhythm
column3: while ""Curious"" folds in bass clarinet and sinewy falsetto. The title track originally appeared as a FOUND Magazine (publisher of found notes
column4: letters
column5: photographs
column6: and stories) song of the month
column7: and features a mess of snagged lyric crumbs
column8: cobbled together into a shockingly logical whole (some of which seems like an eerily apropos PTSD response to military propaganda: ""OK
column9: so I'm no longer/ The best of the best/ No longer defending the U.S.A."") Still
column10: the track
column11: which mixes tinkling bells with steel guitar caws and high
column12: layered harmonies
column13: has moments of chilly clarity: ""You've done enough/ Quit and/or Fight
column14: Orth implores. It's the perfect title for a band that demanded self-evolution
column15:
and got exactly what it wanted.

of Light largely failing live up to the band's original run. It's not
a
terrible
column2: but it doesn't exactly play to their

column1: strengths
either. Indeed
column2: it seems as though Auer & Stringfellow are somewhat

column1: preoccupied with proving that they rock
and it comes at the expense of the effortless hook-craft of <em>Frosting on
the
Beater and Success. Frosting... represents the band's commercial (and
for
me
column2: creative) peak
column3: and it seems as though they're reaching back to

column1: that
sound on a lot of these songs
column2: but in the wrong order. Whereas the

column1: crunchiness of that record was incidental
column2: the volume cranked high in

column1: the
service of the songwriting
column2: in this case
column3: the guys seem to be writing

column1: the
songs to fit the volume they want to play at
column2: a strategy that doesn't

column1: work
nearly as well.
So you get self-conscious rockers like ""I Finally Found a Jungle I
Like""
column2: a

column1: flailing song with novelty lyrics and a horn part that references the
Who's
""5:15"" but that's way too busy and graceless to leave a lasting impact.
""All in a Day's Work"" similarly pounds away with tons of distortion but
forgets to offer anything memorable. If
that were the whole story
column2: the record would be an unqualified mess
column3: but

column1: thankfully
column2: the Posies are too good to make an entire album of

column1: uninspired
goop. You can hear echoes of the band's past glory in the exquisite
verse melody of ""I Guess You're Right"" and the thundering
column2: Moog-tinged

column1: rocket ride of ""Second Time Around""
column2: the album's only song that strives for their trademark heavy pop rush and actually nails it.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: album opener ""It's Great to Be Here Again"" is a fascinating foray into a humid
column3: claustrophobic r&b; sound
column4: with guitars and

column1: mellotrons
trading off the ominous countermelodies while Auer and Stringfellow
interweave their vocals with their usual deftness. Auer's effortlessly
melodic ballad ""Conversations"" is another highlight
column2: featuring soft

column1: verse/loud chorus grunge dynamics that should feel played out by now
but
actually work perfectly. Stringfellow gets in his own nice ballad with
the
alcohol-soaked ""Last Crawl""
column2: a song that reflects a lot of his recent

column1: solo
work with its smooth AM gold sheen.

that we
might have hoped for
