spiked with a few classic moments of patent posies pop ecstasy. Fans
will
want to have it
column2: for sure

back catalog to Frosting... or the Dream All Day compilation. The

may not be what they once were

column3: if only for the handful of great

they offer here

I'm glad they're still around.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/5837/homepage_large.a401949e.jpg|Wrath of Circuits|3117.0|The Nein|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sonic Unyon']|2005-08-09 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:55:49.344314|"

Mired in self-consciously muddy aural manipulations
column2: this North Carolina band can't (and don't) live up to their acute
column3: exacting name on this debut full-length. With the post-punk party currently in the thick of its heaving
column4: cash-in-reunion stage (a precursor to the inevitable ""Real World vs. Road Rules""-style cannibalization)
column5: the foursome tries to reinvigorate the bash by throwing out the straight-on kick-drum angularity of their EP and enrolling in a hazy art class where Dave Thomas visually represents skewed entropy by throwing Mark E. Smith through a sugar-glass window. Hardly melodic and not adventurous or invigorating enough to pull off the scuzzy brassiness of its yelping forefathers
column6: the Nein get all anguished and pissed as it alternates between grubby grunge slow jams and lo-fi oom-pah on Wrath of Circuits.

column1: Much of the group's murkiness can be credited to the addition of samples guy Dale Flattum
column2: who sprays utterly random noises all over the album
column3: diluting its semi-weak impact in the process. On ""The Vibe"" we get aquarium bubble pops
column4: atonal video game bleeps
column5: and a plinky keyboard loop
column6: but instead of somehow adding a much-needed fresh Faustian dimension to the song
column7: the found sounds highlight its aimlessness. With Flattum's tape wrangling a constant distraction
column8: inconspicuously snarling singer Finn Cohen seems to be holding back from truly unleashing a wail worthy of the best posting and punking. His largely incomprehensible musings on relationships and technology make Trail of Dead's similarly themed Source Tags & Codes seem like an unbridled lyrical masterpiece.

column1: Fittingly
column2: the ""oh oh"" chorus of the relatively lucid
column3: hi-hat stomping ""Lost Sounds"" provides brief respite from the purveying sub-Sparta At the Drive In spin-off crud. Proving once again that the Nein would be better off without their own muddle butt Jim O'Rourke causing an unrequited mess
column4: the spare ""Bleeding Elvis"" is a fine smooth-burning ballad Trent Reznor would love to cry about. Just try to ignore the words--""I had to replace those integers with impossible functions and irrational combinations leading to more furtive glances""-- which are headache causing pseudo-computer puzzles nobody wants to crack.

column1: Excess is usually something post-punks don't have time to worry about-- and it should stay that way. Though they're clearly (desperately) trying to initiate their own neo-post branch
column2:
the Nein don't have the tunes or the funk or the strut to break free from the surplus sonic ballyhoo that engulfs much of Circuits. Maybe they should have just copied Gang of Four. More.

Eight thousand Michael Jackson fans-- the ones in the U.S. that actually
bought this collection in its first week of release-- could be wrong
though I think it's more likely that the group outside of those 8K are
the ones with the loose screws. After all
column2: a two-disc best-of

column1: collection from a performer with more than 150 million records sold
worldwide is bound to have better sales numbers than the latest volume
of Now That's What I Call Music!. But
the majority of those millions were sold years ago
column2: before (most of)

column1: the plastic surgeries
column2: the 30-foot statue floating

column1: down the Thames
column2: the gold-plated baseball equipment
column3: the crotch

column1: grabbing
column2: the ethnic slurs
column3: the baby dangling
column4: and the countless

column1: accusations of child molestation. Suffice it to say that any pop
capital Michael Jackson accrued during his reign as the self-appointed
King of Pop has long been spent. However
column2: as these two discs ably

column1: show
his honorarium was
column2: for a time
column3: actually justified.

column1: For most folk
column2: Disc One might be more than enough MJ. The disc covers

column1: the meat of Jackson's career
column2: starting with the Jackson 5
column3: and ending

column1: with the title track from Thriller. Anyone that doesn't know
""ABC"" or ""I Want You Back"" must be deaf
column2: and anyone that doesn't enjoy

column1: these songs must be dead. Pitchfork staffer Tom Breihan will be happy
to know that ""The Love You Save"" is included-- it's the J5 #1 that
never
gets any play
column2: and it might be the best of the bunch. Of course
column3: as

column1: much as Jackson is all about the finger-snapping funky dance stuff
he's
also about the treacly ballad
column2: so instead of ""I'll Be There""
column3: there's

column1: ""Got To Be There""
column2: which really shouldn't be anywhere. And then

column1: there's
""Ben""
column2: a song about a boy and his homicidal rat that touched the lives

column1: of both Crispin Glover and Eddie Vedder. Yay for the skip button
because right after that roadblock comes great unsung tracks from the
Jacksons
column2: like ""Blame It On the Boogie""
column3: and the ubiquitous Quincy

column1: Jones
collaborations that made Jackson a legend.
The final 12 tracks of Disc One are comprised with cuts from <em>Off
The Wall and Thriller
column2: including all seven Top Ten singles

column1: from the latter album. The importance of Thriller can't be
understated
column2: musically or otherwise-- 27x platinum in

column1: the
U.S. alone
column2: ushered in the age of milking albums for all they're worth

column1: helped dimwits at MTV realize that having popular black artists on
their
nascent network might be a good idea
column2: gave John Landis a chance to do

column1: more werewolf stuff-- but it's the Off The Wall tracks that
shine
brightest. The triple-threat of ""Don't Stop Till You Get Enough
""Rock
With You""
column2: and ""Off The Wall"" hinted at the effortless pop hopscotch

column1: Jackson would execute on the next record. Thriller does manage to
make the Beatles and heavy metal (and
column2: um
column3: monster movies) hold hands

column1: like BFFs-- no easy feat in the early 1980s
column2: regardless of who's doing

column1: it-- but it could take years of distance and brainwashing for ""Beat It""
or ""Billie Jean"" to shake off their played-out flavor. Hearing ""Thriller""
away from the zombie chorus line is interesting
column2: though
column3: if only

column1: because
one comes to realize that a song about being pursued by 40-eyed
behemoths actually made CBS a boatload of cash. Of course
column2: the title

column1: track's success came in the wake of a song that goes from a refrain of
""You're just a buffet/ You're a vegetable"" to a coda of tribal
chanting
column2: which goes to show how off-the-wall Thriller actually

column1: was.
In light of what Disc One offers
column2: Disc Two will invariably disappoint

column1: just as the 8x platinum Bad was a disappointment in the
wake of the unparalleled success of Thiller. With hindsight
column2: it's hard not to see the songs from Bad in an

column1: unflattering light. As Tom B. noted in his write-up regarding the
Michael Jackson box-set
column2: this is where all the tics and affectations

column1: that people think of when they think of Michael Jackson came to roost-- not five seconds pass without an unwarranted ""shamon"" or ""hee-hee"" or
hiccup or ""woo"". While Bad boasted more #1 hits than its
predecessor-- ah
column2: the joy of riding coattails-- most of the singles are

column1: just lesser versions of Thriller tracks. ""Bad"" is a beat-down
""Beat It""
column2: ""The Way You Make Me Feel"" is a tepid rehash of ""P.Y.T.""
column3: and

column1: the hamfisted seduction in ""Dirty Diana"" is light years from the
alluring ambiguity of ""Billie Jean"". And then there's ""Man
in
the Mirror""
column2: wherein the King reacquires his taste for schmaltzy

column1: sub-""Ben"" balladry
column2: now cutting it with a need to ""make that change""

column1: for
the sake of the entire human race. It might be simply a matter of a
failed negotiations
column2: but it's no small blessing that ""We Are the World""

column1: is far
column2: far
column3: far away from this collection. Unfortunately
column4: no such

column1: boon
kept the chirpy and grointastic ""Black Or White"" off the board.
That said
column2: the second disc does right by Jackson
column3: culling quality

column1: tracks
from the sparse smattering of original material that followed That
Album
column2: and all the non-musical nonsense that surrounded this music.

column1: Without such selectivity
column2: an interested novice would be better served

column1: just grabbing Off The Wall and Thriller. Instead
Bad's gorgeous ""I Just Can't Stop Loving You"" and neglected Dangerous single ""In The Closet"" receive
their deserved moment. Even the DOA single from his latest album
column2: ""You

column1: Rock My World""
column2: sounds surprisingly spry. Being far removed from that

column1: awful video featuring Marlon Brando's corpse and Michael Tucker as
Mini-MJ helps
column2: just as getting the hell away from Iman and Eddie Murphy

column1: does wonders for ""Remember the Time"". Therein lies the rub of
Jackson's
career-- as fantastic a performer
column2: songwriter
column3: and singer he is
column4: people

column1: at large are going to remember Michael Jackson more for his Wacko Jacko
public persona than for his exemplary body of work. Given recent
events
column2: the backlash is understandable
column3: but in regards to the actual

column1: music being offered here
column2:
it's a damn shame.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/13206/homepage_large.6fa9385d.jpg|Analord 6|111.0|AFX|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rephlex']|2005-08-08 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:55:51.484289|"

Again
column2: Richard James travels to his past-- if not to save the future
column3: then at least to save extravagantly for it. The Aphex Twin mastermind's first project since 2001's perplexing Drukqs started promisingly enough
column4: albeit expensively
column5: with the 40 quid Analord 10 last December. However
column6: subsequent offerings in this procession of 12-inches have raised disconcerting questions: Why is one of the 90s most enduring electronic musicians splitting so much time between 80s electro and the sound of his own early-career Analogue Bubblebath efforts? Is he washed up
column7: or just acid-washed? Taking us to the cleaners?

column1: As of the sixth
column2: seventh
column3: and eight Analord installments
column4: James     seems more TB-303 now than man
column5: twisted and primeval. These insistent
column6: repetitive analogue compositions are almost perversely anachronistic
column7: a robot curled up in the fetal position rather than the conqueror of new colonies we'd once come to expect. The multi-layered beats of Drukqs persist
column8: but the glistening melodies that set apart the     Twin's finest work are
column9: after burbling just beneath the surface of some early Analord tracks
column10: all too infrequent in this batch.

column1: Much of Analord 6 will be familiar to anyone who's heard its predecessors. ""Batine Acid"" plies rote acid lines with intermittent spookiness
column2: ""Snivel Chew"" adds sawtooth synths and rapid handclaps
column3: and ""2 Analogue Talks"" at least mixes things up with squeaky
column4: high-pitched scales giving way to the monotonous
column5: clock-like donging     of what sounds like a horn sample. Standout ""I'm Self Employed""     suggests that whatever James is up to
column6: he's not just going through the     motions-- at least not always. Fragile
column7: lonely melodies and countermelodies reminiscent of his ambient works build into a rust-eyed chorus and actually take it somewhere.

column1: Analord 7 kicks off with the (deceptively?) straightforward acid-house of ""Lisbon Acid""
column2: which bloops
column3: thumps
column4: fuzzes
column5: squelches
column6: and ultimately meanders for an entire side. The echoey off-key     synths of ""Pitcard"" start and stop on a dime
column7: which is better than a     nickel (worth more
column8: too!). The ""AFX Acid 04"" evokes almost an acid     remix of Spoon's ""I Turn My Camera On"" with its slinky changes and     martial pace
column9: before giving way to ominously discordant skarronking.

column1: The tracks on Analord 8 are named for computer viruses
column2: likely     in an effort to discourage file-sharers. Then again
column3: the pieces might     have been so named because a few are among the series' most infectious     so far. Awash in disco hi-hats
column4: ""PWSteal.Ldpinch.D"" beckons with the     type of decidedly non-digital lust
column5: come-hither bass line
column6: and slightly     detuned hooks that a Kylie Minogue could have taken upchart. Blippy     ""W32.Deadcode.A"" is almost as good once the bridge arrives like a     between-storms rainbow. ""Backdoor.Berbew.Q""
column7: meanwhile
column8: rises and     subsides with a burbling bass and choir-like synth chords
column9: and     ""Backdoor.Spyboter.A"" unfolds similarly over pings and more handclaps
column10:
but neither really goes anywhere. That's the disappointing crux of James's current collection of never-awful but rarely remarkable noodlings.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/3309/homepage_large.648f0733.jpg|Lepidoptera|1645.0|Fursaxa|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ATP']|2005-08-08 00:00:00||2016-06-11 20:55:52.200484|"

The visionary 12th century theologian
column3: scientist
column4: and composer Hildegard von Bingen once referred to herself and her creations as ""a feather on the breath of God."" Perhaps it could be said that there are hints of this same celestial guidance at work in the ethereal music of West Philly's Tara Burke
column5: aka Fursaxa. Drawing inspiration from Hildegard's hypnotic medieval plainchants
column6: as well as from a host of other ancient folk and psychedelic traditions
column7: Fursaxa's fourth official full-length Lepidoptera ripples and flutters with an enthralling mantric pulse uniquely its own.

column1: With previous albums released by Acid Mothers Temple and on Thurston Moore's Ecstatic Peace
column2: as well as appearances on such compilations as this year's epochal By the Fruits You Shall Know the Roots
column3: Burke has managed to associate herself with the ongoing free-folk movement. But
column4: as is the case with contemporaries like Charalambides or Tower Recordings
column5: Fursaxa utilizes folk music's essential ingredients-- acoustic guitars
column6: hand percussion
column7: simple
column8: repetitive melodies-- in a such a deeply personalized (and wholly unpredictable) fashion that she's able to construct enchanted new meadows of sound that exist completely beyond any reductive classification.

column1: Centered predominantly upon Burke's multi-tracked
column2: endlessly coiled vocals and the steady hum of vintage keyboards
column3: Fursaxa also bears comparison to Nico's The Marble Index and
column4: especially
column5: to the post-Opal solo work of Kendra Smith. As with those performers
column6: Burke often tends to prefer arrangements that feature their instruments one or two at a time
column7: with tracks like ""Russian Snow Queen"" carried along solely upon the steady current of a single pump organ and her swirling
column8: wraith-like vocal loops. Despite their humble settings
column9: however
column10: the songs of Lepidoptera attain an astonishing degree of richness and tranquil warmth
column11: possessing a depth of field unheard on earlier Fursaxa releases like 2000's Mandrake.

column1: Throughout the album
column2: Burke's lyrics (such as they may be) remain stubbornly inscrutable
column3: but on tracks like the opening convocation of ""Freedom"" her cascading
column4: self-replicating harmonies render her actual words superfluous. And on the primitive campfire rounds of ""Velada""
column5: ""Neon Lights""
column6: or the expansive
column7: sublime ""Poppy Opera""
column8: one can't help be transfixed by the way her gently dividing melodies continually circle back on their tails
column9: as Burke uses raised fingers to trace infinity symbols across the constellations
column10:
sounding for all the world like that feather carried aloft by unseen hands.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/840/homepage_large.1fe859b0.jpg|The Body Lovers/The Body Haters|417.0|The Body Lovers/The Body Haters|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Young God']|2005-08-08 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:55:52.760183|"

Continuing Michael Gira's effort to consolidate anything Swans-related into 2xCD period piece comes the The Body Lovers / Body Haters. It seems to be the ""post Swans drone"" period. That's nice because it walks a thin line with being the ""I'm gonna release whatever experimental bullshit I feel like because I own a record label"" period. Luckily
column2: two decades of quality drone and repetition under the Swans moniker
column3: has made Gira a master of the two.

column1: The Body Lovers was originally released in 1998 with the subtitle Disc 1 of 3. It was eventually followed by The Body Haters. Since then Gira has focused on the song-oriented Angels of Light project and the chaperoning of freak-folkers Devandra Barnhart and the Akron/Family.

Gira has now packaged his hour-long-song period with a 10 minute bonus track and expanded artwork full of swine and human sex organs. The Body Lovers is 73 minutes (segued into 10 tracks) of semi-calculated instrumentation-- the kind that doesn't find the artist jacking off with the EQ or sampler to their hearts content. It starts with what sounds like the distant chimes of gamelan music reverberating around a cavern and then morphs into a different winding style every eight minutes or so. There are funeral dirges
column2: shimmering and floating guitars
column3: crescendos reminiscent of Godspeed You Black Emperor
column4: impenetrable walls of stretched notes
column5: austere jangle
column6: samples of crying babies and weeping women
column7: and only one minute of Gira singing. It's all attention holding and it's very reminiscent of what the Swans were trying on <em>Soundtracks for the Blind
column8: which is fitting since parts of Body Lovers were culled from sound samples dating back to 1982. The rest is from the standard Swans crew like Jarboe
column9: Bill Rieflin
column10: and Larry Mullins
column11: while members of Pan Sonic
column12: Origami
column13: and Deathprod also make contributions.

column1: While <em>The Body Lovers pulls disparate sounds together into one enthralling hour
column2: The Body Haters just wanders around in some gloom and doom for 36 minutes. It simply sounds like Gira indulged in some looping software and did some half-assed processing. The bonus track is 10 minutes of instantly recognizable bits of Swans songs chopped up and layered on top of each other. The Body Haters isn't crap
column3: it just pales in comparison to everything else Gira has done and therefore sounds very amateurish. But I'll allow a few mistakes in two decades of high quality mind warping music.

column1: If it's just repetitive droning
column2: what makes The Body Lovers so good? It's because Gira has consistently made atmospheric music that doesn't take you into the atmosphere. It doesn't invite you to escape reality. It suffocates you with the not so comforting truths of humanity
column3: without causing introspection
column4: retrospection
column5: or even speculation. The emotions are so strong yet so indistinct that half the Swans fans you'll meet can't make a cohesive argument as to why they listen to them. If Gira can cause all this enigmatic wonder in an hour-long piece without his trademark lyrics then he must truly be making special music...The catch is that it only works at night.

column2: 'Metal'
column4: Baltimore's rowdiest Rowdyists
column5: have long pursued the perfect

column1: hoax: They constructed an apocryphal protest narrative around their
2002 Oxxxes LP
column2: and released a fake split with Arab on Radar

column1: that pissed off the entire experimental-hardcore community (all ten
members of it). The knee-jerk reaction is to write off these
boondoggles as publicity stunts; more realistically
column2: they seem to

column1: stem from an abiding sense of playfulness: ""Let's see what'll happen
if we do this."" How many extra records are you going to sell
for pretending to be Arab on Radar
column2: anyway?

column1: In another counterintuitive turn
column2: the band known for their long

column1: absurd song titles seems to have omitted them entirely from their
latest EP. This could scan as a rejection of song-as-bio-fodder
column2: a

column1: tacit manifesto stating that music belongs to the moment
column2: not the

column1: museum. The stance would dovetail nicely with the fact that Oxes
really occur in the ephemeral live setting
column2: and remain unable to

column1: accurately translate their visceral shows to the album format. The
five songs on Oxes EP are brambly
column2: muscular math-metal slabs

column1: but listening to pre-recorded versions of them is like looking at
graffiti in an art gallery. The execution is remarkable
column2: the lines

column1: expressive
column2: the colors vibrant
column3: but they lose something vital without

column1: the world clamoring around them.
Still
column2: Oxes manage to put a unique spin on math-rock and metal. Let's

column1: be frank: Math-rock is some boring
column2: noodly-ass shit that
column3: by packing

column1: ""surprises"" into every abrupt meter and dynamic shift
column2: completely

column1: squanders its capacity to surprise. Oxes focus on math-rock's
bodily
column2: combustible potential and turn it into drunken party music

column1: never forgetting which part of the genre's name is the modifier and
which is the foundation. The bluesy metal vamp of the first track
never squanders a shred of momentum for forced complexity
column2: and the

column1: second is a twisted Southern rock shredfest that's intricate without
being cerebral.
While American metal often resorts to vague tropes of Germanic
fascism
column2: Oxes forgo guttural vocals and jackbooted cadences in

column1: favor a metal that sounds drenched in American pride. This
faux-jingoism really comes to the fore on the fourth track
column2: with its

column1: anthemic stomp and satirically patriotic guitar lead that echoes
Hendrix's incensed ""The Star-Spangled Banner"". This blend of
bombast and belligerence undercuts the entire album (ironically
column2: but

column1: with a vitality that would shame Toby Keith)
column2: barring the final track

column1: which bends toward a compressed
column2: gnarly sort of Krautrock. If it isn't

column1: a breakthrough record
column2: Oxes EP is another solid entry from a

column1: band that refuses to abandon the sense of play and mischief that rock
music threatens to lose as it vies for space in the safe havens of

glossy column inches.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/6583/homepage_large.384d1223.jpg|Weird Tales of the Ramones|3524.0|Ramones|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rhino']|2005-08-07 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:55:53.910665|"

The tale of the Ramones is as sad as it is weird. Four guys from down-and-out Queens adopted a common surname and the same juvenile delinquent uniforms as they blasted short
column2: simple
column3: sublime pop songs from cramped stages. Eventually some of the brothers-in-arms became bitter enemies. When Johnny stole his girl
column4: Joey didn't fight him at the lockers
column5: but wrote ""The KKK Took My Baby Away"". Therein lies a large part of the Ramones' charm: they made rock music with bored kids in mind
column6: with short-attention-span song lengths
column7: blunt guitar riffs
column8: and unsophisticated lyrics. The band was self-aware
column9: sure
column10: but the Ramones always seemed genuinely invested in what might seem like the shallowest eddies of pop culture. In the process
column11: they tapped the essence of rock music in its purest form.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the movement the Ramones helped to jumpstart quickly got away from them
column3: turning their practiced naivete into impractical nihilism. Their desperate hopes for mainstream popularity
column4: which showed through in their professionalism and dogged work ethic
column5: were dashed when the Sex Pistols made the new style a four-letter word. Instead of taking over the airwaves
column6: they became a cult band
column7: but always seemed too big for such a diminutive label. As their contemporaries imploded or exploded
column8: the Ramones maintained a surprisingly consistent pace
column9: continuously putting out albums but refusing to expand their sound too far beyond the template they established on their self-titled debut. The Ramones were the anti-Beatles: they resisted musical growth and maturation
column10: and we're all the better for it.

column1: Collecting 85 songs from 20 years
column2: Weird Tales of the Ramones
column3: which Johnny helped to curate
column4: reveals just how little the Ramones' sound changed and just how little that mattered. Every song
column5: from the first track (""Blitzkrieg Bop"") through the last (""R.A.M.O.N.E.S."")
column6: shares the same basic elements: sharp
column7: fast guitar riffs; punchy momentum; driving tempos; and handclaps or sha-la-las or some other nod to pre-album rock pop music. The Ramones' aesthetic has become such common currency
column8: though
column9: that it's easy to forget how raw they could sound
column10: how tough and tender
column11: how just a handful of elements could be recast in infinite variations.

column1: If they were reluctant to evolve their sound
column2: the Ramones constantly tested its flexibility. Phil Spector gives ""Do You Remember Rock and Roll Radio?"" the wall-of-sound treatment
column3: and ""Rock and Roll High School"" is basically a revved-up Beach Boys song. In the 1990s
column4: they covered Tom Waits (""I Don't Want to Grow Up"")
column5: the Who (""Substitute"")
column6: the Amboy Dukes (""Journey to the Center of the Mind"")
column7: and Love (""7 and 7 Is"")
column8: but best of all is their webslingin' version of the original ""Spider-Man"" theme
column9: which originally appeared on the 1995 compilation Saturday Morning: Cartoons' Greatest Hits.

column1: Like most box sets these days
column2: Weird Tales is a multimedia package. A DVD contains all of their videos
column3: most of them embedded in a 1990 program that includes short interviews with contemporaries (Debbie Harry
column4: Tina Weymouth) and fans (former New York Yankees pitcher Dave Righetti
column5: who doesn't seem to get the band). Most of the videos are just silly enough to fit with the Ramones' particular aesthetic
column6: although ""Something to Believe In"" is a hilarious parody of stuffy mid-80s USA for Africa self-seriousness.

column1: But this box set's real attraction
column2: aside from the music
column3: is the packaging
column4: which includes a thick comic book inked by several artists including Mary Fleener (<i>Life of the Party)
column5: Bill Griffith (Zippy the Pinhead)
column6: John Holmstrom (two Ramones album covers)
column7: and Sergio Aragones
column8: whose work in Mad magazine was influential to the Ramones specifically and to early New York punk in general. Despite the reliance on the questionable narrative that the Ramones destroyed synthetic disco and bloated arena rock (which is truer as a personal listener reaction than as rock history)
column9: the comics avoid self-serving remembrances by fawning devotees and fussy rock-critic exegeses that often sanitize subversive artists. These strips are informative
column10: imaginative
column11: and-- oh yeah-- pretty damn funny. Moreover
column12: this art form is the inky equivalent of the Ramones' music and image-- their scuffed Chucks
column13: ripped jeans
column14: Mickey Mouse t-shirts
column15: and outlandish haircuts-- and reinforces their aura of permanent adolescence.

column1: This sort of inspired cleverness keeps Weird Tales from eulogizing the Ramones or
column2: worse
column3: explaining away their mighty mysteries. And perhaps their lack of mainstream success during their lifetimes ensured a larger and posthumous triumph: in the thirty years since their debut
column4: several generations of listeners have connected with their music in a very personal way without the interference of institutionalized nostalgia. Weird Tales makes it possible for future generations of pinheads
column5: dropouts
column6: glue-sniffers
column7: brats
column8: cretins
column9: mama's boys
column10: and punk-punk-punk rockers to discover the Ramones as if for the very first time. Gabba gabba hey!

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/2597/homepage_large.29c4a4cb.jpg|More Than Music
column3: as crew mixtapes go
column4: Dipset's new <em>More Than Music
column5: Vol. 1 is a cut above the typical riffraff
column6: does that mean the Dipset emcee is superior to his counterpart in Ruff Ryders or G-Unit? No
column7: it's a package deal. Even with three-four hitters Cam'ron and LaRon ""Juelz Santana"" Jones skewing the group average
column8: Dipset has its acknowledged bench players. But with most products of its kind coming off as second-stringer pity parties
column9: More Than Music is generously well apportioned
column10: complete with assiduous rapping
column11: pricey beats
column12: and packaging that wasn't printed on a cousin's Epson.

column1: For New York crews
column2: mere proliferation isn't good enough; world domination is more their speed. Dipset has similarly high-minded ambitions
column3: and if you've missed its highfalutin talk of spearheading a new Harlem Renaissance
column4: the title track clarifies: Amid thunder claps
column5: a sermoning voice announces
column6: ""In the beginning of this movement
column7: it was all a dream. The passion...the dedication...the persistence...TO ACHIEVE GREATNESS."" Talk of movements is hardly cutting edge
column8: but Dipset infuses even its fluffiest shit-talkin' with ungodly energy. To hear the opener's stony
column9: swelling strings is to feel the world shifting beneath your feet.

column1: But how much of this is just ""Final Countdown"" quixotism? Depending on who's blogging
column2: a lot or more. Is Dipset the most galvanizing crew in hip hop
column3: or another peacocking cadre? Yes. All that chest puffing is part of what makes them so gripping. Juelz Santana calls himself ""crack in the flesh"" and his best tracks make you believe it. Cam specializes in corner talk
column4: but his is a unique breed
column5: full of doublespeak
column6: circular logic
column7: and fantastical imagery. He scampers around boilerplate topics like a jester
column8: abstracting and obstructing like he's too smart to help it. Even those apprenticed to the head honchos are coming up strong. So
column9: cardboard moralists dismiss at will
column10: but Dipset outstrips the species norm by a crosstown block.

column1: Above all
column2: Dippers be thuggin' to the sound of Dips-- all razoring strings
column3: airtight beats
column4: and clenched-teeth deliveries. That sound is a shot of stanozolol wherever MTM threatens to wane
column5: which is often enough. Believe it or not
column6: at 67 minutes
column7: the album has some soft spots. But the triumphant opener ""Dipset Symphony"" is not such a spot. More rag than symphony
column8: the track rides a rickety piano roll while 16's fly by at a frantic clip. (Featuring no fewer than six emcees and the hypeman's bloviating inside of three minutes
column9: it's the album's busiest number.) No one quite steals the show
column10: but Santana christens the melee (""All eyes on the honorable. Who?/ Dipset
column11: back to the grill again. Live at the barbeque."").

column1: Among the understudies
column2: J.R. Writer is my frontrunner to crash the big leagues. He takes ""You Make Me Say""
column3: a bittersweet
column4: 6/8-feel beat from Heatmakerz
column5: and delivers Cam-lean verses in his own
column6: edgier voice (""See you draped in designer wear/ Nice clothes/ Like those?/ I'll take you to buy a pair/ Where? That's Paris to Milan/ Fill your bag up with Vuitton/ You the baddest and the bomb/ Understand
column7: I'm a rapper with some charm/ Don't worry 'bout the little groupies grabbing on my arm""). Close behind Writer may be recent Dipset newie (and charter female member) Jha Jha. She spits on the immaculate ""So Gangsta""
column8: which samples Aalon Butler's 1977 semi-classic ""Rock and Roll Gangster"". Unlike
column9: say
column10: Three 6 Mafia's Gangsta Boo
column11: who reaches down into her belly for her rhymes
column12: Jha isn't afraid of the higher registers.

column1: Considering the typically slipshod nature of these things-- and a scant three appearances from Cam'ron-- More Than Music should be worse. But Dipset economized-- the album is low on skits (there's only one) and superstar cameos (again
column2: only one
column3: as Fabolous drops in on Santana's thrilling ""What's It Gon' Be"")-- to make room for its lesser-known emcees. When blessed with the type of talent Dipset has among its top brass
column4: that kind of generosity is heartening. When the fledglings deliver like sturdy blue-chippers
column5:
that's astonishing. Dipset group hug (no homo).

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/2909/homepage_large.269a28d7.jpg|All Over the World: The Very Best of Electric Light Orchestra|1427.0|Electric Light Orchestra|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Epic']|2005-08-07 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:55:54.913930|"

The treasure chest of unheard and underappreciated
bands must surely be running dry
column2: what with

column1: us coming close to two full decades of CD-Age
vault-plundering and with multitudes of internet sites
cratedigging for the next forgotten masterpiece. So
rather than continuing to look for those artists that
sold 11 copies of their wildly influential debut
record before imploding
column2: perhaps we should be

column1: re-appraising bands that have been right under our
nose all the time
column2: almost annoyingly so.

column1: Electric Light Orchestra is one of those ubiquitous
bands that could be due for a second glance
column2: a concept

column1: that briefly gained some momentum when ""Mr. Blue Sky""
all of a sudden became mandatory accompaniment for
Charlie Kaufman-scripted films. However
column2: a number of

column1: elements appear to be aligned against any sort of
serious
column2: non-kitschy ELO revival: 1) That absurd (yet

column1: appropriate!) name
column2: 2) The incredibly Muppetish

column1: appearance of frontman Jeff Lynne
column2: and 3) The group's

column1: all too easily parodied and carbon-dated sound
column2: with

column1: its liberal use of falsetto and classical strings.
But the things that so firmly attach ELO to a
particular time in music history (the 1970s) are also
the things that make them so uniquely great. ELO
existed at a point in music history where I was
brought up to imagine the armies of rock and disco
locked in a mortal battle like the Cubs and Cardinals
wherein the two flavors were mutually exclusive to
apartheid-like extremes thanks to fun things like
racism and homophobia and fear of keyboards. New- ave
compilations have somewhat dissuaded me of that
notion
column2: but the field of what is now classic rock most

column1: assuredly remained a genre that surely treated the
influx of disco's dance beats and string arrangements
as straight heresy
column2: and it was against this backdrop

column1: that ELO made its heroic stand.
Of course
column2: Lynne's bold mixing of the disco and

column1: the rock seems almost accidental in retrospect--
books tell me that disco didn't peak until the
mid-seventies
column2: while the self-titled first ELO album

column1: hit stores in 1971
column2: so the chronology doesn't quite

column1: match up. The original vision for the Electric Light
Orchestra was rather coarsely telegraphed by their
name: a merger of pop
column2: rock
column3: and classical music that

column1: yielded some pretty embarrassing early moments (including the
Beethoven/Berry mash-up of ""Roll Over Beethoven""
column2: not

column1: included here) and some pretty great ones (rock +
opera aria = ""Rockaria!""
column2: included). Early on
column3: Lynne

column1: and co. made music that was sky-high on excess
column2: drunk

column1: on the ambitious precedent set by the Beatles and the
fact that
column2: wow
column3: studios have that many tracks to work

column1: with now?!
So it was pretty much serendipity when
column2: by the middle

column1: of the decade
column2: classical-sounding strings were

column1: suddenly a hot property thanks the burgeoning disco
scene
column2: Walter Murphy's ""A Fifth of Beethoven"" even

column1: echoing ELO's own attempts to update old Ludwig van.
To Lynne's credit
column2: he didn't follow his rock peers in

column1: mocking the new dance sound
column2: but rather embraced the

column1: accidental resemblance
column2: recording the group's best

column1: singles (""Evil Woman""
column2: ""Living Thing""
column3: ""Telephone

column1: Line"") in an extravagant and non-condescending fusion
of disco and rock. Only the Bee Gees were able to
ride the wave of fashion more profitably
column2: though each

column1: band's success should hardly be held against
them...there's a reason why both are still heard on the
radio incessantly.
All of the above makes ELO an excellent greatest hits
band
column2: as there's not a whole lot to be found in the

column1: deep cuts of albums like Out of the Blue and Face the
Music. It's appropriate then
column2: that there are

column1: numerous ELO greatest hits sets already
available
column2: with <em>All Over the

column1: World only the latest entry. Truthfully
column2: it's

column1: fairly interchangeable with the other comps
already on the market
column2: covering the band's

column1: less-rewarding backbeat-obsessed early period through
the heady disco days described above through to the
proggier late-70s work which birthed ""Mr. Blue Sky""
(and it's lesser-known sibling ""The Diary of Horace
Wimp""). Only two reasonable complaints can be lodged:
the baffling omission of choice slow jam ""Can't Get It
Out of My Head""
column2: and the pointless

column1: just-barely-two-discs length.
It's a bit difficult to argue the
cred-bolstering relevance of ELO in 2005
column2: given that

column1: it's practically impossible to find a current band
that sounds anything like Mr. Lynne's studio
concoction. Pushed to the wall
column2: I'd probably argue

column1: for the importance of ELO in paving the way for what
we're now referring to as ""hyperprog
column2: the condition

column1: of idea/instrument abundance employed by bands like
The Fiery Furnaces and Head of Femur. Yet none of
these bands possess that essential quality of pure
excess that sets ELO apart
column2: that coke-infused sheen I

column1: associate with the 70s thanks to P.T. Anderson films
and VH-1 documentaries. Based off this second-hand knowledge
column2: Electric Light Orchestra are

column1: about as perfect a sound representation of that era as
you're bound to find...and that makes them a band worth

remembering.

While some indie bands
column2: with their impenetrable song structures
column3: vexing lyrics
column4: and contrived wardrobes
column5: practically beckon for a lambasting
column6: Chapel Hill's Doleful Lions aim to purr and meow their way onto your lap in the damned most adorable way possible. For seven years they've Snuffleupagussed themselves into fans' hearts by setting saccharine folk-pop in a lysergic fantasyland of sasquatches
column7: werewolves
column8: and other assorted bugaboos. Yet even at their most far-fetched offerings
column9: the band's only elicited a mere chuckle and slap on the wrist from critics. That's the perk of possessing one of the most soothing lullaby voices this side of Stuart Murdoch
column10: and singer Jonathan Scott knows it.

column1: On 2002's Out Like a Lamb
column2: Scott finally cashed in on his stirring voice and keen pop sensibilities by ebbing his New Age fixations and utilizing a full band. For better or worse
column3: Shaded Lodge marks a return to the cauldron for the Lions as studio wizard David Jackson and Scott collaborate to conjure up more kooky things that go bump in the night. However

column1: ""kooky"" for the Lions is hardly an Olivia Tremor Control or even Flaming Lips brand of quirky pop
column2: but rather stripped down Simon and Garfunkel acoustic ditties drenched in reverb and the occasional sound effect.

column1: Despite the eerie blips and screeches
column2: Out Like a Lamb is the only thing really haunting this record. The tracklist's split between sprightly indie pop and drowsy
column3: woebegone folk. Opener ""Shame Magic in the Night Galley"" takes a ginger step towards ebullient pop but it's reserved and simplistic sound portends the downcast mood swing to come. ""Watch the Skies / A Boy's Life"" follows the tradition of ""Bridge Over Troubled Water"" both musically and lyrically
column4: though cumbersome images of Arthurian adventure convolute its message: ""Let's smash the magic wonder window...in the halls of Abel's fault."" I mean
column5: the stagnant melody's uninspiring enough
column6: but who'd actually rally around the credo ""Snuff the mortal candelabra's light""?

column1: Luckily tracks like ""Destroyer of the West"" and ""Satanic Blood"" stand as the white knights in this tale. The former features Elliott Smith/Cass McCombs hybrid vocals coupled with jangly guitar almost slow enough to pass as shoegazer. Yeah
column2: ""Satanic Blood"" is another ""Just Like Heaven"" permutation
column3: but Scott's raspy vocals greatly contrasts Robert Smith's
column4: and these days who isn't hitching ersatz Cure tracks to their albums for good measure? After all
column5: immediacy like this makes Scott's seven-minute doldrums somewhat worth the wait. However
column6: while fantastical lyrics and Lord of the Rings settings may buy you time when ideas are lacking
column7: as Scott himself sings
column8:
add too much filler and ""the hexagon and necroworm won't wait.""

column2: a friend organized an Unsane show at bar in New Jersey

column1: Lizard
column2: Big Black
column3: Helmet

column1: drifts and got a place in front (not that there was much competition).
As my feet thawed (I remember puddles of water)

Live

In fact

column3: Matthew Herbert released <em>The Mechanics of Deconstruction under his Radio Boy moniker. Each of the album's tracks was created using a single commercial product that Herbert found objectionable. Selections included ""Nike"" and ""Television"" and ""Gap""
column4: along with food-themed offerings like ""Coca-Cola"" and ""McDonalds"". The Mechanics of Deconstruction was a curious artifact
column5: moving Herbert's hypercritical pop art into a more overt realm
column6: and
column7: best of all
column8: it was a free download. You could (and still can) pluck the tracks off the web and then listen while reading along with one of Herbert's anti-corporate rants. It wasn't a great record by any stretch but it was certainly novel
column9: and enjoyable to a large extent because of Herbert's genius with sampling and arrangement.

column1: The fire inside that motivated Herbert to create ""Starbucks Is Coming"" from <i>Mechanics-- a track made by manipulating
column2: recording
column3: and processing one caramel latte and one Frappucino-- still burns. Plat du Jour shares a lot with the earlier Radio Boy record
column4: only this times the methods and arrangements are far more sophisticated and the critical guns are trained solely on the globalized corporate food industry including
column5: again
column6: Starbucks. Per the record's website
column7: ""An Empire of Coffee"" contains a sample of ""60 Vietnamese robusta beans being dropped in to an empty container of monsanto-made roundup weedkiller."" The figure is chosen because 60 beans is the approximate number used to create a shot of Starbucks espresso.

column1: With Herbert
column2: I've always been happy to consider the political content of the records to be a clever bonus
column3: while the music as a purely sonic experience is allowed to stand on its own. I listened to Plat du Jour five or six times without paying attention to the song titles and not having read the online methodological descriptions
column4: and this one didn't hold up quite so well. Opener ""The Truncated Life of a Modern Industrialised Chicken"" has impressively dense production
column5: juggling macro and micro samples (field recordings of massive coops of terrified chickens are heard alongside eggs bumping into Pyrex bowls to create bell-like tones). But the musical elements-- the way with chords and melody that set the highly trained Herbert apart-- fail to add anything substantial
column6: and we're left with an OK mid-tempo electronica tune. ""These Branded Waters"" is similarly forgettable
column7: with a music box arrangement of manipulated samples of Dasani water bottles that's brings to mind a middling electro-twee act.

column1: The songs that work best are faster and let Herbert indulge his skill for propulsive rhythm. The aforementioned ""An Empire of Coffee"" has some heavily caffeinated peaks where all the man's weird noises coalesce beautifully into a cartoon bump machine. The music on ""Hidden Sugars"" goes well with its title and theme
column2: as it sounds like something Tim Burton might've incorporated into his film of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
column3: highly mechanized but playful and candy-striped
column4: with vague hints of menace lurking in there somewhere. ""White Bread
column5: Brown Bread"" is as funky as a package of onion kulcha a week past its sell-by date. The album's lone vocal track
column6: ""Celebrity""
column7: on the other hand
column8: is a smug indictment of celebrity food endorsements
column9: with an embarrassing chorus that ends with ""Go Beyonce! Go Beyonce!""

column1: Maybe here the album is only half the art. Maybe one needs to go to the accompanying website
column2: read how the pieces were made
column3: and contemplate the state of the modern agriculture industry to really experience what Herbert is getting at. If that's true
column4: who exactly is the audience for this sort of thing? What advantage do these songs have over an essay? I've read <i>Fast Food Nation
column5: enjoyed it
column6: and I haven't had a hamburger
column7: McDonald's or otherwise
column8: in three or four years (though the Schlosser book had nothing to do with me quitting beef). But nothing in the music feels connected to any feelings I have toward the food industry. Surely
column9: in the end we have to judge the music as music
column10:
and Herbert has done a lot better.

When we describe records to you
column2: we tend to talk about the other records they resemble
column3: the genres they relate to
column4: and the sorts of people who might listen to them: One band sounds like Joy Division
column5: another has something to do with house music
column6: another is for metal kids. Talk about The Golden Morning Breaks
column7: though
column8: and you'll find yourself stuck talking about nothing more abstract or general than the instruments used to make these sounds-- the bells and the proto-cellos
column9: the cathedral ambience
column10: and the 19th century glass glockenspiel.

column1: And sure
column2: a lot of albums are all about sound. But what sets this one apart is how natural it is about that agenda: This is the rare variety of abstracted
column3: post-electronic New-Music recording that's almost entirely its own creature. (Sounds like? Sounds like beautiful bells!) On Colleen's last album
column4: Cรฉcile Schott crafted the same delicate drifts from ghostly samples and found sounds
column5: but that just kept it all rooted in our common vocabulary of German sound artists and laptop soundscapers. With this album
column6: she's left sampling behind entirely
column7: crafting elegant
column8: barely-there compositions from the pure timbres of instruments old and
column9: well
column10: old; will it surprise anyone that the album's title comes from the work of a 17th century lute virtuoso?

column1: So maybe you get something like Fennesz unplugged
column2: or the Georgian-era chamber version of Kompakt's Pop Ambient discs-- but then maybe you don't. Where your laptop dreamers turn their attention to the crackles and the staticky thunderstorms that hover around their music
column3: Schott composes; the incredible ""Summer Water"" spends most of its time pushing strings into ever-so-slightly different arrangements
column4: each new interval shading new colors onto the looping lute figure in the center. And where electronic ambience fills the stereo spectrum with one immersive swell of sound
column5: Colleen sits closer to Brian Eno's original vision of it-- she's interested in the way these instruments can play delicate harmonic figures without ever gathering them up into linear form. Funnily enough
column6: it's her most organized pieces that are both the most unique and the easiest to like; it's when she weaves farthest out into the abstract and the formless that she starts to sound most like something you've heard elsewhere.

column1: But only 15% of your brain is following what the instruments are playing. The other 85% is soaking in the pure sound of their reverberations-- the secret-garden chime of ""The Heart Harmonicon""
column2: the harbor-spanning organ of ""The Happy Sea""
column3: the rounded pluck of the lute and the pearly fog that drifts behind it. The strange part is that Schott's all-natural recordings and endlessly-pretty harmonic shifts make this album far more accessible than you'd ever dream; PC technicians rarely get this musically hospitable
column4: and I'm not sure who on the modern-composition New Music side gets quite this relaxed and generous. (I'm not sure which of them would put a fairy-nuzzling unicorn on an album cover
column5: either.)

column1: Oh
column2: it's still abstract. Even if you love it
column3: you may struggle to find the appropriate moments to really spend with it-- how much time do you set aside each week to sit quietly with your eyes closed and think about all the different qualities of light you could imagine when you were a child? And if you're not particularly inclined to that beautiful pure-sound formlessness
column4: Colleen's moves in the opposite direction still might not make this much more than some glorious wallpaper-- not the worst role
column5: but not the best Colleen can take. Because at its most effective
column6: this album is kinda everything it should be
column7: and everything we should ask: Something simple
column8: beautiful
column9: and coherent
column10: something that feels remarkably imaginative but entirely unpremeditated. If I didn't have bills to pay and a kitchen to clean
column11:
I'd be all over it.

The reason alaska! is providing support for Dinosaur Jr.'s reunion tour probably has more to do with intraband connections than musical similarities. Alaskan! bassist Russ Pollard played in Lou Barlow's post-Dino group Sebadoh from 1997 until 2000
column2: and singer/guitarist Imaad Wasif toured with another Barlow project
column3: the Folk Implosion. But the exclamation point-enhanced trio isn't really an oddball choice for touring buddies: while they don't share Dinosaur Jr's penchant for messy
column4: genre-busting musical chaos
column5: alaska! has a similar potential for controlled noise: at its best the trio churn guitar-grinfing maelstroms that sound barely contained.

column1: That potential
column2: unfortunately
column3: is not entirely realized on their second album
column4: <em>Rescue Through Tomahawk
column5: which sounds all too contained. Musically
column6: it's frenetic in all the right ways: The rhythm section-- Pollard and former Red Aunts drummer Lesley Ishino-- moves agilely across a range of dynamics
column7: from quiet to loud on the gradually building ""Surrender""
column8: from slow to fast on ""The Light""
column9: from gentle to harsh on almost every track. Throughout Rescue Through Tomahawk Imaad Wasif's guitar weaves menacingly
column10: adding a darkly hesitant intro to ""Through the Years"" and a triumphant coda to ""Surrender"". When alaska! plays like an instrumental band
column11: it proves surprisingly formidable: a little subtler than Kinski
column12: a little less abstract than the equally exclamatory Godspeed You! Black Emperor
column13: a little less brutal than Mogwai.

column1: However
column2: alaska! isn't an instrumental band; lyrics and vocals dominate their songs. Wasif proves a perfectly adequate singer: his gravelly voice tends toward expressive overenunciation and to-the-rafters projection
column3: and his trippily oblique lyrics lean more toward eerie evocativeness than outright clarity. But really
column4: vocals and lyrics are the least interesting aspects of this album; Wasif doesn't say anything on <em>Rescue Through Tomahawk that the band doesn't state more clearly
column5: concisely
column6: and compellingly through its wound-tight sound
column7: its clockwork interplay of instruments
column8: and the friction between styles and musical elements.

column1: The songs seem hemmed in by their devotion to Wasif's lyrical structures
column2: and often the attempt to subvert them creates some intriguingly
column3: if unintentionally
column4: tense moments. Pollard kicks out a bassline on ""Real Is Your Control"" that bounces like French pop
column5: and it gives the song an unexpected punch. The guitar solo on ""A Fury of Trees"" plays like an outro
column6: at least until Wasif comes in again with one last verse
column7: but really
column8: the frenetic momentum sounds like the song's one true reason for being. Likewise
column9: most of these songs sound somehow clipped
column10:
like they want to cut loose and stretch and sprawl well beyond their imposed limitations.

Allow me to burst your bubble: Fruit Bats have found a new drummer
column2: 11 days after Pitchfork deemed their ISO newsworthy. His name is Ron Lewis
column3: and by day he's a cheesemonger. (Folks
column4: you can't make this stuff up.) But buck up
column5: would-be Bonhams: There are more exciting outfits to get down with
column6: bands that change tempo
column7: use odd meter
column8: leave space for rip-roarin' tom rolls. Fruit Bats
column9: not so much; they traffic in power-pop without the crunch and speed-- or
column10: in brainchild Eric Johnson's ambitious mind
column11: the hypothetical link-up of Holy Modal Rounders and Rumours-era Fleetwood Mac.

column1: Ron Lewis
column2: I hereby charge you
column3: sir
column4: with making these fine songwriters less fucking facile. I want you to bring a brick of oozy stilton to rehearsal and let that sucker stink up these folk-poppers' cleanly confections.

column1: If you want a tutorial in how to render well-written songs flaccid and boring
column2: pick up Spelled in Bones. Critics bray about ""trimming the fat"" but that's specious; fat is good! Fat is French! Fruit Bats could use some flab; even the title track
column3: a groggy wisp of a ballad that should drag on ad infinitum
column4: wraps up in under four minutes. Where are the tumescent guitar peals
column5: the reverb-drowned vocals
column6: the bombastic drums? There is no two-part coda. Worse
column7: no trumpet fanfare. Mr. Lewis
column8: you have a tough road to hoe.

column1: But you're ideal for the job. Johnson retains his affinity for spic-and-span 70s pop-- the kind that put newspaper in the bass drum
column2: sat Elton John at the keys
column3: and was tooled on a microbiotic level. But what John and the Macs (both Fleetwood and P. __Cartney) lacked in daring
column4: they more than made up for in cheese. So it's to the Fruit Bats' credit that they chose a replacement skins-hitter who actually peddles the stuff.

column1: Spelled in Bones doesn't achieve Rounders-Rumours synthesis
column2: but it does successfully update arena fro-yo by excising the coke-fed navel-gazing. Where their forebears slung self-absorbed musings from a druggy maw
column3: Johnson's words harmonize with the Bats' docility.

column1: Fruit Bats previously got pleasant with a pair of sleepy Brian Deck-produced slabs
column2: 2001's Echolocation and 2003's Sub Pop debut Mouthfuls. But Spelled in Bones
column3: their most polished effort
column4: teeters near soporific. And that's a shame
column5: because it houses some of the band's best songs. Though the consistency of instrumentation
column6: volume
column7: and tempo invite the ear to wander
column8: there are jags of awesomeness. Amid so much swooshing fluidity
column9: the closing vocal repetition on ""Silent Life"" is almost defiant. Listless ballad ""TV Waves"" is jolted by a chugging
column10: hi-hat driven pickup
column11: which
column12: beneath melty guitar peals (finally)
column13: gives the illusion of double-time. Johnson's vox are polite and low-key mostly
column14: which is why his sudden unblanketing of a sultry falsetto on ""Born in the '70s"" is both a much-needed spark and a tease.

column1: Instead of paying homage to the megastars of a bygone era-- whose sound comes naturally but whose spirit remains evasive-- Fruit Bats should focus on where they fit in among active analogues. For Pete's sake
column2: they're on Sup Pop. With a loosened-up approach Johnson could put himself in a league with A.C. Newman and labelmates the Shins. As for newcomer Lewis: Bring it

column3: arguably the greatest ""black rock"" band ever...Actually

column5: they are far and away the best black rock band ever. In fact

column7: they're one of the greatest rock bands period
column8: up there with any classic rock dinosaur you care to name. And though it's tempting to launch an essay on the racism of rock radio-- or rock journalism for that matter-- I'll stick to the band. Even as they're revered as legends and purveyors of the some of the best funk of the 70s
column9: I've read relatively few accounts on their greatness as a pure rock band. But they had it all: great players
column10: great singers
column11: a great look

column13: actual hits
column14: great albums
column15: great drugs

column1: They started small
column2: backing up ringleader George Clinton's Parliaments in the late 60s. When Clinton got into arguments with his label Revilot over money and rights
column3: he decided to start recording his backup band instead
column4: using the original Parliaments singers (Clinton
column5: Ray Davis
column6: Clarence ""Fuzzy"" Haskins-- and come on
column7: dude's name is ""Fuzzy""-- Calvin Simon and Grady Thomas) as ""guests."" Guitarists Eddie Hazel and Tawl Ross
column8: bassist Billy Nelson
column9: drummer Tiki Fulwood
column10: and eventually
column11: master keyboardist Bernie Worrell were the band that would turn this fairly traditional soul group into the intense live act that wowed Detroit's Westbound Records head Armen Boladian. He signed them
column12: and from the get-go
column13: their music cut through genres and money bullshit like neither had ever existed. Never mind that half the band quit and came back again during recording sessions for their first record
column14: Funkadelic was destined for greatness. Ace's reissues of the band's Westbound catalog is long overdue-- they sound a world better than the terribly mastered original CD pressings
column15: and contain a wealth of bonus tracks
column16: alternate mixes
column17: and liner notes.

column1: Funkadelic from 1970 was a bomb dropped all over rock and soul. No matter Hendrix
column2: no matter James Brown
column3: no matter the MC5

column9: I've read relatively few accounts on their greatness as a pure rock band. But they had it all: great players
column10: great singers
column11: a great look
column12: a great concept
column13: actual hits
column14: great albums
column15: great drugs
column16: freaky sex
column17: disputes over money-- everything Led Zeppelin (or Spinal Tap) taught us was necessary to make the world's greatest rock music.

column1: They started small
column2: backing up ringleader George Clinton's Parliaments in the late 60s. When Clinton got into arguments with his label Revilot over money and rights
column3: he decided to start recording his backup band instead
column4: using the original Parliaments singers (Clinton
column5: Ray Davis
column6: Clarence ""Fuzzy"" Haskins-- and come on
column7: dude's name is ""Fuzzy""-- Calvin Simon and Grady Thomas) as ""guests."" Guitarists Eddie Hazel and Tawl Ross
column8: bassist Billy Nelson
column9: drummer Tiki Fulwood
column10: and eventually
column11: master keyboardist Bernie Worrell were the band that would turn this fairly traditional soul group into the intense live act that wowed Detroit's Westbound Records head Armen Boladian. He signed them
column12: and from the get-go
column13: their music cut through genres and money bullshit like neither had ever existed. Never mind that half the band quit and came back again during recording sessions for their first record
column14: Funkadelic was destined for greatness. Ace's reissues of the band's Westbound catalog is long overdue-- they sound a world better than the terribly mastered original CD pressings
column15: and contain a wealth of bonus tracks
column16: alternate mixes
column17: and liner notes.

column1: Funkadelic from 1970 was a bomb dropped all over rock and soul. No matter Hendrix
column2: no matter James Brown
column3: no matter the MC5
column4: nobody had ever heard anything like this. This music was slower than sludge
column5: dirtier than the ""raw funk"" Herb ""Sparky"" Sparkman talks about in ""Music For My Mother"". It was a great big fucking mess
column6: and a lot of people didn't know what to make of it. I remember reading a Rolling Stone review from the time that ended with ""who needs this shit?"" and a writer from the Blues & Soul 'zine from a year later admitted
column7: ""Funkadelic has never been one of my favorite R&B; acts"". Still
column8: the record sold (peaking at #16 on the Soul LPs chart)
column9: and planted the seed of a cult worship that would balloon in the latter half of the decade
column10: making the P-Funk enterprise the most successful soul act on the planet.

column1: ""Mommy
column2: What's a Funkadelic?"" started out with the sound of Clinton's wet mouth and the best ever opening line for an album: ""If you will suck my soul
column3: I will lick your funky emotions."" When the beat hits with Hazel's guitar line
column4: there can be no doubt that Funkadelic were without peer as far as this stuff was concerned. This stuff-- hell
column5: tunes like ""Mommy"" and ""Good Old Music"" are slams to the gut as powerful as anything Zep ever did
column6: and with beats to spare. ""Music For My Mother"" is like a Southern myth
column7: detailing a loner's travels through ""Keep Runnin' Mississippi""
column8: hearing music he thought long dead
column9: yet getting trapped by its sticky black allure. ""What Is Soul?"" drops more classic lines (""soul is a hamhock in your cornflakes
column10: ""Soul is chitlins foo young
column11: ""soul is a joint rolled in toilet paper"") in seven minutes than most bands muster up in a career. Bonus tracks like the tight instrumental ""As Good As I Can Feel"" and several single versions of album cuts make this album one of the most indispensable of all indispensable Funkadelic records.

column1: Even as Funkadelic was an inspired statement
column2: it wasn't exactly a coherent one
column3: especially as most of the band had quit and come back again during the recording sessions. Their second record
column4: 1971's Free Your Mind was the first (of only two) records done by the core unit from start to finish-- albeit
column5: according to Clinton
column6: one recorded in the span of a single day
column7: while everyone was tripping. Compared to the debut
column8: it's a lot more ""rock"" and a little less ""soul."" The opening track ""Free Your Mind and Your Ass Will Follow"" was like a Sly Stone jam gone haywire
column9: with fuzzed out guitar and bass
column10: distorto-organ
column11: and spoken
column12: chanted or otherwise freaked vox appearing all over the mix. ""Friday Night
column13: August 14th""
column14: ""Funky Dollar Bill""
column15: and ""I Wanna Know If It's Good to You"" were a bit tighter
column16: and a lot harder. ""Funky Dollar Bill"" features another down-home-on-a-porch-and-an-amp-with-probably-some-pot-and-other-things guitar riff from Hazel and Clinton and company sounding completely fucked up and screaming out at you from the depths of the stereo on lines like ""you don't buy a life
column17: you live a life
column18: a father learns much too late-- HE WAS A-NEVER HOME!!"" ""Euology and Light"" is like a lysergic Lord's Prayer
column19: replete with backwards choir. The bonus track ""Fish
column20: Chips and Sweat"" is again reminiscent of Sly
column21: but in his ""Dance to the Music"" guise

column1: And then they got serious: Maggot Brain
column2: released in the July of the same year
column3: is the peak of the Funkadelic experience. The songs jam harder
column4: the way out stuff is way fucking out there. Seriously
column5: how many dimensions is Hazel traveling through on the instrumental title cut? His 10-minute guitar soliloquy is a spiraling model of the blues filtered through a psychedelic lens
column6: and almost single-handedly places him in a realm with Hendrix
column7: Jimmy Page
column8: and Eric Clapton as one of the great classic rock guitarists. But it got better: ""Super Stupid"" was the tale of a dumbass junkie set to a tune Black Sabbath would have been proud of; ""Hit It And Quit It"" is a funk anthem where keyboardist Worrell gets his licks in and the beat turns around a dozen times before we hit the chorus; ""Can You Get to That"" is honest-to-whoever pop that showed Funkadelic could be serious from time to time
column9: especially when it came to social commentary (and also featured Isaac Hayes' female background singers
column10: giving it a classic soul sheen)
column11: and ""Wars of Armageddon"" (recently
column12: wisely used by Optimo on the Psyche Out mix) is a knock-out-drag-down fight to the death between the world's best rhythm section and paranoid
column13: psychedelic sound effects and crowd sounds. Maggot Brain was an explosive record
column14: bursting at the seams with exactly the kind of larger than life sound a band called Funkadelic should have made.

column1: Too bad most of the band left afterwards. Tiki Fulwood was fired due to drugs getting in the way of his reliability as a band member; Tawl Ross reportedly got into an ""acid eating contest
column2: then snorting some raw speed
column3: before completely flipping out
column4: per Billy Nelson
column5: and has not performed professionally since; Nelson himself quit over a money dispute with Clinton
column6: leaving only Hazel and Worrell from the original Funkadelic lineup. Drummer Tyrone Lampkin replaced Fulwood
column7: while guitarist Gary Shider (who'd already played with the band on parts of Maggot Brain) came aboard to fill out the sound. However
column8: a lot of folks would look at former JBs like Phelps and William ""Bootsy"" Collins additions as the most significant. Certainly
column9: Bootsy's mark on the whole Parliafunkadelicmint thang would eventually be almost as strong as Clinton's.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: 1972's America Eats Its Young is a disparate
column3: schizophrenic record. Despite Clinton's efforts to produce a record that would have a better chance at crossover appeal than the first three Funkadelic records
column4: like many double LPs
column5: there's simply too much material

column7: it has its classics: ""Loose Booty"" and ""A Joyful Process"" are the two of the best pure funk songs the band ever did

column9: Don't Produce the Cause""
column10: ""Biological Speculation""
column11: ""Everybody Is Going to Make It This Time""
column12: and ""Miss Lucifer's Love"" are great evidence of the band's strong pop bent even as their chosen subject matters could range from dark to disturbing to sci-fi. Tunes like ""I Call My Baby Pussycat""
column13: ""Balance""
column14: and ""Philmore"" even hark back to the more rock-oriented stuff of the first three records. However
column15: it's hard to hear ""We Hurt Too"" (a maudlin ballad about the hidden tenderness of men) as anything but a joke
column16: and the title track
column17: similar to Maggot Brain's title cut

column19: containing too much great stuff to dismiss
column20: but by almost anyone's standards
column21: containing more than it needs.

column1: From here on out
column2: Funkadelic would devote increasingly more time to maintaining and expanding their appeal. Albums like Let's Take It to the Stage and Standing on the Verge of Getting It on (also reissued
column3: along with Tales of Kidd Funkadelic) were considerably less freaked-out than the early stuff

there's just something undeniably awesome about a funk band blasting guitar jams and telling me about neurotic bitches who want to take over the universe.

Scotland's Teenage Fanclub are the standard-bearers of modern power pop. Eight albums into their career
column3: no one else comes close to their mastery of the genre
column4: and when you think about it
column5: the pieces for their run of remarkably consistent albums were in place from the beginning. The band has three accomplished songwriters whose voices blended as though nature intended it; what it lacked is a sense of adventurous experimentation
column6: and as such
column7: their discography is consistent almost to a fault
column8: always good but never surprising or amazing.

column1: It's possible that the band felt the need for a bit of a shake-up when it came time to record Man-Made
column2: and they traveled to Chicago to record with John McEntire at his Soma Electronic Music Studio. The change of venue and the choice of McEntire are the kinds of moves that could precipitate real change in a band's sound
column3: but as it turns out the record is full of the same intensely classicist power pop that's filled every Teenage Fanclub album. McEntire's influence is felt keenly on the edges of the music
column4: though
column5: in the textures of the guitars and bass and in the injection of a host of buzzing and burbling keyboards low in the mix. So while it's not a reinvention
column6: the production does bring in a subtle infusion of the kind of energy and youthful vigor that was missing from recent outings like Howdy! and Songs from Northern Britain and makes Man-Made possibly the band's best outing since 1992's near-masterpiece Bandwagonesque.

column1: The tracklist is split amongst four songs each from Norman Blake
column2: Gerard Love
column3: and Raymond McGinley. Blake's finest is opener ""It's All in My Mind""
column4: which features the band's trademark gentle harmonies through a monster hook that counter-intuitively pulls back from the verse. Francis MacDonald's drums give the song an insistent beat while buzzing organ and e-bowed guitar quietly mingle in the background to lend the sound a little extra punch. Blake's ""Slow Fade"" is an invigorating nod to the swifter tempos and louder volumes of the band's early-90s salad days
column5: whipping by in less than two minutes and including a spry if somewhat tuneless guitar solo.

column1: Love's ""Time Stops"" benefits from well-placed
column2: almost inaudible pizzicato strings in the pensive verses and floats by on a buoyant rhythm full of richly recorded drums and artful piano accents. McEntire's peculiar talent for recording basslines is on full view on McGinley's ""Nowhere""
column3: which rides and especially nice one in its harmony-soaked verses. The vocals aren't the only thing harmonized on ""Feel""
column4: a song that bursts out of the gate with doubled lead guitar and rides a loose groove the relies on a sparse piano part for a lot of its motion.

column1: <em>Man-Made ultimately sounds exactly like you'd expect a Teenage Fanclub album to sound
column2: but with just enough extra to make it feel new again. It's unlikely at this point that any of their fans would want them to completely overhaul their approach anyhow
column3: and indeed those fans are treated to the band's best collection of songs in more than a decade here. The uninitiated shouldn't skip over Bandwagonesque for this
column4:
but fans of both Teenage Fanclub and power pop in general will be very pleased with this.

Some Girls have made it pretty simple for us: either you currently have space in your life for pure-grain
column2: 50-second hardcore shots with titles like ""Nazi Rodeo"" or ""Don't Hate Me Just 'Cause I Hate You""
column3: or else you don't. Luckily

These may surely come to be cherished minutes for tradition-bound punk zealots-- and as useful talons as any for those of us with the occasional itch-- but for listeners intent on originality or (not to put too fine a point on it) traceable musical progress
column6: Some Girls sound only too happy to spit upon your daydreams.

column1: Arising from the always-fertile (and cross-bred) San Diego scene
column2: Some Girls form a sort of hardcore supergroup
column3: drawing membership from the ranks of several generally more innovative acts like the Locust
column4: Give Up the Ghost

column1: Needless to say
column2: the brief running time of these tracks virtually eliminates the possibility of any instrumental tangents or digressions
column3: and each winds up carrying less than one percent body fat on its sinewy frame. Fortified by Justin Pearson's distorted bass and the frantic
column4: buried-alive vocals of Wes Eisold
column5: tracks like the quaintly titled opener ""I Need Drugs"" bear some resemblance to the punishing experimental noise of Lightning Bolt. But the hammering Dr. Know (ca.'82) power chords of guitarists Rob Moran and Chuck Rowell wrap these songs in decidedly familiar casings
column6: and the group sounds altogether too content to blithely (albeit rowdily) animate all of hardcore's toastiest chestnuts.

column1: The Yeah Yeah Yeah's Karen O makes a cameo on the headlong title track
column2: although her Punk Everywoman shriek is so generic that unless you're sitting on FBI-caliber voice recognition software you're probably gonna have to take their word for it. Her presence here appears to be an oblique nod to a wider punk marketplace
column3: one that's amplified by Some Girls' recent signing with Epitaph. And though there is some delight in the thought of these guys unchaining their vicious arch-nihilism onto the broader unsuspecting public
column4:
one can't help but wish that Some Girls exhibited more ambition to blow minds rather than simply chopping heads.
