Drone is liturgy. Since its mid-century installation in the repertoire of experimental music
column2: drone has been coded with naked aspirations: people looking to the holy East; people looking to the archaic; people looking into deep space
column3: into the pure machine
column4: into the stranger mind. Drone has always been enamored of the faraway. The sacred
column5: as always
column6: must be imported from there.

column1: Its devotees are few but fervent. But the faith has always seemed strangely incommunicable: It doesn't seem to get many converts
column2: just initiates and infidels and no commerce between them. Missionary work is a slog. Those who have made stabs at evangelization know the response is usually incredulity rather than hostility. Minimalist classics have been returned to me with a blankness bordering on incomprehension
column3: as if I'd handed out videotapes of television snow and demanded an assessment of character arcs. So it is rare to find yourself born again to a random airing of You Are My Everlovin'/Celestial Power. If you own it
column4: chances are you've already been saved by it.

column1: But the seekers of the world owe a just debt of gratitude to Antony Milton's PseudoArcana label for offering up a fine little hymnal for our headphone communions. True to form
column2: the call to prayer comes by way of the Perseus Cluster
column3: a gathering of galaxies some 250 million light years away
column4: which astronomers believe has been humming a steady B-flat drone since the universe was a toddler. Marshalling the extensive and shadowy networks developed between NASA and the New Zealand free noise scene in the wane of the Carter administration
column5: a tribute album to the bass cluster has emerged. And though of dubious scientific merit and obscure political import
column6: The Tone of the Universe (=The Tone of the Earth) is a monumental collection of music.

column1: Appropriate to a work of intergalactic negotiation
column2: the compilation draws from the farthest flung reaches of terrestrial drone: New Zealand
column3: the UK
column4: Italy
column5: Argentina
column6: Finland
column7: and the U.S. have sent delegates
column8: like some kind of very slow and poorly-lit Olympiad. This geographical variety translates brilliantly into sound
column9: every contributor seemingly speaking in his or her own musical language
column10: and none falling back on the ponderous immobility that can render minimalism so oppressive.  On ""Map of Dusk""
column11: the Blithe Sons
column12: charter members of San Francisco's illustrious Jewelled Antler collective
column13: dispense with their California pastorals and backyard musique concrete for something less humane: a pestilential little cloud of harmonium evaporations and feedback expanding and compressing like an iron lung. Peter Wright's idyllic ""Haboob""-- one of the collection's high points-- is barely drone in any sense of the word
column14: a lyrical 12-string guitar prayer plucked over delicately tremulous strings.

column1: The heavy trappings of bow-and-scrape drone are eschewed in Finnish experimentalist Keijo's ""Stellar Wind""
column2: a weirdly rollicking folk blues ramble. Even shot through with warbling treated winds and chirpy electronica
column3: the track seems more suited to the high plains than the higher nebulae. And for those somehow not satiated by last year's sprawling 3xCD set
column4: Pontiac Lady
column5: the mighty Vibracathedral Orchestra add a short jagged slab of noise-rock much more uproarious than their usual skittering ceremony. ""3 Bb Moods"" lurches into Acid Mothers territory with shrapnel guitar lines exploding over psilocybin raga. Vibracathedral's explosive excursion into electric heavyland resolves into Hands of Satisfaction's long ""Version 1""
column6: 11 minutes of noise pointillism
column7: where dead guitar bursts punctuate soft clatter and glitch. Expansive and not entirely successful
column8: ""Version 1"" flags early and doesn't vary its formula.

column1: The second disc of the collection is dominated by contributions from the Celebrate Psi Phenomenon crowd. C/Psi/P label head Campbell Kneale's own Birchville Cat Motel serves up a behemoth of bright and majestic skree ""I Am But Dust"". Few practitioners of the art have the natural virtuosity of Kneale
column2: who
column3: like surgeons and serial killers
column4: succeeds by sheer dint of patience. Kneale trusts his own ideas and is unafraid to let them unfold over great durations; and the eight-minutes of washed-out organs and screaming guitars in ""I am But Dust"" proceed with the pomp and circumstance of a coronation procession. Seht's unnerving and appropriately titled ""Antarctica Download (Edit)"" turns warm analog cold
column5: with bright keyboards dripped as icicles ominously from all directions. The piercing scrapes and gongs of 1/3 Octave Band's ""Dominion""
column6: on the other hand
column7: are harsh and unpleasant
column8: albeit mercifully brief.

column1: The Tone of the Universe concludes with the grand galactica of the brothers Opalio
column2: the Italian sonic cosmonauts better known as My Cat is an Alien. Amidst bells and phasers and dubious space opera sound effects
column3: an accented continental repeatedly urges us to ""hear the voice of the cosmos."" But to his credit he does not say precisely where one must listen for it.

column1: Even with the odd failed experiment or heavy-handed concoction
column2: The Tone of the Universe on the whole succeeds brilliantly
column3: not by paying homage to heavenly bodies resonating 57 octaves below the limits of human hearing
column4: but by bringing the cold and scattered outskirts of the musical galaxy a little closer to hand. There is great solace in hearing that there are still strange goings-on abroad on this planet. And that
column5: brothers and sisters
column6:
is truly the good news.

abuse from the pop single still recognizable as a pop single. As the
dawned

This

Unfortunately

""If

You have to wonder why the hell Mike Patton seems to be constructing an empire out of the Melvins. Out of his Ipecac label's 69

column1: spine numbers
column2: at least 25 are Melvins releases or feature a member of the band.  If we create sanctuaries for bald eagles
column3: why

column1: can't we make one for the goofball kings of sludge?  Through Ipecac
column2: the Melvins have been safe to release a book
column3: a noise album

column1: a handful of seven-inches
column2: a re-release of their first album
column3: and even a trilogy.  So what kind of gimmick release could top all

column1: this? Try a collection of demos from the band's original lineup.
When listening to Mangled Demos From 1983
column2: it's apparent that hardcore ruled U.S. indie rock in the 80s.  Your parents probably

column1: met at a Bad Brains show
column2: and you were probably conceived to a Minor Threat tape later that night (thus making you the straight-edge

column1: antichrist). It's no wonder
column2: then
column3: that before they played sludge or Dale Crover joined on drums
column4: these drunk-ass punks from an isolated

column1: town in Washington state started a hardcore band.  ""Forgotten Principles""
column2: ""If You Get Bored""
column3: and ""Set Me Straight"" have all the

column1: generic traits of TSOL
column2: DRI
column3: MDC (and any other acronym you can think of)
column4: with their surly
column5: semi-guttural vocals
column6: high-pitched

column1: buzzing guitars
column2: and drums that suddenly switch to double-time in an attempt to mask that the same riff is played over and over.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: ""Matt Alec"" predicts the meandering grunge that the Melvins were known for
column3: and which millions of kids in overpriced Doc

column1: Martens would discover after getting into Nirvana. (""It just ain't a Melvins review without a Cobain reference
column2: my hardcore mom used

column1: to say.)
The highlight of this amateur collection is the Elks Lodge Christmas radio broadcast of ""If You Get Bored"".  It starts with banter
between God-fearing
column2: blue-collar
column3: WASP announcers and a laughably ""punk as fuck"" Matt Lukin (who would leave after these recordings

column1: to eventually form Mudhoney).  After the announcers treat the band like cute little kids at a church talent show
column2: Buzz Osbourne and

column1: crew proceed to horrify the small town audience with a barrage of blistering noise.
Thank God Buzz and company learned to love Sabbath and gave up on being the next hardcore band to move to L.A. and get prominently
featured on cheaply photocopied fliers. The Melvins have made some great albums over time (Lysol
column2: Bullhead
column3: and <i>Stoner

column1: Witch among them) yet Mangled Demos probably should have lingered in obscurity
column2: cannibalized on various bootlegs for the

column1: inquisitive fan to stumble upon on the internet.  Instead
column2: thanks to Ipecac
column3:
the world has yet another Melvins record floating around.

From a fan's perspective
column2: Norway's Turbonegro have epitomized everything that can go wrong with a rock band. After releasing two amazingly deprived
column3: hedonistic
column4: sometimes downright unsettling punk-rock albums in the late 90's (1997's Ass Cobra and 1999's Apocalypse Dudes)
column5: the band broke up amidst self-perpetuated rumors of rock'n'roll excess
column6: drug abuse
column7: and mental breakdowns. In the years that followed
column8: however
column9: the band's popularity grew
column10: especially stateside
column11: where they were practically unknown during their original tenure. In 2002
column12: they returned with Scandinavian Leather
column13: an album that placed more emphasis on mid-tempo rock than any of their work so far
column14: and although it was a definite step down from previous work
column15: it still delivered plenty of the band's characteristic sub-toilet humor while showcasing their impressive musicianship.

column1: But really
column2: it didn't come as much of a surprise that Scandinavian Leather didn't deliver the same quality as the pre-breakup albums. How often does a band return from a split and maintain their momentum? And unfortunately
column3: Turbonegro have continued their downward descent with their sixth studio album
column4: Party Animals
column5: a steaming pile of generic cock-rock with hardly a trace of the ""death punk"" the band began bashing out over a decade ago.

column1: For a band that has used surprise and shock value to their credit so often in the past
column2: to hear Turbonegro slink their way into such a predictable pattern is a disappointment to say the least. Just like the two albums before it
column3: Party Animals begins with a brief intro before launching into the first true song. But unlike the other two intros
column4: this one is just a mess
column5: combining obnoxious guitar soloing
column6: an unintelligible robotic voice over
column7: and a ""We Will Rock You"" style drum beat. It's more irritating than anything
column8: and it does nothing to ramp up the listener for the rest of the album.

column1: The first real song
column2: ""All My Friends Are Dead""
column3: is one of the better tracks
column4: but even so it wouldn't quite hold up in the context of the band's stronger work. It's on par with some of the more upbeat work from Scandinavian Leather as your basic three-chord punk
column5: but it's also the first sign of how crisp and clean of the album sounds
column6: thanks in part to Redd Kross bassist/producer Steve McDonald. And from there on
column7: it's a miss-or-horribly-miss affair until the end. ""Blow Me Like the Wind"" is way too catchy for its own good
column8: and singer Hank Von Helvete's lyrics are so insipid you'll crave the depth of such past hits as ""Wipe It 'Til It Bleeds."" A sample: ""If I gave you a dime
column9: would you blow my paradigm? If I gave you my candle
column10: would it be too hot to handle? If I ran for election
column11: would you support my erection?""

column1: Don't get me wrong; I expect sexual puns from Turbonegro
column2: but I also expect something at least mildly clever and humorous. But Party Animals is neither of those. About the most clever thing here is the track ""If You See Kaye"" (saying it out loud might help to spell out the joke for you
column3: a pun already used by the Poster Children). Elsewhere the band apes everyone from the Dead Boys (""Wasted Again"") to Van Halen (""Stay Free"")
column4: and continues with the intentionally just-barely-offensive lyrics.

column1: The album's worst offender is ""City of Satan""
column2: which brings back the generic beat you'd hoped to forget from the intro
column3: and features an unlistenable sing-along refrain. But then
column4: about four minutes in
column5: something odd happens. The rhythm changes
column6: the vocals almost completely drop away
column7: and horns and strings join in to punch up the melody. It's like they wanted Bob Ezrin to produce
column8: but could only afford him for those two minutes. This then is the most frustrating aspect of Party Animals: These guys are incredibly talented musicians and arrangers. If they pulled out the strong parts of each song and scrapped the garbage
column9: we'd have an EP that would easily stand alongside anything the band has done in the past.

column1: Of course
column2: that's not how it turned out. Party Animals is a failure. It's the sound of a band trying to keep their growing fan base on the upswing
column3:
while completely running out of new ideas; the sound of a band collapsing under the weight of their own gimmick.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/2552/homepage_large.f5816f8d.jpg|Ta Det Lugnt [Expanded Edition]|1225.0|Dungen|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kemado']|2005-08-01 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:56:07.024971|"

Despite the constant influx of catchphrase-coordinated marketing campaigns that would lead you to believe that life-affirming records are released daily
column2: it's forever rare to stumble upon one as consistently mind-blowing and aesthetically far-reaching as Dungen's Ta Det Lugnt. Because of this scarcity
column3: when such an unexpected (and immediate) discovery does take     place
column4: it's like being struck by indescribable melodic lightning:     Unlike discs that warrant facile disses or mediocre passing grades
column5: the countless reasons for its boundless successes remain ineffable and shadowy despite repeat late-night close-listening sessions.

column1: Simply put
column2: Dungen exhibit all the signs of legitimate
column3: hard-won staying power. Ta Det Lugnt is an exceedingly triumphant psych-pop oddity that evokes Keith Moon's drum fills on The Who Sell Out
column4: the     wraiths of unsung bedroom psyche celebrants
column5: and the acoustic sustain and harmonizing of The Byrds' Younger Than Yesterday. Ta Det Lugnt feels less like a new release than some ancient tome
column6: a fully formed masterpiece dropped unexpectedly on corduroy laps from some blue-brown sky. It's so aesthetically tight that even carbon dating insists that it could not be post-millennial.

column1: To be sure
column2: there's a major difference between retro and somehow     embodying your parents' vintage zeitgeist: It's damn-near impossible     to believe that the humming tubes
column3: crackling drums
column4: smoky backdrop
column5: and complexly interwoven melodies on Ta Det Lugnt were birthed in a     quick-fix iPod age. But perhaps even more impressive is that
column6: despite     the music's headiness and intricacy
column7: its anachronistic results feel     unusually effortless
column8: earnest
column9: and unpretentious: Dungen seem driven     to this sound not for bloodless cred points
column10: but out of a very sincere devotion to the music from a bygone era.

column1: Accomplished beyond his years
column2: 26-year-old Swedish     multi-instrumentalist Gustav Ejstes is the pin-up mastermind behind     Dungen's vibrant polish. For the full duration of his third album's 13     bracing tracks
column3: he perfectly inhabits-- and then expands upon-- his     homeland's late-60s/early-70s acid-rock scene. Ta Det Lugnt     particularly taps into the expansiveness of his Swedish psych     predecessors
column4: Parson Sound
column5: while maintaining a murky rocker edge:     Imagine that band colliding with The Kinks
column6: or Amon Dl II with Olivia     Tremor Control
column7: or Comets on Fire with The Zombies on their way to Terrastock.

column1: Interested in pushing pop glitter to its limits
column2: Ejstes doesn't go as     far afield into psych-pop cliches like chirping birds and hippie     atmospherics as his elder brethren
column3: but his equally vintage garage     sound allows a definite space for ethereality in the form of funereal     dew-drop strings
column4: free jazz breakdowns
column5: brief whiffs of AM radio     tuning
column6: flute minuets
column7: lushly cascading pianos
column8: prog time changes
column9: florid medieval chimes
column10: sky-melting freak outs
column11: church organs
column12: fuzz-guitar jousts
column13: doubled mountain-top whistles
column14: roaring six-string     solos
column15: and autumnal instrumental interludes. It's obvious his songs     are painstakingly arranged with a sense of depth
column16: gradations
column17: and tonal three-dimensionality redolent of something as off the charts as Pet Sounds.

column1: I said all of the above and more last year
column2: and it still holds true. Hindsight and new layers of hype included
column3: Ta Det Lugnt remains a consistently amazing album. Since my initial tongue-wagging Dungen's deservedly gone from limited distribution and whispered word-of-mouth to NME hyperbole and glowing write-ups in just about every community newspaper from the Philadelphia Daily News to San Francisco Weekly (and beyond). There's also been a rush to offer more sounds: A few months back came the generally misunderstood compilation 1999-2001
column4: wherein Ejstes     re-stitched early material into three lengthy soundscapes instead of     presenting them in their original form
column5: and now
column6: of course
column7: comes the     U.S. re-release of the fire starter
column8: Ta Det Lugnt.

column1: Repackaged by NYC's Kemado Records (home of Elefant
column2: Diamond Nights
column3: and goofy Brooklyn loft crashers     Cheeseburger)
column4: the album is as it was
column5: but comes with an extra CD that     includes five previously unreleased tracks
column6: which will also eventually     appear on Subliminal Sounds as a vinyl 12"". As might be expected
column7: the     add-ons aren't as amazingly ordered or cohesive as the album proper
column8: but they do pleasingly expand the Dungen oeuvre.

column1: Of the five tracks
column2: four are instrumental. Only the opener
column3: ""Tyst     Minut""
column4: an outtake from the Ta Det Lugnt sessions
column5: offers a new     taste of Ejstes' Swedish. The sleepy mid-tempo four minutes     open with crystalline strums
column6: Nyquil vocalizations and chordal rings
column7: then turn back into     a semi-smoking singsong. The chorus picks things up a bit with accompanying     guitar noodle and the bridge is a molasses solo that shifts into     florid piano cascades. It's followed by ""Jamna Plagor""
column8: an     instrumental from 2003
column9: notable for its interesting percussion sound     (tinny
column10: echoed hand drums?) and mid-song dissolve into a brief metagalactic     interstices. Though enjoyable
column11: it's nothing special.

column1: More interesting are the three new recordings
column2: ""Sjutton""
column3: ""Christopher""
column4: and ""Badsang"" (""Bathing Song"")
column5: which give a taste of     Dungen yet-to-come. There's a free
column6: loose feel honing in at points on     improvisational jazz and/or Can's galvanic sweep. ""Sjutton""'s     pronounced flute and cocky shaker keep time while the rest of the band     swaggers and staggers alongside cymbal crashes. The     blistering ""Christopher"" is a two-minute showcase of sweaty
column7: Hendrixian psychedelia
column8: as well as a nod to dark-minded LSD     trips everywhere. Closer ""Badsang"" sounds very much like     something you and yours would plug into while frolicking with water     nymphs in a sunny
column9: dusky forest
column10: though the vibrational Dr. Who halfway point does grow a little lizard-king creepy.

column1: As increasingly de rigueur reviews cloud the water
column2: it should be interesting to see if Dungen can one day top Ta Det Lugnt
column3: or if album     three proves a magically brilliant and unrepeatable accomplishment.     Regardless
column4: they seem to be taking the success in stride
column5: showcasing     more than a few positive-growth indicators including their emergence     as a solid live band (and not simply an elaborate studio project)
column6: the     decision to continue recording in Swedish
column7: Ejstes' folk fiddle     mastery
column8: and the well-grounded
column9:
astute experimentation suggested in their newer work.

Lotta acid in 2005. Apparently the long elliptical orbit of music
fashion has brought the squelchy buzz of the 303 back into view. It's
just the tip of the iceberg
column2: I'm sure
column3: but in the last couple months

column1: I've sifted through all the AFX Analord releases
column2: digested Uwe

column1: Schmidt's faux comp Acid Evolution 1988-2003
column2: Soul Jazz's Chicago acid house disc
column3: and this
column4: Luke Vibert's

column1: collection of three acid-themed 12-inches put out by Planet Mu. Of the newly recorded material
column2: this is

I've never been a huge Vibert fan in any of his various guises (Plug
Wagon Christ
column2: etc). His music has always seemed workmanlike and

column1: consistently listenable
column2: but I was never able to tease out much in the

column2: though
column3: reveals Vibert as a producer

column1: with
a keen sense of musical humor and an abiding interest in funkiness.
""Funky Acid Stuff"" from the ""'95-'99"" 12-inch is an excellent opener-- a
James Brown bassline sample combined with big
column2: splashy drums
column3: which  drives an

column1: wonderfully obnoxious acid line through the center of the thing. The
breaks on ""Acid2000"" also draw rhythmic inspiration from hip-hop
column2: with

column1: a
simple piano progression serves as a delicious contrast to the busy
electronics. On these tracks it's enjoyable to hear Vibert's
instrumental hip-hop Ninja Tune aesthetic with the lead 303 way out
front.
The pure machine tracks are slightly less interesting but still good.
""Lover's Acid"" is a spacey mid-tempo number that's basically just dinky
analog drum programming behind a lead squiggle
column2: and the late-90s track

column1: ""Analord"" has a vintage palette quite similar to the recent AFX project
of the same name. Vibert's take on the sound is simpler and more pop
with regular hints of sing-songy new wave in the melody. ""Come on
Chaos""
column2: a rougher electro track out of a sci-fi film chase scene
column3: loses

column1: some energy with clichยd ""C-c-c-c come on!"" vocal samples. Two tracks
the Mo' Wax-style trip-hop ""Prick Tat"" and the faux-exotica ""Gwithian""
forego the acid theme entirely
column2: and both come across as the same sort

column1: of

Comparisons can be deal-breakers but what the hell: Clor vocalist Barry Dobbins sounds a little like the Arcade Fire's Win Butler. Well

column1: Clor play buzzy
column2: hopped-up indie pop that sounds great with your first caffeine of the day. They're pop in perhaps the most literal sense of the word-- their songs POP out at you
column3: glowing bright blue-green like a Nike tracksuit. Dudes can play
column4: too
column5: and with music this dense (Clor tracks are a frottage of guitar
column6: bass
column7: live drums
column8: drum machine
column9: vocals
column10: and upwards of 14 vintage synthesizers likely purchased on eBay)
column11: precision is ne plus ultra. Bios list only five members

column13: but that's allowed. These boys nail their notes
column14: and unlike most indie poppers
column15: they can thump. Piloted by chichi sequencers and a house-inflected rhythm

column1: In indie rock
column2: a rigidly self-contained genre whose bands employ strikingly similar sounds and production techniques
column3: the difference between mediocrity and greatness is often
column4: literally
column5: one or two notes. Clor delight in making unexpected stylistic choices. They excel at turning left where most would turn right or not turn at all
column6: and their shiftiness rarely seems forced. Take single ""Love + Pain"". For its first 47 seconds
column7: ""Love + Pain"" teeters on obnoxiousness. Notes bop and bubble in a jittery morass
column8: while Dobbin's nasally vocals claw at nearby skin. It's not bad
column9: just a little nauseating. But then the chorus hits. I'm sorry-- first the prechorus
column10: i.e.
column11: the four bars that make all the difference. Instead of launching into the refrain
column12: with its one-line hook and beeline chord changes
column13: Clor prime the canvas with a palate-cleansing arpeggiated riff. Perfect.

column1: Like a stand-up comic who overuses shock value
column2: a band can be unpredictable in very predictable ways. Many Clor-type bands use a glitzy
column3: structurally overloaded approach in order to curry favor with bored listeners. But Clor are master blenders
column4: cobbling together tasty unrelated nuggets and making them seem like sonic soul mates. Opener ""Good Stuff"" superimposes a Hives-y quarter-note riff over an ambiguous instrumental backdrop
column5: in which grainy drum machine and chorus-drenched bass invoke post-wavers Poster Children. ""Hearts of Fire"" rubberizes a benumbed Kraftwerk-style motor groove with guitar and vox
column6: both pliant and catchy
column7: before drifting off in an extended instrumental passage featuring more computers than the Very Large Array. They even get mushy on the immaculate ""Gifted"".

column1: So it's a bummer the album fizzles a bit toward the end. Clor are so flashy and blemish-free
column2: they're almost celluloid. They work plasticity to their favor mostly-- and damn that's hard-- but ""Magic Touch""
column3: which is wanky
column4: and ""Making You All Mine""

column8: FX-laden blockbuster

column10: FX-laden albums of its ilk go
column11:
you could do much worse.

Austria's Christian Fennesz is among the most vital artists from the abstract edge of the electronic music spectrum
column2: in part because     he never stops growing. Whether he's remixing the indie pop band     Junior Boys
column3: immersing himself in improv with Fenn O'Berg and     Polwechsel
column4: or crafting dark songs in tandem with David Sylvain
column5: Fennesz is constantly challenging himself while holding on to and developing his core style. That he sometimes fails is a testament to his willingness to step outside his comfort zone.

column1: Add one-man entertainment industry Ryuichi Sakamoto to Fennesz' long list of collaborators. This unlikely pair is at present working on an album together
column2: and this teaser EP consists of a single 19-minute track     they performed live last year at a festival in Italy. Sakamoto has been     working in music too long and in too many contexts to be summed up in a     few words. Being a key member of the Yellow Magic Orchestra is a career     for most
column3: but for Sakamoto YMO was just the beginning. Since then there     have been dozens of records including film scores
column4: vocal pop records
column5: orchestral compositions
column6: and ambient mood music
column7: not to mention a number of acting gigs. Now Sakamoto joins Fennesz shoulder-to-shoulder in front of their laptops to fill a concert hall with challenging computer music.

column1: When I finish this review and put Sala Santa Cecilia back on the CD shelf
column2: I'm definitely going to file it with my Fennesz releases.     There's     no way for me to know for sure who is doing what in this collaboration
column3: but the texture and structure of the music fits nicely alongside the more serene and dreamy passages of Live in Japan. It starts with the two men tuning their machines
column4: playing with and discarding an     assortment of eerie and uncertain industrial tones
column5: then locking the     pieces that fit into pointy spires of sound. They never stay in one     place long
column6: though
column7: as the music is constantly shifting and being     bumped     off track. During a long stretch of small buzzes and thumps the piece     seems adrift and on the verge of floating away into chaos. But then a     tender symphonic drone
column8: which sounds to me like it was constructed by a     guy with deep understanding of film music and storytelling
column9: pulls the piece back into itself to close with an extremely long and wistful fade to black.

column1: Santa Cecilia being the patron saint of church music and this performance having taken place of Rome
column2: it's not hard to read into this     piece a kind of gothic drama. The long glitchy passage aside
column3: Sala Santa Cecilia sounds deep and wide
column4: like it was meant to echo inside an     enormous room with dark stone walls. If I'm understanding the division     of labor correctly
column5: Sakamoto's outsized orchestral flair is an     excellent     compliment to the more fastidious choices made by Fennesz
column6: and the     ideas     presented here
column7: while exciting on their own
column8: bode very well for the upcoming full-length.

With origins in the same Versailles terroir that birthed Air
column2: it's difficult to resist scrutinizing Jean-Emmanuel Krieger's electronic project Baรฏkonour for similarities to his fellow countrymen's distinctively purified synthetic landscapes. And though there are moments on Baรฏkonour's full-length debut
column3: For the Lonely Hearts of the Cosmos

column5: iridescent environments of Talkie Walkie

column7: jazz-inflected musicianship and an inspired navigation of spiraling
column8: locomotive Krautrock dynamics.

column1: For the Lonely Hearts also distances itself through its unabashed embrace of reliable (if not precisely traditional) rock-based structures. Most of the tracks here feature live drumming provided by Imitation Electric Piano's Lee Adams
column2: and it's often his muscular
column3: hangar-spaced pummel that allows Baรฏkonour to avoid the stagnant eddies of soporific post-rock. Following the delicate harp-string shimmer of the opening ""Lick Lokoum""
column4: Krieger and Adams immediately kick into the unstoppable motorik-cum-Stax propulsion of ""Coltan Anyone?"" Combining surprisingly humid
column5: greasy rhythms with Krieger's baroque
column6: Floydian keyboard flourishes

column9: sci-fi sterility.

column3: however

column6: as on ""Hoku To Shin Ken""

column8: Byrds-like guitar arpeggios. Elsewhere ""Proto-Coeur"" plows a recharged Peter Gunn riff around and through various hairpin turns and blind alleys
column9: while tracks like ""Rusk Plasmique"" and ""60 To 0"" can recall M83's synthesized My Bloody Valentine atmospheres. Throughout the album
column10: Krieger consistently astonishes with the daring breadth of his playing
column11: as he embellishes several otherwise straightforward pop hooks with as much florid ornamentation as good taste will allow.

column1: Aside from the occasional submerged whisper
column2: as on the classic-Stereolab echoes of ""2/3/74""
column3: For the Lonely Hearts of the Cosmos contains no vocals or lyrics to speak of
column4: but still the album retains the impression of a cohesive

column4: the Mo' Wax entrepreneur seemed listless on official follow-up <em>Never
column5: Never Land

column7: scratching

column1: Originally created for a ""future cinema"" exhibit at London's Institute for the Contemporary Arts
column2: Edit Music basically takes Lavelle's omnipresent love for all things ominous and cinematic and works them into two hour-long DJ sets that haphazardly cut and paste dialogue from dumbfuck obvious flicks like Scarface and Kill Bill alongside slightly tweaked seven-year-old UNKLE jams (""Lonely Soul"")
column3: and continuity-foiling soundtrack picks like Elton John's ""Tiny Dancer"" (Almost Famous) and Chris Isaak's ""Bad Bad Thing"" (Eyes Wide Shut).

column1: Disc One is introduced by the horn-blaring 20th Century Fox theme and such cutesy flourishes (yes
column2: the THX noise-blast and 2001 theme are here too) render these discs throwaway silly. Once the (quaint) thrill of Name That Movie dies down
column3: there's little left besides sometimes pulsing
column4: sometimes ambient soundtrack music that hardly coalesces into a thematic whole (an implicit goal thanks to the frustrating lack of individual track breaks). The image conscious spinner seemingly spent more time on the album's stark quasi-Vader cover than the actual mix; Lavelle's once-refreshing anything-goes ethos has fallen into aimless self-parody as he's now outdone by creative
column5: open-minded mp3 blog-mixers on a daily basis.

column1: Even for the few trenchant UNKLE obsessives left
column2: this liner notes-less import is not only unessential but also kind of sad. Foolishly slaving to a lame at-the-movies blueprint
column3: Lavelle ignores the most exciting British beat-styles of today (ahem
column4:
grime) and sticks with his trademark doomsday sludge that now sounds as creaky as a knee-jerk John Williams score. Dude should stick to pawning those tres unique (read: fugly) new UNKLE-Nike Dunks on eBay--$102.50 with an hour left!

The title of Iggy Pop's second career retrospective seems to me as arbitrary as
column2: say
column3: That's Like Hypnotizin' Chickens or Of Course I've Had It in the Ear Before
column4: albeit much less entertaining. And it's subtitled like we've been waiting for it for a long
column5: long time-- which is true
column6: but only to an extent. For the past nine years
column7: Pop's career has been summarized only by the single-disk <i>Nude & Rude: The Best of Iggy Pop
column8: which tried to explain a complex artist in only 17 tracks. Even to an initiate
column9: Nude & Rude had to seem only cursory-- a problem A Million in Prizes seeks to correct. It collects 38 tracks from nearly 40 years (!)
column10: including alternate takes
column11: non-album tracks
column12: and live cuts. It renders its predecessor immediately obsolete-- look for N&R; to flood your local used CD store-- and is probably as good a Pop retrospective as we're likely to get on two disks.

column1: Most collections like this give us an opportunity to reassess an artist's accomplishments and reconsider the shape and effect of their output. A Million in Prizes: The Anthology
column2: however
column3: seems just the opposite: several years of revisiting and reconsidering his past work have finally culminated in a retrospective anthology that might be the crest of a second wave that started with <i>Trainspotting (did it really? or did it just seem to?) and has been building ever since. In the intervening decade
column4: Pop has become a legend to the garage rock bands and punk nostalgics while remaining a guiding saint to throngs of disaffected adolescents (including the dropout who used to blare ""Lust for Life"" in the apartment above me all hours of the day and night). Todd Haynes made a movie about him
column5: Jim Jarmusch made a movie with him
column6: and we here at Pitchfork placed four Iggy-related albums on our Top 100 Albums of the 70s list.

column1: Murmured rumors and outright statements claim that Pop's the father of both punk and the garage-rock revival. While it's tempting to assign that extra meaning to his stage surname
column2: influence does not necessary produce a positive paternity test. Pop is punk only in retrospect. Instead of defining a movement (that already had a leg up with MC5 and wouldn't hit full steam for several more years)
column3: the Stooges simply stripped 50s rock and roll down to its animal essence-- broken-glass blues riffs
column4: steady backbeats
column5: and punctuating hand claps-- then exaggerated its hedonistic appetites and self-destructive tendencies to brutish
column6: nearly comic proportions on their first three albums
column7: which are represented by 10 tracks on A Million in Prizes-- almost a fourth of the compilation.

column1: I can't really argue with that. The Stooges' distillation of rock is no small feat
column2: but Pop wasn't a first amendment pioneer. A succession of 60s artists from Jim Morrison to Lou Reed had already cleared the way for Pop's anarchic aesthetic
column3: but just as this lineage doesn't dull his music
column4: neither does it dull his legacy. Instead
column5: it points out his distinct accomplishment-- the performative aspect of his music. It wasn't the lyrics that made his songs dangerous
column6: but Pop's yelping insistence
column7: the depraved howls that punctuated his verses and hid a curiously smooth baritone. Just like his body
column8: his voice was wiry and exposed and graceful
column9: slithering and bleeding and peanut-buttery.

column1: The first disk of <em>A Million in Prizes showcases this aspect of Pop's music
column2: but the second disk has the unenviable task of summing up everything since
column3: from New Values and Soldier to Beat Em Up and Skull Ring. Admittedly
column4: there are some incredible moments: the live cut of ""TV Eye"" from the 1993 Feile Festival in Ireland suggests Pop hasn't lost as much edge on stage as he has in the studio. Two duets stand out: he and B-52 Kate Pierson are well matched on the wistful ""Candy""
column5: and he and Debbie Harry have a goof with Cole Porter's ""Well
column6: Did You Evah!"" from Red Hot + Blue. And even though it mercifully omits his collaboration with Peaches
column7: the second disk can't possibly match the first for sheer raw power. Really
column8: who could keep it up that long?

column1: But A Million in Prizes tells a story that's greater than the individual tracks themselves
column2: one that elevates even the dimmest of material. Even so
column3: there's something a little sad about seeing such a vital artist canonized like this. Greatest hits compilations are round holes into which pegs of every shape are fitted
column4: and they tend to have a neutering effect
column5: absorbing rebel music into the very system it once railed against. Even though <em>A Million in Prizes accomplishes exactly what it set out to do
column6: it's difficult to get excited about this collection
column7:
especially with upcoming reissues of The Stooges and Fun House to look forward to.

column3: Tracy Peterson

column3: behind the song's main chorus

column1: Many of the most captivating passages on Four Winds the Walker
column2: however
column3: occur when the Spires stretch their songs and put their restlessly inventive combinations of instruments to work. On cuts like ""Ong Song"" or ""Shining"" the group match their curious string instruments and tuned percussion (or perhaps that's the bul bul tarang I'm hearing) in a manner that recalls Harry Partch's hobo jungle
column4: while the cracked hoedown of ""Imaginary Skin"" features some marvelously bent fiddle that eventually gives way to a wordless vocal hayloft serenade. When operating at their peak

column7: ageless music one might expect to hear emanating from the deepest forest
column8:
as mysterious black-cloaked figures dance around the fire-ring. Whether that sounds more like a warning or an invitation is left up to the traveler.

The latest from audio collagists Negativland employs three
rhetorical strategies to examine the nature of fair use in an age when
corporate media outlets are fighting battles on the
grassroots
column2: unregulated frontier of the internet. How copyright law

column1: affects artists and consumers is a topic on which Negativland is
well-qualified to hold forth
column2: having spent their career pushing

column1: against the boundaries of fair use to demonstrate how it impedes
artistic progress and serves record companies more than the artists it

The first angle is an essay called ""Two Relationships to a Cultural
Public Domain"". Even though it's fairly even-handed
column2: it is essentially

column1: polemical in nature
column2: lucidly outlining the cultural developments and

column1: opposing points of view that will be more obliquely addressed on the
CD. The crux is that the internet has galvanized a drastic ideological
polarization as to what constitutes the public domain. The mainstream
record industry's position is a throwback to when cultural product was
replicated via physical means
column2: which spawned material artifacts of

column1: limited supply and calculable monetary value. The opposing position
stems from the prominence of digital media
column2: which eliminates the

column1: need for costly physical production and places the power of
reproduction and dissemination in the hands of anyone with a computer.
It states that the internet is public domain
column2: a concept that's

column1: anathema to free market capitalism.
You can easily guess which side of the debate Negativland takes up.
The essay goes on to outline the history and cultural ramifications of
copyright law
column2: from its stifling of ""folk art"" (since folk art is a

column1: communal
column2: viral process more concerned with transmission of heritage

column1: than singularity) and collage-based art
column2: to the flaws inherent in the

column1: record industry's m.o. that make this potentially beneficial
development a threat to its sustainability. The essay closes with a
clarion call for an expanded
column2: more sensible definition of fair use

column1: one that protects original works from being plagiarized outright and
assures that their creators are compensated for them
column2: while

column1: decriminalizing derivative works of satire and reinterpretation
column2: thus

column1: no longer impeding what has become our era's most vibrant art \xD0 the
art of appropriation and collage.
As opposed to the didactic nature of the booklet
column2: the audio portion of

column1: No Business tends more toward arch satire of the ongoing debate
over fair use in digital media
column2: creating a prรฉcis of its

column1: contradictions and ideological schisms rather than advancing a
particular thesis. Some pieces simply intend to display the artistic
possibilities inherent in collage
column2: and are more humorous than

column1: pedagogical: The title track recasts Ethel Merman's ""There's No
Business Like Show Business"" as a tirade against
entertainment-industry iniquity instead of a giddy celebration of it
and ""Favorite Things"" rearranges the Julie Andrews classic into an

column2: like

column1: ""Piece a Pie""
column2: a mid-century radio drama chopped up into some sort of

column1: hellish recursive time loop
column2: like Groundhog Day in a diner. But

column1: the album's centerpiece must be ""Downloading""

column1: weighted mash-up of anti-filesharing speeches
column2: Disney's <em>The Little

column1: Mermaid (""It won't cost much/ Just your voice!"")
column2: and other

column1: wildly disparate sources
column2: which seems to intend to limn the urgency

column1: and complexity of the debate over filesharing more than to stake out a

The third stage in this three-pronged statement is a whoopee cushion

column1: portion of No Business that states Negativland's stance on the

Though you wouldn't know it to listen to bulk of Pro Agonist
column4: Exile is a junglist. He has releases on some of the genre's biggest and most seminal labels
column5: including Moving Shadow
column6: Renegade Hardware
column7: and John B's Beta. He is as comfortable with rigid electro-steppers as breakneck break splicing and drooling drumfunk. The first track
column8: ""Silicon Chop""
column9: is a collaboration between Exile and Sub Focus
column10: currently the king of peak-time super-rave drum & bass via his releases on Ram like ""X-Ray"".

column1: But
column2: as with many English techheads who prefer the bucolic splendor of the Midlands
column3: he's also something of a rotter. Pro Agonist
column4: for example
column5: is on Mike ""U-Ziq"" Paradinas' Planet Mu label. Despite being home to the collected works of jungle god Remarc
column6: the label's concept of jungle owes much to the Squarepusher tempo tantrum school. And though his tunes often do feature a traditional junglist structure-- intro/drop/breakdown/drop/outro-- Exile can't resist corroding that framework with digital abuse.

column1: The aforementioned ""Silicon Chop"" and ""Open Mike"" imagine a tentative bridgehead between big-room drum & bass and the micro-intensities of the Inperspective Records choppage scene. ""Silicon Chop"" takes a fat
column2: cheesy synth hook aimed straight at the teenage raver as the eye of its hurricane of metallic
column3: scuttling bongos
column4: phased snares
column5: and ants-in-your-pants drum bits. ""The Forever Endeavor"" stomps like gabba
column6: shoots random bursts of breaks into the air
column7: and gouges you with cattle prod synth surges. ""Sure You Did"" samples a few of his pals' incredulity at his own fucked up beats in true Aphexian fashion. And that's where things take a bit of a wrong turn.

column1: ""Mushroom Santa"" features an excessively twee ""childlike"" melody married to shrill
column2: chipper drill & bass beats that even the biggest spunk jazz apologist would have to call a joke. (And even if it is
column3: I still ended up skipping it from the second play on.) ""Spring Cum Air"" is slightly better with its Selected Ambient Works II atmosphere and flurries of computer pings and plucks
column4: as if Derek Bailey suddenly took up a iBook. His remix of John B's ""Broken Language"" sounds like eight different drum & bass tunes sutured messily together on the fly with a pocket knife and some cinnamon dental floss.

column1: ""The Devil's Chimney""-- with creepy ""the devil is in exile"" sample followed by an avalanche of EQ'd-to-fuck ""Amen"" snares and gothic rave stabs-- is straight forward enough for one of the more brutalist neo-techstep labels. It makes me sound like an old disco grouch to prefer this to the more ""my jazz is useless"" pervert-o glitch like ""Rage Is The Beautiful Light That Struck Her"". (Oy
column2: those titles.) I guess I had been hoping for more tunes like ""Silicon Chop"" and his excellent 2005 single ""Cut By Plastic"". Records that sprouted unsightly moles and hair in odd places but were still recognizably drum & bass. Instead I got that plus a side of ProTools fuzz and kooky samples about chiming penises. If that's more your thing
column3:
you can look at is as getting a side of a few really forward-thinking dance tunes. And then wash that beard.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/7699/homepage_large.3a32142a.jpg|Kiss the Future|4130.0|Mark Stewart|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Soul Jazz']|2005-07-26 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:56:21.612605|"

Since his work as the frontman of the seminal UK post-punk combo the Pop Group
column3: the fascinating
column4: enigmatic Mark Stewart has seldom moved in a straight line
column5: but rather has seemed to ripple in a series of concentric circles
column6: with each successive ring expanding to absorb an ever-wider array of styles and sub-genres. As a solo act and with his bevy of talented collaborators
column7: Stewart's sound has encompassed fractured strains of punk
column8: funk
column9: avant dub
column10: free jazz
column11: and dancehall
column12: and has always been infused with his distinctive rabble-rousing politics and an ear uncannily pitched to the perpetual reinventions of street culture.

column1: Throughout Stewart's career
column2: he's remained a prescient figure
column3: but his restless
column4: thorny innovations have also likely contributed to the erratic nature of his discography. His recent history is pockmarked by extended stretches of inactivity
column5: and many of his key titles-- including both of the Pop Group's proper studio albums-- are currently out of print in the U.S. So it's surely with this unruly back catalog in mind that Soul Jazz presents <em>Kiss the Future
column6: a concise retrospective that features tasters from nearly every portion of Stewart's career
column7: including several new or previously unreleased tracks.

column1: Containing a mere 12 songs
column2: <em>Kiss the Future is more of a strategic strike than a comprehensive introduction
column3: as it represents whole periods of Stewart's career with only a track or two
column4: and ignores some of his albums entirely. And though the set provides a tantalizing
column5: remarkably unified glimpse at some of Stewart's most pioneering work
column6: the collection feels so closely edited that one can't escape the notion that too many choice selections were left abandoned on the cutting room floor.

column1: At their hot-wired best
column2: the Pop Group delivered their experimental
column3: roots reggae-inflected polemics with a barbed ferocity unmatched by few peers this side of the Birthday Party. <em>Kiss the Future includes three vintage 1979 Pop Group blasts (""We Are All Prostitutes""
column4: ""She Is Beyond Good and Evil""
column5: ""We Are Time"") that tidily anticipate the moves of contemporary post-punk revivalists from Liars to the Ponys. As with all of this collection's best material
column6: these tracks appear to have aged not a day
column7: which is accentuated by the album's non-chronological running order which places them immediately alongside new cuts like ""Radio Freedom""
column8: Stewart's recent grimy
column9: dubbed-out collaboration with Kevin ""The Bug"" Martin.

column1: Other highlights include several pieces by Stewart's excellent post-Pop Group outfit the Maffia
column2: which showcased the original Sugerhill Gang rhythm section of guitarist Skip McDonald
column3: bassist Doug Wimbish
column4: and drummer Keith LeBlanc. On tracks like ""High Ideals and Crazy Dreams"" or ""Hypnotized"" (presented in its 12"" version) the Maffia expel grainy
column5: industrial smears of noise-funk
column6: carrying the type of rugged sonic scars typically associated with a beloved
column7: over-duped cassette tape. Best of all might be ""Jerusalem""
column8: an expressionist
column9: cut-up take on William Blake's traditional tune that features a spectral brass band periodically marching through in a narcotic haze. Like the bulk of <em>Kiss the Future
column10:
it's a track that somehow manages to sound simultaneously familiar yet revolutionary (not bad for a nearly 25-year-old recording) and serves to powerfully whet the appetite for the hopefully not-too-distant future when more of Stewart's keenly far-seeing works are once again easier to come by.

Brooklyn throwback rockers Diamond Nights are the latest cyclical rockers
column2: hoping to woo girls who won't realize their moms were fawning to virtually the same band 25 years ago during REO Speedwagon shows. After the Darkness pecked away at metal-phobic listeners' prejudices
column3: the subsequent carbon-copying of the Cure and Duran Duran decimated listeners' retro barriers
column4: allowing anything sounding dustier than Dad's record collection to seep in. If right now the Killers are trashing Ritz-Carlton suites and spilling Port on their suit jackets
column5: retro-cousins Diamond Nights at least must be leaving candy wrappers on the floor at Best Western.

column1: Four of this EP's five offerings are pure frat party filth
column2: cashing in on the reemergence of ""Jessie's Girl"" and ""867-5309/Jenny"" (did they ever go away?) on kegger playlists. ""Dirty Thief"" swipes the chords to ""Just What I Needed"" but forgets the hooks to match
column3: leaving us with an unremarkable tale of heartbreak and rote soloing. ""Saturday Fantastic"" offers much of the same as the band pulls out its beefiest power chords and testosterone-soaked vocals. Amazing to think four years ago these guys would be tarred and feathered by both underground and mainstream critics
column4: no?

column1: Before totally denouncing them completely
column2: check opener ""Destination Diamonds"". It's not exactly pushing the envelope
column3: but it's also not jumping up and down screaming ""pick me!"" like so many outlandish revivalists. Frontman Morgan Phalen borrows the verse melody to ""Blinded By the Light""
column4: but fluffy guitar riffs and disarming falsetto puts the diffident
column5: vulnerable spin on arena rock that the Foo Fighters and Queens of the Stone Age so often miss.

column1: Unfortunately those slight gains are nullified by Diamond Nights' most vile error-- inexplicably feeling the need to prove they can use synthesizers. ""The Girl's Attractive"" reeks of lechery and tackiness
column2: and the camp is residual on the fist-pumping faux-Rocky montage ""Buddies"". No one's being narrow-minded here
column3: you simply can't just ape your parents' music
column4: pass Go and collect your 200 bucks anymore (OK
column5: I guess you get the money sometimes). Once We Were Diamonds unabashedly sports a caveat emptor
column6: but that's exactly what drunk kids want to pay for when they stumble into Wal-Mart at 2 a.m. anyways
column7:
right?

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/5376/homepage_large.5fe6cacf.jpg|Body of Song|2842.0|Bob Mould|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Yep Roc']|2005-07-25 00:00:00|2005|2016-06-11 20:56:23.449922|"

Time to face facts: The architect of the sound and voice that launched a thousand moshpits (and as many bands) hasn't been making that noise for over 15 years. Despite a brief return as a pop noisenik/Kevin Shields fanboy with Sugar
column2: the majority of Bob Mould's recorded work has done more to move past this legacy than actively further it. If you're a teenager
column3: you're primed to have your head popped off by Zen Arcade or New Day Rising. If you're inching towards 30
column4: then you're more likely to hear Mould's music introduce ""The Daily Show"" or segue into an NPR news story. And if you're Bob Mould
column5: you're probably splitting time spinning records at DC-area clubs and getting ready to tour behind your supposedly guitar-heavy full-band album
column6: Body of Song.

column1: If you're looking for ""Another Good Idea"" (or
column2: God help you
column3: ""Another Celebrated Summer"")
column4: then you're better served giving your ""Remaster the SST Catalog"" letter-writing campaign another go. If Body of Song is anything
column5: it's a look back on the neglected portion of Mould's musical career. As Mould phrases it in ""Best Thing""-- ""This would be/ The sound of me/ Looking for some kind of closure.""

column1: Of course
column2: if you put an electric guitar in Bob Mould's hands
column3: what gets put to tape will invariably be a rock-like substance. And having Fugazi drummer Brendan Canty in tow definitely helps. ""Always Tomorrow"" actually resembles the sort of slinky
column4: groove-laden
column5: bass-heavy stuff available on recent Fugazi albums
column6: and the storms kicked up by ""Underneath Days"" and ""Beating Heart the Prize"" give Canty a chance to bang to his heart's content. However
column7: when Mould opts to rock out the way he used to-- as on Sugar-lite stuff like ""I Am Vision
column8: I Am Sound"" and ""Missing You""-- the results are less favorable. And
column9: of course
column10: this being a Bob Mould solo album
column11: there are ballads that ably mix Mould's awkward nasal voice with impassioned strumming and sometimes clunky lyricism.

column1: ""Days of Rain"" features a few clunkers-- ""If you make it clear/ Doubt will surely disappear""-- but it gets the job done
column2: building gradually to a satisfying rock outro (with the requisite Mould guitar heroics). The disarming ""Gauze of Friendship"" is a more successful endeavor
column3: with Mould keeping the music simple (acoustic guitar
column4: drums
column5: and some cello offered by DC-area musician Amy Domingues) and cutting the fat from his words-- ""He reminds you of a boy you dated once or twice/ Just about the same size /Just about the same eyes/ The only difference being the cadence of his voice.""

column1: For the most part
column2: Body of Song offers the expected mix of rock tracks and balladry that one would expect from a Bob Mould solo record. There is one notable exception. ""(Shine Your) Light Love Hope"" is
column3: for all intents and purposes
column4: a dance track. Atop layered guitars and Canty's fervent Saturday night fever
column5: Mould makes like a vocodered disco diva
column6: chanting the song's title in a dreamy
column7: wispy voice. It's unlike anything else in Mould's rock catalog
column8: more reminiscent of the unexpected deviations that peppered his Hรผsker-era output (cf. ""99 Ways to Skin a Cat""
column9: ""Reoccurring Dreams""). It's also one of the highlights of his post-Hรผsker career
column10: and I don't doubt that Mould agrees-- on the limited-edition bonus disc included with preorders of this album
column11: there are two remixes of ""Light Love Hope"".

column1: Longtime fans of the Flying V and the sonic boom could be outraged at Mould betraying his legacy with what they'll perceive as a techno version of ""I Was Made For Loving You"". But no doubt Mould would answer this indignant outrage by telling these so-called fans when and how to kiss his distortion pedals. Press kits and biographies will impress upon readers that Mould's lasting legacy is his part in founding and shaping the fast hard rules of the alternative rock nation
column2: giving voice to a thousand grudging young would-be millionaires that have long since disappeared into cut-out bins. Nearly two decades removed from those iconic days
column3:
Mould has amassed a body of work that proves there's something to be said for running a slow and steady race.

They say all press is good press

column4: Jackson Browne

column4: and its songs blend together. It's difficult to remember just where one ends and one begins. Partly because Witmer never changes his vocal tone

but never losing sight of the style he's honed for years.

Lungfish is about as far from dancepunk as you can get
column2: yet the core

column1: structure of dance music is a good comparison for understanding how
they arrive at their sui generis style. Dancepunk usually
appropriates the trappings of dance music-- shuffle beats
column2: robotic

column1: bass
column2: crisp tempo-changes and dynamic shifts-- and arrays them in

column1: serial
column2: song-oriented structures. But what really identifies dance

column1: music as such is its structural development: More vertical than
lateral
column2: achieved through variations and amplifications on a theme

column1: not concatenated linear progression. This is exactly what Lungfish
does with punk music
column2: which is particularly apparent on instrumental

column1: tracks like ""Picture Music"". They stretch the basic elements of punk
into long
column2: tense arcs
column3: where central themes are tweaked and coaxed

column1: through subtle variations. The idea is an interesting one
column2: but even

column1: the most unique ideas have a limited shelf-life
column2: and on <em>Feral

column1: Hymns
column2: one gets the sense that it's played out its possibilities.

column1: It's common to complain of one band sounding too much like another
but Lungfish has fallen into a rarer trap-- they've begun to sound too

much like themselves.

When Swedish instrumental duo Sagor and Swing broke up last year
column2: the world lost one of the few remaining retro-lounge-prog bands worth more than their weight in kitsch. The band's excellent <i>Orgelplaneten featured the usual roller-rink organ melodies and surf-rock inspired drumming
column3: alongside spacier Moog excursions that somehow never quite sounded like the arcane
column4: gnome hymns you might expect given their proximity to fellow Swedish legend Bo Hansson's classic 1973 Lord of the Rings LP (which you should probably download right now). In fact
column5: Sagor and Swing produced some of the best melodies and mellowest moods this side of Cluster
column6: and I'd mourn their passing a lot more if organist Eric Malmberg hadn't just released his first solo disc
column7: Den Gรฅtfulla Mรคnniskan (or ""The Enigmatic Man"").

column1: Malmberg was responsible for the melodic half of Sagor and Swing's charm
column2: writing most of the music and performing almost all of it via his trusty Hammond. For some reason
column3: bands stopped playing this instrument despite a whole bunch of cool sound effects and rhythm presets that put most modern synthesizers to shame in terms of warm ambience
column4: and absolutely destroy whole families of Casio sound banks. <i>Den Gรฅtfulla Mรคnniskan is a true solo record
column5: eschewing drums or any other sound besides Malmberg's Hammond
column6: but if anti-gravity mood music is your thing
column7: you'll hardly notice the Spartan setup. Melodies ring
column8: echo
column9: and decay like reflections of ice crystals around Saturn; clumpy little drum patterns that sound piped in from Zuckerzeit gallop like analog unicorns under layers of finely aged space dust
column10: the kind for which Tim Gane would probably sell his soul. Like countrymen Dungen
column11: Malmberg's music could just as easily have been recorded 35 years ago as today
column12: and like them
column13: he manages to avoid the pitfalls of mining the past by being a perfectionist: this kind of music doesn't really get much better.

column1: The opener ""Det H\x9Agre Medvetandet"" (or ""The Higher Awareness""-- even translated
column2: some of this doesn't really
column3: er
column4: translate
column5: which I guess explains a lot of Abba lyrics) wastes no time in establishing the tone of the record
column6: with a spectral glissando and reverberated triplet-motifs
column7: all of which set up a solemn
column8: almost hymnal melody. The optimistic
column9: misty-eyed phrases sound like the first thing I'd want to hear in the morning
column10: were I waking up in Rivendell. That's right. And Malmberg doesn't let up
column11: as each song segues into the next; out of this mystical den flow the minor key arpeggios of ""Undermedvetandet""
column12: sounding like I've been transported from an elfin parlor to the lunar surface. ""Jaget"" introduces a soft
column13: pitter-patter bossa-beat and a melancholy tune that is vaguely reminiscent of the break in ""A Whiter Shade of Pale""-- though given the organ sounds
column14: that's not very surprising. More likely
column15: this is straight out of Scandinavian folk music
column16: which is often faintly regal
column17: yet colored gray. It's pretty.

column1: ""Sprรฅk och Tankestrukturer"" features more arpeggios
column2: though faster this time
column3: and a little similar to what Philip Glass used to do before someone convinced him symphonies and soundtracks were cooler than all night concerts in New York lofts. And again
column4: the melodies keep the piece from floating into the stratosphere; Malmberg is always able to ground his music with things you can hum
column5: even as you might feel you're levitating. The closer ""Mรคnniskan och Evigheten"" does actually drift out to the celestial sea
column6: but not before bathing itself in waves of milk via the drone of overdubbed organs and distant piano figures. True
column7: Den Gรฅtfulla Mรคnniskan is drenched in the trippy atmospheres of true blue space music and prog
column8: but it's hardly pretentious or bellowing. Rather
column9:
this is the kind of thing that gives good names to organists and gnomes alike.

My personal history with Richard Dorfmeister and Rupert Hurber's Tosca project shows the enduring strength of strong first impressions. I was a Kruder & Dorfmeister fan but somehow didn't get around to hearing Tosca's 1997 debut Opera until early '99. Opera's opener ""Fuck Dub Part 1 + 2"" immediately struck me as the best thing K or D had ever released
column2: and even now I can't think of another track that so successfully weds the slow-burn funk rhythms of ""golden age"" hip-hop with the disorienting production tricks of dub. ""Fuck Dub"" to me was the ultimate expression of the weeded-out aesthetic those in the Kruder & Dorfmeister orbit cultivated (hydroponically
column3: of course).

column1: That the rest of the album was a mess-- basically a couple of great singles interspersed with an amalgamation of half-baked grooves
column2: ambient drones
column3: and crude recordings of old black guys talking the kind of jive German DJs find cool-- only added to my enjoyment. This sloppy handling of talent went down easy for a guy who stood ready to defend the genius of Mark's Keyboard Repair.

column1: Tosca cleaned up right quick
column2: though. Suzuki (2000) polished the rough edges of the debut and was recognized as the perfect accompaniment to the turn-of-the-millennium retail experience. No Gap manager was ever fired for throwing Suzuki on the store PA
column3: which shouldn't take away from the fact that Tosca does crisp
column4: catchy downtempo better than almost anybody (it's all in the bassline
column5: you see). 2003's Dehli9 mixed things up a little by introducing samba and vocals but it looked as though the loose
column6: weird Tosca of the first album was probably gone forever.

column1: Now we have the fourth album. There's not much to report on the weird/novelty front
column2: but Tosca remains in fine form. It's uncanny how just how much mileage these guys get from small
column3: easy gestures
column4: like the simple bass riff that drives the opening head-nodder ""Rondo Acapricio"". On the one hand it sounds borrowed
column5: something you've heard a million times before in some overplayed rare groove classic. But it's also a signature sound
column6: identifiable as Tosca and relentlessly catchy. Throughout the record Tosca employ guest stars of various styles and tongues (more than half the tracks have vocals) but it all fits easily into their highly refined world.

column1: Egypt-born Parisian Samia Farah sassily lilts her way through the electro-cocktail number ""Heidi Bruehl""
column2: Chris Eckman from The Walkabouts evokes the glamorous high-contrast noir of Chris Isaak as he half-sings on ""John Lee Huber""
column3: and ""Damentag"" is perfectly frothy glitter disco. The bass throughout is astonishingly deep and clear
column4: and for the first time in my reviewing career I feel compelled to give a shout-out to the mastering engineer.

column1: Not all the songs work. ""The Big Sleep"" with its vibrato guitars and horns has a neo-roadhouse vibe but the vocals by Austrian rocker Graf Hadik sound like tossed-off space filler. Still
column2: the good far outweighs the bad. J.A.C. is ultimately a simple record covering well-worn territory that is no less engaging for its familiarity. While it sadly does not return to the unpredictability and high highs of Opera
column3:
this is probably the best thing Tosca has released otherwise. If you're the type of person who values things like consistency and high production values this is the Tosca record to get.

A Willie Nelson reggae album is an idea that's almost as crazy-brilliant as casting the Red-Headed Stranger as Uncle Jesse in the Dukes of Hazzard movie. For starters
column2: both country and reggae build on outlaw imagery and class issues
column3: making heroes of rebels and outsiders
column4: and the sunny island rhythms have the potential to counterbalance the dark gospel sobriety of many of Nelson's songs. Furthermore
column5: Nelson's reputation for cannabis consumption
column6: while not a pervasive trend in conservative country music
column7: suggests that maybe music wasn't the primary motivation for recording in Jamaica. It's an act of cool wit that <i>Countryman prominently features a marijuana leaf on the album cover-- although many chain stores are stocking the tamer version
column8: which features a palm tree.

column1: The idea for Countryman is one that Nelson has been entertaining for about a decade: He began recording tracks for it in 1995 when he signed to Island
column2: but the album was shelved during the late-90s turmoil of label buyouts and mergers. Now Nelson's new label
column3: Lost Highway Records
column4: is finally showing it the light of day. However
column5: what's intriguing in concept doesn't hold up very well on <i>Countryman. The album mixes new versions of old songs like ""Darkness on the Face of the Earth"" and ""One in a Row"" with a few covers
column6: most notably Johnny Cash's ""Worried Man"" (here a duet with Toots Hibbert) and Jimmy Cliff's ""The Harder They Come"" and ""Sitting in Limbo"". The 72-year-old's feisty musical curiosity is certainly admirable
column7: and the results prove more listenable than Nelson's recent genre outing Milk Cow Blues
column8: but these songs generally sound half-baked.

column1: Much of the blame can be placed on producer Don Was
column2: who dresses the songs in garishly percolating rhythms that seem to have no connection to Nelson's laidback vocals. Nelson has trained his nylon-string guitar and his tried-and-true touring band to follow his signature phrasing
column3: which is patient and unfussy as it skirts the beat. But Was's generic rhythms keep chugging along irrespective of Nelson's vocals
column4: so that the two elements sound disjointed. As a result
column5: songs like ""Do You Mind Too Much If I Don't Understand"" and ""You Left Me a Long
column6: Long Time Ago"" have the awkward musical synthesis of an amateur mash-up. ""I've Just Destroyed the World"" and ""Darkness on the Face of the Earth""
column7: in particular
column8: suffer unflattering comparisons to better versions on the more or less contemporaneously recorded Teatro; coming off the success of Emmylou Harris's Wrecking Ball
column9: producer Daniel Lanois showed a much more intuitive understanding of Nelson's limitations and worked the songs accordingly. While it's certainly ambitious and even occasionally playful
column10: Countryman displays no such musical comprehension; it's usually just a shambles
column11: and not even an interesting one at that.

column1: There is
column2: however
column3: one song that makes this excursion more or less worthwhile. Nelson's cover of ""The Harder They Come"" proves all the more adventurous for sounding more like Nelson than like Jimmy Cliff. Was keeps the percussion to a minimum-- mainly it's just wood blocks and a gently struck tom-- which leaves more room for Mickey Raphael's harmonica
column4: Robby Turner's dobro
column5: and elegant backing vocals from Toots Hibbert's daughter Lieba Thomas and Jamaican singer Pam Hall. Nelson seems perfectly at home in this mellower setting
column6: confidently translating Cliff's urban rebel philosophy into a desert drifter's credo. ""The Harder They Come"" is pure outlaw reggae
column7: fulfilling the album's crazy-brilliant promise to meld island rhythms with plains melodies. However
column8: even as it provides the template for a remarkable and powerful reggae record
column9:
it also reinforces how disappointingly this one turned out.

Longwave's Life of the Party EP cautiously explored

There's a Fire is an ambitious album-- the kind that wants to be

a hint of atmosphere. ""River (Depot Song)"" takes

effect-laden verses; the result is a darker

I hear the ghost of Elliott Smith haunting Meredith Bragg's debut-- especially on ""Work and Winter""
column2: where the semblance is uncanny. Over a gently strummed guitar and gently tapped triangle
column3: the former Speedwell member arcs his whispery voice across a plaintive melody
column4: enunciating higher notes for a lyrical phrase before descending again to a more comfortable range. Singing just above his natural level
column5: Bragg crafts the tune and the performance for maximum poignancy. It's the work of a bright student: a little self-conscious and overeager
column6: but nevertheless affecting.

column1: On the other hand
column2: the lyrics on ""Work and Winter"" are particularly Gibbardesque: ""Smiling as I felt your breathing align/ In alliance with mine."" It would be a little rash to dismiss Bragg and his Terminals as just another troupe of pop-sensitive
column3: heart-on-sleeve folkies. Admittedly
column4: most of Vol. 1 draws heavily from obvious sources
column5: and most of the ideas here will be familiar to anyone who's heard Nick Drake
column6: Death Cab for Cutie
column7: or the New Year. And yes
column8: the album's aesthetic of failure-- its tendency toward extreme self-reckoning-- derives from Smith's canon of introverted and expressive songs. However
column9: despite these influences and even despite its Decemberistical album art
column10: Vol. 1 transcends any accusation of imitation: These 11 tracks have their own high stakes and dire consequences and seem as specific to Bragg himself as Smith's were to him
column11: as Gibbard's are to him.

column1: Instead of mining Smith's sense of self-compromise or entertaining the DCFC frontman's romantic whimsy
column2: Bragg writes lyrics that are more plainspoken and austere in their jadedness. He's wary of relationships on the bare-bones ""Early Sign""
column3: surprised that he can be guardedly hopeful on ""Carolina""
column4: and
column5: over uncorrected guitar flubs
column6: sweetly reminiscent on ""Seventeen"". All of this introspection is couched in music that is at once intimate yet expansive
column7: concise yet darkly atmospheric
column8: understated yet occasionally powerful. Bragg sings in a soft voice
column9: carefully enunciating his syllables as if uncertain he'll be understood. Only when he alters his voice for ""Waltz No. 1"" does the album falter
column10: but elsewhere his risks pay off. Bragg spends half of the seven-and-a-half-minute ""I Won't Let You Down"" half-humming the short melody over and over
column11: stoically building to something uncertain yet ineluctable.

column1: That ""I Won't Let You Down"" sounds so confident and immediate is not just to Bragg's credit
column2: but also to the credit of the Terminals
column3: who prevent Vol. 1 from descending gravitationally into dreariness. Jonathan Roth's drums propel the melodies and anchor Bragg to the world
column4: while Elizabeth Olson's cello adds tremulous gravity to tracks like the short ""Before the Storm"" and ""Bitter at Best"". But it's Brian Minter who adds most to the band's sound and helps make it distinct from their forebears. His piano makes a perfect foil for Bragg's mechanistic guitar rhythms on the propulsive closer
column5: ""Shattering""
column6: and his ""Vibraphonic Devices"" evoke a noir chiaroscuro on the dark ""My Own Worst Enemy"". Bragg and the Terminals may not have pioneered their sound
column7:
but they sound perfectly at home all the same.

I'm not ashamed to admit I did a little dance when this turned up in the mail
column2: not because I was holding it in my hands
column3: but because I had no idea it was coming out in the first place. That's sort of how Alan Braxe operates
column4: I guess. Despite making some of the most robust and radiant disco-house of the last decade-- Gallic or otherwise-- he's never seemed to be one for fanfare. In the insular world of French house
column5: he's like a mid-altitude cruiser to Daft Punk's twirling tandem airshow; dependable and always moving
column6: but hardly the type to write his name in the sky.

column1: So
column2: some background: Since debuting on Thomas Bangalter's seminal Roulรฉ imprint in 1997
column3: Braxe (real name: Alan Queme) has casually tossed off a series of 12s that hit in the same league as Daft Punk's concurrent singles. But with the possible exception of last year's cokey synth anthem ""Rubicon"" and the definite exception of his co-sign on 1998's ""Music Sounds Better With You""
column4: chances are you won't recognize anything on The Upper Cuts. Even those who do might be caught a bit off guard
column5: because it's easy to lose sight of Braxe's considerable talent when he's only issuing one new thing every six months; this widescreen snapshot of his work makes it impossible to forget just how good he is at what he does.

column1: Although billed as the work of Alan Braxe & Friends so as to allow for the inclusion of occasional drop-ins like Daft Punk's Thomas Bangalter (with whom Braxe co-produced the aforementioned Stardust track)
column2: singer Benjamin Diamond (who sang on it)
column3: and little-known French crooner Romuald Louverjon (who comprised the other half of a short-lived outfit called The Paradise)
column4: the creative partnership at the heart of <i>The Upper Cuts is between Braxe and bassist Fred Falke. Together
column5: the duo account for seven of the album's 12 tracks
column6: and of those
column7: only 2003's ""Love Lost"" is anything less than thrilling. The rest
column8: from the glinting electro of ""Most Wanted"" to the staccato
column9: fat-bottomed basslines of ""Palladium"" to the defiantly unfashionable 80s guitar peel of ""Rubicon""
column10: stack up one-by-one to mount a pretty convincing case for Braxe as French house's most slept-on producer.

column1: In addition to those seven cuts
column2: the asthmatic coo of Paradise's dewey-eyed ""In Love With You"" and the Stardust track (which
column3: I'm happy to say
column4: is still great as ever) <em>The Upper Cuts contains one throwback
column5: one remix
column6: and one misstep. The throwback is Braxe's first ever release
column7: 1997's ""Vertigo""
column8: and although it's dwarfed by his later material
column9: it makes sense here
column10: especially as a curtain closer. The remix is his spangly 2002 disco edit of Shakedown's ""At Night"" which is every bit as strong as his original material. (Braxe's remixing chops don't get often their proper due-- check out his versions of Annie's ""Heartbeat"" and Death From Above 1979's ""Black History Month"" for more.) The misstep is
column11: unfortunately
column12: the compilation's only track from 2005
column13: a Braxe-produced Long Beach g-funk pastiche for a sorta hip-hop artist named Rec. It seems jokey and blunted and woefully out of sync with everything else here
column14: and its presence makes the exclusion of ""Rubicon"" B-side ""Chrystal City"" even more confounding.

column1: By this point
column2: though
column3: I'm just tinkering
column4: trying to find a way to make a V-8 supercar run a hundredth of a second faster. When it comes down to it
column5: <i>The Upper Cuts is sleek and inspired and exhilarating
column6: and after nearly a decade
column7: it's nice to have all this stuff in one place. If it can manage to spark some sort of coming out party for Braxe and company over the coming months
column8: even better
column9:
although frankly I'll be just as happy to settle for another ""Rubicon"" and a few more Annie remixes.
