A User's Guide to They Might Be Giants is the band's fifth retrospective
column2: following Miscellaneous T (1991)
column3: Then: The Earlier Years (1997)
column4: Best of the Early Years (1999)
column5: and Dial-a-Song: 20 Years of They Might Be Giants (2002). Does the world really need another summation of Johns Flansburgh and Linnell's career? Actually
column6: yes. User's Guide has a few advantages over its predecessors: by benefit of its timing
column7: it's much broader and perhaps more representative of their two decades of prodigious output. Furthermore
column8: by virtue of its defining concept
column9: it avoids the obvious chronological presentation of singles and shoulda-been hits in favor of a much more playful overview whose organization reflects the Johns' guiding whimsy.

column1: Song length-- not history or popularity-- informs the order of the generous tracklist. Beginning with the 47 seconds of ""Minimum Wage""
column2: the tracks get increasingly lengthy
column3: peaking with the 12th song
column4: ""Guitar""
column5: which clocks in at nearly four minutes; the remaining tracks get progressively shorter until the 51-second ""Spider"" closes the compilation out. The packaging cleverly plays out this highly ordered approach: the sleeve contains ""A Fairly Complete List of They Might Be Giants Gigs Since 1985*"" (""*1982-84 have yet to be documented"") along with a timeline
column6: a list of presidents mentioned over two decades
column7: and a ""comparison chart of personal pronouns in TMBG song titles."" The cover art is derived from the UPC bar code
column8: which expands to dominate the cover art and purports to measure melody
column9: fidelity
column10: and quantity. It's a sly reversal of the typical best-of aesthetic. Instead of presenting disparate material as a holistic statement of artistic intent and accomplishment
column11: User's Guide explicitly acknowledges its commercial aims: These 29 songs are simply subjects from which variable data can be gathered
column12: analyzed
column13: and graphed. And sold.

column1: While there are some curious omissions (where's ""(She Was a) Hotel Detective""?)
column2: the tracklist proves that Flansburgh and Linnell never lost their gifts for quirky and complex pop hooks
column3: as evidenced by late-career highlights like ""Cyclops Rock"" and ""Doctor Worm"". However
column4: songs like ""James K. Polk"" reveal a tendency toward humorless overliteralization of history; ""Meet James Ensor"" and the subtext-heavy ""Purple Toupee""
column5: on the other hand
column6: exposes a tendency toward the opposite.

column1: However
column2: a statistical analysis reveals more than just the band's prolificity and diversity of output. User's Guide collects five tracks from the well-selling Flood (1990); four from Apollo 18 (1992); and three songs each from the band's self-titled debut (1986) and breakthrough Lincoln (1988)
column3: as well as from their recent children's album No! (2002). All in all
column4: 18 of the 29 tracks date from the period 1985-1994
column5: whereas only 11 are from 1995-2004/5; TMBG cull more tracks from the fewer albums in 1985-1994 and fewer tracks from the greater number of albums in 1995-2004/5.

column1: While these figures may seem slightly tedious presented here
column2: they prove scientifically what many listeners have long asserted
column3: at least beginning with Apollo 18-- the first decade of They Might Be Giants' career produced an abundance of quality material (see: ""Ana Ng"" and ""She's an Angel"")
column4: but the second decade of their career has seen an appreciable decline in that quality (see: ""Boss of Me"" and ""James K. Polk""). This slippage could be attributed to the mid-90s post-grunge hostility to levity and quirk or perhaps to They Might Be Giants' transformation from a duo into a full band
column5: which expanded their range beyond their charm. That's only subjective speculation
column6:
though. User's Guide seems to be an honest acknowledgement of the band's falterings as well as an implicit promise to keep playing around.

Victim of Space is Metalux's first album for 5 Rue Christine

column4: however

column1: Using a rapidly decaying assortment of analog electronics
column2: inflamed guitars
column3: splintered tape loops
column4: and inscrutable vocals
column5: the veteran duo of M.V. Carbon and J. Grรคf belong to the growing contingent of noise peddlers whose work bears ever less direct relation to standardized rock-based (or jazz
column6: or electronic) forms. While portions of their 2004 Load album Waiting for Armadillo occasionally alluded to traceable forward-moving rhythms and brooding No Wave song structures

column5: insect-like sounds swarm to nibble the piece to confetti. Throughout the length of theatrical cuts like ""Shipwreck"" or ""Shelldrum""
column6: Carbon and Grรคf are stubbornly reluctant to allow their audience to become attached to any one noise

column8: always-just-shy-of-earshot lyrics. As compelling and curiously unknowable on 10th listen as on the first

column10:
listening to your stereo.

column1: A fierce student of both hyper-speed UK beat styles and (gasp!) American hip-hop

column1: While recent breakouts like the Game rep their idols with simple ad nauseam shout-outs

column3: Black Sabbath-sampling chorus
column4: the clipped-guitar ""99 Problems"" Jr. scuff-up ""I Don't Know Why"" finds the MC acutely aping Jay-Z's Blueprint-era cadence (along with a couple Oompa Loompa-esque sing-song lines) as he lands pretty-boy punches with a knowing grin. The album's lead-off title track showcases his roided-chameleon adaptability as he eases listeners into his wordy realm by initially winding-up with a slow
column5: off-kilter flow before gunning in-the-pocket fastballs all over the track's airtight electronic playing field
column6: courtesy of frequent collaborator Mikey J.

column1: Produced by famed world traveler Diplo
column2: the frighteningly impressive ""Reload It"" provides a living
column3: breathing drum 'n' bass gauntlet that Kano duly annihilates as it skips between double-time snare-snap and ambling

column1: Not to say his wordplay and content are simple. Along with a wide-range of production styles and multi-flow grandstanding comes an equally assorted thematic breadth. Whether he's bitching-out brut bouncers with verbal assaults (""Typical Me"")

column3: calling-out closed-minded youths (""Nobody Don't Dance No More"")
column4: offering a mega-ton boast-a-thon (the already classic

column1: ""P's & Q's"")

column4: the lovey-dovey ""Brown Eyes""

column1: Stellar album cuts like the introspective stunner ""Sometimes"" see Kano tempering his encroaching stardom with second-thoughts. ""When they say I'm the next one to blow I say why do they think me
column2: he admits
column3: ""All I do is stay in mostly and sleep/ And all I do is watch Channel U and drink tea/ Why me?"" He combats such internal struggles with staggering maturity and an appealing
column4: hard-working sense of earning ends on his own terms. ""The hood think I'm signed
column5: they like 'I swear he is'/ But I'm still in the grind writing lines all day
column6: every night
column7: he insists with focused intensity and ghetto guilt on the blue-collar anthem ""9 to 5""
column8: taking absolutely nothing in his life for granted.

column1: Such striving
column2: self-motivational forces are no stronger than on ""Signs of Life""

column5: chicks
column6: and your bits now/ Shit
column7: you should have fixed up/ Fuck drugs
column8: the mic you should've picked up/ And it was all for big bucks
column9: now your sittin' in a cell doing sit-ups.""

column1: Kano doesn't just defy the sonic tradition of grime on Home Sweet Home

column6: this nimble artist's future destination is promising and unpredictable: No matter what happens to grime
column7:
Kano is poised to endure.

John Maclean has long been DFA's secret weapon. The Rapture gives good face. James Murphy gives good copy. Delia and Gavin give good ""oh
column4: they're easily my favorite"" hipster trump card. But Maclean is the most effective. If any DFA records come close to hands-aloft status
column5: it's his ""Give Me Every Little Thing"" and ""You Can't Have It Both Ways"". They're
column6: you know
column7: house music. No need for any prefixes or suffixes.

column1: Maclean's former band
column2: Six Finger Satellite
column3: were a bruising mixture of skinny tie and thick neck
column4: mixed eye-meltingly loud by Murphy live
column5: and all but blueprinting Les Savy Fav (who I like better
column6: but why lie?) on record. Which might explain why his dance music is so muscular (have you listened to those early Rapture EP's lately?)
column7: but it does make Less Than Human
column8: a good chunk of which could be described as ""gentle"" or at least ""pretty""
column9: a bit surprising. It's not quite the masterpiece everyone (at least me) was hoping for (the exclusion of ""You Can't Have It Both Ways""
column10: for example

column12: which in 2005 is almost the same thing.

column1: ""Shining Skinned Friend"" is filled to bursting over its bacon fat drums: theremin noise
column2: vocodered sprites
column3: ghostly coos
column4: vocal synths
column5: italo ripples
column6: ""dark"" Euro vocals. This is his happening and it freaks me out. ""Give Me Every Little Thing"" is pure bliss
column7: from the interstellar electrical storm opening to the whammy bar keytar solo that closes it out. In between
column8: you've got a giant's handclaps
column9: a groaning slap bass
column10: barbiturate P-Funk chanting
column11: and call-and-response synth squiggles. ""Tito's Way"" is one of the few nu-disco tracks that recognizes the power of the Party Whistle. (No ""whoop whoop"" though.) It also has breaking bells
column12: steady-rocking drums
column13: farty robot bass
column14: and sassy-yet-dead-eyed femme vocals.

column1: The rest of the record is surprisingly melancholy. ""Love Is in the Air"" is Metro Area after a crying jag. ""In The Afternoon"" is background music for a breakup scene in a WB teen drama starring Ralf und Florian. ""My Time Is Running Out"" opens with Arcadian
column2: cascading synth-strings and trills of bleeps like all-white Christmas lights blinking on and off. It could be the intro to a Kylie Minogue record before it rolls out another gently bumping
column3: mid-tempo groove. (Actually
column4: re-reading that
column5: I'm not sure if it isn't a Kylie Minogue record.) Closer ""Dance With Me"" lopes for 12 minutes towards a climax that never comes
column6: a busted robot shooting little sparks of piano as it limps towards Nancy Whang's siren song.

column1: The title track of Less Than Human (which appears nowhere on the album) was first released on the 2004 DFA Compilation #2. But come on: Even allowing for coincidence
column2: is it possible to hear it without this year's Daft Punk album looming like an unanswered question? Alongside Vitalic-- Maclean's closest contemporary
column3: especially when you factor in the penchant for queasy synth miniatures like opener ""AD2003""-- Maclean the student is now doing the ""robot rock"" thing better than the masters. And he only rocks about half the time. But then again Daft Punk once made their rep singing about unrequited love
column4: rather than just breaking hearts.

Before performing with Ryuichi Sakamoto in classic Japanese synth pop outfit Yellow Magic Orchestra (or just YMO)
column2: producer and onetime session bassist Haruomi Hosono made his share of eclectic music. If you're familiar with YMO
column3: you might imagine he was involved in Kraftwerk-influenced electronic music
column4: or perhaps more traditional pop
column5: but as it happens
column6: he made his name as session bassist and playing in bands like the psychedelic Apryl Fool and folk rockers Happy End-- a far cry from the modernist slant of his reputation in the West. However
column7: he also made a record in 1978 called Cochin Moon with keyboardist Shuka Nishihara
column8: and future YMO bandmates Sakamoto and Hideki Matsutake that is arguably more bizarre and forward thinking than anything he's done since.

column1: Cochin Moon-- co-credited to Pop artist Tadanori Yokoo
column2: who did the incredible Bollywood-style cover art-- is an electro-tropical soundtrack to a fake movie of the same name. That is
column3: there was no film called Cochin Moon
column4: but after visiting India
column5: Hosono was inspired to make music suggesting the exotic
column6: luxurious
column7: and seemingly wonder-filled scenarios played out in Indian cinemas. However
column8: the actual sound he and his cohorts came up with is often a world away from India: Imagine a totally electronic world of chattering bugs
column9: fluttering birds
column10: magic harps and drums that alternate between a thud and a blip. Hosono shares compositional duties with Nishihara
column11: and Sakamoto's playing style is readily on display
column12: as are Matsutake's considerable programming skills. As a historical document to YMO fans
column13: Cochin Moon is interesting; as a slice of out-music stuck somewhere between Tangerine Dream
column14: Wendy Carlos and Disney's Fantasia
column15: it's almost classic.

column1: Hosono's ""Malabar Hotel"" trilogy-- comprised of a ""Ground Floor""
column2: ""Upper Floor"" and ""Roof Garden""-- occupied the first side of the original LP
column3: and eases me in like a snake. The brief ""Ground Floor...Triangle Circuit on the Sea-Forest"" begins with high-pitched insect-sirens
column4: soft enough to mistake for crickets even when I know analog synths and primitive computers generate them. In the distance are waves breaking on a shore
column5: and soon bass synth notes and alarms go off signaling the transition into the ""Upper Floor...Moving Triangle"". As a THX-esque sound test introduces fluttering percolations
column6: an off-balanced
column7: Indian-styled beat materializes. Half the beat is on the right
column8: and half on the left; in between
column9: where a snare should be
column10: sits only the call of some robotic frog and a fly that just won't go away. This is tropical
column11: and I can hear a pattern creep up from behind
column12: and what sounds like men chanting. Filtered through an alien vocoder
column13: it's difficult to decipher what they're saying
column14: and as soon as I get close enough to make out the fuzzy
column15: sonic outline of their words
column16: they're interrupted by stuttering bass melody that eventually turns into a demi-cadenza
column17: held afloat by ever more quickly percolating drum machine pulses. Bursts of angelic chord clusters accentuate the ends of melodic phrases
column18: and from out of nowhere come electronic harp glissandi. Up and down
column19: forward and backwards it runs
column20: and soon the fizz of synthetic ocean mist drowns out the pulse
column21: leaving only enough room for the pixie-bell harp
column22: sudden eruptions of lava bubbles and that damn fly.

column1: ""Roof Garden...Revel Attack"" is born out of the fly's orbit
column2: and introduces squeaky (near glitch) underwater computer blips. They start soft and spaced out
column3: but soon gather momentum
column4: all the while turning the fly buzz into a chorus of warped jet trail. A human voice speaking Japanese dips above the cacophony
column5: and someone appears to be unwrapping a small package on the right. Then
column6: just as suddenly
column7: a synth line reminiscent of the melody from the ""Upper Floor"" reappears
column8: with digitally harmonized voices supplying watercolor fanfares. The harp returns
column9: in counterpoint with helicopter pulse on the right. The helicopter
column10: apparently not satisfied in its supporting role
column11: grows larger
column12: overwhelming the competing melodies with sprawling whirl
column13: and soon with more watery mist
column14: like a rainstorm called on by a village shaman. And after a while
column15: the storm passes
column16: marked by the toll of a gong. And the fly is still there
column17: buzzing in its lowest register before the gong closes the doors of the hotel and the piece fades into black.

column1: Nishihara's pieces are a bit less exotic
column2: but no less interesting. ""Hepatitis"" is a shiny
column3: bouncy piece of computer pop that might work well as a soundtrack to a Pixar sci-fi short about robotic fish. The bubbling sound effects are everywhere to be found
column4: while cartoon-y melodies and state-of-1978 synth programming turn what might otherwise overwhelm itself with its own goofiness into something more bizarre. ""Hum Ghar Sajan"" (apparently
column5: taken from a phrase by Indian guru Granth Sahib) is understated synth raga
column6: as if informed equally by Kraftwerk and Ravi Shankar-- and accurately predicts Asa Chang & Junray's excursions into electro-exotica. A chanted vocal melody gives the song a mystical edge
column7: and its recurring
column8: high-pitched instrumental solo breaks sound straight out of Indian classical music.

column1: ""Madam Consul General of Madras"" is more tribal
column2: sounding like ritualistic gamelan music meeting head on with the electronic tone poems of Wendy Carlos. Gradually
column3: layers are painted on top
column4: including a spazzed out synth line and more percolated synth patter sounding leftover from the Malabar's lobby
column5: and the piece dissolves into dizzying keyboard clutter and the cricket sirens from the ""Ground Floor"". And I guess you can check out any time you like
column6: but...well
column7:
you know the rest.

Frank Black has earned the right to do whatever the hell he wants
column2: and he unfortunately seems to know it. The man who brought you the Pixies and
column3: by extension
column4: the alternative rock boom of the early 90s
column5: took four days out of his busy schedule touring with his triumphantly reunited old band to record in Nashville with such legendary session men as Steve Cropper and Spooner Oldham. The result is Honeycomb
column6: as album that has its inspired moments but ultimately comes off like something of a vanity project
column7: with Black tackling a midpoint between classic country and classic r&b;
column8: winding up with a sort of adult contemporary album full of lyrics about shrimp and selkies
column9: those half-seal/half-human creatures of Orkney legend.

column1: To his credit
column2: Black seems genuinely excited to be playing with his heroes
column3: and he's invested in the material
column4: as always
column5: but the backing definitely has the ultra-competent feeling of a session rather than a band really gelling. Likewise
column6: Black's written several great songs
column7: but he may not actually be the best guy to sing them
column8: as his voice has a tendency to die out on some of the more ambitious melodies. For instance
column9: ""Strange Goodbye"" is a masterfully written duet that could have easily come from the Stax hit factory in the late-60s
column10: but Black and his ex-wife Jean (they were still married at the time) here aren't a compelling pair-- ironic considering it's written about their impending break-up.

column1: The record's two peaks are actually covers of Dan Penn & Chips Moman's ""Dark End of the Street"" and key Black influence Doug Sahm's ""Sunday Sunny Mill Valley Groove Day"". The former finds Black doing a pretty good job with a tricky classic soul melody
column2: while the latter is an exuberant
column3: uptempo country-rock tune that the whole band seems to enjoy playing. The third cover
column4: ""Song of the Shrimp""
column5: is a bizarre ballad about a shrimp that leaves his parents for New Orleans
column6: not realizing where the shrimp boat is taking him. Black
column7: of course
column8: turns in his own share of odd lyrics
column9: peaking on ""Strange Goodbye"" and bottoming out these lines from the opening of ""Another Velvet Nightmare"": ""Today I felt my heart slide into my belly/ So I puked it up with liquor/ And I slept right where I lay.""

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Cropper livens up ""My Life Is in Storage"" with richly phrased guitar solo and Black spikes his closing exhortation to ""Sing for Joy"" with tales of alcoholism and murder. The sum of it all is a bit less than what you might expect from the parts. Black has strangely proven himself an accomplished writer of songs that would sound great in the hands of a soul singer and a house band
column3:
but he's also proven that he's not necessarily always the right singer for his songs.

Get Physical Music and its stable of producers (M.A.N.D.Y.
column3: Booka Shade
column4: DJ T

column6: they restored Brutish physicality to an underground house scene that had pushed clicks and pops about as far as they could go. But where Tiefschwarz stuffed their famed remixes with details
column7: GPM tracks favored simple
column8: crisp rhythms รก la Metro Area and unadorned electro basslines. And where Blackstrobe oozed throwback EBM attitude and campy menace
column9: GPM was almost friendly
column10: nearly lush. The result was straight up enough to pull those who don't give a shit about microhouse and just subtle enough to pull those who do. Their second anniversary mix CD is probably the one record we'll point to in a decade to say ""that was house in 2004.""

column1: Like many electrohouse pioneers

column3: from Sasha and Digweed caning Kompakt
column4: to Villalobos' omnipresence (everywhere except his club dates)
column5: to Isolรฉe being the toast of all the rock mags (and
column6: ahem

column13: sometimes deeper
column14: sometimes more revelatory
column15: but rarely as fun.

column1: Opening with a few tracks of clicks and cuts and a DJ trying to remember the names of all the Isley Brothers
column2: trunks are finally rattling with the bass and nasty sand dune riffs of Booka Shade's ""Panoramic"". As the bass grumbles and glowers
column3: Marlow's ""Quiet"" patterns some delicate vocal science (a cheap route to ecstasy that works every time) before the banging drums of Marc Houle's ""Has to Do"" brings a bit of needed earthiness to all those half-breaths and chipped syllables. Guido Schneider's remix of Dub Kult's ""Bip"" has buried handclaps and scatting vocals dipped in heavy-echo syrup. There's a long stretch of 80s revivalism leaning hard on the arpeggiation
column4: be it Depeche Mode (Sterac Electronic's ""Destination Reached"") or Vangelis (Hans-Peter Lindstrom's ""I Feel Space""

On Further From Grace
column2: the second album from Nick Castro
column3: the hirsute L.A.-based troubadour has wisely taken full advantage of the extensive network of inspired folk eccentrics currently mushrooming across the countryside. Featuring appearances from Josephine Foster and Espers' Meg Baird
column4: in addition to the uniformly stellar work of his crack(ed) band the Poison Tree
column5: Further From Grace positively shimmers with willowy
column6: sun-dappled ensemble playing
column7: and firmly establishes Castro as yet another noteworthy voice of the present acid folk resurgence.

column1: As is the case with Philadelphia's Espers
column2: Castro's music hearkens less to old-timey American forms of Appalachian folk or country blues than it does to the golden age of 60s-70s UK folk-rock
column3: as practiced by groups like the Incredible String Band or Mellow Candle. Inching softly away from some of the more blatant Donovan/ Syd Barrett solo emanations of his 2004 self-released debut A Spy in the House of God
column4: here Castro and company employ an ambitious menu of exotic acoustic instruments to forge a verdant
column5: medieval-tinged sound
column6: one which draws on any number of pan-global folk traditions. And though there are times when the album threatens to capsize beneath its own preciousness (such as on the delightful
column7: flute-centric ""To This Earth""
column8: which incautiously risks floating away like a puff of new-agey Celtic Myst) the strength of Castro's melodic compositions and the group's deft musicianship should manage to enchant any but the most Hobbit-phobic listeners.

column1: With his clear
column2: refreshingly unmannered vocals on straightforward tunes like ""Won't You Sing to Me
column3: Castro strikes a figure recalling Tom Rapp of Pearls Before Swine or a young
column4: more starry-eyed David Gilmour. In Castro's lyrics
column5: cheeks tend to be white as snow and eyes are apt to shine like diamonds
column6: which is perhaps another reason why most of the memorable passages on Further From Grace are instrumental in nature. The opening ""Sun Song"" combines Baird's lap dulcimer with Otto Hauser's nimble hand percussion and Foster's mesmeric
column7: wordless vocalizing to create a full-scale gypsy swoon
column8: one that could easily continue on weightlessly for miles before you realize your gas tank is empty and your watch has lost its hands.

column1: Even further transporting is the brief ""Music for Mijwiz""
column2: a whirling Middle Eastern dervish on which Castro plays the titular Arabic
column3: double-reeded woodwind over a sandstorm rhythm
column4: or the epic ""Deep
column5: Deep Sea""
column6: a captivating piece whose lengthy intro is adorned with Adam Hershberger's lyrical
column7: surprisingly jazzy flugelhorn
column8: before Castro eventually leads the whole company back into more familiar Soft Machine-like canyons and valleys. As the album closes with the aptly-named acoustic soar of ""Walk Like a Whisper""
column9: the seasoned folk-rock traveler will undoubtedly recognize many a feature of this tranquil landscape
column10: but will also likely be helpless to resist the urge to continually retrace Castro's every step
column11:
reluctant to miss out on a single contour of this varied and beguiling album.

column3: White Out-- as comprised by multi-instrumentalist Lin Culbertson and drummer Tom Surgal-- have been one of the most consistently absorbing and unpredictable experimental outfits on the grid. The duo's fertile sound is unusually malleable
column4: due in part to a top-notch succession of collaborators ranging from the No Neck Blues Band's David Nuss to Nels Cline to Thurston Moore. For their third album
column5: China Is Near
column6: White Out have enlisted perhaps their most sympathetic ringers yet-- percussionist William Winant and avant-chameleon Jim O'Rourke. And with the aid of these familiar
column7: well-traveled guests-- each of whom has appeared on more records than most of us could consume in a decade-- White Out are here again able to boldly pilot their freeform clamor toward distant alien horizons.

column1: China Is Near marks White Out's second studio go-around with their frequent live partner O'Rourke
column2: following their Ecstatic Peace alliance on 2000's Drunken Little Mass. Thanks in large measure to Culbertson's extensive use of burbling analog synths
column3: that album showcased the collective at their most overtly jazzy
column4: their cosmic agitations frequently recalling early-70s era Herbie Hancock or Sun Ra at his Moogiest. And while China Is Near retains a few hazy echoes of that predecessor
column5: here the group has further atomized their nebulous sound
column6: continually spiraling the music's various fragments further and further outward from previously mapped territories and definable genres.

column1: With the presence of Winant
column2: the album unsurprisingly finds White Out's work increasingly dominated by its astonishing variety of percussive textures. Neither Winant nor Surgal is the type of percussionist who settles easily for the mundane duties of timekeeping. Here instead the two augment their wide assortment of drums with an eclectic array of chains
column3: scrap metal and gongs as they stretch their loose
column4: intuitive playing to inhabit whatever open space Culbertson and O'Rourke can spare. This approach results in intensely evocative tracks like ""Empty Centre""
column5: a gauzy drone that Winant and Surgal encompass with jingle bells and the rattle of knives to ward off all evil spirits and/or grizzly bears. Similarly
column6: on ""Mutinous"" a mounting force of tympanis pound like the sinister footsteps of an encroaching invasion force as swarms of growling electronics slowly build to do feverish battle
column7: the listener forcibly encouraged to quickly choose sides.

column1: Since they use such an unorthodox array of electronic and treated instrumentation-- such as the distorted
column2: unearthly autoharp that rakes across the face of ""Stipledmoon""-- it's often difficult to pinpoint exactly which musician is generating each specific noise. O'Rourke
column3: as always
column4: blends effortlessly into his surroundings
column5: and though this masterful versatility makes him a valuable addition to virtually any ensemble
column6: it can also render his individual voice rather invisible. (If he's contributed any guitar here
column7: I must admit I don't immediately recognize it.) Consequently there's nothing on China Is Near-- besides its general air of restless
column8: questing curiosity-- that stands out as distinctively ""O'Rourkian
column9: but that certainly does little to detract from this album's molten
column10:
form-shifting splendor.

Almost every music genre has a batch of fans that consider the earliest formative material to be the never-bettered ""pure"" expression of the style. In jazz you have Louis Armstrong and the Hot Five records. In blues take your pick of pre-WWII blues artists like Son House or Charley Patton. In rock'n'roll you have Elvis Presley
column2: Jerry Lee Lewis
column3: Little Richard
column4: and Chuck Berry. In punk you have the Ramones. Even if you don't particularly rate such seminal artists
column5: you still have to admire their mastery of their respective idioms and the way each came to define a form.

column1: Hip-hop doesn't seem to work the same way; few if any fans believe it peaked with the sides released by Enjoy and Sugarhill at the dawn of the 80s
column2: as much as they might dig selected singles. Maybe hip-hop was such a new and radical expression it took its community a few years to understand what it was about and how best its innovations could be applied. It being the late 70s
column3: a time when recording was widespread and after a few novelty records had become hits
column4: the awkward early stages were fully documented
column5: to resurface later on endless streams of ""Old School"" comps and
column6: occasionally
column7: reissues of complete albums. Here are two such artifacts
column8: the first two long-players by Grandmaster Flash's group. Everyone knows now how influential Grandmaster Flash was to the mechanics of DJing
column9: with his invention and popularization of various mixing and scratching techniques. And speaking of the ""early stuff is best"" phenomenon mentioned above
column10: his 7-minute piece ""The Adventures of Grandmaster Flash on the Wheels of Steel"" (not included on these records) is arguably the finest DJ collage in hip-hop history. The group released a handful of other stellar early singles-- ""Superrappin'""
column11: ""Freedom""
column12: ""Birthday Party"". As an ""album artist
column13: though
column14: well...

column1: The Message has two absolutely essential songs
column2: both of which have been widely anthologized. The title track has rightly been hailed as hip-hop's first overtly political expression
column3: with sharply observed scenes of New York at its broken-down worst voiced by lead Furious Five rapper Grandmaster Melle Mel. Less discussed is the fantastically likable musical backing
column4: with the squelchy synth riff that's now completely burned into the collective pop music consciousness
column5: and it's stiff'n'funky drum machine beat. But even the sonic treat of ""The Message"" pales next to the polished chrome man-machine of ""Scorpio""
column6: for my money the greatest early electro track and the best vocodered robot-rap of all time.

column1: The next tier of The Message contains single ""It's Nasty"" and the upbeat party jam ""She's Fresh"". The former appropriates the music from Tom Tom Club's ""Genius of Love"" the way Sugerhill Gang appropriated Chic
column2: and no matter what you're doing out front
column3: it's hard to go wrong with that particular synth riff and beat. Down further is ""It's a Shame""
column4: a forgettable but inoffensive mid-tempo rap
column5: and then the record bottoms out with ""Dreamin"" (a tribute to Stevie Wonder-- sample lyrics: ""Stevie
column6: you make me wonder. I dream about you
column7: Stevie"") and ""You Are""
column8: abysmal ballads that sound like they were pulled from a ""Mr. Show"" parody.

column1: Shortly after The Message was released Melle Mel became Grandmaster Melle Mel and took two of the Furious Five with him to form his own group. Melle Mel recorded ""White Lines (Don't Do It)
column2: the final classic track associated with this crew. Flash soldiered on
column3: assembling a new group and recorded They Said it Couldn't Be Done. Oddly
column4: it's more consistent than the debut
column5: with no flat-out bad tracks
column6: but also no real high points. The use of synthesizers is more sophisticated (which isn't always a good thing)
column7: and some of the quick-cut proto sampling has historical interest. When the chorus hooks are on
column8: as with ""Girls Like the Way She Spins""
column9: it's not bad. It was 1985
column10: though
column11: and by then Run D.M.C. was on the scene; relatively speaking Grandmaster Flash sounds way behind. Sensing this
column12: Flash steals a title and a sound with ""Rock the House""
column13: which has guitars and a mid-tempo rock backbeat though none of the energy of the guys from Hollis. Flash would release a couple more records in the 80s without much success
column14: and then he dropped off the radar
column15: resurfacing periodically to play shows when given a boost by current DJs who understand his importance to hip-hop's development. In his world
column16: though
column17:
""importance"" doesn't necessarily pay.

column2: both of which have been widely anthologized. The title track has rightly been hailed as hip-hop's first overtly political expression
column3: with sharply observed scenes of New York at its broken-down worst voiced by lead Furious Five rapper Grandmaster Melle Mel. Less discussed is the fantastically likable musical backing
column4: with the squelchy synth riff that's now completely burned into the collective pop music consciousness
column5: and it's stiff'n'funky drum machine beat. But even the sonic treat of ""The Message"" pales next to the polished chrome man-machine of ""Scorpio""
column6: for my money the greatest early electro track and the best vocodered robot-rap of all time.

column1: The next tier of The Message contains single ""It's Nasty"" and the upbeat party jam ""She's Fresh"". The former appropriates the music from Tom Tom Club's ""Genius of Love"" the way Sugerhill Gang appropriated Chic
column2: and no matter what you're doing out front
column3: it's hard to go wrong with that particular synth riff and beat. Down further is ""It's a Shame""
column4: a forgettable but inoffensive mid-tempo rap
column5: and then the record bottoms out with ""Dreamin"" (a tribute to Stevie Wonder-- sample lyrics: ""Stevie
column6: you make me wonder. I dream about you
column7: Stevie"") and ""You Are""
column8: abysmal ballads that sound like they were pulled from a ""Mr. Show"" parody.

column1: Shortly after The Message was released Melle Mel became Grandmaster Melle Mel and took two of the Furious Five with him to form his own group. Melle Mel recorded ""White Lines (Don't Do It)
column2: the final classic track associated with this crew. Flash soldiered on
column3: assembling a new group and recorded They Said it Couldn't Be Done. Oddly
column4: it's more consistent than the debut
column5: with no flat-out bad tracks
column6: but also no real high points. The use of synthesizers is more sophisticated (which isn't always a good thing)
column7: and some of the quick-cut proto sampling has historical interest. When the chorus hooks are on
column8: as with ""Girls Like the Way She Spins""
column9: it's not bad. It was 1985
column10: though
column11: and by then Run D.M.C. was on the scene; relatively speaking Grandmaster Flash sounds way behind. Sensing this
column12: Flash steals a title and a sound with ""Rock the House""
column13: which has guitars and a mid-tempo rock backbeat though none of the energy of the guys from Hollis. Flash would release a couple more records in the 80s without much success
column14: and then he dropped off the radar
column15: resurfacing periodically to play shows when given a boost by current DJs who understand his importance to hip-hop's development. In his world
column16: though
column17:
""importance"" doesn't necessarily pay.

Okemah is a small town in eastern-central Oklahoma that's famous as the birthplace of Woody Guthrie
column3: who serves as the guiding spirit of Son Volt's comeback album. On the leadoff track

column1: He's not the only musician Farrar turns to for guidance on <i>Okemah

column4: which revisits Creedence Clearwater Revival's ""Fortunate Son"" but with a much more specific target (just guess). But Farrar doesn't seem to be trying to re-fashion himself as a modern-day Guthrie on these songs; as always

column1: Okemah proves to be not just 13 protest songs
column2: but 13 songs about protest songs. Farrar believes unquestioningly in music's ability to affect tremendous social change
column3: soothe a nation
column4: or stop an ""endless war with no moral face."" That idea still sounds as attractive and optimistic now as it was 70 years ago when Guthrie sang about the Dust Bowl
column5: and although he doesn't seem to consider that perhaps reverent hindsight grants protest music most of its power
column6: Farrar wants to resurrect that musical populism as a weapon against the current administration.

column1: Appropriately
column2: <em>Okemah is grassroots in both politics and sound. Despite its new line-up
column3: Son Volt churns out the same sturdy riff-heavy rock of Trace and Wide Swing Tremolo
column4: but the band sounds more invigorated on songs like ""6 String Belief"" and even on slower tracks like ""Medication"". Farrar's and Brad Rice's sandpaper guitars evoke the mythic Americana of 70s Southern rock
column5: especially against the chugging rhythm section of drummer Dave Bryson and one-time Meat Puppet Andrew Duplantis on bass.

column1: Despite the heightened band dynamics
column2: Farrar remains the central figure on these songs
column3: and his distinct approach complicates and occasionally compromises Okemah. The melodies are less lethargic than those on Straightaways and the lyrics more intelligible than those on Wide Swing Tremolo; if they're devoid of Guthrie's humor
column4: at least ""Jet Pilot"" manages some disgusted sarcasm toward (you guessed it) Bush. And ""Who"" manages a devious ambiguity: ""Who makes the minutes move/ The post-meridian news/ Who
column5: who else but you?"" ""You"" could be either the populace or Fox News; the song either a populist anthem or a middle finger.

column1: As the album progresses
column2: though
column3: Farrar's lyrics become increasingly stilted and veiled
column4: reverting to the forced wordplay and disconnected evocations of his most obscure songs. In the past
column5: this tendency toward purple opacity could be excused
column6: but on Okemah it hinders Farrar considerably
column7: clouding the issues rather than arguing or elevating them. ""Ipecac"" takes on big corporations and class differences-- important topics after the Enron fallout-- but
column8: head-scratchingly
column9: he warns us to ""watch out for love like ipecac""
column10: perhaps more drawn to the word's cutting consonants than to its connotations. <em>Okemah is in the end too cerebral
column11: lacking the gutpunch impact of the best protest music. With ""rock and roll 'round my head like a 6-string belief
column12:
Farrar's been thinking so much about Woody Guthrie that these songs never leave his own head.
